entity_name: Squamous cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid differentiation
definition: This is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) showing evidence of sarcomatoid differentiation, usually recognizable as chondroblastic, osteoblastic, rhabdomyosarcomatous, or myoid differentiation.
clinical:
SCC with sarcomatoid differentiation typically shows rapid growth, but it has no individually characteristic features.

---

SCC with sarcomatoid differentiation is exceedingly rare.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is similar to that of common forms of SCC.

---

The pathogenesis is unknown, although epithelial–mesenchymal transition is postulated. Both elements share a common clonal origin by next-generation sequencing.
microscopic: SCCs with sarcomatoid differentiation typically have a component of SCC with classic morphology demonstrating keratinization, along with a sarcomatous component. The sarcomatous component accounts for a variable proportion of the tumour, and thorough sampling may be necessary to establish the diagnosis. In non-genital sites, a background of severe solar elastosis is typical. Heterologous elements may include chondroblastic, osteoblastic, rhabdomyosarcomatous, and myoid differentiation. Elements with myoid differentiation are rarely positive for markers of epithelial differentiation.
staging: These tumours should be staged according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: Like for other cutaneous SCCs, surgical excision is usually sufficient.
related_terminology: Acceptable: carcinosarcoma; metaplastic carcinoma; sarcomatoid squamous cell carcinoma. Not recommended: pseudosarcomatous squamous cell carcinoma.

definition: Spindle cell squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a rare, poorly differentiated type of SCC; it is composed predominantly of spindled tumour cells with partial or complete loss of morphological squamous differentiation.
clinical:
Spindle cell SCC is typically a raised or exophytic plaque, nodule, or tumour, and it is indistinguishable from classic SCC. It is often about 20 mm in largest dimension and can reach up to 100 mm. Patients often present with bleeding or ulceration, and they may report a history of rapid tumour growth.

---

These skin tumours arise most commonly in elderly White men and rarely in Asian populations. The incidence is highest among individuals aged > 70 years. The reported age range for penile tumours is broad (28–81 years).
pathogenesis:
Ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure, iatrogenic ionizing irradiation, scarring burns, solid-organ transplantation, and immunosuppression predispose individuals to this type of SCC. Penile tumours are frequently associated with high- or low-grade squamous intraepithelial dysplasia or lichen sclerosus.

---

A monoclonal origin for these tumours is the currently accepted theory. The morphological changes have been postulated to be caused by epithelial–mesenchymal transition, in which the precursor squamous cells lose polarity and cohesiveness and transform into spindle-shaped cells, acquiring increased motility and invasiveness.
microscopic: Spindle cell SCC typically occurs in a background of severe solar elastosis and is composed of closely packed fascicles of pleomorphic spindle cells, with frequent mitotic activity. There may be a background of actinic keratosis or SCC in situ. Keratinization is usually absent. The tumour involves the dermis and may extend into the subcutis and along interlobular fat septa.
differential_diagnosis: The most common differential diagnoses are atypical fibroxanthoma, superficial undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, desmoplastic and spindle cell melanomas, leiomyosarcoma, and less common tumours in the differential diagnosis include spindle cell and sarcomatoid lymphomas. The finding of an overlying in situ or intermingled keratinizing component can be helpful, but immunohistochemistry is required to establish the diagnosis in most cases. Specifically, positive staining for p63, p40, 34βE12, CK5/6, and/or MNF116 is usually required for the diagnosis, particularly if no epithelioid squamous component is present. EMA, AE1/AE3, and CAM5.2 are less sensitive. S100-positive intratumoural dendritic cells must not be confused with the cells of spindle cell melanoma; other melanoma-specific stains can facilitate this distinction.
staging: Tumours should be staged according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: Spindle cell morphology itself may be a predictor of poor prognosis. Depth of invasion (particularly invasion into bone or muscle), as well as origination at the site of a burn or radiation damage (including sun damage), may be associated with worse outcome or death. Positive margins are associated with significantly higher rates of recurrence and metastasis, and with significantly poorer survival. Penile spindle cell SCCs have a high rate of metastasis and are associated with a high rate of death due to metastatic disease.
related_terminology: Not recommended: pseudosarcomatous squamous cell carcinoma; sarcomatoid squamous cell carcinoma.

Spindle cell squamous cell carcinoma. Note the edge of a tumour nodule with marked solar elastosis.
Spindle squamous cell carcinoma. Epithelioid, vaguely nested cells in transition to a fusiform elongated spindled morphology.

Spindle cell squamous cell carcinoma. Pancytokeratin immunostaining is positive in scattered lesional cells.

definition: Clear cell squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a histologically defined type of SCC that microscopically shows abundant clear cytoplasm.
clinical:
These tumours, which often arise in elderly men, have no clinical features to distinguish them from conventional SCC.

---

This rare SCC type often occurs on sun-damaged skin of older men.
pathogenesis:
The risk factors appear to be similar to those for conventional SCC. The genetic susceptibilities beyond those associated with conventional SCC are unknown.

---

The pathogenesis is unknown. There is accumulation of glycogen in the cytoplasm of the neoplastic cells.
macroscopic: The macroscopic appearance is similar to that of conventional SCC (see section Squamous cell carcinomas).
microscopic: The tumours contain malignant squamoid clear epithelial cells with cytoplasmic vacuolation and focal keratinization. There is no consensus on the required proportion of clear cells for the definition of clear cell SCC, but > 25% has been suggested. The tumours may be invasive or in situ. Intracytoplasmic vacuoles are typically unilocular, unlike in sebaceous neoplasms. The clear material is usually PAS-positive glycogen. Some clear cell SCCs without glycogen have been identified, with vesiculation possibly representing a degenerative phenomenon or artefact. When a single cytoplasmic vacuole compresses the nucleus, the lesions may be designated as signet-ring cell SCC. Immunohistochemistry is similar to that of conventional SCC; BerEP4 is negative.
differential_diagnosis: There is some morphological similarity between the histological appearances of clear cell SCC, signet-ring cell SCC, and trichilemmal carcinoma. Trichilemmal carcinoma is usually deeply seated, with no connection to the epidermis, and it may show peripheral palisading, basement membrane prominence, and pilar keratinization. Sebaceous carcinoma shows multivacuolated cytoplasm with frequent positivity for perilipin, adipophilin, AR, and BerEP4. Clear cell basal cell carcinoma is BerEP4-positive. The presence of ducts, highlighted by staining for CEA and EMA, helps to identify porocarcinoma, hidradenocarcinoma, and dermal duct tumours. In clear cell atypical fibroxanthoma, cytokeratin staining is negative and keratinization is absent. Clear cell and balloon cell melanomas stain for melanocyte markers. If there is no evidence of epidermal origin, metastatic carcinomas should be considered, especially from the kidney (PAX8-positive).
staging: Tumours should be staged according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis of clear cell SCC is comparable to that of other SCC types (see section Squamous cell carcinomas).
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Clear cell squamous cell carcinoma. Cytoplasmic vacuolation is prominent in areas with some signet-ring cells.
Clear cell squamous cell carcinoma. The cells have glycogen-rich cytoplasm and give a positive PAS reaction.

definition: Lymphoepithelial carcinoma is a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) admixed with variable amounts of lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate.
clinical:
This rare type of SCC typically shows rapid growth, but it has no features to distinguish it from other SCC types.

---

Lymphoepithelial carcinomas of the skin are exceedingly rare.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is similar to that of common forms of SCC (see section Squamous cell carcinomas).

---

Although lymphoepithelial carcinoma of the skin resembles undifferentiated nasopharyngeal carcinoma (lymphoepithelioma) histologically, a strong association with EBV has not been demonstrated.
microscopic: Lymphoepithelial carcinoma of the skin is characterized by poorly differentiated tumour cell islands surrounded and infiltrated by lymphocytes and variable numbers of plasma cells. Accordingly, the lesions resemble undifferentiated nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry (pancytokeratin, CK5/6, or p63) confirms the presence of epithelial elements that may be masked by the lymphoid component.
differential_diagnosis: Lymphoepithelial carcinoma of the skin must be distinguished from reactive and neoplastic lymphoid infiltrates of the skin, or inflamed SCC. Lymphadenoma has a banal epithelial component.
staging: Tumours should be staged according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: Excision is usually sufficient, but radiotherapy is sometimes used in cases with positive margins.
related_terminology: Not recommended: lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma.

media.legend: Lymphoepithelial carcinoma. Poorly differentiated tumour cell islands surrounded and infiltrated by a heavy inflammatory infiltrate.

Lymphoepithelial carcinoma. The tumour consists of numerous lymphocytes, scattered multinucleated giant cells, and plasma cells, in which malignant infiltrative squamous epithelial elements are embedded.

Lymphoepithelial carcinoma. Nodular aggregates of atypical epithelial cells surrounded by dense lymphocytic infiltrate, mimicking a lymphoid nodule. Epithelial cells show large vesicular nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and moderate to abundant vacuolated cytoplasm.

definition: Acantholytic squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a histological type of invasive SCC characterized by impaired intercellular adhesion that may result in the formation of pseudoglandular spaces.
clinical:
The clinical appearance of acantholytic invasive SCC is the same as that of its non-acantholytic counterpart (see section Squamous cell carcinomas).

---

Acantholytic SCC accounts for < 5% of all SCCs, although the criteria for this designation (focal vs widespread acantholysis) are not well established. Older men are most frequently affected, and an increased incidence has been reported in organ transplant recipients.
pathogenesis:
Given that most acantholytic SCCs occur in chronically sun-exposed sites, ultraviolet (UV) radiation–induced damage is probably a causative factor. The known association with chronic immunosuppression implies a role for defective immunosurveillance.

---

The histogenetic factors are most often the same genomic, molecular, and causative factors that are applicable to ordinary invasive SCC. Compared with non-acantholytic SCCs, acantholytic SCC has been shown to have decreased expression of desmoglein-3 and E-cadherin. Defective desmosomal protein expression has been confirmed and is probably largely responsible for the acantholytic pattern observed histologically. The genetic profile of and potential susceptibility loci for acantholytic SCC are not yet understood.
microscopic: At scanning magnification, the overall architecture of invasive acantholytic SCC does not differ substantially from that of ordinary non-acantholytic SCC types. The overlying epidermis is often thickened and hyperkeratotic or ulcerated, and full-thickness carcinoma in situ may be absent (a factor to consider when evaluating superficial shave biopsies). The hallmark of this type is acantholysis resulting in variably sized spaces within the invasive tumour lobules, which result from cell separation due to acantholysis of tumour cells, often containing floating individual tumour cells, which are rounded in contour and may exhibit premature keratinization (dyskeratosis) or necrosis. When these spaces are bordered by an intact layer of tumour cells, a pseudoglandular pattern may develop, reminiscent of glandular or vascular spaces (pseudovascularization). Immunohistochemically, acantholytic SCC shows reactivity typical of ordinary invasive SCC: pseudoglandular spaces are negative for mucin, CK7, and CEA, and pseudovascular regions are negative for CD31 and ERG.
differential_diagnosis: Lesions with extensive acantholysis can mimic either primary cutaneous (adnexal) or metastatic adenocarcinoma, and pseudoglandular spaces must be differentiated from the expression of true glands, as seen in adenosquamous carcinoma. Pseudovascular regions may superficially resemble angiosarcoma. Generally, acantholytic SCCs are not sufficiently well differentiated to elicit consideration of acantholytic benign keratosis (e.g. warty dyskeratoma).
staging: Depending on the site, the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM staging system applies.
prognosis_and_prediction: It has been suggested that acantholytic SCC is more aggressive than other SCC types, with a mortality rate at follow-up of 19%, although more recent data conflict with this interpretation. Histological attributes that may confer aggressive behaviour have recently been comparatively evaluated for acantholytic versus non-acantholytic SCC; these included microscopic tumour diameter, depth of invasion, degree of differentiation, and presence of perineural invasion. No significant differences between acantholytic and non-acantholytic ordinary SCCs were identified; overall, the notion that acantholytic SCC is a biologically and clinically more aggressive type of SCC has not been substantiated.
related_terminology: Not recommended: pseudoglandular squamous cell carcinoma; pseudovascular squamous cell carcinoma; adenoid squamous cell carcinoma.

media.legend: Acantholytic squamous cell carcinoma. At low magnification, acantholytic spaces are visible within much of the tumour.
Acantholytic squamous cell carcinoma. There is prominent acantholysis within many of the nests of invasive squamous cells.
Acantholytic squamous cell carcinoma. An invasive, ulcerated carcinoma, with acantholysis within the invasive tumour lobules, and some foci of dyskeratosis. Note the pseudoglandular appearance.

definition: Verrucous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a rare, well-differentiated type of cutaneous SCC; it has a characteristically undulant architecture and often exhibits locally aggressive behaviour, yet has low potential for metastasis. Similar lesions also affect mucosal surfaces.
clinical:
The clinical appearance of cutaneous verrucous SCC varies according to its site of occurrence. Palmoplantar lesions tend to grow and evolve slowly, forming hyperkeratotic plaques that may be confused with verrucae or callosities. Anogenital lesions form exophytic, condylomatoid excrescences that may be deeply invasive and difficult to eradicate, particularly in the setting of immunocompromise. Occasionally, tumours can have a more nodular clinical appearance.

---

Verrucous SCC is a tumour predominantly of older men, with 75% of patients aged ≥ 60 years.
pathogenesis:
Chronic irritation, inflammation, HPV infection, and impaired immunity have been proposed as possible etiological factors. As with other forms of cutaneous SCC, chemical carcinogens and environmental exposures have also been implicated. However, the precise inciting factors responsible for this uncommon type of SCC remain unknown.

---

Verrucous SCC has been described in association with a variety of reactive and inflammatory conditions, including vulvar lichen planus, although the precise histogenesis remains unclear. The role of HPV is controversial, in part because of diagnostic confusion between condylomatous and hyperplastic lesions and true verrucous SCC. An analysis of 13 rigorously defined verrucous SCCs from head and neck, anogenital, and extragenital skin using PCR-based HPV detection failed to implicate a causal role for HPV. However, there is a clear association between certain oncogenic HPV types and cutaneous SCC, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression, and the potential role of HPV in verrucous SCC warrants further investigation. Overexpression of MDM2, a negative regulator of p53, has been implicated.
microscopic: The histopathology of verrucous SCC is similar at all sites of occurrence. The lesions show a complex exophytic and endophytic architecture, with hyperkeratosis (often prominent) and characteristic deep tongues of intradermal growth that are club-like in contour. Cytological atypia is minimal, apart from several layers at the interface of the bulbous tips of the endophytic extensions. Characteristically, the inter-rete spaces are greatly diminished, with apparently reduced vascularity. The associated stroma may be inflamed, and fields of verrucous epidermal acanthosis and lichen simplex chronicus may flank lesions. Viral cytopathic alterations are generally not present in verrucous SCC, although they may be seen in the adjacent hyperplastic epidermis.
differential_diagnosis: The most frequent diagnostic challenge is differentiation from exuberant reactive processes. Penile lesions of verruciform xanthoma have been described as simulants of verrucous SCC. Verrucoid and endophytic squamous proliferations associated with fungal, leishmanial, and non-tuberculous mycobacterial infections may bear some resemblance to verrucous SCC. Confusion with fields of plantar verrucae may occasionally result in patients receiving less aggressive therapy than is required for verrucous SCC. Overall, the finding of deeply endophytic, club-shaped tongues with pushing borders of well-differentiated squamous epithelium, with only one or two cell layers (at most) at the advancing border showing atypia, should raise suspicion for verrucous SCC.
staging: Staging, which depends on the site, is according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: Incompletely excised lesions have a high recurrence rate, and recurrences can be more aggressive than the initial tumour. Metastasis generally does not occur, although transformation to more aggressive forms of SCC has been described in patients who had received irradiation or chemotherapy.
related_terminology: Not recommended: oral florid papillomatosis; Ackerman tumour; epithelioma cuniculatum; Buschke–Löwenstein tumour; giant condyloma acuminatum; papillomatosis cutis carcinoides.

media.legend: Verrucous squamous cell carcinoma. Scanning magnification shows a well-differentiated, keratinizing field giving rise to exuberant hyperkeratosis; the endophytic component forms invasive tongues with a characteristic club-shaped architecture.
Verrucous squamous cell carcinoma. The epithelial–stromal interface is mostly smooth but focally irregularly contoured.

definition: Cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a malignancy of epidermal keratinocytes that exhibits varying histology. It goes through stages of development from dysplasia to in situ lesions to invasive carcinoma.
clinical:
SCC appears as a solitary red scaly plaque, progressing to a hyperkeratotic, often ulcerated nodule. Lesions with perineural involvement produce pain/paraesthesia. Regional lymph node involvement is the first route of metastasis. Dermoscopy shows distinctive vascular patterns: small dotted, glomerular, hairpin/looped, and/or serpentine vessels.

---

The incidence of SCC is difficult to establish, but data on non-melanoma skin cancer suggest that there were an estimated 701 000 SCC tumours affecting 430 500 people in the USA in 2006 (assuming that 20% of tumours are SCC). SCC is the second most common form of skin cancer (after basal cell carcinoma) and is more common in men than in women. Most cases occur in sun-exposed skin of elderly individuals, most commonly individuals with lighter skin pigmentation.
pathogenesis:
In addition to ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure, other factors that have been implicated in the etiology of SCC include chronic immunosuppression, other forms of radiation, topical carcinogens, burn scars, chronic inflammation, sinus tracts, HPV infection, arsenic, and coal tar. Cutaneous SCC was the first occupational cancer to be identified, described in the scrotal skin of British chimney sweeps in 1775 by Percivall Pott. Patients with xeroderma pigmentosum, vitiligo, and albinism are at increased risk of SCC. A recent two-stage genome-wide association study of a large number of SCCs revealed 11 susceptibility loci. Of these, 7 are related to pigmentation: MC1R, ASIP, TYR, SLC45A2, OCA2, IRF4, and BNC2. The other 4 are involved in tumour immune evasion, apoptosis inhibition, or other oncogenic pathways: 11q23.3 (CADM1), 2p22.3, 7p21.1 (AHR), and 9q34.3 (SEC16A).

---

Most UV radiation–related cutaneous SCCs appear to develop through a multistep process in actinic keratoses or in fields of squamous dysplasia. Common mutations involve tumour suppressor genes such as TP53, NOTCH1, and NOTCH2. Activating mutations in genes such as HRAS and KRAS are also frequently involved. UV radiation–induced TP53 mutations probably occur early on in the process. Advanced age, immunosuppression, and environmentally determined defects in the epigenome appear to contribute to impaired elimination of precursors of malignant transformation. Cutaneous SCC probably arises from an epidermal or follicular stem cell. Recent genetic expression profile studies suggest that the differentially expressed genes CXCL8 (IL-8), MMP1, HIF1A, ITGA6, and ITGA2 are promising diagnostic and therapeutic targets.
microscopic: Although many SCCs progress from in situ lesions to progressively more deeply invasive tumours, some SCCs have no identifiable in situ precursor. Invasive SCC varies from well to poorly differentiated, with most classified as well to moderately differentiated. Some well-differentiated forms have a histological resemblance to keratoacanthoma, which is now considered to be a separate type of epidermal neoplasm. These are often termed keratoacanthoma-like SCC. Invasive tumour shows polygonal cellular profiles, pleomorphism, and varying amounts of cytoplasmic and extracytoplasmic keratin. Immunohistochemistry is generally not required, except for some poorly differentiated SCCs. Cutaneous SCC expresses p63, p40, CK5/6, MNF116 keratin, and 34βE12 keratin, with patchy EMA positivity. Unlike basal cell carcinoma, BerEP4 is negative.
differential_diagnosis: Paget disease and melanoma in situ may mimic SCC in situ. CK7 or CEA positivity in Paget disease, and SOX10 in melanoma, are diagnostic. Well-differentiated SCC must be distinguished from pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia, syringometaplasia, inverted follicular keratosis, and inflamed verruca. Re-excision perineural invasion occurs when squamoid cells surround nerves in scars, and it can mimic SCC. Poorly differentiated or sarcomatoid SCC must be differentiated from melanoma, atypical fibroxanthoma, sarcoma, and lymphoma; a panel of immunohistochemical stains including SOX10, CK5/6, p63, and CD45 (LCA) is recommended. Colonization by melanocytes or melanoma may occur.
staging: The eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM staging system is applicable to SCCs of head and neck origin only; it uses tumour diameter, invasion of underlying structures such as bone, and perineural invasion in nerves > 0.1 mm diameter for primary tumours and incorporates nodal and systemic involvement.
prognosis_and_prediction: Confirmed high-risk histological prognostic features are a tumour thickness of > 2 mm, Clark level IV or V invasion, perineural invasion, primary site on the ear or lip, and poor differentiation. Perineural invasion of nerves ≥ 0.1 mm in diameter correlates with higher disease-specific death rates. SCCs arising in organ transplant patients are often multiple and aggressive. Some types of SCC show distinct prognoses. Tumours with desmoplastic histology are often considered worse. Lymphoepithelial carcinoma of the skin is considered to have an intermediate metastatic potential, with a 5–10% risk of regional metastasis. Acantholytic SCC does not show a worse prognosis than typical SCC.
cytology: FNAC is used to evaluate enlarged regional lymph nodes. Pap-stained slides show orangeophilic polygonal cells with an increased N:C ratio, hyperchromatic nuclei, and chromatin clumping.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Not recommended
related_terminology: None
subtypes: Individual SCC types are described in the sections that follow this overview.

media.legend: Squamous cell carcinoma. Clinical appearance of typical invasive squamous cell carcinoma forming a nodule surmounted by hyperkeratotic scale, arising in chronically sun-damaged skin.

definition: Fibroepithelial BCC is a BCC composed of thin, interanastomosing strands of basaloid cells surrounded by abundant fibroblastic stroma.
clinical:
Fibroepithelial BCC appears as an exophytic, flesh-coloured nodule, often resembling a fibroepithelial polyp, and it may be pigmented. Dermoscopy shows fine arborizing vessels and white septal lines or streaks. Grey-brown structureless pigmentation and grey-blue dots may be seen in pigmented lesions.

---

Fibroepithelial BCC is rare, accounting for 0.2–1.4% of all BCC cases.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Controversy exists over whether this tumour may represent a trichoblastoma, because it occurs in locations uncommon for BCC, and it features horn cysts and fibroblast-rich stroma that are unusual in BCC. However, fibroepithelial BCC is uncommon on the head and neck but can be found on the foot, in contradistinction to trichoblastoma.
microscopic: Fibroepithelial BCC shows multiple strands of basaloid epithelium with peripheral palisades emanating from the epidermis. The strands are surrounded by abundant fibroblastic, eosinophilic stroma.
differential_diagnosis: Eccrine syringofibroadenoma shows a similar growth pattern, but the tumour strands show ductal differentiation, and it is more often located on extremities. Fibroepithelial BCC frequently shows retraction artefact and mucinous stroma, and stains for AR, distinguishing it from trichoblastoma.
staging: These tumours should be staged according to Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) guidance, depending on site.
prognosis_and_prediction: This is considered to be a low-risk type of BCC for which standard excision is recommended.
related_terminology: Not recommended: fibroepithelioma of Pinkus; Pinkus tumour.

entity_name: Basal cell carcinoma with adnexal differentiation
definition: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) with adnexal differentiation is a type of BCC with follicular, sebaceous, eccrine, or apocrine differentiation.
clinical:
The clinical features are similar to those of other members of the BCC family (see section Basal cell carcinomas).

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
pathogenesis:
Multiple infundibulocystic BCCs are a feature of multiple hereditary infundibulocystic BCC syndrome and naevoid BCC syndrome. BCC with sebaceous differentiation may rarely be seen in Muir–Torre syndrome.

---

A small series of sporadic BCCs with matrical differentiation showed molecular abnormalities in CTNNB1, KIT, CDKN2A, TP53, SMAD4, ERBB4, and PTCH1, providing supporting evidence that these tumours may be a type of BCC.
macroscopic: There are no distinctive macroscopic features.
microscopic: BCC with adnexal differentiation can show different patterns, including ductal differentiation, matrical differentiation, and sebaceous differentiation, or an infundibulocystic pattern. BCC with matrical differentiation contains shadow cells, trichohyalin granules, and grey-blue keratin indicative of hair matrix / inner root sheath differentiation. Infundibulocystic BCC shows differentiation towards the follicular infundibulum, with anastomosing cords and nests of basaloid cells, punctuated by small infundibular cyst-like structures. BCC with sebaceous differentiation shows mature sebocytes that stain for EMA or adipophilin. BCC with ductal differentiation contains CEA-positive and EMA-positive ducts, with or without a cuticle, resembling those found in apocrine or eccrine glands (normal apocrine and eccrine ducts are indistinguishable). BCC with apocrine glandular differentiation shows decapitation secretion.
differential_diagnosis: Matrical, sebaceous, or apocrine differentiation in BCC is generally a focal finding, and a predominance of areas of conventional BCC is a clue to the diagnosis. In a limited specimen, distinguishing BCC with adnexal differentiation from true adnexal tumours can be exceedingly difficult. BCC with conspicuous matrical differentiation must be distinguished from pilomatrical carcinoma. The differential diagnosis of infundibulocystic BCC includes basaloid follicular hamartoma and trichoepithelioma. BCC with sebaceous differentiation should be differentiated from sebaceous carcinoma and sebaceoma. BCC with ductal differentiation must be distinguished from other sweat gland carcinomas and entrapped native apocrine and eccrine ducts.
staging: These tumours should be staged according to Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) guidance, depending on site.
prognosis_and_prediction: The presence of adnexal differentiation confers no prognostic significance.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Inherited infundibulocystic BCCs are associated with mutations in SUFU, whereas sporadic tumours were additionally found to harbour alterations beyond SUFU in the hedgehog pathway, including SMO, GLI1, and GLI2. PTCH1 is implicated in naevoid BCC syndrome.
related_terminology: Not recommended: basal cell carcinoma with divergent differentiation.

media.legend: Basal cell carcinoma with matrical differentiation. Infiltrative basaloid tumour containing islands of shadow cells indicative of hair matrix differentiation.
Infundibulocystic basal cell carcinoma. Anastomosing cords of basaloid tumour cells punctuated by small keratin-filled cysts.
Basal cell carcinoma with sebaceous differentiation. Basaloid tumour containing multivacuolated mature sebocytes, consistent with sebaceous differentiation.

entity_name: Basal cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid differentiation
definition: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) with sarcomatoid differentiation has an epithelial BCC component and malignant stroma that can show varying differentiation.
clinical:
Patients present with a rapidly growing new lesion or rapid enlargement of a longer-standing lesion. It is typically large at diagnosis (average: 28 mm). The morphology is usually that of an exophytic nodule, and ulceration is frequent.

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The epithelial component is believed to undergo divergent mesenchymal differentiation, leading to the development of the stromal component. While the sarcomatous stroma is typically negative for keratins and p63, positive p63 staining in 1 case bolsters this hypothesis.
microscopic: Nodules of BCC are separated by a malignant mesenchymal stroma that resembles pleomorphic undifferentiated sarcoma, osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and (rarely) myoepithelial carcinoma. Sarcomatous stroma will have focal or absent staining for keratins or p63.
staging: Staging is according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: This type of BCC has a similar recurrence rate and metastatic potential to other BCCs of similar size, despite its aggressive histology. This is in contradistinction to the more aggressive behaviour of sarcomatoid squamous cell carcinoma and adnexal carcinomas with sarcomatous differentiation.
related_terminology: Not recommended: metaplastic carcinoma; carcinosarcomatous basal cell carcinoma; sarcomatoid basal cell carcinoma.

definition: Basosquamous carcinoma (BSC) is a type of basal cell carcinoma (BCC) with areas of both BCC and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and may contain transition zones between the two.
clinical:
Patients present with a slowly evolving papule or nodule, which is frequently ulcerated. Dermoscopy shows combined features of both BCC and SCC, with unfocused arborizing vessels, white structureless areas, keratin masses, ulceration or haemorrhagic crust, white structures, blue-grey blotches, and blood spots on keratin masses. A dermoscopic pattern with criteria for both BCC and SCC raises suspicion of BSC.

---

BSC is a rare tumour type, estimated to account for 1.2–2.7% of all skin cancers.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Controversy over the origin of this biphenotypic carcinoma exists, and some consider it to represent a collision between BCC and SCC. More recently, it has been considered to represent a BCC in which a component undergoes genetic transformation in a higher-grade squamous carcinoma. Immunohistochemical and histological evidence of a transition zone between a BerEP4-positive/EMA-negative basal cell component and BerEP4-negative/EMA-positive SCC component supports this hypothesis.
microscopic: Lesions show histologically and immunophenotypically distinct zones of BCC intermixed with SCC, in varying proportions. There may be a zone of transition between the two growth patterns, or they may be closely intertwined. The BCC areas show the typical basaloid cell growth and are often of infiltrative histology; SCC zones show histological atypia with keratinization. Perineural invasion is seen in 5.5% of lesions.
differential_diagnosis: Nodular BCC with squamous differentiation shows focal mature keratinization in the centre of basaloid nests, without high-grade atypia. Squamous change around an ulcer may mimic BSC.
staging: These tumours should be staged according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system, depending on site.
prognosis_and_prediction: BSC is considered an aggressive carcinoma and is characterized by a higher local recurrence rate than both BCC and SCC and a relatively high metastatic potential. Recurrence after surgical excision has been reported in 12–51% of cases, with a 4% recurrence rate after Mohs micrographic surgery. Male sex, positive margins, and lymphatic and perineural invasion predict recurrence. The metastatic rate is similar to that of SCC (5–8.4%) and occurs most commonly in regional lymph nodes, followed by lungs. The overall prognosis for metastatic disease is intermediate between BCC and SCC; in a study of 19 patients, the median overall survival time was 6.5 years, the median progression-free survival time was 1.1 years, and the 5-year overall survival rate was 54%.
related_terminology: Not recommended: metatypical basal cell carcinoma; basal cell carcinoma with squamous differentiation.

media.legend: Basosquamous carcinoma. Basaloid areas (upper portion of the field) intermingled with areas of malignant squamous epithelium (lower portion of the field).
Basosquamous carcinoma. Infiltrative basaloid strands intermixed with islands of polygonal atypical squamous cells.

definition: Sclerosing/morphoeic basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a BCC type characterized by very thin cords of basaloid cells surrounded by abundant collagenous stroma.
clinical:
Patients with this type present with a poorly defined, scar-like plaque that rarely ulcerates or bleeds. On dermoscopy it is typified by thin serpentine vessels.

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
pathogenesis:
See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
microscopic: Narrow cords of tumour (1–5 cells thick) are compressed by induced sclerotic collagenous stroma, disrupting the normal dermal architecture. Peripheral palisading and retraction artefact are uncommon. These tumours penetrate deeply and show an irregular/tentacular, deeply infiltrative border with the surrounding stroma. There is often overlap with infiltrating BCC, which lacks the prominent induced collagenous stroma.
differential_diagnosis: Sclerosing/morphoeic BCC can be difficult to distinguish from desmoplastic trichoepithelioma and microcystic adnexal carcinoma; immunostaining may facilitate this distinction. Fibroblast activation protein is positive in stromal fibroblasts of BCC but not in desmoplastic trichoepithelioma. BerEP4 is expressed in BCC but not in microcystic adnexal carcinoma. A cytoplasmic staining pattern of laminin-γ2 is found in infiltrating and morphoeic BCC, whereas in microcystic adnexal carcinoma, laminin-γ2 is present both along tumour nests and in the cytoplasm. Laminin-γ2 is negative in desmoplastic trichoepithelioma and syringoma.
staging: Staging is according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognostic and predictive factors are similar to those of infiltrating and micronodular BCCs. This type of BCC has a tendency for perineural invasion and local recurrence; surgical excision with strict margin control is mandatory.
related_terminology: Acceptable: morpheaform basal cell carcinoma.

media.legend: Sclerosing/morphoeic basal cell carcinoma showing jagged tumour islands surrounded by abundant fibrocellular stroma.
Sclerosing/morphoeic basal cell carcinoma showing cellular preponderance of fibrocollagenous stroma compressing tumour islands.
Sclerosing/morphoeic basal cell carcinoma. Clinical photograph of sclerosing/morphoeic basal cell carcinoma showing depressed white plaque with telangiectasia.
Sclerosing/morphoeic basal cell carcinoma. Dermoscopy of morphoeic basal cell carcinoma shows thin, serpentine vessels.
Sclerosing basal cell carcinoma. Thin infiltrating strands of basaloid cells, one to two cells thick, in a sclerotic stroma.

definition: Infiltrating basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is characterized by elongated islands and strands of basaloid cells that are poorly circumscribed with spiking projections.
clinical:
These tumours are usually pink papules and plaques that are frequently ulcerated and may have a scar-like presentation. They are most frequent on the head and neck. On dermoscopy they are typified by thin serpentine vessels. Biopsy should include deep reticular dermis for most accurate diagnosis.

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
pathogenesis:
See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
microscopic: Variably sized, sometimes jagged nests of basaloid tumour cells infiltrate the normal dermal collagen. The tumour has an irregular permeating pattern of invasion at the deep tumour edge. Approximately one third of infiltrating BCCs are admixed with a nodular BCC component. Perineural invasion is more frequent in this type of BCC. There is often overlap with sclerosing/morphoeic and micronodular BCCs, which has led to a proposal to group these three tumour types into one group called infiltrative BCC.
differential_diagnosis: Differentiation of infiltrative BCC from other types of BCC with infiltrative growth (sclerosing/morphoeic and micronodular BCCs) can be difficult. Infiltrating BCC can also be admixed with nodular and superficial BCCs, but the presence of infiltrative morphology defines the tumour type.
staging: Staging is according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: This type of BCC has a high risk of recurrence, requiring surgery with strict margin control.
related_terminology: Acceptable: infiltrative basal cell carcinoma. Not recommended: basal cell carcinoma with aggressive growth pattern.

Infiltrating basal cell carcinoma. Dermoscopic image of infiltrating basal cell carcinoma showing white papule with serpentine vessels.

Infiltrating basal cell carcinoma. Narrow tumour islands compressed by collagen with fibromyxoid appearance.
Infiltrating BCC. Whole slide image of infiltrating BCC

definition: Micronodular basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is an aggressive type of BCC characterized by small nests with an irregular, tentacular, and infiltrative deep or peripheral edge. It typically extends deeply into the dermis or beyond.
clinical:
Patients with micronodular BCC usually present with a pink papule or nodule that is often ulcerated and cannot be distinguished from nodular BCC on naked-eye examination or dermoscopy.

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
pathogenesis:
See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
microscopic: Micronodular BCC is composed predominantly of rounded, ovoid, or slender groups of basaloid cells that are often scattered throughout the dermis and subcutis. These may appear as separate satellites outlined by a thin rim of stroma and separated by normal dermis. The tumours have an irregular, tentacular, and infiltrative deep or peripheral edge composed predominantly (i.e. > 50%) of rounded, small, discrete groups of cells (< 0.15 mm in diameter). Single nodules may be seen distant from the bulk of the main tumour. The tumours can reach a large size and may demonstrate perineural involvement. This type of BCC is frequently mixed with other types, including nodular and infiltrative BCC. Punch biopsies have a significant false negative rate for detecting micronodular BCC and mixed tumours. Section misorientation and the lack of strict definitions in terms of the size and number of micronodules may contribute to poor interobserver reproducibility in the diagnosis of this BCC type.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes nodular BCC with focal micronodular architecture, but such tumours are encased by a common stroma and lack the satellite pattern seen in micronodular BCC.
prognosis_and_prediction: Prognostic data for micronodular BCC are limited by inconsistent histological classification and poor interobserver reproducibility. Nevertheless, this tumour type appears to be strongly associated with an increased risk of local recurrence.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Micronodular basal cell carcinoma (clinical photo). Micronodular basal cell carcinoma usually presents as a pink papule or nodule. It is often ulcerated and cannot be distinguished from nodular basal cell carcinoma on naked-eye examination or dermoscopy.
Micronodular basal cell carcinoma shows small nests separated by fibrous stroma.
