Micronodular basal cell carcinoma.

definition: Nodular basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common BCC type and is defined by well-circumscribed large dermal tumour islands with peripheral palisading.
clinical:
Patients with nodular BCC present with a pink papule or nodule with frequent ulceration and occasionally pigmentation. On dermoscopy, nodular BCC shows arborizing vessels and, if pigmented, blue globules. Cystic BCC may be translucent and resemble hidrocystoma.

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
pathogenesis:
See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
microscopic: Well-circumscribed, variably sized nodules of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading and retraction spaces are seen; disorganized nuclear arrangement with apoptosis is frequently observed in the centre of the nodules. The tumour is usually connected with the epidermis. The stroma is paucicellular; amyloid deposition or keloidal-type collagenous stroma may be seen, but not desmoplasia. Functional melanocytes are found in many BCCs and may be associated with melanin pigment in tumour nests and in stromal melanophages. Patterns of nodular BCC include pigmented, keratotic, cystic, and nodulocystic. Keratinizing BCC tumour nests show central mature keratinization. Nodulocystic or cystic BCC shows cystic degeneration within tumour islands. Cribriform tumour nests are seen in adenoid BCC. Less common patterns include rippled, labyrinthine, or trabecular arrays. Clear, signet-ring, granular, and giant (monster) cell types have been described.
differential_diagnosis: Cases with small nodules should be differentiated from aggressive micronodular BCC. Distinction from benign and malignant trichoblastic tumours, especially trichoblastoma, can be difficult in some cases. The presence of papillary mesenchymal bodies and eosinophilic fibroblastic stroma encasing tumour nodules but retracting from the surrounding dermis favours the latter. Lesions with cystic change may simulate other adnexal tumours, particularly adenoid cystic carcinoma. BerEP4 expression is found in BCC and Merkel cell carcinoma, which may cause diagnostic difficulties. Conversely, BCC can express markers of neuroendocrine differentiation, such as chromogranin and synaptophysin in as many as 27% of cases, but it lacks the dot-like perinuclear positivity for CK20 typical of Merkel cell carcinoma. Ulcerated BCC may show superficial mature-appearing squamoid change immediately beneath the ulcer, raising the possibility of squamous cell carcinoma. Basosquamous carcinoma shows malignant-appearing squamous elements admixed with typical basaloid carcinoma elements.
staging: Staging is according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: Prognostic and predictive factors include tumour location, tumour size, and patient immune status. After complete surgical excision, recurrence and metastasis are exceedingly rare.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Nodular basal cell carcinoma with focal pigmentation, demonstrating pearly papulonodule with telangiectatic vessels centrally.
Nodular basal cell carcinoma. Dermoscopy of nodular basal cell carcinoma shows blue, brown, and white globules, as well as serpentine vessels.
Nodular basal cell carcinoma with several patterns, including cystic change and focal keratinization.
Nodular basal cell carcinoma. Basaloid neoplasm with large nodules of basaloid cells in dermis. Nodules show peripheral palisading and clefting. Fibromyxoid stroma.

definition: Superficial basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a type of BCC, often with multifocal epidermal connection, that is confined to the papillary dermis.
clinical:
Superficial BCC is characterized by erythematous, often annular, mildly scaly patches with rolled borders, ranging from 1–2 mm to > 100 mm in diameter. Dermoscopy most often reveals short fine telangiectasia, multiple small erosions, and shiny white structures.

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
pathogenesis:
See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).

---

See the family description (section Basal cell carcinomas).
microscopic: Lobules of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading extend from the base of the epidermis, and occasionally the adnexal epithelium, into the papillary dermis. Retraction of lobules from surrounding fibromyxoid stroma and a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate may be seen. Lesions may appear multifocal but are connected in three dimensions. Admixed regions of nodular, micronodular, and infiltrative BCC may occur.
differential_diagnosis: BerEP4/EpCAM is positive in BCC but negative in actinic keratosis. Follicular induction resembling superficial BCC may be seen over dermatofibromas, scars, and other reactive or neoplastic conditions.
prognosis_and_prediction: Superficial BCC is considered to have a low risk of recurrence and a negligible risk of metastasis (see section Basal cell carcinomas).
related_terminology: Not recommended: superficial multifocal basal cell carcinoma; superficial multicentric basal cell carcinoma.

media.legend: Superficial basal cell carcinoma presents as an erythematous patch, often with rolled borders and multifocal erosion.
Superficial basal cell carcinoma. Dermoscopy of superficial basal cell carcinoma shows chaotic pigmentation, multiple microulcerations, and white lines.
Superficial basal cell carcinoma showing multiple nests of basaloid epithelium emanating from dermoepidermal junction.
Superficial basal cell carcinoma. Nests of superficial basal cell carcinoma intermingled with a chronically inflamed, fibrotic-appearing dermis.

Superficial basal cell carcinoma. Basaloid neoplasm with small buds of basaloid cells extending from epidermis. Buds of basaloid cells show peripheral palisading and clefting. Fibromyxoid stroma in the underlying papillary dermis.

definition: Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a family of carcinomas that arise either from epithelial cells of the epidermis or from hair follicle stem cells. There are numerous morphological types with distinctive clinical and histological features but similar epidemiology and etiology. All types have in common the presence of nests of basaloid cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and minimal cytoplasm.
clinical:
BCC is most common on the head and neck, followed by the trunk and extremities; the various types show different location predilections and clinical appearances. BCC has also been reported in the perianal and genital region, nail unit, palm, and sole. Dermoscopy improves the sensitivity of clinical diagnosis over visual examination from 67% to 85%.

---

BCC is the most common human malignancy and represents about 80% of all cancers of the skin. Incidence worldwide is rising, with an estimated 4 million new cases worldwide in 2019. The highest rates are seen in Australia, and the lowest in parts of Africa. Over the past decade, the largest increase in incidence occurred in the USA; there were unexpected increases in eastern Asia and tropical Latin America and decreases in Brazil and some African countries. Incidence is inversely related to geographical latitude combined with the pigment status of the population. Risk increases with age, and prolonged life expectancy has contributed to the rise in cases. Although BCC is more common in men overall, a dramatic increase in incidence has been seen in young women in Europe and the USA, resulting in a predominance of women in that age group. This may be due to higher use of indoor tanning and closer attention to skin health with increased medical visits.
pathogenesis:
Patients who are older, are male, have sensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure due to light skin pigmentation, and are exposed to intense intermittent UV radiation are most likely to develop BCC. Chronic arsenic exposure may cause BCC. Radiation treatment, especially in youth, is strongly associated with BCC development. All patients with naevoid BCC syndrome (Gorlin syndrome) develop BCCs; patients with xeroderma pigmentosum, Bazex–Dupré–Christol syndrome, and Rombo syndrome are also at risk. Polymorphisms in the MC1R, ASIP, and TYR genes, which regulate melanin production, increase the risk of BCC.

---

The pathogenesis of BCC involves an interplay between genetic susceptibility and sporadic UV radiation–induced mutations; BCC has the most mutations of any human cancer. Germline mutations in PTCH1 on chromosome 9q22.3-q316 are the cause of BCC in Gorlin syndrome; see section Naevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (Gorlin syndrome). Loss of heterozygosity of PTCH1 is seen in 58–69% of sporadic BCCs; less frequently, SMO and PTCH2 are affected, and most of these are UV radiation signature mutations. Mutant PTCH1 and PTCH1 proteins are receptors for the sonic hedgehog protein, and mutant PTCH1 leads to the increased release of transmembrane protein SMO, which leads to downstream activation of the GLI1 transcriptional pathway that is involved in cell renewal, fate, and survival, and in angiogenesis. Inactivating TP53 alterations are seen in 40–65% of sporadic cases; loss of heterozygosity of this gene is mutually exclusive with PTCH1. TP53 alterations cause dysregulation of cell-cycle arrest, apoptosis, and DNA repair.
macroscopic: See the individual BCC tumour types.
microscopic: All types of BCC are characterized by basaloid tumour cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Apoptotic cells are common within the nests. Stromal changes include fibromyxoid change, retraction of tumour nests from stroma, calcification, and amyloid deposition. Tumour nests may be colonized by melanocytes and contain melanin pigment. Colonization by melanoma (lentigo maligna) cells has been reported. Mature keratinization is most common in nodular BCC.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes basaloid follicular neoplasms (trichoepithelioma, trichoblastoma, basaloid follicular hamartoma), basaloid squamous cell carcinoma, sebaceous carcinoma, and Merkel cell carcinoma. BCC shows strong expression of p40/p63 and CK5/6, diffuse BCL2 and CD10 positivity, and focal AR expression, and is negative for EMA, CEA, and CK20. The basaloid follicular neoplasms show colonizing CK20-positive Merkel cells, stromal but not tumoural CD10 expression, and peripheral BCL2 positivity. Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma is positive for EMA and negative for BerEP4, and sebaceous carcinoma is strongly positive for EMA, AR, and adipophilin, but negative for BerEP4. Merkel cell carcinoma is diffusely CK20-positive with perinuclear dot-like positivity and diffusely expresses neuroendocrine markers. A potential pitfall is that BCC may express neuroendocrine markers: CD56 (NCAM) is positive in 95% of cases, chromogranin A in 28%, and synaptophysin in 18%.
staging: Staging is according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system, as for other cutaneous malignancies.
prognosis_and_prediction: The National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines stratify BCC types by risk of recurrence, on the basis of clinical and pathological parameters (see #34667Table 2.02). A consensus panel has advocated unifying infiltrating, sclerosing/morphoeic, and micronodular BCC into a single infiltrative BCC category to improve reproducibility in diagnosis and stratification to the high-risk group.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular testing is not required for primary diagnosis, but identification of mutations in the hedgehog pathway along with a high tumour mutation burden may be helpful in diagnosing a rare case of metastatic BCC. Mutations in SMO confer resistance to pharmacological inhibition of the hedgehog pathway by vismodegib.
related_terminology: Not recommended: basal cell epithelioma; basalioma; trichoblastic carcinoma.

definition: Benign keratoses with distinctive morphological patterns that do not meet the criteria for any of the entities described in the previous sections include acantholytic acanthoma, acantholytic dyskeratotic acanthoma, epidermolytic acanthoma, granular parakeratotic acanthoma, psoriasiform keratosis, and melanoacanthoma.
clinical:
Acantholytic acanthomas are solitary papules or nodules (5–12 mm), with a predilection for the trunk of adults (median age: 60 years). Males are more commonly affected. Multiple lesions have been reported in the setting of immunosuppression. Acantholytic dyskeratotic acanthomas are solitary lesions (< 10 mm) that affect the trunk of adults, with a slight female predominance. The nail may also be affected. Epidermolytic acanthomas are verrucous papules or plaques (2–12 mm) that may be solitary or multiple. The anatomical distribution is wide and includes genital and mucosal sites. A wide age range is affected. Granular parakeratotic acanthomas are rare solitary lesions affecting mainly the trunk and extremities and occurring in adults. Psoriasiform keratoses are solitary scaly erythematous papules or plaques (≤ 30 mm). The anatomical distribution is wide, with a predilection for the extremities of adults. Melanoacanthomas are dark-brown, well-circumscribed plaques or nodules reaching sizes as large as several centimetres. They have a wide anatomical distribution and affect adults.

---

Unknown
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: Acantholytic acanthoma is a well-circumscribed keratosis characterized by epidermal acanthosis, a papillomatous growth pattern, and overlying hyperkeratosis. There is prominent acantholysis affecting various levels of the epidermis and resembling pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus foliaceus, or benign chronic pemphigus (Hailey–Hailey disease). Focal dyskeratosis may also be present, and there is an associated superficial dermal chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate. Acantholytic dyskeratotic acanthoma is sharply demarcated and shows acanthosis with prominent acantholytic dyskeratosis, with corps grains and corps ronds. Epidermolytic acanthoma is a well-delineated keratosis with verrucous epidermal hyperplasia showing striking epidermolytic hyperkeratosis. Granular parakeratotic acanthoma is a well-circumscribed epidermal proliferation with a growth pattern reminiscent of adenoid seborrhoeic keratosis but showing marked granular parakeratosis. Psoriasiform keratosis is characterized by verrucous irregular epidermal hyperplasia with hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and intracorneal neutrophils. Dilated vessels and a chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate are apparent in the superficial dermis. Melanoacanthoma is microscopically similar to seborrhoeic keratosis or other benign squamoproliferative lesions, but it shows colonization by numerous dendritic melanocytes with bland cytological features. In addition, there is marked melanin deposition within keratinocytes. Immunohistochemistry for melan-A or HMB45 highlights the dendritic melanocytes.
differential_diagnosis: The above-mentioned keratoses closely resemble the various dermatoses reflected in their names. Because they may be indistinguishable histologically, their clinical presentation as solitary papules, nodules, and plaques is the key to correct diagnosis. Melanoacanthoma may be mistaken for melanoma; immunohistochemistry for melanocytic markers demonstrates the colonization of a keratosis by dendritic melanocytes. Verrucous keratosis is a descriptive term used for a keratosis that shows overlapping features of verruca vulgaris and seborrhoeic keratosis and may represent either a collision or a viral superinfection of the seborrhoeic keratosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: These are benign keratoses.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Acantholytic acanthoma. Well-circumscribed keratosis characterized by epidermal thickening and acantholysis.
Acantholytic acanthoma. Higher magnification reveals prominent acantholysis with lack of dyskeratosis, reminiscent of benign chronic pemphigus (Hailey–Hailey disease).
Melanoacanthoma. The prominent intralesional melanin pigment may lead to an erroneous diagnosis of a melanocytic lesion.
Melanoacanthoma. Immunohistochemistry for melan-A highlights colonization by dendritic melanocytes.

definition: Warty dyskeratoma is a benign endophytic squamoproliferative lesion arising in association with pilosebaceous units and showing prominent acantholytic dyskeratosis.
clinical:
Warty dyskeratomas appear as solitary tan to light-brown papules or small nodules and may appear umbilicated. They are rarely multiple. Mucosal lesions are white.

---

Warty dyskeratoma occurs across a wide age range, with a predilection for elderly individuals (median age: 61 years, range: 3–88 years) and a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Warty dyskeratomas have been reported in association with BRAF inhibition, suggesting that this may play a role in their formation. Multiple warty dyskeratomas are rare; they have been reported in the setting of renal dysfunction.
microscopic: Warty dyskeratoma is a well-circumscribed, cup-shaped epidermal invagination. It is composed of a proliferation of keratinocytes, with budding into the surrounding papillary dermis. There is prominent acantholysis, with suprabasal clefting, dyskeratosis, corps ronds, corps grains, and an overlying parakeratotic plug. Mitoses are common. The surrounding epidermis may be hyperplastic or papillomatous, and an epidermal collarette may also be seen. A connection with a pilosebaceous unit is common. The surrounding stroma is often hyalinized and contains stromal clefts and a chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate, as well as melanophages. Rarely, cystic and nodular patterns are encountered, and a combination of the various patterns may be present in an individual neoplasm.
differential_diagnosis: Darier disease and Grover disease can be excluded on clinical grounds. Acantholytic squamous cell carcinoma shows keratinocytic atypia; it lacks the circumscription and well-demarcated outlines, and commonly shows an infiltrative growth pattern.
prognosis_and_prediction: Warty dyskeratoma is benign.
related_terminology: Not recommended: isolated dyskeratosis follicularis; follicular dyskeratoma.

media.legend: Warty dyskeratoma. Note the lesional circumscription and slightly endophytic architecture on low-power magnification.
Warty dyskeratoma. Suprabasilar acantholysis and a central parakeratotic plug are present.
Warty dyskeratoma. Note the suprabasilar acantholysis and the dyskeratotic cells on higher magnification.

definition: Large cell acanthomas are benign intraepidermal keratinocytic proliferations on a morphological spectrum with solar lentigines and early seborrhoeic keratoses.
clinical:
Large cell acanthomas appear as well-circumscribed tan to brown macules, typically measuring < 10 mm.

---

Fair-skinned, middle-aged to elderly adults are mainly affected.
pathogenesis:
Large cell acanthomas are linked to chronic ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure.

---

There is considerable overlap with solar lentigo with respect to the expression of keratin and of antiapoptotic and proliferative markers.
microscopic: Large cell acanthomas are sharply delineated from the adjacent normal epidermis and characterized by epidermal flattening and overlying basket-weave hyperkeratosis. They are composed of enlarged keratinocytes with nuclei up to twice the size of those of adjacent normal keratinocytes. The lesional keratinocytes contain abundant cytoplasm and the nuclear contours are smooth and regular. There is no nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic figures are rare. Hyperpigmentation of the basal cell layer is frequently observed. There are often admixed or adjacent changes of solar lentigo.
differential_diagnosis: Actinic keratoses show squamous dysplasia affecting the lower and mid epidermal layers, often associated with overlying parakeratosis. Lentigo maligna is characterized by confluent growth of single junctional melanocytes, which may be highlighted by immunohistochemistry for melan-A or SOX10.
prognosis_and_prediction: Large cell acanthomas are benign.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Large cell acanthomas show enlarged keratinocytes twice the size of adjacent normal keratinocytes. The nuclear contours are smooth, and mitotic figures are absent. Also note the overlying basket-weave orthokeratosis.
Large cell acanthoma. This epidermal tumour is sharply demarcated and shows acanthosis and overlying orthohyperkeratosis.
Large cell acanthoma. The hallmark feature is the presence of large keratinocytes with smooth nuclear contours and no signs of keratinocyte dysplasia.
Large cell acanthoma. Mild acanthotic and hyperorthokeratotic epidermis with slight papillomatosis, as well as cells showing large nuclei, almost twice the size of normal keratinocytes.

definition: Clear cell acanthoma is a sharply demarcated intraepidermal keratinocytic proliferation with pale- to clear-staining cytoplasm.
clinical:
Patients present with sharply delineated, solitary, erythematous or brown papules and nodules, measuring from 5 mm to a few centimetres and occasionally showing a polypoid growth. Dermoscopy reveals a linear or serpiginous vascular pattern with a string-of-pearls appearance against a homogeneous pale or pink background.

---

Middle-aged to elderly adults are most commonly affected, without a marked sex bias.
pathogenesis:
It is unclear whether clear cell acanthoma represents a benign neoplasm or an inflammatory/reactive dermatosis. The solitary nature, persistence, and lack of regression point to a neoplastic origin, but immunohistochemistry has demonstrated similarities in keratin expression with psoriasis.

---

Unknown
microscopic: Clear cell acanthomas are well circumscribed, with psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia and elongated and fused rete ridges with thinning of the papillary plates and sparing of the adnexal structures. They are composed of keratinocytes with pale- to clear-staining cytoplasm, and there is an abrupt radial transition to adjacent normal keratinocytes. The pale keratinocytes contain PAS-positive glycogen. There is overlying parakeratosis and there are admixed intraepidermal and intracorneal neutrophils. The superficial dermis contains a mixed inflammatory infiltrate and prominent vasculature. Squamous cell carcinoma in situ can be separated by the presence of squamous dysplasia. Psoriasis is excluded clinically.
prognosis_and_prediction: Clear cell acanthomas are benign.
related_terminology: Not recommended: pale cell acanthoma; Degos acanthoma.

media.legend: Clear cell acanthomas are characterized by psoriasiform epidermal hyperplasia with clear or pale cell change.
Clear cell acanthoma. There is a sharp demarcation with the adjacent normal epidermis.
Clear cell acanthoma. The tumour cells contain abundant clear cytoplasm. Also note the intralesional neutrophils and the dilated papillary vessels.

Clear cell acanthoma. Well-demarcated, acanthotic epidermis with clear/pale cells showing distinct transition from surrounding normal keratinocytes. Overlying parakeratosis. Neutrophils may infiltrate the epidermis, sometimes forming microabscesses in the stratum corneum. Dermis shows mild perivascular lymphocytes and dilated blood vessels in oedematous pale dermal papillae.

definition: Lichen planus–like keratosis is a benign intraepidermal keratinocytic neoplasm with features reminiscent of seborrhoeic keratosis and an additional superficial dermal chronic inflammatory infiltrate with interface change, probably reflecting regression.
clinical:
Lichen planus–like keratoses are solitary erythematous, violaceous, or brown macules and plaques with variable scale, measuring 5–20 mm. They may be mistaken for basal cell carcinoma.

---

Lichen planus–like keratoses are common and affect middle-aged to elderly adults, with a female predilection.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is similar to that of seborrhoeic keratosis, from which a large proportion of these lesions arise; there is an age relationship, but the cause is otherwise unknown.

---

Like in seborrhoeic keratoses, mutations in FGFR3, PIK3CA, HRAS, and KRAS have been identified in a subset of lichen planus–like keratoses.
microscopic: Lichen planus–like keratoses are well-circumscribed intraepidermal keratinocytic proliferations with variable epidermal hyperplasia and overlying hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis. There is an associated superficial dermal band-like inflammatory infiltrate composed mainly of lymphocytes and histiocytes. There is interface change with vacuolar degeneration of basal cell layer keratinocytes. Apoptotic keratinocytes are present, and pigment incontinence may be seen in the superficial dermis. In severe examples there may be subepidermal clefting and bulla formation. Late-stage examples may show epidermal atrophy and superficial dermal fibrosis. A background of a solar lentigo or a seborrhoeic keratosis is sometimes recognizable.
differential_diagnosis: The most important differential diagnosis is with a regressed melanocytic lesion, especially regressed melanoma. Deeper levels and immunohistochemistry for SOX10 may be useful in the identification of a residual melanoma in situ component. Immunohistochemistry with melan-A or SOX10 may highlight clusters of small, cytologically benign melanocytes in lichen planus–like keratosis, often admixed with degenerated keratinocytes and macrophages. Benign cytology, a lack of pagetoid growth, and the presence of apoptotic keratinocytes can exclude melanoma in situ. The presence of tumoural melanosis is a further indication of a regressed melanoma. Lichenoid actinic keratosis is separated by the presence of squamous dysplasia. Lichenoid drug eruptions and lichen planus occur in a different clinical setting.
prognosis_and_prediction: Lichen planus–like keratoses are benign.
related_terminology: Acceptable: lichenoid keratosis; lichenoid benign keratosis.

media.legend: Lichen planus–like keratosis. There is epidermal hyperplasia and a band-like chronic inflammatory infiltrate in the superficial dermis.
Lichen planus–like keratosis. Note the vacuolar interface change, with numerous apoptotic keratinocytes and a superficial dermal chronic inflammatory infiltrate showing pigment incontinence.

Benign lichenoid keratosis. An extensive band-like lichenoid inflammation at the dermoepidermal junction with interface change is observed. Orthokeratosis with foci of parakeratosis, variable epidermal acanthosis, and civatte bodies are seen.

definition: The solar lentigines of solar lentigo are ultraviolet (UV) radiation–related benign intraepidermal keratinocytic proliferations, closely related to seborrhoeic keratoses.
clinical:
Patients with solar lentigines present with small and uniformly pigmented tan to brown macules, measuring a few millimetres in diameter. Darkly pigmented examples are also referred to as ink-spot lentigines.

---

Solar lentigines are markers of chronic UV radiation exposure. Their incidence increases with age, and onset is typically in middle-aged to elderly adults with fair skin.
pathogenesis:
Chronic UV radiation exposure is the main etiological factor.

---

Little is known about the pathogenesis of these keratinocytic proliferations. Like in seborrhoeic keratoses, mutations in the FGFR3 and PIK3CA genes have been detected in a number of cases. Solar lentigines appear to lack BRAF mutations.
microscopic: Solar lentigines are well-demarcated intraepidermal proliferations of bland basaloid keratinocytes, characterized by elongated rete ridges with hyperpigmentation of the basal cell layer and budding at the base. There may be fusion of rete ridges, overlying hyperkeratosis, and mildly increased numbers of junctional melanocytes. Solar lentigines typically arise on a background on solar elastosis. Ink-spot lentigines are small and sharply circumscribed, with intense melanin pigmentation of basal cell layer keratinocytes that is most prominent at the tips of the rete ridges. Solar lentigines may show some morphological overlap with seborrhoeic keratosis, and reliable separation is not always possible. Pigmented actinic keratoses are characterized by squamous dysplasia. Lentigo maligna is typically associated with loss of the rete ridge pattern and shows confluent growth of atypical melanocytes, best highlighted by immunohistochemistry for melan-A, SOX10, or MITF.
prognosis_and_prediction: Solar lentigines are benign.
related_terminology: Acceptable: actinic lentigo. Not recommended: senile lentigo.

media.legend: Solar lentigo. Elongated rete ridges with occasional fusion are characteristic of the solar lentigo.
Solar lentigo. Basal cell layer hyperpigmentation accentuated at the tips of the rete ridges is frequently seen in solar lentigines.

definition: Seborrhoeic keratoses are benign intraepithelial neoplastic squamous proliferations encountered on ageing skin.
clinical:
Seborrhoeic keratoses may be solitary or multiple and manifest as flat-based warty papules and plaques with tan to brown or black discolouration and a stuck-on appearance. Stucco keratoses are small and confined to the lower extremities. Dermoscopy reveals multiple brown or white clods, representing plugs of keratin, and thick ridges impart a cerebriform pattern. The abrupt onset of numerous keratoses has been referred to as the Leser–Trélat sign and may be an indicator of an underlying visceral malignancy.

---

Seborrhoeic keratoses are very common and show an increasing incidence with age, typically arising in middle-aged and elderly people. There is no significant sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
The development of seborrhoeic keratoses is related to the interplay between increasing age and sun exposure; an inflammatory milieu may also predispose to lesions.

---

Paradoxically, oncogenic mutations are noted, including somatic mutations in FGFR3, which may result in increased keratinocyte proliferation and reduced apoptosis. Other mutated genes include PIK3CA, KRAS, HRAS, EGFR, and AKT1, as well as TERT and DPH3 promoter mutations. The mechanism by which these mutations fail to lead to malignancy in seborrhoeic keratosis is unknown.
microscopic: Seborrhoeic keratoses are intraepidermal proliferations of basaloid keratinocytes. They are well circumscribed, with papillomatous outlines and a flat base. There is overlying hyperkeratosis, and tangential sectioning of the squamous invaginations gives rise to so-called horn cysts. The keratinocytes are small and bland-appearing, without cytological atypia or nuclear pleomorphism. Increased cytoplasmic melanin pigmentation may be seen. Different growth patterns and subtypes may be encountered. The acanthotic pattern is most commonly encountered and shows broad, regular columns of neoplastic keratinocytes, whereas the keratotic or papillomatous subtype shows a florid papillomatous architecture with abundant hyperkeratosis. The adenoid or reticulated pattern is composed of interconnecting elongated and delicate rete with small horn cyst formation. The clonal pattern is characterized by intraepidermal nests of neoplastic keratinocytes (Borst–Jadassohn pattern). The irritated subtype shows associated chronic inflammatory changes with areas of squamatization and squamous eddy formation. Tumours containing prominent intracytoplasmic melanin pigment are often also associated with pigment incontinence in the superficial dermis and are regarded as the pigmented subtype. Stucco keratosis shows papillomatosis and hyperkeratosis with a church-spire appearance.
differential_diagnosis: The most important differential diagnoses include actinic keratosis and squamous cell carcinoma in situ, which are characterized by squamous dysplasia not encountered in seborrhoeic keratoses. Squamatization and reactive atypia in the irritated subtype may be mistaken for squamous dysplasia. It is also important to understand that squamous dysplasia may arise in a background of a seborrhoeic keratosis. Verrucae can be separated by the presence of viral cytopathic change. The distinction between seborrhoeic keratosis and viral wart is often difficult. The presence of viral cytopathic change and dilated papillary dermal vessels favours the latter. HPV DNA is found in as many as 50% of seborrhoeic keratoses, especially in genital regions. Lesions with overlapping features may be termed verrucous keratosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Seborrhoeic keratoses are benign.
related_terminology: Not recommended: senile wart; seborrhoeic wart; basal cell papilloma.

media.legend: Seborrhoeic keratosis. Seborrhoeic keratoses are well-circumscribed with a papillomatous architecture and a flat base.
Seborrhoeic keratosis. Seborrhoeic keratoses are composed of bland polygonal basaloid cells without cytological atypia.
Acanthotic seborrhoeic keratosis. The acanthotic pattern is composed of broad columns of neoplastic keratinocytes with “horn cyst” formation.
Keratotic seborrhoeic keratosis. The keratotic pattern shows marked papillomatosis and hyperkeratosis.
Adenoid seborrhoeic keratosis. The adenoid pattern is characterized by interconnecting elongated rete ridges with horn cyst formation.
Clonal seborrhoeic keratosis. The clonal pattern shows intraepidermal nests of neoplastic keratinocytes giving rise to the Borst–Jadassohn pattern.
Irritated seborrhoeic keratosis. Hallmark features of the irritated subtype are areas of squamatization with squamous eddy formation.
Pigmented seborrhoeic keratosis. The pigmented pattern shows extensive cytoplasmic melanin pigmentation of the neoplastic keratinocytes.
Seborrhoeic keratosis. Broad sheets of small polygonal keratinocytes, which look monotonous throughout the lesion. Scattered horn cysts and pigment are seen.

definition: Verruca plana is an HPV-induced benign epidermal proliferation characterized by flat-topped cutaneous papules.
clinical:
Patients present with several smooth-surfaced, skin-coloured to light-brown papules. Associated koebnerization can occur. Redness or depigmentation is often indicative of regression. Dermoscopy has emerged as a useful diagnostic adjunct.

---

Verruca plana most commonly affects children. In adults, there is a predilection for women.
pathogenesis:
The most frequently implicated HPV types are HPV3, HPV5, HPV10, and HPV28. Epidermodysplasia verruciformis, an autosomal recessive genodermatosis with mutations in TMC6 (EVER1) or TMC8 (EVER2) confers susceptibility to causative HPV types. Immunosuppression is a risk factor. Multiple plane warts occupying > 5% of the body surface area are a potential harbinger of underlying HIV infection. In patients infected with HIV, a sudden eruption of lesions may herald the immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome.

---

See the Pathogenesis subsection of the section Verruca vulgaris section .
microscopic: There is orthokeratosis, mild acanthosis, and variable hypergranulosis, but only minimal papillomatosis. Scattered koilocytes (some with grey-blue cytoplasm) are present in the upper third of the epidermis. Owls-eye intranuclear inclusions may be found. Regression is associated with a superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate, lymphocytic exocytosis, and keratinocytic apoptosis. Epidermodysplasia verruciformis exhibits a spectrum of features, including orthokeratosis, an irregular granular layer, and enlarged keratinocytes with abundant bluish-grey, often vacuolated cytoplasm.
differential_diagnosis: Seborrhoeic keratoses tend to be more scattered, and apart from being histologically distinctive, they possess different dermoscopic and reflectance confocal microscopic features from plane warts.
prognosis_and_prediction: Some lesions show spontaneous regression, whereas others can be persistent or recurrent despite treatment. In one historical study of plane warts that had regressed, 64% were found to have done so spontaneously; the other 36% underwent regression following various forms of treatment.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Routine HPV subtyping is not indicated.
related_terminology: Acceptable: plane wart; flat wart.

media.legend: Verruca plana. The epidermis shows orthokeratosis, mild acanthosis, hypergranulosis, and a central aggregate of koilocytes.
Verruca plana. A cluster of flat-topped pinkish papules is present.
Verruca plana. The epidermis shows orthokeratosis, mild acanthosis, hypergranulosis, and a few aggregates of koilocytes.

definition: Verruca plantaris is an HPV-induced benign epidermal squamoproliferative lesion affecting the soles or palms.
clinical:
The lesions can be single or multiple, and they are often painful. The myrmecial form (associated with HPV1) presents as a hard, slightly elevated keratotic papule or nodule on the plantar or palmar surface. The more superficial mosaic form (associated with HPV4 and HPV2) exhibits confluent growth and is resistant to therapy. Black dots reflect intralesional vascular thrombosis. Dermoscopy is a useful diagnostic adjunct and tool for assessing response to treatment.

---

Children are affected more frequently than adults, with a reported prevalence of 1.8–20%.
pathogenesis:
HPV1, HPV2, and HPV4 usually predominate. HPV27 and HPV57 have been recorded in cases from Spain and California. HPV60 has been linked to plantar warts and epidermal cysts. Primary hyperhidrosis and visits to swimming pools and communal showers are risk factors. Patients with HIV may have larger and more numerous lesions.

---

See the Pathogenesis subsection of the section Verruca vulgaris section .
microscopic: The lesions are characterized by marked hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, hypergranulosis, and koilocytosis. Papillomatosis is usually mild. The myrmecial (ant-hill) form shows endophytic growth and vacuolated keratinocytes containing coarse eosinophilic keratohyalin granules. Regressing lesions exhibit haemorrhage, necrosis, thrombosis, and a mixed inflammatory infiltrate.
differential_diagnosis: Callosities occur on pressure points and are also endophytic and hyperkeratotic, but they lack koilocytes and coarse keratohyalin granules. Molluscum contagiosum also displays endophytic growth but has basophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions rather than heterogeneous eosinophilic keratohyalin granules.
prognosis_and_prediction: Verruca plantaris often regresses spontaneously. Lesions in children typically resolve more rapidly. Verrucous carcinoma is a very rare complication.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Routine HPV subtyping is not indicated.
related_terminology: Acceptable: plantar wart; palmoplantar wart; plantar verruca. Not recommended: myrmecia.

media.legend: Verruca plantaris. This myrmecial-type wart comprises a keratotic nodule on the sole of the foot and shows a surrounding blister.
Verruca plantaris. Partly endophytic and mildly papillomatous epidermal lesion, with marked hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.
Verruca plantaris. Coarse intracytoplasmic inclusion-like keratohyalin granules are present within the superficial keratinocytes.
Verruca plantaris. Papillomatous exophytic epidermal proliferation with compact hyperkeratosis and vertical columns of round parakeratosis ending with haemorrhagic crust above peaks.

definition: Verruca vulgaris is a common HPV-induced benign cutaneous squamoproliferative lesion.
clinical:
Lesions present as single or multiple verrucous, keratotic papules or nodules, 1–20 mm in diameter. Facial lesions may appear filiform. Occasional verrucae present as a cutaneous horn.

---

The reported prevalence rates are as high as 16% in children and 3.5% in adults. Immunosuppression is a risk factor. Verrucae have been reported to account for 10% of skin lesions in renal transplant recipients. Lesions may occur on tattoos, and on the scalp in a possible association with barber clippers.
pathogenesis:
Verruca vulgaris is caused by various subtypes of HPV. The main HPV types implicated are HPV1, HPV2, and HPV4. Others include HPV7, and HPV26–29. HPV75–77 have been detected in immunosuppressed patients. The genital HPV types HPV6 and HPV11 have rarely been detected in common warts among children. HPV16 (a genital type with oncogenic potential) was detected in 6.6% of non-genital warts in 45 immunocompetent patients. Verrucae sometimes occur on the vulva in children and adults.

---

HPV infects the suprabasal keratinocytes, the interappendageal epidermis, and the stem cells of the follicular bulge. HPV DNA synthesis takes place in the superficial prickle cell layer. Full virus assembly with capsid production occurs within the accentuated granular cell layer. Viral particles are released via desquamated cornified cells.
macroscopic: Excised lesions mirror the clinical appearances.
microscopic: The lesions feature hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and papillomatosis, with prominent, inwardly proliferating rete ridges. Columns of parakeratosis overlie foci of papillomatosis. There is hypergranulosis, with coarse keratohyalin granules. Koilocytes are often present in the superficial epidermis. Dilated, tortuous capillaries occupy the papillary dermis. A lichenoid inflammatory infiltrate is sometimes present and may correlate with regression.
differential_diagnosis: Verrucae should be distinguished from seborrhoeic keratoses, verrucous psoriasis, and epidermolytic acanthomas; this is particularly challenging when koilocytes are absent, which is more common in older warts. Occasionally, distinction from an inflamed seborrhoeic keratosis is not possible, leading to the use of terms such as verruciform keratosis or benign squamous papilloma. Keratoacanthoma shares architectural features with crateriform verruca.
prognosis_and_prediction: Spontaneous involution may occur, although it is less frequent in immunocompromised patients. In patients infected with HIV, antiretroviral therapy often expedites regression. Squamous dysplasia occasionally supervenes. Rare verrucae may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in the setting of immunosuppression.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Routine HPV subtyping is not indicated.
related_terminology: Acceptable: common viral wart.

media.legend: Verruca vulgaris. A keratotic nodule is present on the scalp.
Verruca vulgaris. The epidermal lesion shows hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, and inward proliferation of the rete ridges.
Verruca vulgaris. Higher-magnification view highlighting the hypergranulosis and koilocytosis.

Verruca vulgaris. Papillomatous exophytic epidermal proliferation. Orthokeratosis and marked acanthosis. Hypergranulosis and prominent keratohyalin-like granules of variable size within the granular layer. Compact hyperkeratosis with vertical columns of round parakeratosis. Infolding of elongated rete ridges towards base. Koilocytes are observed within or below the granular layer. Slight inflammation of the underlying papillary dermis.

entity_name: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease)
definition: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in situ, also known as Bowen disease, is SCC confined to the epidermis and superficial adnexal epithelium, further characterized by full-thickness involvement of the epidermis by dysplastic squamous cells.
clinical:
Patients with SCC in situ usually present with a solitary, slow-growing, scaly, erythematous patch or plaque, which can remain unchanged for many years. Clinical features include crusting, pigmentation, and a verrucous appearance. Dermoscopic features include scale, glomerular vessels, yellow crust, haemorrhage, hypopigmentation, and linear irregular vessels.

---

Most cases arise in the sun-exposed skin of elderly White patients with higher levels of cumulative sun exposure; the median age at presentation is > 60 years. Specific populations at higher risk of SCC in situ include organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive regimens and populations with long-term exposure to high levels of arsenic in drinking-water. Ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure from tanning beds has resulted in an increased number of young people presenting with SCC in situ, but the finding of SCC in situ in a young person with minimal sun damage should prompt consideration of arsenic exposure.
pathogenesis:
Most cases of SCC in situ (Bowen disease) are caused by UV radiation exposure, including UVB and UVA radiation exposure from sunlight or tanning beds. Radiotherapy and photochemotherapy are also etiological. High-risk (alpha genus) HPV infection is the major cause of SCC in situ involving the periungual region and genital skin (see the relevant volumes of the WHO classification). Beta genus papillomaviruses may have synergistic effects with UV radiation in the setting of immunosuppression due to organ transplant or HIV infection in causing some cutaneous SCCs in situ. Arsenic ingestion can play a role in SCC in situ in non–sun-exposed skin (see section Arsenical keratosis).

---

The pathway from actinic keratosis to SCC is characterized by a progressive accumulation of UV radiation signature mutations. Targeted deep sequencing of SCC in situ shows TP53 mutations as an early step in carcinogenesis. Alterations in TP53 or NOTCH1 mutations are found in 94% of SCCs in situ. Progression to invasive SCC is associated with immune dysregulation and with increases in FOXP3-expressing lymphocytes, Langerhans cells, and PDL1 expression.
microscopic: SCC in situ is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia, involvement of superficial skin adnexal epithelium, and no invasion of the underlying dermis. The stratum corneum is usually hyperparakeratotic, but may demonstrate orthokeratosis. Epidermal thickness is variable, but acanthosis is common. Atypical squamous cells (which are enlarged and pleomorphic and demonstrate hyperchromatic nuclei) replace the full thickness of the epidermis, often showing a loss of polarity. Mitotic figures are increased in number and typically extend to the epidermal surface. The granular layer is frequently absent. The basal layer may be retained (eyeliner sign). Occasional cases demonstrate single or nested atypical squamous cells dispersed throughout the full thickness of the epidermis, imparting a pagetoid appearance. In some cases, cytological atypia is more subtle, and demonstration of full-thickness epidermal staining with Ki-67 is helpful for confirming the diagnosis of SCC in situ. Immunohistochemistry for p16 may be similarly helpful in assessing the degree of dysplasia in genital lesions.
differential_diagnosis: SCC in situ with a pagetoid growth pattern must be distinguished (often requiring immunohistochemistry) from mammary and extramammary Paget disease, melanoma in situ, and less common benign simulants such as clonal seborrhoeic keratosis and hidroacanthoma simplex. Actinic keratosis is distinguished from SCC in situ by the lack of full-thickness epidermal dysplasia. Whereas SCC in situ shows confluent parakeratosis, in actinic keratoses the dysplasia spares the epithelium of adnexal structures, correlating with a flag sign of alternating orthokeratosis and parakeratosis. Microinvasive SCC may be difficult to distinguish from SCC in situ, especially when lichenoid inflammation is present, but careful examination of the dermoepidermal junction in SCC reveals jagged, often keratinizing dermal invasive foci.
prognosis_and_prediction: Approximately 3–5% of all SCC in situ lesions progress to invasive SCC.
related_terminology: Acceptable: intraepidermal carcinoma; Bowenoid papulosis. Not recommended: keratinocytic intraepidermal neoplasia (KIN III); erythroplasia of Queyrat.

media.legend: Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). There is full-thickness epidermal dysplasia associated with acanthosis and parakeratotic hyperkeratosis.

Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). Full-thickness epidermal dysplasia is present; the superficial dermis shows severe solar elastosis and a patchy lymphocytic inflammatory cell infiltrate, but there is no dermal invasion.
Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). Full-thickness epidermal dysplasia is present.
Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). Bowen disease on chronically sun-damaged skin in the form of a red, scaly patch.
Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). The corresponding dermoscopy of Bowen disease shown in <<37241>> is characterized by glomerular (coiled) vessels, scales, and a small erosion.

Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). Low-power view of the dermatopathology of the case of Bowen disease shown in <<37241>> and <<37242>>, with acanthosis of the epidermis, hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis, full-thickness dysplasia, and a lymphocytic infiltrate (see <<37244>>).

Squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease). High-power view of the dermatopathology of the case of Bowen disease shown in <<37241>> and <<37242>>, with acanthosis of the epidermis, hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis, full-thickness dysplasia, and a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Bowen disease. Full-thickness atypia of epidermis is seen. Atypical cells involve / encroach upon adnexal epithelium (unlike in bowenoid actinic keratosis). Increased mitotic figures with atypical forms are observed, as well as hyperkeratosis with confluent parakeratosis.

definition: PUVA keratosis is a hyperkeratotic cutaneous lesion developing on sun-protected skin following prolonged psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) treatment.
clinical:
Patients with PUVA keratoses present with multiple warty, hyperkeratotic, and scaly papules with a broad base, measuring from a few millimetres to 10 mm.

---

The affected individuals are those receiving PUVA treatment for underlying skin conditions (e.g. psoriasis).
pathogenesis:
This type of keratosis arises in association with prolonged medical use of PUVA treatment for skin conditions. The effect is dose-dependent.

---

Frequent TP53 (57%) and HRAS (44%) mutations of the ultraviolet (UV) radiation signature type point to UV radiation exposure as the main etiological factor in these lesions.
microscopic: PUVA keratoses are well demarcated and characterized by acanthosis and overlying hyperkeratosis. A papillomatous growth and focal parakeratosis may be present. Mild keratinocyte dysplasia is noted in approximately 50% of biopsies. An additional finding is the presence of a superficial dermal chronic inflammatory infiltrate.
prognosis_and_prediction: There is an increased risk of the development of non-melanoma skin cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma and less often basal cell carcinoma, years after prolonged PUVA treatment in patients with PUVA keratosis.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: PUVA keratosis. Hyperkeratosis with scattered parakeratosis. Note the effacement of the epidermal rete ridges, with atypia of the basal layer cells.

PUVA keratosis. Prominent atypia of the basal layer, with variably sized nuclei and focal squamatization. The squamous cells show dysmaturation with a variable increase in size and pallor; the granular cell layer is retained.
PUVA keratosis. Clinical appearance.
PUVA keratosis. Clinical appearance, close-up view.

definition: Arsenical keratoses present as multiple hyperkeratotic lesions with a predilection for the hands and feet, following chronic exposure to arsenic.
clinical:
Patients present with diffuse or localized hyperpigmentation and raindrop pigmentation affecting mainly the trunk, as well as yellowish hyperkeratotic papules and confluent verrucous plaques with a predilection for palmoplantar skin, measuring 2–10 mm and developing with a latency of decades after arsenic exposure.

---

The incidence in high-income countries is very low; the disease occurs predominantly in poorer nations, due to contamination of the groundwater.
pathogenesis:
The main reasons for chronic arsenic exposure include environmental, medicinal, and occupational exposure.

---

Chronic arsenic exposure promotes oxidative stress, which leads to antioxidant depletion, immune dysfunction, genotoxicity, impaired DNA repair, and disrupted signal transduction. A pathogenetic role of HPV has also been postulated.
microscopic: Arsenical keratoses show a spectrum of morphology ranging from acanthosis, papillomatosis, and hyperkeratosis to squamous dysplasia, often with the dysplastic keratinocytes showing vacuolization, multinucleated forms, and atypical mitotic activity. The squamous dysplasia does not affect the full-thickness epidermis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Arsenical keratoses continue to grow with time and may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, with potential for metastatic disease.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Arsenical keratosis. Almost full-thickness atypia of the epidermis, with dysregulated granular cell layer. Note the marked vacuolization of the cells, which is a helpful (although not diagnostic) feature.
Arsenical keratosis. Marked hyperkeratosis with a hyperplastic, highly dysregulated epidermis; there is slight papillomatosis.

Arsenical keratosis. Biopsy of the sole reveals basaloid hyperplasia with marked atypia, budding downward into the inflamed dermis. The lichenoid infiltrate is associated with apoptosis and clustered dyskeratosis of cells. Note that the overlying squamous cells are hyperplastic but without marked atypia.

definition: Actinic keratoses (AKs) are very common neoplastic intraepidermal squamous proliferative lesions associated with ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure and characterized by squamous dysplasia. AKs may remain stable, regress spontaneously, or progress to invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
clinical:
A presentation as scaly erythematous patches and plaques measuring 2–10 mm on a background of sun-damaged skin is typical. The lesions are frequently multiple and may coalesce.

---

AKs are very common. There is an increasing incidence with age, and a predilection for fair-skinned individuals residing in areas of high UV radiation exposure.
pathogenesis:
Cumulative exposure to UVB light and chronic immunosuppression are the main risk factors for the development of AKs. Male sex, lighter hair and eye colours, and baldness are also risk factors.

---

Similar to SCC, AKs show a UV radiation signature, high mutation burden, and somatic copy-number alterations. Frequently mutated genes include TP53, CDKN2A, CDKN2B, NOTCH1, NOTCH2, and FAT1.
microscopic: AKs are characterized by squamous dysplasia affecting the basal to mid-spinous layer keratinocytes. The dysplastic keratinocytes show enlarged and irregular hyperchromatic or vesicular nuclei. Mitotic figures, including atypical forms, are common. The granular cell layer is typically absent and there is overlying parakeratosis. The acrosyringeal units and follicular ostia are spared, but dysplastic keratinocytes may extend along pre-existing adnexal structures. By definition, squamous dysplasia does not affect the full-thickness epidermis. The superficial dermis shows evidence of solar elastosis, and a chronic inflammatory infiltrate is often present. The lichenoid subtype is characterized by a dense, band-like chronic inflammatory infiltrate with vacuolar change affecting basal cell layer keratinocytes. While the epidermis is typically thinned and flattened, epidermal hyperplasia with marked parakeratosis and lichen simplex chronicus–like changes are seen in the hypertrophic subtype. Budding of dysplastic epidermis is noted in the proliferative subtype, while pronounced epidermal atrophy is seen in the atrophic pattern. Occasionally, acantholysis of the dysplastic keratinocytes (acantholytic AK) is seen, and there may be increased melanin pigmentation of the dysplastic basal cell layer keratinocytes (pigmented AK). In the pigmented subtype, the overlying parakeratosis may be absent. AKs may develop in a background of solar lentigines or seborrhoeic keratoses. Bowenoid AK has been described as AK with full-thickness squamous atypia and an increased risk for progression to SCC; as such, it is best considered to represent SCC in situ.
prognosis_and_prediction: AKs may remain stable, regress, or progress to invasive SCC. Although 65% of all primary SCCs were found to arise in a background of AK, the risk of progression was estimated at only 0.6% after 1 year and 2.57% at 4 years; 55% of clinically detected AKs had regressed after 1 year of follow-up, and 70% after 5 years.
related_terminology: Acceptable: solar keratosis. Not recommended: keratinocytic intraepidermal neoplasia; bowenoid solar keratosis; bowenoid actinic keratosis; senile keratosis.
subtypes: Proliferative actinic keratosis; hypertrophic actinic keratosis; lichenoid actinic keratosis; pigmented actinic keratosis

media.legend: Actinic keratosis. Squamous dysplasia affecting the lower and middle epidermal layers with overlying parakeratosis on a background of sun-damaged skin.
Actinic keratosis. Higher-power magnification highlighting the non–full-thickness squamous dysplasia and overlying parakeratosis.
Hypertrophic actinic keratosis. The hypertrophic subtype is characterized by verrucoid epidermal hyperplasia with massive overlying parakeratosis.
Proliferative actinic keratosis. The proliferative subtype shows prominent buds of dysplastic epidermis protruding into superficial dermis.
Actinic keratosis, acantholytic pattern. Acantholysis is a commonly seen feature in actinic keratoses.
Pigmented actinic keratosis. The pigmented subtype is characterized by cytoplasmic melanin pigmentation of the basal cell layer dysplastic keratinocytes.
Pigmented actinic keratosis. Melan-A immunohistochemistry highlights increased numbers of single junctional melanocytes, but there is no confluent growth of melanocytes excluding lentigo maligna.
Actinic keratosis. Clinical appearance of scaly erythematous patches on the face.
Actinic keratosis. Variable keratinocytic atypia in lower layers of epidermis with overlying focal parakeratosis is observed.

definition: Metastatic melanoma in the skin is melanoma that has spread from a primary melanoma (cutaneous or extracutaneous) to the skin.
clinical:
Metastatic melanoma manifests as one or several pigmented or amelanotic nodules or plaques, sometimes in a zosteriform or erysipelas-like formation. Metastases within a 20 mm radius of a primary melanoma are termed satellite metastases, and those farther away but between the regional lymph node basin are called in-transit metastases. Metastatic disease may occur without prior history of melanoma.

---

The epidemiology is similar to that of the respective primary melanoma.
pathogenesis:
The risk of metastatic disease increases with thickness of the primary.

---

Cutaneous melanoma metastasis develops from lymphatic, haematogenous, or perineural spread of the primary lesion, resulting in local, regional, or distant metastases. In addition, melanoma can spread without entering and exiting the circulation, by engaging in angiotropic extravascular migratory metastasis.
microscopic: There is a well-circumscribed nodule in the dermis and/or subcutis, with sheets of atypical melanocytes with mitoses. Epidermal involvement (epidermotropism) is seen in as many as 5% of cases and can simulate a primary melanoma, and it is usually narrower than the underlying nodule. Tumour cells are present within adjacent vessels in 5% of cases. Clinicopathological correlation is essential to correctly identify metastatic melanoma. A history of multiple lesions developing in the same locoregional distribution as the primary melanoma is suggestive. Microsatellitosis is a histologically defined pattern of cutaneous metastasis characterized by microscopic foci of metastatic tumour, often angiotropic, in the skin or subcutis, clearly discontinuous from the primary tumour.
ancillary_studies: Neoplastic melanocytes express melanocytic markers, including melan-A, SOX10, HMB45, and S100. If the primary melanoma was PRAME-positive, the metastasis usually is too. Dedifferentiated metastatic melanomas may lose melanocytic markers and aberrantly express cytokeratin and/or muscle markers.
differential_diagnosis: The histological differential diagnosis of metastatic melanoma in the skin includes primary melanoma, primary dermal melanoma, and atypical naevus. Blue naevus–like metastases are difficult to distinguish from common or epithelioid blue naevus. The presence of cytologically atypical epithelioid melanocytes and mitotic figures can mimic blue naevus–like melanoma.
staging: Staging is performed according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM criteria. The presence of microsatellite, satellite, or in-transit (non-nodal regional) metastases is associated with a worse prognosis and represents an N-category criterion and stage III disease. Cases with distant cutaneous metastases are categorized as M1 and stage IV disease.
prognosis_and_prediction: See section Melanoma metastatic to other organs .
cytology: FNA is uncommonly used in the skin. The cytological features are similar to those of metastases in other sites.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Driver mutations can be helpful in making conclusions about the primary tumour and its localization, if not known. For example, metastases arising from acral or mucosal melanoma have distinctive copy-number changes, whereas GNAQ/GNA11 mutations are typically drivers in melanoma arising in blue naevus or uveal melanoma.
related_terminology: None

Melanoma metastatic to the skin. Multiple new lesions on the leg of a patient with a previous history of melanoma. Lesions are pigmented, some of them elevated.

Melanoma metastatic to the skin. A well-circumscribed multinodular lesion in the dermis surrounded by stromal fibrosis. Tumour cells are epithelioid with a high level of atypia. There is absence of a junctional component and a very mild inflammatory infiltrate.

definition: Dermal melanoma is a primary melanoma limited to the dermis and subcutis, without intraepidermal involvement, regression, or ulceration.
clinical:
Dermal melanoma manifests as a solitary firm nodule of variable size, most often < 10 mm, with variable colour, ranging from flesh-coloured to red to blue.

---

Dermal melanomas are rare tumours, accounting for < 1% of all melanomas.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The pathogenesis is not fully understood. Dermal melanomas with BRAF and NRAS driver mutations have a similar oncogenic progression to that of other melanomas with these anomalies.
microscopic: Dermal melanoma is a circumscribed dermal, or dermal to subcutaneous nodule composed of atypical melanocytes. Tumours may display areas of necrosis and haemorrhage. Cytomorphology may be epithelioid, spindled, rhabdoid, or pleomorphic, and mitoses are common. By definition, ulceration or significant regression, having possibly obliterated an intraepidermal component, should not be present. A precursor naevus excludes this diagnosis.
ancillary_studies: Neoplastic melanocytes express melanocytic markers, including melan-A, SOX10, HMB45, and S100.
differential_diagnosis: Metastatic melanoma is typically associated with a history of melanoma, clinically suspected melanoma elsewhere, or multiple lesions of rapid growth. Local recurrence of melanoma typically shows an adjacent scar. A regressed intraepidermal component of a conventional melanoma is indicated by papillary dermal fibrosis, often with melanophages.
staging: Dermal melanoma is staged according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM criteria like other cutaneous melanomas.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis is better than for metastatic melanoma and better than for other melanomas of similar thickness. However, locoregional recurrences, distant metastases, and deaths have been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Mutations in GNAQ or GNA11 suggest melanoma arising in blue naevus. Fusions in relevant genes suggest mesenchymal tumours such as cutaneous clear cell sarcoma or a cutaneous tumour with CRTC1::TRIM11 rearrangement.
related_terminology: None

definition: Naevoid melanoma is a primary melanoma that resembles the architectural and cytological features of a common intradermal or compound melanocytic naevus.
clinical:
Patients with naevoid melanoma present with a papule or nodule, with varying or no pigmentation, that can resemble an intradermal or other benign naevus. The presence of atypical vascular structures and irregular globules/dots dermoscopically is a diagnostic clue.

---

Naevoid melanomas represent < 0.5% of melanomas and can occur throughout life, with no sex predominance.
pathogenesis:
The etiology appears to be similar to that of other melanomas, both those in skin with a high degree of cumulative sun damage (CSD) and those in low-CSD skin.

---

There is no evidence that naevoid melanoma represents a distinct molecular type, and mutations in BRAF or NRAS are common.
microscopic: Several patterns have been described. They mimic, on scanning magnification, a benign papillomatous or intradermal naevus. The neoplastic melanocytes are small to intermediate in size, with less atypia, and can show maturation with descent into the reticular dermis. Mitoses are usually present and are the main diagnostic clue.
ancillary_studies: The immunohistochemistry is similar to that of low-CSD melanoma.
differential_diagnosis: The main differential diagnoses are common or dysplastic naevi. Atypical architectural and cytological features can be seen as a reactive phenomenon in the intraepidermal component of polypoid compound melanocytic naevi. Increased mitoses can be seen in naevi during pregnancy. Sclerosing naevi with pseudomelanomatous features can be difficult to distinguish on morphological grounds alone. Immunohistochemistry for p16, Ki-67, and PRAME can be helpful. Melanoma metastases may also have a naevoid appearance.
staging: Naevoid melanoma is staged according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM criteria like other cutaneous melanomas.
prognosis_and_prediction: It has been suggested that naevoid melanoma may be less aggressive than other melanomas, but this has not been firmly established. Childhood naevoid melanoma composed of small cells with a predilection for the scalp may have a poor prognosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The diagnostic molecular pathology is similar to that of low-CSD melanoma.
related_terminology: Not recommended: minimal deviation melanoma.

Naevoid melanoma. Haematoxylin eosin saffron stain. Papillomatous pattern. The melanocytes are atypical, with crowded, sometimes hyperchromatic nuclei and enlarged nucleoli. Mitoses are seen.

Naevoid melanoma. Haematoxylin eosin saffron stain. Papillomatous pattern. “Puffy-shirt” silhouette lesion characterized by elongated thin rete ridges separating the melanocytic component into compartments. The melanocytes are atypical, with crowded, sometimes hyperchromatic nuclei.

definition: Nodular melanomas are primary melanomas in vertical growth phase (VGP) that lack an appreciable radial growth phase (RGP).
clinical:
Nodular melanomas manifest as pigmented or unpigmented nodules. They often grow rapidly, can ulcerate and bleed, and can be mistaken for vascular or other neoplasms.

---

Nodular melanoma may not be a distinct entity but rather a manifestation of an accelerated progression of melanomas of multiple pathogenetic pathways (see #33781Table 3.05, in section Genomic landscape of melanoma), including melanomas in skin with a low or high degree of cumulative sun damage (low- and high-CSD melanomas), acral melanoma, and mucosal melanoma. Their epidemiology is therefore similar to that of melanomas in these pathways. An increased incidence in older men has been described.
pathogenesis:
Nodular melanomas have etiological factors similar to those of the melanomas in the respective pathway (see #33781Table 3.05, in section Genomic landscape of melanoma). Ultraviolet (UV) radiation–mediated mutagenesis is the major etiological factor in tumours on sun-exposed skin.

---

The concept of nodular melanomas propounds that these tumours progress to the VGP without an appreciable RGP; however, it is possible that any antecedent RGP could have been replaced or obliterated by the expanding nodule of VGP. A possible explanation is that nodular melanomas acquire the necessary genetic alterations in rapid succession or in altered sequential order, so that the barriers that prevent partially transformed tumours from developing a VGP are overrun before the proliferation-inducing alterations are acquired. No specific genetic alterations, patterns of oncogenic mutations, or DNA copy-number changes distinguishing nodular melanomas from melanomas with an adjacent RGP of the same pathogenetic pathway (see #33781Table 3.05, in section Genomic landscape of melanoma) have been identified. The genetic landscapes of melanomas in these pathways are discussed in other sections of this volume.
microscopic: Nodular melanoma may arise de novo or from a pre-existing naevus. Histologically, nodular melanomas appear as cohesive aggregates of often epithelioid or spindled neoplastic melanocytes in the dermis. Any overlying epidermal involvement is by definition coterminous with the dermal component, and the flanking skin does not show regression, as evidenced by a zone of fibrosis with pigment-containing macrophages and free melanin. An epidermal collarette often flanks the nodule.
ancillary_studies: Markers of melanocytic lineage, such as melan-A, HMB45, tyrosinase, MITF, and SOX10, are typically expressed, as well as S100.
differential_diagnosis: Unpigmented tumours must be distinguished from squamous cell carcinomas, appendageal tumours, sarcomas, and cutaneous lymphomas by immunohistochemistry. Melanoma metastases tend to have more mitoses or intravascular deposits of neoplastic melanocytes at the base.
staging: Nodular melanoma is staged according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM criteria like other cutaneous melanomas.
prognosis_and_prediction: Standard prognosticators, in particular ulceration, tumour thickness, Clark level of invasion, and mitotic count, have the same value as in other melanomas (see section Melanocytic neoplasms: Introduction).
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The diagnostic molecular pathology considerations are similar to those of the primary categories of low- and high-CSD, acral, and mucosal melanomas. To differentiate primary melanomas from cutaneous metastases, molecular analyses can help assess the clonal relationship to any other melanomas of the patient.
related_terminology: Acceptable: rapidly growing melanoma (subset); primary melanoma without a radial growth phase.

entity_name: Diffuse meningeal melanocytic neoplasms: Melanocytosis and melanomatosis
definition: Meningeal melanocytosis is a diffuse or multifocal meningeal proliferation of cytologically bland melanocytes. Meningeal melanomatosis is a diffuse or multifocal meningeal proliferation of melanoma cells arising from leptomeningeal melanocytes and often shows CNS invasion.
clinical:
Neurological symptoms arise secondarily to either hydrocephalus or local effects on the CNS parenchyma. Once malignant transformation occurs, symptoms progress rapidly. Diffuse meningeal melanocytic tumours frequently occur in the setting of neurocutaneous melanosis. About 10–15% of patients with large congenital melanocytic naevi of the skin develop clinical symptoms related to meningeal melanocytosis, and radiological evidence of CNS involvement has been reported in as many as 23% of asymptomatic children with giant congenital naevi. The incidence of neurological involvement, melanoma, and death is significantly associated with the projected adult size of the largest congenital melanocytic naevus and presence of satellite lesions. CT and MRI of meningeal melanocytosis and melanomatosis typically show diffuse thickening and enhancement of the leptomeninges, often with focal or multifocal nodularity. Depending on melanin content, they may have an isodense or hyperintense signal on T1-weighted images and a hypointense signal on T2-weighted images.

---

The incidence of neurocutaneous melanosis is reported as 0.5–2 cases per 100 000 person-years. Melanocytosis mainly affects children, mostly in the context of neurocutaneous melanosis. Melanomatosis has a bimodal age distribution and may manifest in children with or without neurocutaneous melanosis, as well as in adults (mostly in the fourth decade of life).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Neurocutaneous melanosis derives from melanocyte precursor cells that reach the CNS after acquiring postzygotic somatic mutations, mostly activating mutations of NRAS (chromosome 1p13) as a first hit in a multistep process. Amplification of mutated NRAS has also been described in an aggressive form of neurocutaneous melanosis. BRAF mutations occur in a minority of cases. Copy-number variations overlap with those in cutaneous melanoma, even in the absence of malignant features at the histopathological level.
macroscopic: Dense black or dusky clouding of the subarachnoid space of the meninges is observed.
microscopic: The tumour cells may assume a variety of shapes, including spindled, round, oval, and cuboidal. In meningeal melanocytosis, individual cells are cytologically bland and accumulate within the subarachnoid and Virchow–Robin spaces. Lesions that show unequivocal invasion of the CNS parenchyma or that have cytological atypia, mitotic activity, or necrosis warrant a diagnosis of meningeal melanomatosis.
ancillary_studies: The tumour cells typically express S100, HMB45, melan-A, and SOX10.
differential_diagnosis: Distinction from metastasis of cutaneous melanoma may be impossible using microscopy alone without clinical correlation and additional molecular testing.
prognosis_and_prediction: Melanocytosis may remain asymptomatic for a variable period of time, but once symptoms develop the prognosis is usually poor. Melanomatosis is usually a very aggressive disease with a dismal prognosis. Distinction of a primary tumour from a metastasis of an extradural (usually cutaneous) melanoma is critical for prognostication and therapy.
cytology: Cytology may reveal atypical, often pigmented cells that often have epithelioid features but immunocytochemically express melanocytic markers.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: See the Diagnostic molecular pathology subsection in section Circumscribed meningeal melanocytic neoplasms: Melanocytoma and melanoma . In children, meningeal melanocytosis and meningeal melanomatosis are often associated with somatic mutations in NRAS.
related_terminology: None

Meningeal melanomatosis. A subpopulation of melanoma cells are heavily pigmented.

Melanoma arising from meningeal melanocytosis. The meningeal melanoma infiltrates the brain, spreading along the small vessels (angiotropism).

definition: Uveal melanocytoma is a subtype of uveal melanocytic naevus, comprising plump polygonal cells with dense intracytoplasmic melanin.
clinical:
Patients typically present with an asymptomatic discoid or dome-shaped dark-grey to black mass that elevates the retina, that can have a mossy or irregular surface that may cause iris heterochromia. Both ciliary body and iris melanocytomas can cause glaucoma. In a few cases, overlying orange pigment and subretinal fluid might be seen, which makes the distinction from a choroidal melanoma or other deeply pigmented choroidal naevi difficult. Imaging techniques of value include high-frequency anterior segment ultrasound biomicroscopy, ultrasound biomicroscopy, and B-scan ultrasonography. In uncertain cases, FNAB may be required.

---

Uveal melanocytomas are rare. The age at presentation ranges from infancy to 90 years. The distribution between the sexes and different ethnic groups is nearly equal.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Uveal melanocytomas harbour GNAQ mutations at exon 5, GNAQ p.Q209L, with no other aberrations detected.
macroscopic: On gross examination, melanocytomas appear dark brown to jet back and generally measure 1–5 mm in thickness.
microscopic: Melanocytomas are composed of large polygonal pigmented melanocytes. Bleaching is usually required to adequately evaluate the tumour cells, which show a low N:C ratio and oval to round bland nuclei with inconspicuous nucleoli. Although necrosis can occur in large tumours, mitoses are frequently absent.
ancillary_studies: Melanocytomas are positive for melan-A, HMB45, SOX10, MITF, and S100. Nuclear BAP1 immunoreactivity is retained. The Ki-67 growth fraction is very low or absent (0–2%).
differential_diagnosis: The major differential diagnoses include uveal naevi and melanoma. Although uncommon, adenomas of the pigment epithelium of the ciliary body, iris, and/or retinal pigment epithelium should also be considered.
prognosis_and_prediction: Instances of malignant transformation to melanoma are rare.
cytology: Uveal melanocytoma has large, ovoid cells with small, centrally located nuclei and pigmented cytoplasm.
related_terminology: Acceptable: magnocellular naevus of the uvea.
