definition: Conjunctival melanoma is an invasive malignant melanocytic neoplasm arising in the conjunctiva.
clinical:
Conjunctival melanomas vary in appearance, coloration, and size. Some lesions are amelanotic (pale or pink). Characteristics that favour a melanoma over a conjunctival naevus include tumour haemorrhage, large tumour base, tortuous feeder vessels, adherence to sclera, corneal invasion, multifocal lesions, and a lack of cysts.

---

Conjunctival melanoma accounts for 5% of ocular melanomas. The incidence is rising and is estimated at 0.3–0.8 cases per 1 million person-years. Conjunctival melanoma is most common in older individuals (in the sixth or seventh decade of life) with northern European ancestry, and less common in Asian and Black populations. There is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
The increased occurrence in sun-exposed areas and the genetic profile of conjunctival melanoma suggest that ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure and cumulative sun damage (CSD) may play a role.

---

Most invasive melanomas (60–70%) have adjacent conjunctival melanocytic intraepithelial lesions. The remaining tumours arise de novo or from a naevus. Conjunctival melanomas are genetically diverse. Most show a high mutation burden. BRAF, NRAS, or NF1 mutations are present in most. TERT mutations are frequent. Other genes associated with conjunctival melanoma progression include CTNNB1, ACSS3, RET, TP53, KIT, TET2, CDKN2A, MAP2K1, RAC1, MET, and SF3B1. Most tumours show copy-number changes involving multiple chromosomes.
microscopic: The histological features are similar to those of invasive melanoma in the skin or mucosa. The intraepithelial component can be nested, pagetoid, lentiginous, or (rarely) absent. It can extend well beyond the invasive component and can involve the skin and/or minor lacrimal glands and invade the cornea. The subepithelial component shows stromal invasion by nests or sheets of atypical melanocytes. Melanoma cells can show the entire spectrum of cytomorphology encountered in melanoma elsewhere, ranging from small naevoid cells to highly atypical pleomorphic melanocytes with spindle or epithelioid cytomorphology. Nuclei can be hyperchromatic with inconspicuous nucleoli or vesicular with prominent nucleoli. Ulceration, mitotic activity, angiotropism, satellite metastases, in-transit metastases, and neurotropism may be seen. A residual naevus may be present.
ancillary_studies: Conjunctival melanoma expresses melanocytic markers such as S100, SOX10, melan-A, MITF, and HMB45. Nuclear expression of PRAME and loss of p16 on immunohistochemistry are more common in conjunctival melanoma than in naevi.
staging: The Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM tumour staging applies.
prognosis_and_prediction: The 10-year disease-specific mortality rate is 25–35%. The 5-year local recurrence rate is 29–45%. Unfavourable prognostic indicators include location on the palpebral conjunctiva, multiple tumours, tumour size > 2 mm, epithelioid cytology, ulceration, mitoses, lymphatic invasion, angiotropic satellite or in-transit metastases, and sentinel lymph node positivity.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: FISH, cytogenetics, and sequencing can be used to identify genetic aberrations consistent with melanoma. GNAQ or GNA11 mutations are indicative of blue naevus–like or uveal melanomas rather than conjunctival melanoma.
related_terminology: None

definition: Conjunctival naevi are benign melanocytic neoplasms of the conjunctival epithelium and its invaginations, the epithelial–subepithelial junction and stroma, or the stroma alone.
clinical:
Conjunctival naevi are well-defined, variably pigmented (usually tan to brown) or amelanotic, mobile macules, papules, or plaques. Compound naevi often show multiple small epithelial inclusion microcysts by slit-lamp examination.

---

Junctional, compound, and subepithelial melanocytic naevi account for 3–6%, 70–78%, and 15–24% of biopsied conjunctival naevi, respectively. Junctional melanocytic naevi have an M:F ratio of 2:1 and occur in childhood or adolescence. Compound and subepithelial melanocytic naevi are diagnosed at a median patient age of 22 years (range: 5–74 years) and 46 years (range: 12–87 years), respectively. Compound and subepithelial melanocytic naevi have an M:F ratio of 1:1 and are more common in White populations.
pathogenesis:
The prevalence of naevi in various populations depends on phenotypic factors (in particular sun susceptibility), sun exposure patterns, and genetic susceptibility. Conventional conjunctival naevi are acquired melanocytic naevi that arise from neural crest–derived melanocytes through somatic mutations.

---

Like other melanocytic naevi, conjunctival naevi are clonal proliferations caused by oncogenic mutation. Most conjunctival naevi have either BRAF or NRAS mutations. Conjunctival naevi with NRAS mutations appear to be larger and occur at a younger age than those with BRAF mutations.
microscopic: Like common acquired naevi of the skin, the three main histological types of melanocytic naevi are junctional, compound, and subepithelial. Junctional melanocytic naevi exhibit an intraepithelial proliferation of round to oval epithelioid cells and/or oval to cuboidal, intermediate, or lymphocyte-like naevus cells. The nucleoli are usually basophilic without atypia. Mitotic figures are rare. The naevus cells can be arranged as a lentiginous proliferation or as individual, confluent, or irregular nests, without pagetoid spread. Compound melanocytic naevi contain naevus cells within the epithelium and the substantia propria, exhibiting maturation with depth. Solid and cystic surface epithelial invaginations of conjunctival epithelium (with goblet cells) are common. Mitotic activity, if present, appears in the superficial layer. Subepithelial melanocytic naevi arise in the substantia propria, with melanocytes arranged as nests. Subepithelial naevi are more likely to be amelanotic or minimally pigmented. The superficial naevus cells tend to be larger and more polygonal, whereas the deep naevus cells may display neuroid differentiation. Sporadic pleomorphism can be seen. Mitotic figures are generally absent. Solid and cystic conjunctival epithelial invaginations are seen in about half of the cases. Uncommonly, junctional and compound naevi may show disordered architectural alterations intermediate between those of conventional naevi and melanoma, such as increased diameter > 5 mm, peripheral extension of the junctional component, asymmetry, poor circumscription, irregular and confluent junctional nesting, and focal pagetoid spread. Aberrant alterations in the subepithelial component may include diminished or even reversed maturation, nodule formation, and occasional mitotic activity. On occasion, naevi may be inflamed with prominent lymphocytic infiltrates, resembling halo naevi in the skin.
ancillary_studies: Most conjunctival naevi are positive for HMB45 in the superficial areas only, with homogeneous deeper staining for melan-A, SOX10, and MITF. They are usually negative for cyclin D1 and PRAME, whereas most conjunctival melanomas are positive for these markers.
differential_diagnosis: For junctional melanocytic naevi, the main differential is the conjunctival melanocytic intraepithelial lesion (see section Conjunctival melanocytic intraepithelial lesions). Junctional melanocytic lesions in an adult should be assumed to be conjunctival melanocytic intraepithelial lesions until proved otherwise. Conjunctival melanoma usually exhibits a larger size, aberrant architecture such as confluent and hypercellular nesting, cytological atypia, and greater mitotic activity. Melanoma cells are larger than naevus cells and show conspicuous nuclear atypia. Adjoining melanoma in situ may be present. Extraocular extension of a uveal melanoma will show widespread broad involvement of the biopsy base by melanoma cells with characteristic cytology and genetics (see the section on choroidal and ciliary body melanomas in the Eye and orbit tumours volume of this series [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Eye and orbit tumours [Internet; beta version ahead of print]. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2023. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 13). https://tumourclassification.iarc.who.int/chapters/65.]]).
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis is excellent. Progression to conjunctival melanoma is rare.
cytology: Conjunctival naevi comprise epithelioid cells (type A), oval to cuboidal cells (type B), and spindled cells (type C).
related_terminology: Acceptable: melanocytic naevus.
subtypes: Junctional naevus; compound naevus; subepithelial (stromal) naevus; balloon cell naevus

media.legend: Conjunctival melanocytic naevus. A compound naevus associated with prominent epithelial inclusion cysts. The lesion shows maturation with depth.

Compound conjunctival melanocytic naevus. In the context of a thin conjunctival epithelium, junctional melanocytic nests appear to be confluent and show consumption of the epidermis. Such a pattern is common in conjunctival naevi and does not indicate atypia.
Conjunctival compound naevus. A variably pigmented, well-circumscribed lesion.
Conjunctival junctional naevus. Junctional nests in a naevus from a teenaged patient.
Compound conjunctival naevus. An example of a compound naevus with prominent nests of naevus cells and occasional epithelial cysts in the substantia propria.
Conjunctival subepithelial naevus. An example of a subepithelial conjunctival melanocytic naevus with mature naevus cells in the stroma.
Conjunctival subepithelial naevus. Higher-power view of a conjunctival subepithelial melanocytic naevus, showing mature naevus cells.

entity_name: Melanoma arising in giant congenital naevus
definition: Melanoma arising in giant congenital naevus is a melanoma that occurs in a pre-existing giant congenital naevus.
clinical:
Melanomas arising in this setting are rapidly growing, often ulcerated nodules or plaques that differ in colour and texture from the congenital naevus in the background. Synchronous lymph node metastases are common.

---

The lifetime risk for melanoma arising in a congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) of any size is approximately 1–2%, and up to 10–15% for large CMNs with satellite naevi or CNS involvement. The risk of melanoma may be overstated in the literature because of the misclassification of proliferating nodules as melanoma in the past.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is related to clonal evolution from the precursor congenital naevus.

---

See the sections on section congenital naevi for the spectrum of initiating mutations in giant congenital naevi. The genetic alterations that demarcate malignant transformation remain poorly understood. Like in common naevi, ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure probably plays a role in the generation of secondary mutations.
microscopic: In prepubescent children, the principal site of melanoma development is the dermis or subcutaneous fat. In contrast, in adults, most melanomas arise from the dermal–epidermal junction. Obvious malignant features are often present and include large expansile nodules with sharp circumscription, necrosis, and mitoses. Cytomorphological features may include epithelioid cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and prominent nucleoli, small cells resembling Ewing sarcoma cells, or spindle cells, and may be strikingly poorly differentiated or dedifferentiated. Focal neural or blue naevus–like, smooth or striated muscle, or adipocyte differentiation may be present.
ancillary_studies: PRAME positivity, loss of p16 and H3 p.K27me3 immunoreactivity, and increased Ki-67 labelling favour melanoma.
differential_diagnosis: The most important differential diagnosis is proliferative nodules in CMN (see section Proliferative nodules in congenital melanocytic naevus). Features indicating melanoma are sharp circumscription with an expansive pattern, necrosis, ulceration, severe cytological atypia, poorly differentiated tumour cells, and a high mitotic count with atypical forms. In very young children, the distinction can be difficult.
staging: Melanoma arising in giant CMN is staged according to the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM criteria, like other cutaneous melanomas.
prognosis_and_prediction: Melanomas arising in giant CMNs have a poor prognosis, which worsens with increasing tumour thickness.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Copy-number analysis typically shows gains and losses of arms or segments of chromosomes in melanoma, whereas proliferative nodules typically harbour copy-number changes involving entire chromosomes.
related_terminology: Acceptable: melanoma in large, bathing-trunk, or garment-like congenital naevus.

media.legend: Dermal melanoma arising in a large congenital naevus. A sharply delimited rounded nodule of melanoma underlies the congenital naevus in the superficial dermis.
Dermal melanoma arising in a large congenital naevus. A monomorphic population of epithelioid melanoma cells is seen in this field.
Melanoma arising in large congenital naevus. Large confluent zones of necrosis are present.
Melanoma arising in giant congenital naevus presenting as a reddish brown nodule (arrow).
Melanoma arising in a large congenital naevus. Sheet-like arrangements of poorly differentiated polygonal melanoma cells are seen in this field.

entity_name: Proliferative nodules in congenital melanocytic naevus
definition: Proliferative nodules (PNs) are benign nodular proliferations of melanocytes arising in medium or giant congenital naevi (GCNs).
clinical:
PNs are pink, brown, blue, or black papules, plaques, or nodules within a congenital naevus. They are typically < 20 mm in size and can be ulcerated. They may be present at birth or arise later and show rapid growth.

---

PNs arise in 3–19% of GCNs.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Secondary genomic aberrations such as mutations, chromosomal rearrangements, or copy-number changes in a congenital naevus lead to expansion of a new clone.
microscopic: Within the dermal or subcutaneous portion of a congenital naevus there is an expansile proliferation of melanocytes with spitzoid, small blue round cell, epithelioid, or spindle morphology. The morphological transition from the surrounding naevus cells typically is gradual with intermediate cellular morphologies, but it can be abrupt. The mitotic count is typically < 2 mitoses/mm2, and cells lack high-grade nuclear atypia. Cases with small blue round cell morphology may have more mitoses.
ancillary_studies: Immunomarkers for melanocytes, such as melan-A, tyrosinase, and SOX10, are expressed in PNs. Loss of p16 or H3 p.K27me3 expression and increased labelling with Ki-67 raise concern for melanoma.
differential_diagnosis: Criteria favouring melanoma are sharply demarcated, expansive nodules; necrosis; nuclear enlargement; pleomorphism; hyperchromasia; prominent nucleoli; numerous mitotic figures; and atypical mitoses. Both melanoma arising in a congenital naevus and PNs may express PRAME, so its usefulness is unclear.
prognosis_and_prediction: There is currently no evidence that PNs progress to melanoma, and nodules tend to spontaneously stop growing and often regress. Local recurrences may occur, showing greater cytological atypia.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Gains or losses of entire chromosomes are seen in PNs, whereas melanomas tend to have segmental copy-number aberrations. Mutations or epigenetic modification of the TERT promoter favour a diagnosis of melanoma.
related_terminology: Acceptable: expansile and cellular nodules; atypical proliferative nodules.

media.legend: Proliferative nodule in congenital melanocytic naevus. A compound giant congenital naevus is observed with multiple proliferative nodules with sharp demarcation from surrounding congenital naevus cells.

Proliferative nodule in congenital melanocytic naevus. Higher magnification of the proliferative nodule shows slightly enlarged epithelioid melanocytes with visible nucleoli and occasional mitotic activity but a lack of high-grade nuclear atypia.
Proliferative nodule in congenital melanocytic naevus. A nodular proliferation consisting of monomorphic small round blue cells filling and expanding the dermis is observed.
Proliferative nodule in congenital melanocytic naevus. Higher magnification shows a monomorphic proliferation of small round blue cells with mitotic activity.
Proliferative nodule in congenital melanocytic naevus. A nodular proliferation consisting of monomorphic small round blue cells filling and expanding the dermis is observed.

Proliferative nodule in congenital melanocytic naevus. A compound giant congenital naevus is observed with multiple proliferative nodules with sharp demarcation from surrounding congenital naevus cells.

definition: Congenital melanocytic naevus (CMN) is a benign melanocytic neoplasm present at birth or appearing in the first year of life (late or tardive congenital naevus). Blue naevi can also arise at birth but are discussed in a separate section.
clinical:
In adults, CMNs are categorized as small (< 15 mm), intermediate (15–200 mm), or giant (> 200 mm). Small and intermediate CMNs typically present as symmetrical, oval or round, brown to black, well-circumscribed macules or plaques that are homogeneous in texture and often have prominent terminal hairs or a rugose or pebbly surface. Giant naevi may exhibit thickening of the skin and soft tissue, and those affecting the scalp and back can involve the CNS (neurocutaneous melanosis).

---

About 1% of newborns have a small CMN. Giant congenital naevi affect 5 newborns per 100 000 births.
pathogenesis:
CMN is a clonal proliferation of melanocytes caused by a postzygotic mutation.

---

The majority (~90%) of large CMNs harbour NRAS mutations. BRAF p.V600E mutations are less common (5–10%). KRAS, APC, and MET mutations and ZEB2::ALK and SOX5::RAF1 gene fusions have also been observed.
microscopic: CMNs are larger than common acquired naevi and frequently involve the reticular dermis and subcutis, with splaying of naevus cells between collagen bundles and around dermal appendages and neurovascular bundles. In infants, there may be striking pagetoid scatter and confluence of the intraepidermal nests in the centre of the lesions. Cells in the dermis often change from large epithelioid type A naevus cells in the upper dermis to small lymphocyte-like type B cells to spindled type C cells in the deep reticular dermis. There is no significant atypia or mitotic activity.
ancillary_studies: CMNs usually express the melanocytic markers melan-A and SOX10 and show a gradual decrease of HMB45 expression with depth.
differential_diagnosis: CMN with an atypical junctional proliferation of melanocytes may simulate melanoma in situ, but such areas are typically restricted to the centre of the lesion. Cases with increased cellularity can be difficult to distinguish from naevoid melanoma. Deep, atypical, or clustered mitotic figures, nuclear enlargement, pleomorphism, hyperchromatism, and sheet-like growth are among the most important features pointing towards melanoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: The lifetime risk of melanoma arising in a CMN of any size is approximately 1–2%; for large CMNs with satellite naevi or CNS involvement it is as high as 10–15%.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular analyses are usually unnecessary for the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: congenital naevocytic naevus; congenital naevus syndrome; neurocutaneous melanosis.

media.legend: Congenital melanocytic naevus. A broad plaque lesion, which in this instance is generally uniformly pigmented brown. This lesion is intermediate in terms of size.

Giant congenital naevus. This pigmented lesion, which was present at birth, covers a large area of skin. Such lesions are sometimes known as “garment naevi”. Note a smaller so-called “satellite” lesion on the thigh.
Congenital naevus. Note the depth of the dermal component and the concentration of cells around skin adnexa.
Congenital naevus, small type. Dome-shaped lesion composed mostly of dark lymphocyte-like type-B cells (upper part of lesion) and pale-staining spindle cells (lower part of lesion).
Congenital naevus, small type. Greater detail of naevus with lymphocyte-like type-B cells and spindled type-C cells. The type-C cells mimic neural structures, exhibiting Schwannian differentiation.
Congenital melanocytic naevus with junctional atypia. A congenital melanocytic naevus is present in the dermis and at the junction.
Congenital melanocytic naevus with junctional atypia. In the uppermost part of the lesion, cells are homogeneous and typical.
Congenital melanocytic naevus. Symmetrical, oval, brown, well-circumscribed plaque with prominent terminal hairs.
Congenital melanocytic naevus. Dermoscopic features showing haloed and target globules and blotches.

definition: Melanoma arising in blue naevus (MBN) is a melanoma occurring in a pre-existing blue naevus, usually a cellular blue naevus.
clinical:
MBN is a fast-growing, large nodule, usually in a longstanding blue naevus.

---

MBN is rare. It can occur across a wide age range (5–73 years), most often in adults aged > 45 years, and shows no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Although sun exposure is a well-known factor in the development of other types of melanocytic naevi, its role in the development of blue naevi and neoplasms evolving therein is less clear.

---

MBNs evolve through genetic progression from blue naevi and related intradermal melanocytic proliferations, caused by somatic mutations of the Gqα signalling pathway typically involving GNAQ, GNA11, PLCB4, or CYSLTR2. Malignant progression is associated with mutations involving SF3B1, EIF1AX, or BAP1, as well as chromosomal aberrations also seen in uveal melanoma, with gains in 6p or 8q, monosomy 3, and loss of 1p.
microscopic: MBN is an intradermal proliferation composed of dense dermal sheets of large spindled and epithelioid melanocytes with severe atypia and high mitotic activity, often effacing adnexal structures. Pigmentation is variable, sometimes only found within a subclone. Central areas of tumoural necrosis are frequent in large tumours. A residuum of blue naevus can usually be found at the periphery.
ancillary_studies: The Ki-67 proliferation index is often > 20%. When nuclear BAP1 staining is lost in the melanoma, the loss typically affects large contiguous populations of neoplastic cells but is retained in any naevus remnant.
differential_diagnosis: Cellular blue naevi have less pleomorphism, lack necrosis en masse, and retain expression of BAP1. Immunohistochemistry for BRAF p.V600E oncoprotein is often positive in metastatic melanoma and local recurrences. WNT-activated and pigmented epithelioid melanocytomas should be excluded, and clear cell sarcoma in unpigmented cases must be considered in less typical presentations.
staging: MBN is staged according to the current Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification for cutaneous melanoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: MBNs are often aggressive, with frequent metastasis to the regional lymph nodes and liver; other common metastatic sites can also be affected. Monosomy 3 and BAP1 inactivation have been proposed as indicators of a less favourable outcome.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: MBNs harbour GNAQ, GNA11, PLCB4, or CYSLTR2 mutations, rather than BRAF or other mutations associated with other melanoma types. Mutations of SF3B1, EIF1AX, or BAP1 can help support the diagnosis of malignant transformation.
related_terminology: Acceptable: blue naevus–like melanoma; melanoma ex blue naevus; melanoma mimicking cellular blue naevus. Not recommended: malignant blue naevus.

media.legend: Melanoma arising in blue naevus. Dense sheet-like, pigmented multilobular tumour with central area of necrosis. The tumour extends into subcutaneous tissue, with well-defined lowermost margin.
Melanoma arising in blue naevus. Large tumoural nodule connected to a fibrous, pigmented, intraseptal melanocytic proliferation in the subcutis (haematoxylin eosin saffron stain).

Melanoma arising in blue naevus. Higher-magnification view showing sheets of large epithelioid melanocytes with multiple mitoses in the malignant area (right side), adjacent to small spindled melanocytes (haematoxylin eosin saffron stain).

definition: Congenital dermal melanocytosis (CDM) is an increased number of melanocytes in the dermis, usually on the lower back and buttocks.
clinical:
CDM manifests as a bluish or darker patch. It can be associated with inborn errors of metabolism, including GM1 gangliosidoses, mucopolysaccharidosis type I (Hurler syndrome) and type II (Hunter syndrome), mucolipidosis, Niemann–Pick disease, mannosidosis, cleft lip/palate, supernumerary digits, benign leptomeningeal melanocytoma, lysosomal storage disease, and Sjögren–Larsson syndrome. Phakomatosis pigmentovascularis is the association of extensive, aberrant, persistent CDM with vascular anomalies, such as naevus flammeus, Sturge–Weber syndrome, or Klippel–Trénaunay syndrome.

---

CDMs are most common in Asian and African populations. There is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The pathogenesis is unclear. It has been proposed that dermal melanosis arises from an arrest of migration of melanocytes, derived from neural crest cells, which become trapped in the dermis instead of reaching the epidermis. GNAQ and GNA11 mutations have been found in cases associated with phakomatosis pigmentovascularis.
microscopic: CDMs are composed of single pigmented dendritic melanocytes sparsely dispersed in the dermis, often parallel to the epidermis.
ancillary_studies: The melanocytes express melanocytic markers such as SOX10, melan-A, or HMB45.
differential_diagnosis: Naevus of Ito and naevus of Ota have similar histology but different anatomical localization. Blue naevi tend to be more cellular and have bundles of dendritic cells.
prognosis_and_prediction: CDMs typically disappear by the age of 5–6 years. Involvement of other sites, multiple patches, size > 100 mm, and dark colour are associated with persistent CDMs.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Mongolian spot.

media.legend: Congenital dermal melanocytosis. Variably sized bluish patches on the buttocks, back, and arms.
Phakomatosis pigmentovascularis. Aberrant congenital dermal melanocytosis on the trunk and extremities coexists with naevus flammeus on the left chest and arm.
Congenital dermal melanocytosis. Pigmented dendritic melanocytes are scattered in the dermis.

entity_name: Naevus of Ito and naevus of Ota
definition: Naevus of Ito and naevus of Ota are dermal melanocytoses involving the shoulder and arm (naevus of Ito) or the face (naevus of Ota).
clinical:
Naevus of Ito and naevus of Ota are bluish patches that are present at birth in about 50% of cases or appear before adolescence. Two thirds of naevus of Ota cases have ocular involvement, with scleral hyperpigmentation. Ipsilateral deafness, meningeal or orbital melanocytoma, and phakomatosis pigmentovascularis may be associated. Spontaneous regression does not occur, and the colour of the naevi deepens with puberty.

---

Naevus of Ito and naevus of Ota are most common in Asian populations. Naevus of Ota is more common than naevus of Ito and has a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
They arise from postzygotic mutations leading to clonal expansion of melanocytes during development.

---

GNAQ and GNA11 mutations are commonly found in naevi of Ota and Ito.
microscopic: Sparse populations of pigmented and dendritic melanocytes are haphazardly dispersed in the upper dermis. A junctional component and mitoses are absent.
ancillary_studies: The melanocytes express melanocytic markers such as SOX10, melan-A, and HMB45.
differential_diagnosis: In cellular proliferations, cellular blue naevus/melanocytoma and melanoma must be considered. Uveal melanoma and melanoma arising in blue naevus may rarely develop in naevus of Ota and show the characteristic secondary genetic alterations, including gains of chromosome 6p and losses of 6q, inactivation of BAP1, and mutations of SF3B1, EIF1AX, and TP53.
prognosis_and_prediction: Malignant transformation is rare. A complication of naevus of Ota is glaucoma caused by angle abnormalities or mechanical occlusion by pigment and melanocytes.
related_terminology: Acceptable: oculodermal melanocytosis; congenital oculodermal melanocytosis. Not recommended: naevus fusco-caeruleus ophthalmomaxillaris.

media.legend: Naevus of Ito. Bluish patch on the right supraclavicular area and shoulder.
Naevus of Ota. Bluish patch on the face, with scleral involvement.
Naevus of Ota. Dark bluish to brown patch on the face in an adult.
Naevus of Ota. Single dendritic melanocytes are dispersed in the upper dermis.
Naevus of Ito. Sparse scattered spindled or slightly wavy dendritic cells containing melanin granules in the dermis are observed.

definition: Mucosal melanomas are melanomas arising in the anogenital, oral, or sinonasal mucosa.
clinical:
Mucosal melanomas arise as irregularly pigmented macules or plaques, typically in older patients. Sinonasal melanomas come to clinical attention with nonspecific symptoms, including nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and sinus congestion, which simulate inflammatory conditions.

---

Mucosal melanomas represent approximately 1–3% of all melanomas. The mean age at diagnosis is 67 years.
pathogenesis:
Mucosal melanomas have no association with ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure.

---

Mucosal melanomas have a low mutation burden, without a UV radiation signature. Instead, they are characterized by numerous chromosomal structural variants and abundant copy-number changes, including multiple high-level amplifications. The most common somatic mutations affect BRAF, NRAS, KIT, NF1, SPRED1, SF3B1, CDKN2A, PTEN, ATRX, and TP53, with frequent amplifications of CCND1, PAK1, GAB2, TERT, CDK4, MDM2, YAP1, and CRKL, and deletions of CDKN2A, PTEN, NF1, and SPRED1.
microscopic: The invasive areas of the tumour are usually composed of sheets and expansive nodules of large pleomorphic and large epithelioid cells or, less commonly, spindle or smaller ovoid cells. The nuclei often have vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli. The presence of an adjacent intraepithelial or superficially invasive component of atypical melanocytes supports a mucosal primary. Melanin production is variable but usually at least focally present within both melanoma cells and background macrophages. Vulvar melanoma often shows an intraepidermal component with a confluent nested and lentiginous growth pattern and with pagetoid spread. In contrast, vaginal melanoma typically has a lentiginous growth of single atypical melanocytes in the basal epithelial layer, sometimes with nests or confluent growth. A subepithelial lymphocytic infiltrate is common. A desmoplastic component may be present.
ancillary_studies: Immunohistochemistry for S100, SOX10, MITF, HMB45, and melan-A is usually positive.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes dysplastic naevi and special-site naevi (see section Dysplastic naevus, and section Special-site naevi (of the breast, axilla, scalp, and ear)).
staging: Mucosal melanomas of the head and neck are staged using specific American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) criteria. Vulvar and vaginal melanomas are staged using the AJCC cutaneous melanoma staging system.
prognosis_and_prediction: The 5-year overall survival of mucosal melanoma ranges from 20% to 50%. Large tumour size, advanced age and stage, and distant metastasis portend a poor prognosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The absence of a UV radiation mutation signature and presence of characteristic clustered copy-number changes may assist in excluding metastatic cutaneous melanoma.
related_terminology: Acceptable: mucosal lentiginous melanoma; vaginal melanoma; vulvar melanoma; vulvovaginal melanoma; genital melanoma; oral melanoma; sinonasal melanoma.

media.legend: Mucosal melanoma. The invasive tumour is composed of uniformly atypical epithelioid cells (bottom left), admixed with numerous melanophages. There is involvement of the overlying epithelium by atypical melanocytes, mostly basal in this field.

Mucosal melanoma. In the squamous epithelium adjacent to a mucosal melanoma, there is a basal (lentiginous) proliferation of atypical melanocytes (relatively subtle, as is often the case), with melanophages and lymphocytes in the subepithelial stroma.
Mucosal melanoma. Melanomas of the oral cavity or the vulvovaginal or urethral mucosae can present as a bulky tumour, as seen in this microscopic field.
Mucosal melanoma. Lower part of the oral mucosa of a multifocal melanoma.
Mucosal melanoma. Vulvar tumour in a 65-year-old woman. Large atypical epithelioid melanocytes, with scattered melanophages and high mitotic activity, are seen in this lesion.

Vulvar melanoma. Vulvar lesion in a 65-year-old woman. Notice a mostly nodular pattern with scattered intraepithelial melanocytes (please see also the mid-power view image of the immunohistochemical study with a panmelanocytic cocktail).

definition: Genital naevus is a benign melanocytic naevus located in the genital region.
clinical:
Genital naevi are uniformly pigmented, well-circumscribed, solitary macules or papules, up to 10 mm in size, that typically arise in young adults.

---

Genital naevi account for < 5% of pigmented lesions in the genital area in women.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is similar to that of common naevi.

---

Most genital naevi have BRAF p.V600E mutations.
microscopic: The junctional component consists of single cells and nests haphazardly distributed along the epidermal rete ridges, often oriented parallel to the epidermal surface, with focal retraction artefact and dyscohesion. The centre may have limited pagetoid scatter. The dermal component may show cytological atypia superficially, but shows maturation with increasing depth. Mitotic figures are very rare and only superficial, with increased numbers in pregnancy. Lesions may be polypoid, have a dense lymphocytic infiltrate (halo phenomenon), or be associated with lichen sclerosus.
differential_diagnosis: Mucosal melanoma is more common in older individuals than genital naevus, has more cytological atypia and mitoses, lacks maturation, shows patchy HMB45 immunoreactivity, and has a higher proliferation rate. Dysplastic naevi share many features with genital naevi, in particular the architectural disorder (bridging and lamellar fibrosis).
prognosis_and_prediction: These are benign lesions. Melanomas associated with genital naevi are very rare.
related_terminology: Acceptable: genital naevocytic naevus; naevus of the genital tract; naevus of special site.

media.legend: Genital naevus. Deeply pigmented cells extending deeply into the underlying stroma with evidence of cellular maturation.
Genital naevus. High-power view of maturation of cells in the stroma.
Genital naevus. A pigmented plaque-like lesion of the vulva.
Genital naevus on the glans. Black macule on a 34-year-old man.
Genital naevus. There is a junctional component of single cells and small nests. The cells of the dermal component display mild atypia.

Vulvar naevus. The lesion has a junctional component of nests, with focal retraction artefact and dyscohesion, distributed haphazardly along the epidermal rete ridges; some are oriented parallel to the epidermal surface. The dermal component displays mild cytological atypia superficially but shows maturation with increasing depth.

Vulvar naevus. The lesion has a junctional component of nests, with focal retraction artefact and dyscohesion, distributed haphazardly along the epidermal rete ridges; some are oriented parallel to the epidermal surface. The dermal component displays mild cytological atypia superficially but shows maturation with increasing depth.

Vulvar naevus. Nests are distributed haphazardly along the epidermal rete ridges, often oriented parallel to the epidermal surface. The dermal component shows mild cytological atypia superficially but shows maturation with increasing depth.
Genital naevus. A compound naevus showing large nests with poor cohesion in the epidermal component but no atypia or mitosis in dermal component.

definition: Melanosis is the presence of pigmented macules on mucous membranes, characterized by hyperpigmentation of epithelial cells and with little to no increase in the number of junctional melanocytes.
clinical:
Clinically, melanosis presents as single or multiple asymptomatic pigmented macules or patches of varying sizes and colours that tend to be asymmetrical with poorly defined borders. Dermoscopically, inhomogeneous black or brown coloration is typical for melanosis, whereas red, blue, or grey raises suspicion for melanoma.

---

Melanosis is common in women, with approximately 8% of women developing melanosis in the genital region. The average age is 46 years. Conjunctival melanosis is frequent in people with Fitzpatrick skin types IV–VI, occurring with lower frequency in White populations.
pathogenesis:
The etiology of melanosis is unknown.

---

The pathogenesis of melanosis is largely unknown. In women, hormonal status has been implicated.
microscopic: Melanosis is characterized by melanin pigment deposited in basilar keratinocytes and may be associated with a slight increase in junctional melanocytes. Other possible features include elongation of the rete ridges, dendritic melanocytes without atypia at the dermoepidermal junction, and melanophages in the papillary dermis.
ancillary_studies: Conjunctival melanocytes are positive for melanocytic markers, including melan-A, MITF, HMB45, and SOX10.
differential_diagnosis: Melanocytic naevi have junctional nests. Melanoma in situ tends to have more melanocytes and is less well circumscribed. In the conjunctiva, the differential diagnosis includes naevi and conjunctival melanocytic intraepithelial neoplasia/lesions, as well as pterygia or squamous cell carcinoma in situ with hyperpigmentation.
prognosis_and_prediction: Melanoses are benign and do not need to be treated. In the conjunctiva, malignant transformation into conjunctival melanocytic intraepithelial neoplasia/lesions or primary acquired melanosis with atypia and/or conjunctival melanoma is exceedingly rare.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular analyses are usually not required for the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: lentiginosis; melanotic macule; constitutional melanosis; complexion-related melanosis. Not recommended: non-proliferative melanocytic pigmentary patch; ephelis; freckle.

media.legend: Vulvar melanosis. 52-year-old woman. Multifocal pigmented lesion with non-homogeneous pigmentation.
Vulvar melanosis. Dermoscopically, irregular diffuse pigmentation characterized by the presence of shades of brown and black colouring in the absence of other dermoscopic parameters.
Vulvar melanosis. There are elongate rete ridges. Pigmentation is restricted to the keratinocytes of the basal layer, with a roughly normal number of melanocytes at the junction.
Vulvar melanosis. Melanocytes are inconspicuous, and rare melanophages are present in the superficial dermis.
Penile melanosis. Multifocal pigmented lesion with non-homogeneous pigmentation.
Benign epithelial melanosis of the conjunctiva. Conjunctival epithelium is pigmented, with some melanophages present in the substantia propria as well. Melanocytes, however, appear normal.
Benign epithelial melanosis of the conjunctiva. A melan-A (MART1) immunostain confirms normal density of dendritic-appearing melanocytes.

definition: Acral naevus is a benign melanocytic neoplasm of the volar skin of hands or feet or the nail apparatus.
clinical:
Acral naevi are brownish to black small macules or flat papules. Most display one of three major dermoscopic patterns: the parallel furrow pattern, the lattice-like pattern, or the fibrillar pattern. NMN manifests as longitudinal melanonychia. Dermoscopy of NMN typically shows thick parallel lines without colour variation, but NMNs may be darker, larger, or multicoloured, and in children they may display Hutchinsons sign.

---

Acral naevi are common, occurring in more than a third of individuals, and their incidence peaks in the third and fourth decades of life. They are more common in females and in individuals with higher constitutional pigmentation and many melanocytic naevi.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Acral naevi harbour BRAF or NRAS mutations, similarly to common acquired naevi.
microscopic: Acral naevi are relatively small and circumscribed, and they can be junctional, compound, or intradermal. Acral skin is a special site where naevi may show features considered atypical in other locations; pagetoid scatter, bridging between rete, and fibroplasia are not uncommon in the centre of the lesion. Naevus cells are arranged as single units and variably sized nests, which can be confluent. There may be random cytological atypia. Intradermal melanocytes display maturation. Nuclear atypia, confluence of melanocytes, focal pagetoid spread, and periungual involvement are common in NMN in children. Melanocytic acral naevus with intraepidermal ascent of cells is a presentation of acral naevus showing pagetoid scatter of nests or single cells, which is more commonly seen in children.
ancillary_studies: Acral naevi express melanocytic markers, which can help reveal subtle proliferations in NMN.
differential_diagnosis: A confluent lentiginous intraepidermal proliferation of atypical melanocytes and a patchy inflammatory infiltrate is more common in acral melanoma than in acral naevus. Strong cyclin D1 expression supports acral melanoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Acral naevi are benign, and progression to melanoma is very rare. NMN in children initially shows a rapid widening and colour variegation and may undergo spontaneous regression by adolescence.
related_terminology: Acceptable: naevi of special sites; melanocytic acral naevus with intraepidermal ascent of cells. Not recommended: atypical lentiginous naevus; acral lentiginous naevus.

definition: Spitz melanoma is a malignant melanocytic neoplasm harbouring the initiating genomic alteration characteristic of Spitz naevus.
clinical:
Patients typically present with a changing or enlarging amelanotic or pigmented papule, nodule, or plaque, typically > 6 mm, which can be pigmented and have a smooth, verrucous, or ulcerated surface. Dermoscopy may reveal a starburst pattern with a peripheral rim of pseudopods or streaks, or there may be a homogeneous pink, blue, or black appearance with or without shiny white streaks.

---

Spitz melanoma is rare. It can occur at any age, although it is rare in prepubertal children and more common in individuals aged > 40 years (mean age: 55 years). It appears to be more common in men.
pathogenesis:
Spitz melanomas arise through genetic progression from a Spitz naevus or Spitz melanocytoma.

---

Spitz melanoma is initiated by the same spectrum of genetic alterations as Spitz naevus. Progression occurs through additional genetic aberrations in melanoma-associated genes such as CDKN2A, PTEN, and TERT. These additional mutations may be caused by ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure.
microscopic: Tumours may have many of the characteristics of a Spitz naevus and melanocytoma, such as epithelioid and spindle cell cytology with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, but also show characteristics of a malignant neoplasm, including a higher degree of asymmetry, pleomorphism, poor circumscription, effacement or epidermal consumption, ulceration, larger aggregates with sheets, or areas of necrosis. Mitoses, including atypical forms, are usually present.
ancillary_studies: p16 expression is often absent, and the Ki-67 proliferation index is often > 20%. Spitz melanoma may demonstrate deep rather than stratified HMB45 staining, and patchy rather than diffuse melan-A staining. Positive immunohistochemical staining for ALK, ROS1, and NTRK can suggest an underlying respective fusion but is not useful for distinction from Spitz melanocytoma.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes Spitz naevus, Spitz melanocytoma, and conventional melanoma (see the various immunomarkers and genomic findings described above and below). The term spitzoid melanoma is sometimes used for melanomas with morphological resemblance to a Spitz tumour but lacking a defining Spitz-related genetic alteration. Many such melanomas have characteristics of melanomas in skin with a low degree of cumulative sun damage (low-CSD melanomas) and have BRAF p.V600E mutations.
staging: Spitz melanoma is staged according to the current Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification for cutaneous melanoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Because of the rarity of bona fide Spitz melanoma, its prognosis is not fully established. In cohorts likely representing a mixture of Spitz melanocytomas and Spitz melanomas, 40–50% of cases showed involvement of sentinel lymph nodes with no further disease spread or fatalities. Adverse prognosticators are older patient age, larger tumour size (> 10 mm), ulceration, higher mitotic count (> 6 mitoses/mm2), and the presence of multiple chromosomal copy-number aberrations including biallelic deletion of 9p21 and TERT promoter mutation.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The identification of a Spitz-associated genomic fusion in the setting of a tumour with spitzoid morphology can confirm Spitz lineage and can help exclude spitzoid melanoma. The presence of melanoma-associated chromosomal copy-number aberrations or the presence of a TERT promoter mutation supports a diagnosis of melanoma over Spitz melanocytoma.
related_terminology: Acceptable: malignant Spitz tumour. Not recommended: mixed epithelioid and spindle cell melanoma.
subtypes: The subtypes of Spitz melanoma are similar to the genomic subtypes of Spitz naevus. See #38596Table 3.08 in section Spitz naevus.

The melanoma metastasized to the lungs and brain, resulting in death 18 months after initial diagnosis. This tumour carried a BRAF fusion and a TERT promoter mutation.

definition: Spitz melanocytoma (atypical Spitz tumour) is a melanocytic neoplasm characterized by one or more atypical features and is morphologically and genetically intermediate between Spitz naevus and melanoma.
clinical:
Spitz melanocytomas typically appear as papules, nodules, or plaques ≥ 5 mm in diameter, and they may display asymmetry, irregular borders, colour variegation, and/or ulceration (see #35968Table 3.09).

---

Spitz melanocytomas can occur at any age but are most common in adolescents and young adults.
pathogenesis:
Spitz melanocytomas arise through genetic progression from a Spitz naevus.

---

Spitz melanocytomas have one of the initiating mutations of Spitz naevus, including fusions involving the kinase genes ALK, BRAF, MET, RET, ROS1, NTRK1, NTRK2, NTRK3, or MAP3K8, or HRAS mutation, but they also harbour additional pathogenic alterations such as inactivation of CDKN2A (see #35968Table 3.09). The full spectrum of secondary alterations that distinguish Spitz melanocytomas from Spitz naevi and Spitz melanomas remains to be characterized.
microscopic: Spitz melanocytomas often arise as asymmetrical, poorly circumscribed proliferations of large epithelioid to spindled melanocytes, arranged as cellular aggregates or nodules that replace the dermis, with little or no maturation and a pushing lower border. Peripheral pagetoid scatter of single cells or small nests, consumption of the epidermis, and ulceration can be present. Kamino bodies are less frequent, smaller, or absent. The neoplastic melanocytes usually have larger, more hyperchromatic nuclei than those of Spitz naevi, with large eosinophilic nucleoli. Large multinucleated melanocytes with bizarre nuclei and foci with necrotic melanocytes may be present. The mitotic count may be increased, and atypical mitoses may be present. The histopathological diagnostic criteria differ with age, with a higher tolerance for atypical features in children aged < 10 years (see #35968Table 3.09).
ancillary_studies: p16 expression is often absent, but absent p16 expression may also be seen in Spitz naevi and Spitz melanomas.
differential_diagnosis: Spitz melanocytoma is defined by one or more atypical histopathological features. There is low interobserver concordance, and a greater degree of atypia is associated with greater diagnostic uncertainty. Molecular analyses are helpful (see #35968Table 3.09). See also section Spitz naevus .
prognosis_and_prediction: Spitz melanocytoma is considered a benign to low-risk neoplasm. Although distant metastasis and death has occasionally been reported, those cases may have been misclassified melanomas or may have represented further neoplastic progression of residual tumour cells. A scoring system has been proposed as an aid for risk stratification. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is not recommended, because it is positive in 40% of cases without predicting an adverse outcome.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Identification of a Spitz initiating oncogene is helpful in confirming Spitz lineage. While rare instances of BRAF p.V600E have been reported in atypical Spitz tumours, these mutations typically indicate a melanocytic neoplasm of a different pathway, such as naevoid melanoma of the low cumulative sun damage (CSD) pathway or a BAP1-inactivated melanocytoma. Complete absence of p16 expression is associated with genetic inactivation of CDKN2A which, by definition, does not occur in Spitz naevi. Other copy-number aberrations can be seen, often affecting chromosomal loci involved in rearrangements generating the kinase fusion. Other copy-number aberrations, in particular those common in melanoma, or genetic alterations involving TERT raise concern for melanoma.
related_terminology: Acceptable: atypical Spitz tumour.
subtypes: The subtypes of Spitz melanocytoma are similar to the genomic subtypes of Spitz naevus. See #38596Table 3.08 in section Spitz naevus.

definition: Pigmented spindle cell naevus (PSCN) is a subtype of Spitz naevus characterized by heavily pigmented, spindle-shaped melanocytes.
clinical:
Patients with PSCN typically present with a black, dark-brown, or blue macule or papule that is well circumscribed, symmetrical, and flat-topped, averaging about 3 mm in diameter (range: 1.5–10 mm). Dermoscopy often shows a starburst appearance or a homogeneous black, blue-black, or dark-brown appearance.

---

PSCN preferentially affects young people (mean age: 25 years) and women. It accounts for < 20% of Spitz neoplasms.
pathogenesis:
Somatic mutations lead to clonal expansion of melanocytes.

---

PSCNs are caused by genomic rearrangements that result in the constitutive activation of protein kinases, involving most commonly NTRK3 or less frequently MET, ROS1, or RET.
microscopic: PSCNs are usually small, well-circumscribed, symmetrical, nested proliferations of spindled and pigmented melanocytes, with overlying epidermal hyperplasia and clefts surrounding nests. Kamino bodies may be present. Pagetoid spread is relatively common, mostly limited to the lower half of the epidermis and not extending peripherally beyond the last junctional nest. PSCNs may involve the papillary dermis and appendages. Some tumours have small cells with delicate nuclei with open chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, and minimal cytoplasm. Others have larger cells with vesicular nuclei, spindle shape, and abundant cytoplasm. There are typically many accompanying melanophages. Atypical pigmented spindle cell tumours are characterized by any of the following features: diameter > 6 mm (often); poor circumscription; asymmetry; effacement of the epidermis; ulceration; single melanocytes extending peripherally along the epidermal basal layer; or a high degree of pagetoid spread, mitotic activity, and cytological atypia. Features of dysplastic naevus may be seen. The lesions may contain cellular aggregates or nodules of melanocytes in the dermis without maturation. Atypical subtypes may be amelanotic spitzoid epithelioid cells present in a background PSCN.
ancillary_studies: There is typically strong p16 expression.
differential_diagnosis: Melanomas are usually larger than PSCNs and often exhibit an effaced and thinned epidermis, prominent basilar single-cell proliferation of atypical spindle cells, and cellular fascicles and nests with diminished cohesion. The identification of BRAF p.V600E mutations suggests a dysplastic naevus with spitzoid features or a melanoma in skin with a low degree of cumulative sun damage (low-CSD melanoma).
prognosis_and_prediction: PSCNs are benign neoplasms.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular analyses are usually unnecessary for the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: naevus of Reed; pigmented spindle cell Spitz naevus.

Pigmented spindle cell naevus (Reed naevus). The naevus is discrete and well-defined, with uniform brown-black coloration.
Pigmented spindle cell naevus (Reed naevus). Dermoscopic features. Note starburst appearance with radial lines and pseudopods at periphery.

Pigmented spindle cell naevus (Reed naevus). Epidermal hyperplasia with fascicles of bland pigmented spindle cells along the dermoepidermal junction. Clefting spaces are noted. Prominent melanophages are seen in the papillary dermis.
Atypical pigmented spindle cell naevus. The lesion is represented by a combination of nests of pigmented spindle cells with uniformly distributed single pagetoid melanocytes.

definition: MITF pathway–activated melanocytic tumours are clear cell tumours with melanocytic differentiation and an ACT::MITF or MITF::CREM translocation.
clinical:
They present as a solitary unpigmented nodule.

---

The age distribution is wide, ranging from children to the elderly. Tumours with an ACT::MITF translocation show a female predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

MITF fusions are the oncogenic driver. MITF is a transcription factor and member of the MiT/TFE family, which also contains TFEB, TFE3, and TFEC and acts as the master regulator of melanocytic differentiation. The actin gene involved in the ACT::MITF translocation can be ACTB or ACTG1. The large C-terminal MITF fragment of the fusion protein retains its transcriptional activation domain, suggesting hyperactive MITF function. MITF::CREM fusions are an alternative driver and may drive expression of the non-rearranged MITF allele, resulting in hyperactive MITF function. CREM is a member of the CREB1/ATF1/CREM family of transcription factors that regulate diverse cellular processes, including transcription of MITF. The N-terminal MITF portion of the fusion protein lacks its transcriptional activation domain, whereas the transcriptional activation domain is preserved in the CREM fragment, analogous to the EWSR1::ATF1 and EWSR1::CREB1 fusions found in clear cell sarcoma.
microscopic: The tumours are primarily dermal with common subcutaneous extension, and they lack an intraepidermal component. There is a distinctive splaying of the reticular dermal collagen bundles, creating a checkerboard-like pattern. The tumour cells are large, with copious optically clear or occasionally granular cytoplasm. The cytomorphological features are variable; morphology ranges from low-grade to higher-grade with nuclear enlargement, nuclear contour irregularity, and nucleolar enlargement. Necrosis, ulceration, perineural involvement, and lymphovascular involvement are not typical, and mitotic activity is inconspicuous.
ancillary_studies: The tumours are positive for HMB45 or melan-A (MART1) and usually for S100. MITF is strongly positive.
differential_diagnosis: Perivascular epithelioid cell tumour (PEComa), melanoma (either metastatic or primary dermal), and clear cell sarcoma represent the main differential diagnoses. S100 expression is typically not prominent in PEComa. Clear cell sarcoma should have EWSR1::ATF1 or EWSR1::CREB1 fusions, whereas cutaneous melanoma typically has MAPK pathway driver mutations.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: Current evidence suggests an indolent course for tumours with actin fusions, whereas the number of cases with CREM rearrangements is currently too small to assess.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Identification of the ACT::MITF or MITF::CREM rearrangement.
related_terminology: None

definition: BRCA1-associated deubiquitinase 1 (BAP1)-inactivated melanocytoma is a compound or intradermal proliferation of epithelioid melanocytes caused by inactivation of the BAP1 gene. It can occur sporadically or in association with BAP1-related tumour predisposition syndrome (BAP1-TPDS).
clinical:
BAP1-inactivated melanocytoma usually arises as inconspicuous, skin-coloured to reddish-brown, dome-shaped papules or nodules 4–12 mm in size, sometimes within a conventional naevus. By dermoscopy, they usually appear as structureless, pink to tan lesions, sometimes with irregular eccentric dots/globules or peripheral vessels, or as a network with raised structureless pink to tan areas or with a globular pattern.

---

BAP1-inactivated melanocytoma is rare and mostly occurs sporadically as a solitary lesion. Multiple BAP1-inactivated melanocytomas arise in patients with the autosomal dominant syndrome BAP1-TPDS (MIM number: 614327), caused by BAP1 germline mutations (see section BAP1-related tumour predisposition syndrome).
pathogenesis:
Mutations in melanocytes are associated with constitutional factors such as tanning ability, DNA repair capacity, and genetic susceptibility, as well as environmental factors such as sun exposure.

---

BAP1-inactivated melanocytoma typically arises from a conventional naevus with BRAF p.V600E or (less frequently) with NRAS mutations or RAF1 fusions, or through biallelic inactivation of the BAP1 tumour suppressor gene caused by loss-of-function mutations resulting in a non-functional or absent protein, deletions of the BAP1 gene, or a combination of both.
microscopic: BAP1-inactivated melanocytomas are predominantly intradermal proliferations of large, unpigmented, epithelioid melanocytes with well-defined cytoplasmic borders, large amounts of eosinophilic cytoplasm, and vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli, often accompanied by a lymphocytic infiltrate. There are no or few mitoses. A conventional naevus remnant is often present.
ancillary_studies: Biallelic BAP1 inactivation caused by deletions or nonsense mutations leads to complete loss of nuclear immunoreactivity in the epithelioid cells, whereas immunoreactivity can be retained in the less common scenario in which inactivating missense mutations corrupt the catalytic domain of BAP1. In approximately 5–10% of BAP1-inactivated melanocytomas, there is retained nuclear expression but a pathogenic variant in BAP1 can be identified by sequencing studies.
differential_diagnosis: BAP1-inactivated melanocytoma may resemble a Spitz naevus, but Kamino bodies are absent and the lesions typically lack the wedge-shaped silhouette of Spitz naevi. Combined BAP1-inactivated melanocytomas may be confused with melanoma arising in a naevus. Helpful clues in the differential diagnosis are the recognition of the typical epithelioid melanocytes, and the loss of BAP1 expression by immunohistochemistry in the absence of malignant features.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: BAP1-inactivated melanocytomas typically have an indolent clinical course. Rare BAP1-inactivated melanocytomas can seed lymph node metastases without any overt features of malignancy. The increased incidence of BAP1-inactivated cutaneous melanomas in patients with multiple BAP1-inactivated melanocytomas indicates an increased risk of progression to melanoma. Histopathological features, patient age, and size of residuum should be considered when making recommendations for a re-excision. See section BAP1-related tumour predisposition syndrome for carriers of BAP1 germline pathogenic variants.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Demonstration of biallelic inactivation of the BAP1 gene can help support the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: BAP1-inactivated melanocytic tumour; BAP1-inactivated naevus. Not recommended: BAPoma; BAP1-inactivated spitzoid naevus; melanocytic BAP1-mutated atypical intradermal tumour (MBAIT); Wiesner naevus; BAP1-deficient tumour.

definition: Pigmented epithelioid melanocytomas (PEMs) are melanocytic neoplasms composed of pigmented epithelioid melanocytes, characterized by combined mutational activation of the PKA (protein kinase A) and MAPK (mitogen-activated protein kinase) pathways.
clinical:
PEMs appear as slowly growing pigmented nodules or papules.

---

PEMs are rare tumours. They can occur at any age, most commonly arising in the second and third decades of life.
pathogenesis:
PEMs can occur sporadically or in patients with Carney complex.

---

Approximately two thirds of PEMs have inactivating genetic alterations in PRKAR1A in addition to one of several activating mutations of the MAPK pathway. PRKAR1A inactivation constitutively activates PKA and induces melanocyte proliferation, differentiation, and pigmentation.
microscopic: Most PEMs are heavily pigmented, predominantly dermal tumours, with an inverted wedge or bulbous configuration. Small junctional nests are seen in 30% of cases, often with accompanying epidermal hyperplasia. They are composed of pigmented dendritic and epithelioid melanocytes with vesicular nuclei that have prominent nucleoli, sometimes resembling Reed–Sternberg cells or fried eggs. The epithelioid cells can show substantial nuclear polymorphism and multinucleation and may have diminished pigmentation. The term atypical PEM may be applied to lesions with severe histological atypia and/or genomic aberrations suggestive of progression towards melanoma.
ancillary_studies: Loss of expression of PRKAR1A is found in as many as 80% of cases.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes blue naevus with epithelioid cells, blue naevus with PRKCA fusion, melanoma (metastatic or primary), Spitz naevus, and WNT-activated melanocytoma. Tumours with fusions of PRKCA or with other mutations in the Gqα pathway can have histological phenotypes resembling PEMs. As mutational activation of the Gqα pathway is pathognomonic of blue naevi, neoplasms with PRKCA fusions are not classified as PEMs but are instead classified with blue naevi and related neoplasms, unless they also have mutations in the PKA pathway.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: PEMs are melanocytic tumours of low to intermediate malignant potential. Spread to regional sentinel lymph nodes was found in 46% of cases, more commonly in cases with ulceration. Distant metastases are extremely rare. The prognosis is excellent, even in cases with lymph node metastases.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: DNA- and RNA-based sequencing helps to establish the diagnosis of PEM by confirming the presence of PRKAR1A inactivating mutations and rule out the presence of molecular markers of progression towards melanoma such as TERT promoter mutations or CDKN2A inactivation in atypical presentations.
related_terminology: Acceptable: epithelioid blue naevus; PRKAR1A-inactivated melanocytoma. Not recommended: animal-type melanoma.
