definition: Combined naevus is a benign melanocytic neoplasm with two or more phenotypically distinct tumour cell populations that is not a WNT-activated, BAP1-inactivated, or pigmented epithelioid melanocytoma; a proliferating nodule; or a collision tumour.
clinical:
Patients with combined naevus commonly present with a papule or nodule in a patch or plaque with different pigmentation. There can be a history of recent change.

---

Combined naevi account for < 1% of melanocytic naevus biopsies. They can develop at any age but typically arise in young adults (mean age: ~30 years). There is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Combined naevi are probably a heterogeneous group of lesions representing forms of stepwise tumour progression similar to melanocytomas, in which a phenotypically distinct subclone arises as a consequence of an additional pathogenic mutation.
microscopic: Typically, there is a compound or dermal naevus of the superficial congenital type with a subpopulation of morphologically distinct cells, usually situated in the superficial dermis. The clone can have varying morphology, but unpigmented epithelioid or hyperpigmented melanocytes are most common. Cytological atypia and mitotic activity are limited.
ancillary_studies: The melanocyte population of the background naevus and the subclone may express different immunophenotypes.
differential_diagnosis: Immunohistochemistry or molecular studies can assist in ruling out BAP1-inactivated, WNT-activated, and pigmented epithelioid melanocytoma, as well as proliferative nodules in congenital naevi.
prognosis_and_prediction: Combined naevi are benign. Recurrences are rare.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The small size of the clone often limits the potential to study its molecular features. By definition, alterations defining any specific melanocytomas should be absent.
related_terminology: Acceptable: biphenotypic naevus; clonal naevus; naevus with phenotypic heterogeneity; naevus with dermal epithelioid component. Not recommended: inverted type A naevus.

media.legend: Combined naevus. Deep dermal nodular melanocytic proliferation (clone) within a common compound naevus (haematoxylin phloxine saffron stain).
Combined naevus. Dermal clone composed of large spindled and epithelioid melanocytes (haematoxylin phloxine saffron stain).

definition: Recurrent naevus is a benign melanocytic naevus that recurs after incomplete removal.
clinical:
Recurrent naevus manifests as an area of pigmentation within a scar that can be uniformly pigmented or variegated causing clinical concern for melanoma. There is usually a history of a prior biopsy.

---

Recurrent naevus predominantly affects women aged 20–30 years.
pathogenesis:
Recurrent naevus develops after incomplete removal of the original naevus. It may also occur after local trauma or cryotherapy. Most lesions recur within the first 6 months after biopsy, and recurrence after 24 months is seen only rarely.

---

Recurrent naevus results from a proliferation of residual naevus cells.
microscopic: There is an atypical junctional and oftentimes superficial dermal melanocytic proliferation overlying a scar, beneath which there often are morphologically bland naevus cells. There is effacement of the rete ridge pattern and epidermal atrophy. The junctional component can be lentiginous with occasional pagetoid scatter and can have irregularly distributed nests. Melanocytes are epithelioid with mild to moderate cytological atypia. Occasionally the atypia is moderate to severe. Any dermal component is within the superficial portion of the scar and cytologically resembles the junctional component. Mitoses are rare. The atypical melanocytic proliferation should be strictly confined to the area of scar, an important distinction from melanoma. Review of the prior biopsy in diagnostically challenging cases is important to avoid misdiagnosis.
ancillary_studies: The proliferation rate in recurrent naevi is low. Immunohistochemistry for tyrosinase or HMB45 antigen shows decreased immunoreactivity in the deeper cells.
differential_diagnosis: The histological differential diagnosis includes melanoma, dysplastic naevus, sclerosing naevus, and dysplastic naevus with florid fibroplasia.
prognosis_and_prediction: Recurrent naevi are benign lesions.
related_terminology: Acceptable: persistent naevus; traumatized naevus. Not recommended: pseudomelanoma.

media.legend: Recurrent naevus. Trizonal pattern of recurrent naevus with atypical junctional component and dermal scar overlying residual banal dermal naevus.
Recurrent naevus. The junctional component is predominantly lentiginous and composed of epithelioid melanocytes overlying dermal scar.
Recurrent naevus. Irregular pigmentation involves a dermal scar related to previous naevus removal. Importantly, this pigmentation does not extend beyond the confines of the scar.
Recurrent naevus. Dermoscopy reveals radial lines, irregular clods, and centrifugal growth patterns confined to the scar.

Recurrent naevus. A compound melanocytic proliferation in association with a central scar. May simulate melanoma because of areas of single cell predominance and the presence of mild to moderate cytological atypia in the junctional component.

definition: Meyerson naevus is a benign naevus with superimposed spongiotic dermatitis.
clinical:
Erythema and scaling symmetrically surround and extend beyond the borders of the central naevus, producing an eczematous halo. The lesions may be pruritic. Multiple naevi may be involved, and similar patterns have been described for atypical naevi and melanomas.

---

Meyerson naevus typically occurs in young adults, with an equal sex distribution.
pathogenesis:
The eczematous reaction is probably triggered by factors within the naevus, because excision of the naevus has been reported to lead to regression of the accompanying inflammation. Meyerson naevus may be associated with atopic dermatitis.

---

Unknown
microscopic: Meyerson naevus is an acquired, dysplastic, or congenital naevus with superimposed acanthosis, spongiosis, and parakeratosis. Eosinophils may be present.
differential_diagnosis: Halo naevi lack the changes of spongiotic dermatitis and have an infiltrate predominant in CD8-positive lymphocytes, whereas Meyerson naevi show a predominance of CD4-positive T cells. Melanoma with associated spongiotic changes can be excluded with close examination of architectural and cytological features.
prognosis_and_prediction: Meyerson naevi are benign neoplasms.
related_terminology: Acceptable: eczematous naevus. Not recommended: halo eczema; halo dermatitis.

media.legend: Meyerson naevus. A compound naevus is associated with epidermal acanthosis, spongiosis, and parakeratosis.
Meyerson naevus. A central naevus is surrounded by a symmetrical erythematous eczematous plaque.
Meyerson naevus. A compound naevus has prominent spongiosis and a lymphocytic infiltrate, consistent with Meyerson “eczematous naevus”.

definition: Halo naevus is a naevus with circumferential depigmentation clinically, often associated with a brisk lymphocytic infiltrate histologically.
clinical:
Halo naevi often arise during the summer, perhaps because the halo contrasts better with tanned skin. They are most common in teenagers and young adults; can be associated with dysplastic naevi; and arise in multiplicity, beginning with the appearance of the halo around a compound naevus, followed by fading and disappearance of the naevus. The most common overall dermoscopic patterns are the uniform globular pattern and the structureless pattern. Halo naevi can be seen in patients with melanoma, sometimes in response to treatment, or in patients with vitiligo.

---

In the general population, the incidence of halo naevi is estimated to be 1%. The average age at presentation is 15 years. Patients with Turner syndrome have an increased incidence of halo naevi. There is no ethnic or sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Halo naevi represent an immune-mediated rejection of a common naevus.

---

Antigen-presenting cells and CD4-positive and CD8-positive T cells have been identified in the inflammatory infiltrates of halo naevi, implicating immunological mechanisms in the destruction of naevus cells. Affected individuals also show activated lymphocytes in their peripheral blood, as well as clonal expansion of T cells and IgM antibodies.
microscopic: Halo naevi are naevi with a superimposed dense lymphocytic infiltrate that partially or completely obscures the naevus cells. Melanin-laden histiocytes and mast cells may be present. Occasional halo naevi contain a few giant cells, or there may be a frankly granulomatous response. The clinically depigmented areas may show complete absence of junctional melanocytes histologically, and there may be a few scattered lymphocytes at the dermoepidermal interface. Hyperchromatism and mild to moderate pleomorphism are present in about 50% of halo naevi and are considered reactive. Mitotic figures are not usually seen.
ancillary_studies: SOX10 or melan-A can be useful to delineate the naevus cells. PRAME is usually negative.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis of involuting halo naevi includes other lichenoid interface reactions, such as those seen in lichenoid keratosis and melanoma with lichenoid inflammation. Findings suggestive of melanoma include the presence of a separate population of cells with an expansile pattern of growth; severe cytological atypia; and frequent mitoses, ulceration, or tumour necrosis. The halo phenomenon may occasionally involve other types of naevi, including dysplastic, Spitz, and congenital naevi, as well as melanomas. In most lesions, there is no intraepidermal melanocytic proliferation adjacent to the dermal component. If in situ or superficially invasive melanoma is present adjacent to a dermal lesion simulating halo naevus, the entire lesion is most likely melanoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Halo naevi are benign lesions. Adult-onset halo naevi are associated with a 1% risk of primary cutaneous melanoma development in the year after diagnosis, a risk comparable to that of individuals with a history of atypical naevi or a personal or family history of melanoma.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Sutton naevus; regressing naevus. Not recommended: leukoderma acquisitum centrifugum; perinaevoid vitiligo; perinaevoid leukoderma.

media.legend: Halo naevus. A papular pigmented lesion surrounded by a symmetrical depigmented halo, in a background of tan skin.

Halo naevus. A well-circumscribed lesion that at first glance could be mistaken for a lymphocytic infiltrate. Infiltrating lymphocytes are intimately admixed with naevus cells, which will lead to apoptosis and ultimately the disappearance of the naevus cells. In later examples, the naevus cells are less conspicuous than in this field.
Halo naevus. This field is at the shoulder of the lesion, beyond the lateral border of the dermal component.

Halo naevus. Dermoscopic features. White halo with increased vascularization of the underlying dermal plexus. Small papule with residual structureless brown pigmentation. The lesion was excised because it was the only halo naevus in an adult patient, and histopathology confirmed a halo naevus.
Halo naevus. 30-year-old otherwise healthy man. Recent onset of a white halo around a pre-existing naevus on the right shoulder.
Halo naevus. A well-circumscribed lesion that mimics a lymphocytic lesion. Infiltrating lymphocytes are intimately admixed with bland naevus cells.

entity_name: Special-site naevi (of the breast, axilla, scalp, and ear)
definition: Special-site naevi are benign melanocytic naevi occurring on the breast, axilla and other flexural sites, scalp, ear, umbilicus, and genitalia and showing atypical or unusual histopathological features that can make distinction from melanoma difficult.
clinical:
Special-site naevi are clinically innocuous, but they may show an increased size (typically > 6 mm) and irregular borders. Most patients are not aware of any recent lesional changes.

---

Atypical naevi of the breast occur in both sexes. Atypical naevi of the scalp occur more frequently in younger patients.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is similar to that of other melanocytic naevi. It is unclear whether special-site naevi are distinct clinicopathological entities or represent a histological variation of common acquired naevi.

---

The pathogenesis and molecular features have not been studied specifically but are likely to be similar to those of common and dysplastic naevi.
microscopic: Special-site naevi have architectural features that deviate from those of ordinary acquired naevi and overlap with those of dysplastic naevi and melanoma. These features include architectural disorder with asymmetry, an irregular arrangement of the junctional nests, cytological atypia, pagetoid spread, or dermal fibroplasia.
differential_diagnosis: Special-site naevi do not show increased mitotic activity or necrotic melanocytes, and the cells demonstrate maturation with descent into the deeper dermis. Dermoscopy is useful in distinguishing special-site naevi from melanoma. However, the dermoscopic features may be misleading, because special-site naevi can show a prominent pigment network with bizarre lines, as well as large globules, mimicking features of melanoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Special-site melanocytic naevi are benign, and no increased melanoma risk has been demonstrated.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular analyses are usually not necessary for the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: melanocytic naevi of special sites; naevi with site-related atypia.

media.legend: Special-site naevi of the breast. Clinical characteristics of breast naevi.
Special-site naevus of the groin. A nested and discohesive pattern is present with irregular junctional nests.
Special-site naevus of the umbilicus. Irregular nesting arrangement is present with a dyscohesive pattern, junctional cytological atypia, slight pagetoid spread, and dermal fibroplasia.

definition: Naevus spilus is a benign melanocytic naevus presenting as a hyperpigmented patch containing a variable number of darker macules or papules.
clinical:
Naevus spilus appears as a light-brown patch with black, brown, or reddish-brown macules or papules within it. It is usually 30–60 mm in diameter, and the speckles within it are commonly 2–3 mm in size. Approximately 80% of these lesions are present at birth or appear during early infancy. They may initially present as café-au-lait macules, with the hyperpigmented macules and papules developing later. In phakomatosis pigmentokeratotica (concomitant naevus sebaceus and naevus spilus), patients additionally have a separate orange-yellow pebbly plaque representing the naevus sebaceus.

---

The prevalence of naevus spilus (0.2–2.8% depending on age) is similar to that of congenital melanocytic naevi. There is no ethnic or sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Genetic and environmental factors may play a role in the occurrence of naevus spilus. Speckled lentiginous naevus syndrome has been characterized as a distinct neurocutaneous phenotype in which ipsilateral neurological abnormalities are present in association with naevus spilus.

---

Naevi spilus probably represent clonal populations of melanocytes resulting from a postzygotic HRAS mutation in a melanocyte precursor. The mutation is present in the background macule, with the individual darker papules having additional alterations, including amplification of the mutant HRAS allele. Mosaic translocations have been demonstrated in agminated Spitz naevi within a naevus spilus. Phakomatosis pigmentokeratotica may harbour HRAS or KRAS mutations.
microscopic: The background hyperpigmented patch has elongated, hyperpigmented rete ridges with slightly increased numbers of melanocytes. The speckles show variable findings, including those of lentiginous junctional, compound or intradermal, congenital-pattern, Spitz, or blue naevi, and naevi with cytological atypia.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes café-au-lait macules, agminated melanocytic naevi, and partial unilateral lentiginosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Naevus spilus is a benign neoplasm. Patients with larger or segmental manifestations of naevus spilus may be at increased risk of developing a melanoma.
cytology: None
related_terminology: Acceptable: speckled lentiginous naevus.

media.legend: Naevus spilus. A large tan patch with multiple small brown macules and papules within it.
Naevus spilus. A smaller form of naevus spilus shows a light-brown patch with three dark-brown macules.
Naevus spilus. Scanning magnification reveals subtle elongation of rete. On the right side of the photomicrograph is a compound naevus representing a small papule in the naevus spilus.
Naevus spilus. The tan patch of naevus spilus shows subtle elongate rete with a mildly increased number of small basilar melanocytes.
Naevus spilus. A small dark papule of naevus spilus shows a compound naevus without atypia.

Naevus spilus. In a background hyperpigmented patch that has elongated hyperpigmented rete ridges with slightly increased numbers of melanocytes, there are clinically evident speckles, in this case having the histopathological morphology of lentiginous compound naevi.

entity_name: Simple lentigo and lentiginous melanocytic naevus
definition: Simple lentigo and lentiginous melanocytic naevus are proliferations of individual melanocytes along the epidermal–dermal junction. Simple lentigo does not have nests but lentiginous melanocytic naevus does.
clinical:
Simple lentigo is a round to oval, uniformly pigmented macule typically < 5 mm in diameter (range: 3–15 mm). Rarely, multiple simple lentigines may be seen, including in familial eruptive lentiginosis and partial unilateral lentiginosis. In the autosomal dominant Noonan and LEOPARD syndromes, caused by mutations in PTPN11, multiple lentigines are seen in association with skeletal and cardiovascular aberrations. Lentiginous naevi are usually < 6 mm in diameter, symmetrical, and uniformly pigmented tan or brown, with a smooth border, and they may be macular or papular. Simple lentigines and lentiginous naevi typically show a reticulated pattern by dermoscopy.

---

Lentigines and lentiginous naevi are predominantly seen in White populations; they are less common in populations with darker skin tones. They may first occur in childhood, accruing into mid-life and diminishing in number with advanced age.
pathogenesis:
Risk factors include phenotypic factors such as Fitzpatrick type I skin, sun exposure, and genetically predisposing factors.

---

The specific nature of oncogenic alterations in benign melanocytic proliferations with a lentiginous growth pattern has not been studied. Simple lentigines lack BRAF p.V600E mutations.
microscopic: Simple lentigo is characterized by hyperpigmentation of basal layer epidermal keratinocytes with elongated rete ridges, and variably increased numbers of junctional melanocytes as solitary units. Lentiginous naevi additionally have nests of melanocytes, defined as a collection of three or more melanocytes. The cornified layer above the proliferation may contain melanin pigment. Junctional naevi do not have dermal melanocytes, whereas compound naevi do. Lentiginous melanocytes may display slight nuclear enlargement, few pigmented dendrites, and (rarely) pigmented cytoplasm. Nested intraepidermal melanocytes may have inconspicuous cytoplasm or display variable degrees of cytoplasmic pigment. Nuclear atypia is absent.
differential_diagnosis: The major criteria that distinguish melanoma include size, symmetry, circumscription, ulceration, cytological atypia, confluent lentiginous proliferation, pagetoid scatter, and dermal mitoses. Dysplastic naevi tend to be larger and have additional attributes (see section Dysplastic naevus).
prognosis_and_prediction: Simple lentigo and lentiginous naevi are benign lesions with a very low risk of progression to melanoma. Individuals with an increased total number of lentiginous naevi may be at increased risk of developing melanoma.
related_terminology: Acceptable: lentigo simplex (for simple lentigo). Not recommended: jentigo; naevus incipiens.

media.legend: Lentiginous junctional naevus. A small, symmetrical, macular or slightly raised, uniformly pigmented lesion.
Simple lentigo. Slightly elongated rete with epidermal pigmentation and individual pattern of melanocytes in the basal epidermis.

definition: Adenocarcinoma of mammary gland type comprises a group of primary vulval tumours showing histopathological features identical to breast carcinomas.
clinical:
Most patients are postmenopausal and present with a vulval mass.

---

These are rare vulval neoplasms.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Adenocarcinoma of mammary gland type is proposed to arise from anogenital mammary-like glands located in the anal and vulval area. Mutations in the genes of the PI3K/AKT cascade have been found in a few studied cases.
macroscopic: The macroscopic appearance is that of a solitary nodule with a fibrous cut surface, similar to breast carcinomas.
microscopic: The most common type is adenocarcinoma, which is identical to mammary invasive ductal carcinoma and may (uncommonly) have an identifiable in situ component in the adjacent glands. Rare types include lobular, tubulolobular, mixed ductal and lobular, and mammary analogue secretory carcinoma. There is commonly expression of ER, PR, GATA3, and ERBB2. Based on the immunoprofile, they can be classified like their breast counterparts into luminal A, luminal B, HER2-enriched, and basal-like subtypes.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Adenocarcinomas of mammary gland type are locally aggressive tumours that often metastasize to regional lymph nodes. Distant metastases are uncommon. Hormonal and anti-HER2 therapy may be helpful.
cytology: No data available
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not clinically relevant in most cases. Secretory carcinoma harbours the characteristic ETV6::NTRK3 fusion.
related_terminology: Acceptable: adenocarcinoma of anogenital mammary-like glands.

media.legend: Adenocarcinoma of the mammary-like glands of the vulva. Mammary-type tubulolobular carcinoma with areas of both tubular formation and a single-file pattern, resembling an invasive lobular carcinoma. Note the stromal and periductal elastosis.

definition: Extramammary Paget disease (EMPD) is a rare adenocarcinoma characterized by a predominant intraepithelial growth of neoplastic cells originating in the skin (primary EMPD) or representing intraepithelial spread of an underlying visceral carcinoma (secondary EMPD).
clinical:
The most common presentation is a relatively well-demarcated flat or slightly elevated, scaly, oozing, erythematous patch or plaque accompanied by pruritus or burning; thus, these lesions often clinically resemble eczema. They generally cover a large area (median: 20.5 cm2). Rare forms include lesions with hyperpigmentation or hypopigmentation and multicentric lesions (e.g. genital lesions associated with unilateral or bilateral axillary involvement, occurring synchronously or metachronously).

---

EMPD accounts for about 1% of all neoplasms in the anogenital area. It mostly occurs in White postmenopausal women, with a median age of about 70–75 years. Men are affected less often.
pathogenesis:
The inciting factors for primary EMPD are unknown, but it may represent colonization of the epidermis by carcinoma cells originating in the underlying glandular structures. It has been suggested that Toker cells might be a source for EMPD. Secondary EMPD represents skin involvement from an underlying carcinoma, most commonly originating from the lower gastrointestinal tract (distal colon or rectum) or urinary tract (urinary bladder or prostate).

---

The histogenesis of primary EMPD is unknown. ERBB2 amplification is rare, but ERBB2 (HER2) expression can be seen in a third of cases. Mutations in genes encoding the PI3K/AKT cascade have been found to significantly correlate with CDH1 hypermethylation. A study using comparative genomic hybridization revealed amplification at chromosomes Xcent-q21 and 19, and loss at 10q24-qter.
macroscopic: Patients present with a pruritic, erythematous, eczematous lesion mimicking a vulvar dermatosis or high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (VIN 3).
microscopic: The intraepithelial neoplastic cells (Paget cells) have vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli and abundant basophilic to amphophilic cytoplasm. They occur as solitary cells or well-demarcated solid nests or gland-like structures. Many cases also involve underlying skin adnexa, especially hair follicles and eccrine ducts. Occasionally, there is focal dermal invasion by single cells, glands, or small groups of cells (invasive Paget disease). Less common morphological changes include epidermal hyperplasia resembling syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum, syringoma-like structures, melanin pigment within the cytoplasm of the neoplastic cells simulating a melanocytic lesion, signet-ring cell morphology, and association with other vulvar lesions. Paget cells usually stain positively with mucicarmine, Alcian blue, and PAS reaction (diastase-resistant).
ancillary_studies: Primary EMPD is consistently positive for CK7 and GATA3 and with CAM5.2, and it often expresses CEA, GCDFP-15, ERBB2, CA125, and AR. ER and PR may be positive or negative.
differential_diagnosis: The most important issue is the distinction between primary and secondary EMPD. Coexpression of CK20 and CDX2 by the Paget cells and dirty necrosis (although the latter is unusual) support a colorectal origin. Uroplakin-3 expression is typical for urothelial carcinoma, whereas coexpression of PSA and NKX3-1 suggests an underlying prostatic carcinoma. Potential mimics of EMPD are vulvar Toker cells, vulvar and penile analogues of cervical stratified mucin-producing intraepithelial lesion, high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion, melanoma, pagetoid dyskeratosis, and clear cell papulosis. In addition to immunohistochemistry, clinicopathological correlation is essential for correct diagnosis.
staging: Staging depends on the subtype, primary versus secondary EMPD, and the location; for example, invasive vulval Paget disease is staged the same way as other vulval cancers. There is a proposal for TNM staging.
prognosis_and_prediction: The recurrence rate of primary EMPD is associated with positive surgical margins, multicentricity, and skip areas, but the overall mortality is similar to the general matched population. Primary EMPD with an invasive component is significantly associated with both lymph node metastasis and a worse prognosis. Cases with mutant PIK3CA and AKT1 are often invasive. Expression of CXCR4 and ACKR3 (CXCR7) appears to be associated with increased aggressiveness. There have been several studies evaluating the possible prognostic value of sentinel lymph nodes. The prognosis of secondary EMPD depends on the underlying malignancy.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Paget disease.

media.legend: Extramammary Paget disease. Clinical presentation in the anogenital area, involving the left labium majus.

Extramammary Paget disease. Intraepidermal proliferation of predominantly single cells with admixed nests throughout the epidermis. Individual cells are large, with ample amphophilic cytoplasm, a large nucleus, and prominent nucleoli.
Primary extramammary Paget disease. A case showing strong expression of CK7 in the intraepidermal tumour cells.
Secondary extramammary Paget disease from the urinary bladder. Strong expression of cytoplasmic CK20 in the intraepidermal tumour cells.
Secondary extramammary Paget disease from the urinary bladder. Strong nuclear expression p63 in the intraepidermal tumour cells.

definition: Mammary Paget disease (MPD) is a neoplastic lesion composed of malignant epithelial cells within the epidermis of the nipple and areola. In > 95% of cases, there is an underlying breast carcinoma.
clinical:
There is usually an eczematous scaly or crusted lesion confined to the nipple or areola, sometimes associated with ulceration or inversion of the nipple and discharge. Rare cases are pigmented, resembling a melanocytic lesion.

---

MPD accounts for 1–4% of all breast carcinomas. It almost exclusively affects women; < 1% of reported cases occurred in men. The age range is 26–88 years. About 10–28% of cases are incidental findings in the nipple in mastectomy specimens, particularly in prophylactic mastectomies in patients with BRCA mutations.
pathogenesis:
Most cases are associated with an underlying mammary carcinoma.

---

More than 95% of cases are associated with an underlying mammary cancer, representing a retrograde extension of the breast carcinoma into the epidermis in a contiguous fashion through spread along the lactiferous ducts. Cases without underlying carcinoma have been postulated to originate from Toker cells, a hypothesis supported by the observation of rare cases in which the Paget cells are genetically different from the neoplastic cells that form an underlying breast carcinoma.
macroscopic: The nipple may appear normal or (more commonly) erythematous.
microscopic: The neoplastic cells (Paget cells) have abundant weakly eosinophilic or pale-staining cytoplasm and large vesicular nuclei. They are scattered in the epidermis (pagetoid spread) in the form of solitary units, clusters, or (rarely) acinar/glandular structures. Skin adnexa can also be involved. Paget cells contain intracellular mucin in 40% of cases, and they may contain melanin due to phagocytosis (a possible diagnostic pitfall). The epidermis is often hyperkeratotic and acanthotic, especially in longstanding lesions. An underlying carcinoma (most commonly a high-grade invasive carcinoma) may be present in the specimen. Paget cells usually have an immunoprofile identical to that of the underlying carcinoma. They express low-molecular-weight cytokeratins (with CAM5.2), CK7, human milk fat globule, and mammary-type apomucin EMA. As many as 90% of cases are positive for ERBB2 (HER2). Approximately half of the cases express GCDFP-15. There is variable positivity for polyclonal CEA. AR has been found in most cases; ER and/or PR are present in approximately 10–30% of cases. Paget cells are negative for CK20. Rare CK7-negative cases retain expression of GATA3.
differential_diagnosis: Clinically, MPD must be distinguished from eczema and nipple adenoma. The histological differential diagnosis includes spongiotic dermatoses, candidiasis/dermatophytes, squamous cell carcinoma in situ (Bowen disease), and superficial spreading melanoma. Rare cases of clinically pigmented MPD contain melanin pigment, usually in isolated dendritic melanocytes, thus raising the possibility of melanoma. These isolated cells express melanocytic markers (melan-A [MART1], SOX10), while the surrounding Paget cells express CK7, EMA, and ERBB2 (HER2). In some cases, hyperplasia of Toker cells, a normal component of the nipple, may present a diagnostic dilemma.
staging: If no underlying carcinoma or ductal carcinoma in situ is present, MPD is staged as Tis according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification. If there is invasive carcinoma, it is staged according to the invasive component [[Brierley JD, Gospodarowicz MK, Wittekind C, editors. TNM classification of malignant tumours. 8th ed. Oxford (UK): Wiley-Blackwell; 2017.]].
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis of MPD is determined by the features of the associated mammary carcinoma and the stage of the disease. The 5-year overall survival rates are 94–98% and 73–93% in the presence of ductal carcinoma in situ and underlying invasive carcinoma, respectively. Detection of invasion from the epidermis does not seem to correlate with an impaired prognosis.
cytology: Some authors have suggested the use of imprint cytology diagnosis, although this is not a widely used technique.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: There is no known association with a specific gene mutation, although it has been suggested that the MSI1/mTOR pathway may drive the pathogenesis of mammary and extramammary Paget disease. Genetically, Paget cells are similar to the underlying carcinoma cells in most cases.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Paget disease of breast; Paget disease of the nipple; breast carcinoma involving nipple skin.

media.legend: Mammary Paget disease. A low-power view of ductal carcinoma in situ associated with Paget disease.
Mammary Paget disease. Higher-power view showing a comedo growth pattern.

Invasive mammary Paget disease. Isolated or small clusters of Paget cells invading through the basement membrane into the superficial dermis. Infiltrating cells are large with abundant pale cytoplasm, histologically similar to the intraepidermal Paget cells.
Invasive mammary Paget disease. A section of nipple with intraepidermal and dermal involvement. The line indicates the depth of invasion.
Mammary Paget disease. Paget cells are readily visualized with immunohistochemical staining for ERBB2 (HER2) (shown here) and CK7 (<<37883>>).
Mammary Paget disease. Paget cells are readily visualized with immunohistochemical staining for ERBB2 (HER2) (<<37882>>) and CK7 (shown here).
Mammary Paget disease. Paget cells in breast epidermis.
Mammary Paget disease. The gross appearance of a nipple affected by Paget disease shows an erythematous area with erosion, scaling, and crust formation.

Mammary Paget disease with ductal carcinoma in situ. Tumour nests, glandular structures, and pagetoid cells are present in the epidermis. Papillary dermis shows inflammation. Ductal carcinoma in situ is observed in one of the sections.

entity_name: Fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumour of anogenital mammary-like glands
definition: Fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumour of anogenital mammary-like glands are biphasic fibroepithelial neoplasms composed of an epithelial glandular component and a predominant stromal component. They are microscopically identical to their mammary homologues.
clinical:
Fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumour occur as solitary nodules measuring 8–60 mm (mean size: 30 mm). In the reported cases, the age at diagnosis was 20–69 years (mean: 39 years).

---

Both tumours are very uncommon, with < 80 cases reported to date. Most patients are female.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The tumours are thought to arise from anogenital mammary-like glands. One study identified AKT1 and MET mutations in fibroadenoma and ABL1 and TP53 mutations in low-grade phyllodes tumour. Single cases of fibroadenoma and phyllodes tumour have been reported in patients with PTEN hamartoma tumour syndrome / Cowden syndrome.
macroscopic: These neoplasms are circumscribed solid masses and may have small cystic spaces. In phyllodes tumours, leaf-like structures may be evident grossly. The size range from < 10 mm to 60 mm or larger.
microscopic: Fibroadenoma is a well-circumscribed neoplasm composed of round or elongated, often branching and anastomosing glandular structures surrounded by a paucicellular stroma containing bland spindled or stellate cells, showing low or practically no mitotic activity. When the glandular lumina maintain round or oval configurations, the image is that of a pericanalicular growth pattern, whereas abundant stroma compressing the glandular elements into slit-like structures produces an intracanalicular pattern. Phyllodes tumour shows a growth pattern with leaf-like projections into glandular lumina. The stroma is usually hypercellular, typically with periglandular condensation; cellularity commonly varies within a given neoplasm. Three categories are delineated: benign, low-grade, and high-grade; the grade is defined by stromal atypia. Most vulvar phyllodes tumours are either benign or low-grade; high-grade tumours are extremely rare. Rare features in these tumours include mammary-type ductal lesions, hyperplasia of myoepithelial cells, pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia (PASH), various types of metaplasia in the glandular component and stroma, and lactation-like changes.
ancillary_studies: The epithelial component stains for ER, PR, and GATA3, whereas ERBB2 (HER2) is negative. Stromal cells, including those in PASH areas, are positive for vimentin and CD34 and variably positive for actins. Vascular markers are negative in PASH.
differential_diagnosis: Fibroadenoma and benign phyllodes tumour manifest overlapping features; in some cases, distinguishing between them can be difficult. Generally, phyllodes tumours have more-cellular stroma (with variation within a lesion), less regular outlines, and leaf-like projections. Focal connection to the epidermal surface with numerous plasma cells may resemble syringocystadenoma papilliferum. Fibroepithelial foci resembling fibroadenoma may rarely be found in other complex lesions of anogenital mammary-like glands. Fibrocystic disease and other lesions with prominent ductal hyperplasia may be differential diagnoses in a limited specimen. Lactation-like change (secretory hyperplasia) must not be confused with malignancy; the presence of intracytoplasmic vacuoles and intraluminal secretion is the clue to the diagnosis. PASH should be distinguished from low-grade angiosarcoma, which exhibits at least mild nuclear pleomorphism and immunopositivity for vascular markers.
prognosis_and_prediction: Most cases are benign. Local recurrence can occur in phyllodes tumours.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: None

Fibroadenoma of anogenital mammary-like glands. The biphasic neoplasm is composed of elongated, branching, and anastomosing glandular structures surrounded by paucicellular stroma; the glandular lumina maintain round to oval configurations (a pericanalicular growth pattern).
Phyllodes tumour of anogenital mammary-like glands. Benign tumour with a leaf-like growth pattern and stromal hypercellularity.

definition: Hidradenoma papilliferum is a benign tumour associated with anogenital mammary-like glands, characterized by branching and interconnecting epithelial and stromal elements, microscopically resembling mammary intraductal papilloma.
clinical:
The lesion occurs as a solitary asymptomatic nodule or cyst-like lesion measuring 2–20 mm.

---

Hidradenoma papilliferum is the most common benign glandular neoplasm of the vulva. It almost exclusively affects White women aged 20–89 years; it occurs rarely in children and in Black populations.
pathogenesis:
Hidradenoma papilliferum is thought to arise from anogenital mammary-like glands.

---

Tumorigenic alterations in the PI3K/AKT and MAPK pathway have been identified.
macroscopic: The tumour is typically a tan or red nodule with a solid to variably cystic cut surface.
microscopic: Hidradenoma papilliferum appears as a well-circumscribed intradermal solid-cystic nodule with a complex pattern of branching and anastomosing tubules interconnected in a labyrinthine manner, focally forming papillae. The tubules and papillae consist of a central axis of fibrous tissue lined by a luminal layer of epithelial cells surrounded by a layer of myoepithelial cells. Decapitation secretion is common. Cystic change, sclerosing adenosis–like and mammary-type ductal changes, and necrosis have been identified. Oxyphilic metaplasia, especially in areas with solid growth with nuclear polymorphism, may simulate adenocarcinoma. Remnants of anogenital mammary-like gland adjacent to the lesion can be seen.
prognosis_and_prediction: This is a benign neoplasm. Cases of carcinoma (including ductal carcinoma in situ) arising in hidradenoma papilliferum have been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Acceptable: papillary hidradenoma.

media.legend: Hidradenoma papilliferum. Well-circumscribed cystic neoplasm with prominent papillary projections.

Hidradenoma papilliferum. The double epithelial lining consists of a peripheral layer of cuboidal myoepithelial cells and a luminal layer of columnar cells, many of which exhibit decapitation secretion.
Hidradenoma papilliferum. Clinical appearance of a vulvar lesion in a 52-year-old female patient.

Hidradenoma papilliferum. Well-circumscribed dermal lesion composed of packed glands with papillary projections into cystic lumina. Glands are lined by double layer of cells: inner layer of tall columnar cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and outer layer of myoepithelial cells. Some decapitation secretions are seen within the lumen.

definition: Sebaceous carcinoma is a malignant epithelial neoplasm demonstrating sebaceous differentiation. Depending on their anatomical location, sebaceous carcinomas are divided into extraocular and periocular (eyelid) sebaceous carcinomas.
clinical:
Patients with sebaceous carcinoma present with a tan-pink-yellow, firm, occasionally nodular lesion measuring 10–30 mm. Periocular sebaceous carcinoma may be mistaken clinically for benign inflammatory or neoplastic conditions, leading to a delay in diagnosis and to higher morbidity and mortality. Pagetoid sebaceous carcinoma may resemble chronic blepharoconjunctivitis.

---

Sebaceous carcinoma develops in older adults, with no sex predilection. The median age at diagnosis is 73 years. The estimated incidence rate per 1 million person-years is approximately 2 cases in White populations, 1 among Asians and Pacific Islanders, and 0.5 in Black populations. Asians and Pacific Islanders appear to be more predisposed to develop a periocular sebaceous carcinoma than other populations.
pathogenesis:
Risk factors include prior radiotherapy, sun exposure, viral infections (HIV and HPV), immunosuppression, and Muir–Torre syndrome, although periocular tumours have almost no association with Muir–Torre syndrome or mismatch repair defects.

---

Extraocular sebaceous carcinomas can be grouped into three molecular-genetic classes based on whether they show an ultraviolet (UV) radiation signature, a paucimutational signature, or a microsatellite instability (MSI) signature. Sebaceous carcinomas with a UV radiation signature carry the highest frequency of mutations, including TP53, RREB1, and NOTCH family mutations. MSI-related sebaceous carcinomas more commonly carry HRAS and KRAS mutations together with TP53, RB1, RREB1, and NOTCH family member mutations. Although defective mismatch repair may be seen in some extraocular sebaceous carcinomas, most of these mutations are somatically acquired, rather than related to Muir–Torre syndrome. Finally, paucimutational sebaceous carcinomas show fewer mutations, but HRAS and NOTCH1 mutations are observed. Periocular sebaceous carcinomas often harbour mutations in TP53, RB1, NOTCH family genes, and ZNF750, as well as gain of the MYC locus. A small subset of cases are related to high-risk HPV infection, and these occur in younger patients, with fewer recurrences.
microscopic: Well-differentiated sebaceous carcinoma consists of lobules of polygonal tumour cells with atypical, oval vesicular nuclei and abundant intracytoplasmic vacuoles that impart a foamy appearance and impinge on the nucleus, creating scalloping. Central comedo-type necrosis may be seen. More poorly differentiated tumours show a higher N:C ratio, nuclear pleomorphism, prominent nucleoli, basophilic cytoplasm with fewer intracellular vacuoles, and brisk mitotic activity. Sebaceous carcinoma may show basaloid, squamoid (often with keratin pearl formation), spindle cell / sarcomatoid, or neuroendocrine (rippled or organoid growth) features. Invasive tumours can adopt various architectural patterns, including well-circumscribed lobules with pushing borders and variable comedonecrosis, papillary architecture, and highly infiltrative cords; combinations of these patterns are often observed. Of note, whereas sebaceous carcinomas with a UV radiation signature tend to be more poorly differentiated, MSI-related tumours show more well-differentiated histopathological features. Approximately 60% of cases carry an intraepithelial component (pagetoid spread) with extension along and partial replacement of pre-existing pilosebaceous units in the skin, and pseudoglands of Henle in the conjunctiva. Notably, intraepithelial skip lesions may also occur, and sebaceous carcinoma in situ (restricted to the epithelium) may be encountered.
ancillary_studies: Sebaceous carcinoma shows immunoreactivity for pancytokeratin (and also CK7), adipophilin, EMA, BerEP4, AR, p40, and p63. EMA labelling may enhance the cytoplasmic vacuolization of the tumour cells, but it is often only positive in well-differentiated tumours and lacks specificity. Adipophilin is a more sensitive and specific marker of sebaceous differentiation. Positivity for CD10, DOG1, KIT (CD117), p16, p53, perforin, and factor XIIIa has also been reported in sebaceous carcinoma.
differential_diagnosis: Sebaceous carcinoma should be excluded when examining basaloid, squamoid, and clear cell epithelial tumours in periocular locations. The differential diagnosis includes sebaceoma, balloon cell melanoma, clear cell squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, Merkel cell carcinoma, and metastatic clear cell carcinomas from visceral organs.
staging: The eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system forms the basis for staging. The application of the eighth edition of the AJCC system was found to be useful in predicting nodal metastasis; however, local recurrence and distant metastasis were not significantly correlated to the T classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Both periocular and extraocular sebaceous carcinomas have a 30–40% risk of local tumour recurrence, a 20–25% risk of distant metastasis, and a 10–30% risk of tumour-related mortality. Approximately 70% of all patients with sebaceous carcinoma survive for ≥ 5 years after diagnosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not relevant for individual tumours. Germline sequencing may be indicated in some cases.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Meibomian gland carcinoma (periocular).

media.legend: Sebaceous carcinoma. Proliferation of neoplastic cells with sebaceous differentiation, showing multivesicular cytoplasmic clearing; focal squamoid differentiation is evident.
Sebaceous carcinoma. Bubbly cytoplasmic vacuolization, pleomorphism, and mitotic activity are evident.
Sebaceous carcinoma. Oil Red O staining highlights the presence of lipid vacuoles.
Sebaceous carcinoma. Immunostaining for adipophilin highlights the intracytoplasmic vacuoles.
Sebaceous carcinoma in Muir–Torre syndrome. A large nodular lesion on nasal skin with ulceration and a yellowish appearance.
Sporadic sebaceous carcinoma. A nodular lesion on the forehead.

definition: Sebaceous adenoma is a benign neoplasm composed mostly of fully differentiated sebocytes, admixed with immature basaloid epithelial cells.
clinical:
Sebaceous adenoma is a well-circumscribed yellow-tan nodule (5–15 mm). Lesions associated with Muir–Torre syndrome may be multifocal and can have a central cystic area or a papillomatous morphology resembling keratoacanthoma. Mismatch repair (MMR)-deficient sebaceous neoplasms occur more commonly outside of the head and neck area than do MMR-stable sebaceous neoplasms.

---

Sebaceous adenomas are principally seen as solitary lesions in people aged > 40 years. They are usually located in sun-damaged skin of the head and neck area. Lesions associated with Muir–Torre syndrome may be multifocal and located at other anatomical sites.
pathogenesis:
Sebaceous adenomas may arise through defective MMR, which manifests as loss of expression of MMR gene products, including MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2; a subset of these lesions are related to Muir–Torre syndrome. Preserved expression of all four proteins suggests microsatellite stability, whereas loss of nuclear staining for any of the proteins indicates deficient MMR, suggests the candidate gene, and indicates the need for further testing (see section Muir–Torre syndrome). However, clinical parameters outperform MMR immunohistochemical studies for identifying patients at risk for Muir–Torre syndrome. Moreover, a newly described rare autosomal recessive form of Muir–Torre syndrome lacks all aberrations in the expression of MMR gene products.

---

Next-generation sequencing studies of sebaceous adenomas have found frequent mutation of RAS family genes (HRAS and KRAS), TP53, CDKN2A, EGFR, and CTNNB1. Abnormalities in TP53 were most common.
microscopic: Sebaceous adenomas are well-circumscribed lobular aggregates composed mostly of mature sebocytes, with a variable rim of immature basaloid cells, recapitulating normal sebaceous glands. The mature sebocytes are characterized by an abundant vacuolated, bubbly cytoplasm and a central scalloped nucleus, and these sebocytes predominate (> 50% of all tumour cells) over the small monomorphic immature basaloid cells. Sebaceous adenoma may show a direct connection to the overlying epidermis, which may be covered by keratin and cellular debris. MMR-deficient sebaceous neoplasms show cystic change, intratumoural mucin, squamous metaplasia, ulceration, a lymphocytic infiltrate, and intertumoural heterogeneity more often than do MMR-stable sebaceous neoplasms.
ancillary_studies: The vacuolated cytoplasm of the mature sebocytes expresses EMA and adipophilin.
differential_diagnosis: The principal differential diagnosis for sebaceous adenoma is sebaceous hyperplasia, in which sebaceous lobules are arranged around a central follicle that is connected to the epidermis, but sebaceous hyperplasia shows a clear association with a central hair follicle, whereas sebaceous adenoma does not. Sebaceoma is another benign nodular lesion composed of a more equal admixture of basaloid epithelial cells and small groups of vacuolated sebocytes. Considerable morphological overlap may exist between sebaceous adenoma and sebaceoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Sebaceous adenoma is a benign lesion, and simple excision is curative. However, the subset of patients with this tumour who have Muir–Torre syndrome may experience morbidity and mortality from associated visceral malignancies.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not relevant for individual tumours. Germline sequencing may be indicated in some cases.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Sebaceous adenoma. A well-circumscribed lobulated proliferation of sebocytes with admixed basaloid cells; sebocytes are predominant; minimal cytological atypia is present.
Sebaceous adenoma. Low-power view of a cystic lesion containing predominantly clear cells (sebocytes). The patient had Muir–Torre syndrome.
Sebaceous adenoma. A nodular sebaceous and basaloid proliferation showing predominance of sebaceous glands, with a minority of basaloid cells without atypia.

definition: Sebaceoma is a benign adnexal neoplasm showing sebaceous differentiation. It is characterized by rounded, cellular lobules and microcystic spaces and consists mostly of immature basaloid cells admixed with occasional mature sebocytes (< 50% of the lesion).
clinical:
Sebaceomas are solitary, yellow-tan papules/nodules. They may rarely arise in a pre-existing sebaceous naevus. Lesions associated with Muir–Torre syndrome may be multifocal. Mismatch repair (MMR)-deficient sebaceous neoplasms occur more commonly outside of the head and neck area than do MMR-stable sebaceous neoplasms.

---

Sebaceomas may be associated with Muir–Torre syndrome, part of Lynch syndrome (see the Digestive System Tumours and Genetic Tumour Syndromes volumes of this series [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Digestive system tumours. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2019. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 1). https://publications.iarc.who.int/579.]] [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Genetic tumour syndromes [Internet; beta version ahead of print]. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2023. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 14). https://tumourclassification.iarc.who.int/chapters/67.]]). The mean patient age at diagnosis is 70 years, and there is a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
Sebaceomas may arise through defective MMR, which manifests as a loss of expression of MMR gene products, including MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2; a subset of these lesions are related to Muir–Torre syndrome. Preserved expression of all four proteins suggests microsatellite stability, whereas loss of nuclear staining for any of the proteins indicates deficient MMR, suggests the candidate gene, and indicates the need for further testing (see section Muir–Torre syndrome). However, clinical parameters outperform MMR immunohistochemical studies for identifying patients at risk for Muir–Torre syndrome. Moreover, a newly described rare autosomal recessive form of Muir–Torre syndrome lacks all aberrations in the expression of MMR gene products.

---

Next-generation sequencing studies of sebaceomas have found frequent mutation of RAS family genes (HRAS and KRAS), TP53, CDKN2A, EGFR, and CTNNB1. Abnormalities of TP53 were most common.
microscopic: Sebaceoma consists of well-circumscribed cellular lobules composed mostly of small monomorphic immature basaloid cells admixed with fewer mature sebocytes (< 50%), haphazardly distributed throughout the tumour. Mature sebocytes have abundant cytoplasmic vacuoles that produce scalloped nuclei. Duct-like structures and cystic areas may be seen, which often show an eosinophilic cuticle and occasionally contain holocrine secretions. Infundibulocystic structures, squamous metaplasia, and apocrine differentiation can also be observed. Mitotic figures may be common in the immature component, but atypical forms and necrosis are not expected. A variety of growth patterns have been described in sebaceoma, sometimes even within the same neoplasm, including reticulated (rippled), cribriform, sinusoidal/labyrinthine, carcinoid-like, and glandular configurations. EMA and adipophilin are immunohistochemical markers associated with the membranes of the cytoplasmic vacuoles. They provide a bubbly appearance in many mature sebocytes and occasional immature basaloid cells of sebaceous lesions. MMR-deficient sebaceous neoplasms show cystic change, intratumoural mucin, squamous metaplasia, ulceration, a lymphocytic infiltrate, and intertumoural heterogeneity more often than do MMR-stable sebaceous neoplasms.
differential_diagnosis: Sebaceous carcinoma and sebaceous adenoma are the most common differential diagnoses. BerEP4 negativity may help in the distinction from basal cell carcinoma. Some other cutaneous neoplasms, such as squamous cell carcinomas and basal cell carcinomas, may show very focal sebaceous differentiation. Many reported cases of so-called ripple-pattern trichoblastomas are in fact sebaceoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Sebaceoma is a benign lesion, and simple excision is curative. However, the subset of patients with this tumour who have Muir–Torre syndrome may experience morbidity and mortality from associated visceral malignancies. Rare examples of malignant transformation to sebaceous carcinoma have been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not relevant for individual tumours. Germline sequencing may be indicated in some cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: sebaceous epithelioma.

media.legend: Sebaceoma. Low-power view showing a nodular proliferation of sebaceous and basaloid cells.
Sebaceoma. There is a predominance of basaloid cells; minimal cytological atypia may be seen.
Sebaceoma. A nodular sebaceous and basaloid proliferation showing predominance of basaloid cells, with minimal cytological atypia.

definition: Trichilemmal carcinoma is a malignant adnexal neoplasm with outer root sheath differentiation. By this definition, trichilemmal carcinoma is the malignant counterpart of trichilemmoma.
clinical:
Trichilemmal carcinoma manifests as an erythematous, tan, or flesh-coloured papule; a keratotic nodule; or an indurated plaque mimicking squamous or basal cell carcinoma. It is frequently ulcerated. Trichilemmal carcinoma may arise in patients exposed to chronic actinic damage, receiving radiotherapy treatment with long latency periods, or affected by xeroderma pigmentosum. It can also occur in solid-organ transplant recipients. Presentation with multiple tumours and occurrence in Black patients has been reported.

---

Trichilemmal carcinoma has a predilection for elderly individuals; the majority of cases occur between the seventh and ninth decades of life. There is no sex predominance.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Some cases originate from pre-existing trichilemmoma.

---

The pathogenesis seems to be related to actinic damage, long-term low-dose X-irradiation, previous trauma or scar, or malignant transformation of trichilemmoma. Genetic disorders (xeroderma pigmentosum), and immunosuppression for solid-organ transplantation may play a role. Loss of the tumour suppressor gene TP53 may contribute to the development of trichilemmal carcinoma.
microscopic: Trichilemmal carcinoma is characterized by a proliferation of tumoural lobules (composed of large atypical cells with clear cytoplasm) with a sharply defined border and pushing margins continuous with the epidermis or pilosebaceous structures. The tumour cells give a positive PAS reaction, and there are prominent nucleoli, frequent mitoses, and foci of trichilemmal keratinization. At the periphery of the lobules, the keratinocytes show palisading and are surrounded by a prominent connective tissue sheath. The tumour is more commonly associated with an invasive component centred on a pilosebaceous unit and may show pagetoid spread in the overlying epidermis. The tumour cells are strongly positive for p53 and focally positive for CD34 (My10), which is a marker of differentiation from the outer root sheath. They are usually negative for EMA. Trichilemmal carcinoma also expresses CK1, CK10, CK14, CK7, and CK17, suggesting that it differentiates towards the follicular infundibulum [[Rongioletti F, Margaritescu I, Smoller BR, editors. Rare malignant skin tumours. Berlin (Germany): Springer; 2015.]].
differential_diagnosis: The main differential diagnosis of trichilemmal carcinoma is clear cell squamous cell carcinoma, although these tumours are considered by some authors to be the same entity. Squamous cell carcinoma with clear cells lacks trichilemmal keratinization and lobular proliferation. Trichilemmal carcinoma must be distinguished from other skin cancers with clear cell changes. The identification of ductal differentiation with CEA and EMA staining is useful for differentiating hidradenocarcinoma from trichilemmal carcinoma. Desmoplastic trichilemmoma may rarely exhibit an infiltrative growth pattern but lacks pleomorphism and mitoses. Malignant proliferating trichilemmal tumour, which is often confused with trichilemmal carcinoma, demonstrates extensive areas of necrosis, abrupt keratinization, minimal pleomorphism, low mitotic activity, and foci resembling a trichilemmal cyst. Sebaceous carcinoma is distinguished by the presence of multiple intracytoplasmic lipid-rich vacuoles indenting the nucleus.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Trichilemmal carcinoma is a low-grade malignancy with a good prognosis that exceptionally can metastasize. Tumour-free margins are needed because of the potential for local invasion and recurrence, and Mohs micrographic surgery can be considered in the head and neck region for tumour eradication. Prognostic factors are limited to lymph node status and the status of surgical margins.
related_terminology: Acceptable: tricholemmal carcinoma; trichilemmomal carcinoma.

media.legend: Trichilemmal carcinoma. High-power view showing the vacuolated cytoplasm and the irregular shape of the nests, with stromal invasion.
Trichilemmal carcinoma. Low-power view showing a poorly circumscribed infiltrative lesion with a central cystic area.

definition: Trichoblastic carcinoma is a biphasic malignant neoplasm with dual differentiation towards the specialized follicular stroma (like that of trichoblastoma) and germinative follicular cells, which can be strikingly atypical. Trichoblastic carcinosarcoma is a rare biphasic follicular neoplasm consisting of a malignant epithelial component resembling follicular germinative cells closely associated with a malignant stromal component differentiating towards specific follicular mesenchyme.
clinical:
These neoplasms appear to affect elderly patients and present as a solitary nodule.

---

Both neoplasms are very rare and probably underrecognized. Fewer than 10 cases of bona fide trichoblastic carcinosarcoma have been reported.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Genetic variants of CDKN2A, TP53, TERT promoter, CTNNB1, and SUFU have been described in trichoblastic carcinosarcoma.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with well-demarcated or poorly demarcated, unencapsulated nodules.
microscopic: Trichoblastic carcinoma is an invasive but well-circumscribed neoplasm composed of a stromal component identical to that of trichoblastoma and a basaloid component that shows moderate to severe atypia. In trichoblastic carcinosarcoma, both the epithelial and the mesenchymal components are malignant, with pleomorphic cells, abnormal mitotic figures, crowding, and hyperchromasia. Each epithelial nodule is intimately associated with the stroma, which recapitulates specific follicular mesenchyme by virtue of papilla-like aggregations that are often aligned across a broad front, resembling continuous papillae. Despite their close association throughout the tumour, the epithelial and stromal cells are sharply separated, with no gradual transition between the two elements; this is an important feature distinguishing this neoplasm from sarcomatoid (metaplastic) basal cell carcinoma.
differential_diagnosis: Trichoblastic carcinoma is distinguished from trichoblastoma by atypia in the epithelial component. Basal cell carcinoma lacks the specialized follicular stroma and is composed of basaloid epithelial cells that are less atypical than those seen in trichoblastic carcinoma/carcinosarcoma. In basal cell carcinoma with sarcomatoid differentiation, the transition between the epithelial and mesenchymal components is gradual, and the mesenchymal component appears as pleomorphic sarcoma rather than resembling follicular papillae. Trichoblastic carcinoma should be differentiated from benign plaque-like trichoblastomas that occur around the mouth and frequently involve the underlying skeletal muscle, which is a normal constituent of the deep dermis in this area.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Reported cases have shown indolent biological behaviour after complete removal. The term trichoblastic carcinoma has been used by some authors for various tumours occurring as a result of malignant transformation of a pre-existing trichoblastoma, and some of these tumours have demonstrated an aggressive clinical course, associated with incomplete removal.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Not recommended: malignant trichoblastoma.

media.legend: Trichoblastic carcinoma. This entity resembles a trichoblastoma due to its epithelial basaloid (follicular germinative) cell nodules associated with abundant specific follicular stroma, but unlike in trichoblastoma, there is cellular atypia in the epithelial component and atypical mitotic figures.

Trichoblastic carcinosarcoma. The epithelial component is composed of basaloid cells resembling those seen in conventional basal cell carcinoma but showing nuclear crowding, abnormal mitotic figures, and necrosis. Germ-like structures are present focally. The epithelial component is intimately associated with the stroma, which recapitulates specific follicular mesenchyme by virtue of its papilla-like aggregations but is composed of clearly atypical cells with numerous abnormal mitotic figures, crowding, and hyperchromasia.
Trichoblastic carcinosarcoma. The tumour is composed of epithelial and stromal components with distinctive appearances.
Trichoblastic carcinoma. A large ulcerated nodule shown to be a trichoblastic carcinoma by histology.
High-grade trichoblastic carcinoma. Low-power examination shows a dermal malignant neoplasm in association with a residuum of benign trichoblastoma, with a detectable zone of transformation.
High-grade trichoblastic carcinoma. The superficial portion of the biphasic tumour shows small nodular aggregations of follicular germinative cells and small infundibulocystic structures.

High-grade trichoblastic carcinoma. The deeper large neoplastic aggregates demonstrate comedo-like necrosis and are composed of basaloid cells with severe cytological atypia. Note the presence of numerous atypical mitoses.

definition: Pilomatrical carcinoma is an adnexal carcinoma with matrical differentiation.
clinical:
Pilomatrical carcinoma presents as a solitary, often ulcerated nodule.

---

Pilomatrical carcinoma is rare. Most cases develop in middle-aged or elderly individuals.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The WNT signalling pathway has been implicated in the pathogenesis of pilomatrical carcinoma. LEF1 and CDX2 have been postulated to regulate the pathway. Cytogenetic analysis in a few cases of pilomatrical carcinoma have demonstrated mutations in exon 3 of the gene encoding β-catenin (CTNNB1).
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a poorly circumscribed dermal tumour, often covered by ulcerated skin.
microscopic: Pilomatrical carcinoma is poorly circumscribed and infiltrative, and it involves the deep dermis, subcutaneous tissue, and even skeletal muscle and fascia. The lesion is composed of solid aggregates of immature basaloid matrical cells with scant cytoplasm, a vesicular nucleus, a prominent nucleolus, and numerous mitoses. Atypical mitoses may be seen. Shadow cells are less abundant in pilomatrical carcinoma than in pilomatricoma, but they are characteristic and useful in the diagnosis. In some cases, inner root sheath differentiation (including trichohyalin granules and nests of bluish-grey cornified material) can be seen. More frequently, necrosis en masse results in cystic spaces containing keratin and cellular debris between the aggregates of matrical cells. Uncommon histopathological findings include desmoplastic stroma, lymphovascular and perineural invasion, and a sarcomatoid component.
ancillary_studies: Pilomatrical carcinomas show both nuclear and cytoplasmic staining for β-catenin in the basaloid matrical cells, as well as nuclear expression of CDX2 and LEF1; BerEP4 is negative.
differential_diagnosis: Pilomatrical carcinoma should be distinguished from pilomatricoma and basal cell carcinoma with matrical differentiation. Pilomatricoma is a benign cystic neoplasm that appears as a symmetrical, well-circumscribed lesion with regular and smooth borders; it usually does not show any areas of necrosis en masse or the cytological atypia seen in pilomatrical carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma with matrical differentiation is a neoplasm with all the architectural and cytological features of a basal cell carcinoma, and focal aggregates of shadow cells; rarely, areas with matrical differentiation predominate and display some degree of cytological atypia.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Pilomatrical carcinomas may develop regional lymph node or visceral metastasis, and patients may die as a consequence of the tumour. Recurrence appears to be a risk factor for metastasis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: pilomatrix carcinoma. Not recommended: calcifying epithelial carcinoma of Malherbe; malignant pilomatrixoma; malignant pilomatricoma; matrical carcinoma; matrix carcinoma.

media.legend: Pilomatrical carcinoma. Scanning magnification showing a nodular lesion with large areas of necrosis.
Pilomatrical carcinoma. Higher magnification showing solid aggregates composed of matrical, intermediate, and shadow cells.
Pilomatrical carcinoma. Still higher magnification showing neoplastic matrical cells around aggregates of shadow cells.
Pilomatrical carcinoma. Clinical appearance of a lesion on the neck.

Pilomatrical carcinoma. In the upper part of the tumour, a pilomatricoma, with some infiltrative borders. In the lower part, the tumour is poorly circumscribed, with numerous solid aggregates of immature and sometimes larger basaloid matrical cells, often with central necrosis.

definition: Proliferating trichilemmal tumour (PTT) is a solid-cystic neoplasm with differentiation towards the isthmic part of the outer root sheath. PTT encompasses a morphological spectrum including benign, atypical (intermediate), and rare malignant lesions.
clinical:
PTT usually manifests as a solitary, slow-growing, exophytic lesion, 20–250 mm in size. Some lesions grow rapidly and may develop ulceration. In 1 reported case, a tumour developed in a pre-existent naevus sebaceus.

---

PTT most commonly occurs in women aged > 40 years.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Some cases develop from a pre-existing trichilemmal cyst. Malignant PTT can develop in patients with multiple trichilemmal cysts.

---

Aneuploidy has been demonstrated in some cases by flow cytometry. TP53 mutations and loss of heterozygosity at 17p have been described in the malignant areas of malignant PTT. CTNNB1 mutations do not seem to play a role in the histogenesis of the neoplasm.
macroscopic: PTT is a large, often multinodular, solid-cystic tumour.
microscopic: PTT displays a morphological continuum. At one end of the spectrum, it appears as a well-circumscribed dermal solid and cystic neoplasm, sometimes involving the subcutaneous tissue. In addition to the typical features of a trichilemmal cyst, the tumour is characterized by prominent epithelial infoldings into the cystic cavity. Small, basaloid cells displaying peripheral palisading are arranged along a thick vitreous membrane, and inner layers of the neoplasm show differentiation towards large monomorphic keratinocytes with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, lacking significant atypia, with low mitotic activity and abrupt keratinization in the absence of a granular layer. Areas of calcification and abundant cholesterol crystals are frequently seen within the compact eosinophilic keratin. The other end of the morphological spectrum is represented by tumours with malignant features including infiltrative growth extending beyond the confines of the cyst wall, nuclear pleomorphism, and high mitotic activity. These areas may be indistinguishable from squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
differential_diagnosis: The histopathological differential diagnosis of PTT includes ruptured trichilemmal cyst, giant trichilemmal horn, SCC, and the proliferating pattern of epidermal (infundibular) cyst. Ruptured trichilemmal cysts may show irregular aggregates of keratinocytes with trichilemmal keratinization, but they lack the solid multilobular structure of PTT. Giant cutaneous trichilemmal horn consists of a mixture of squamous cells and trichilemmal keratinized debris and in some cases is connected at its base to a trichilemmal cyst. Mitotic activity is frequent, and cytological atypia is lacking. Uncommonly, SCC may show a cystic configuration, but nuclear atypia is more marked than in PTT. SCC shows no evidence of trichilemmal differentiation. The proliferating pattern of epidermal (infundibular) cyst consists of cystic structures lined by infundibular epithelium associated with basket-weave, basophilic, and orthokeratotic keratin.
staging: The eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM staging system applies for cases with metastases.
prognosis_and_prediction: In most reported cases, the behaviour is benign. In the rare instances of malignant PTT, distant metastases have been reported.
related_terminology: Acceptable: proliferating tricholemmal tumour; proliferating pilar tumour. Not recommended: proliferating trichilemmal cyst; proliferating trichilemmal cystic carcinoma.

definition: Trichodiscoma and fibrofolliculoma are hamartomatous lesions that differentiate towards the epithelium and mesenchyme of the hair follicle mantle.
clinical:
Trichodiscoma and fibrofolliculoma arise as solitary or multiple white or skin-coloured papules with a smooth surface, measuring 1–10 mm, with no symptoms. The presence of multiple lesions strongly suggests Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome, in which they are associated with angiofibromas, oral papules, cutaneous collagenomas, renal neoplasms, and pulmonary cysts [[Sattler EC, Steinlein OK. Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome. In: Adam MP, Mirzaa GM, Pagon RA, et al., editors. GeneReviews. Seattle (WA): University of Washington, Seattle; 2006 Feb 27 [updated 2020 Jan 30].]]. Spindle cell–predominant trichodiscoma (SCPT) is a pattern presenting as a solitary, dome-shaped, skin-coloured papule with a smooth surface, measuring 5–10 mm. Clinically, it may be mistaken for a melanocytic naevus, basal cell carcinoma, or cyst.

---

Trichodiscoma, fibrofolliculoma, and SCPT are rare. Solitary lesions tend to occur in the fifth or sixth decade of life, with no sex predilection. Multiple, syndromic lesions are seen earlier in life.
pathogenesis:
The etiology of sporadic lesions is unknown. Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome is an inherited autosomal dominant syndrome associated with a pathogenic variant in the folliculin gene (FLCN) [[Sattler EC, Steinlein OK. Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome. In: Adam MP, Mirzaa GM, Pagon RA, et al., editors. GeneReviews. Seattle (WA): University of Washington, Seattle; 2006 Feb 27 [updated 2020 Jan 30].]]. Outside the setting of Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome, multiple familial trichodiscomas with no systemic organ involvement and no FLCN mutation have also been reported.

---

Trichodiscoma, fibrofolliculoma, and SCPT are thought to be hamartomatous tumour lesions derived from the hair mantle.
microscopic: Fibrofolliculoma and trichodiscoma represent stages of a single pathological process forming a morphological continuum. Fibrofolliculoma is a symmetrical dermal infundibulocentric proliferation, with a central dilated infundibulum from which thin epithelial strands and sebaceous glands emanate, sometimes with a fenestrated pattern. The characteristic stroma is composed of fibrillary ribbon-like collagen, mucin, and fibrocytes in varying proportions. The fibrocytes are spindle-shaped, with elongated, slightly wavy nuclei and tapering cytoplasm. Collagen bundles are perpendicular to the epithelial strands. In trichodiscoma, the predominant component is stroma, with peripheral clusters of sebaceous lobules described as mitts or hands of banana. Depending on the section plane, morphological variation may occur. SCPT is a pattern with abundant mucinous stroma and a cellular haphazard proliferation of fibrocytes. Discrete lipomatous metaplasia is a common feature, and histopathological differential diagnosis with spindle cell lipoma may be challenging. Uncommon histopathological findings include a focal palisaded, schwannoma-like arrangement of fibrocytes and lesions with hyperchromatic pleomorphic nuclei (symplastic SCPT). Fibrocytes in fibrofolliculoma, trichodiscoma, and SCPT are positive for CD34 and negative for S100. A morphological pattern of SCPT with few entrapped S100-positive nerves was previously described as neurofollicular hamartoma.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes dermal spindle cell lipoma and neurofibroma. In contrast with spindle cell lipoma, most spindle cells may show loss of RB1 staining, but FISH analysis does not demonstrate heterozygous deletion of RB1. The spindle cells of neurofibroma are S100-positive.
prognosis_and_prediction: Trichodiscoma, fibrofolliculoma, and SCPT are benign.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: No genetic data are needed for the diagnosis. Patients with multiple lesions should be referred for oncogenetic consultation and testing.
related_terminology: Not recommended: mantleoma; neurofollicular hamartoma.

definition: Tumour of the follicular infundibulum is a rare benign adnexal neoplasm showing differentiation towards the epithelium of the follicular isthmus.
clinical:
Tumours of the follicular infundibulum occur as solitary or (more often) multiple smooth or slightly hyperkeratotic and hypopigmented papules arranged in plaques. Multiple lesions are more common on photoexposed areas and appear as grouped hypopigmented macules with a reticulated pattern, or they may present as lesions mimicking hypopigmented plane warts. In some patients, eruptive lesions have been described. Tumour of the follicular infundibulum may develop in a pre-existing naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn.

---

The relative frequency reported is 3–17 cases per 100 000 skin biopsies or 12 cases per 121 500 biopsies. There is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
macroscopic: Patients typically present with hypopigmented papules arranged in plaques.
microscopic: Tumour of the follicular infundibulum is composed of anastomosing horizontally arranged cords of pale epithelial cells, connecting at intervals with the epidermis and creating a fenestrated pattern. Most cells within the cords are large, with pale cytoplasm (as a result of abundant intracytoplasmic glycogen) and a small round or oval nucleus. Peripheral cells are basaloid, with basophilic, poorly defined cytoplasm and palisading of the nuclei. At the periphery of neoplastic cords, epithelial prominences consisting of small infundibular cysts are seen. Small ductal structures with irregular luminal borders, similar to sebaceous ducts, and small clusters of mature sebocytes may be also seen. The stroma of is composed of loose fibrovascular connective tissue with numerous elastic fibres arranged in a reticular pattern.
differential_diagnosis: Superficial basal cell carcinoma shows peripheral clefting and cytological atypia.
prognosis_and_prediction: Tumours of the follicular infundibulum are benign lesions.
related_terminology: Not recommended: infundibular tumour; tumour of the follicular isthmus; infundibuloma.
