definition: Pilar sheath acanthoma is a benign follicular adnexal neoplasm with infundibular and isthmic differentiation.
clinical:
Pilar sheath acanthoma arises as a single papule or nodule with a central depression filled with keratin. Clinical diagnosis is usually as a giant comedo.

---

Pilar sheath acanthoma is rare. It usually develops in middle-aged and elderly patients (age range: 30–76 years), with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a papule with a central keratotic plug.
microscopic: Pilar sheath acanthoma is a symmetrical, well-circumscribed, vertically oriented lesion. It consists of a large central crater filled by basket-weave orthokeratotic keratin and formed as a result of the confluence of several contiguous dilated follicular infundibula. Emanating from this central crater, in a radial arrangement, are solid lobules composed of pale eosinophilic cells similar to those seen in the outer root sheath of the isthmus of the hair follicle. These lobules often show peripheral palisading of the cells and contain small ducts lined by a wavy eosinophilic cuticle. In rare instances, the neoplastic lobules are distributed in a horizontal configuration, and they may contain ductal structures showing decapitation secretion or contain small clusters of mature sebocytes.
differential_diagnosis: This includes dilated pore of Winer and trichofolliculoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Pilar sheath acanthoma is a benign neoplasm.
related_terminology: Not recommended: infundibuloisthmicoma; outer root sheath acanthoma; infundibular adenoma.

definition: Trichofolliculoma is a cystic lesion with panfollicular differentiation, consisting of a central dilated follicular infundibulum from which several smaller secondary hair follicles radiate into the surrounding dermis.
clinical:
Patients with trichofolliculoma present with a single skin-coloured, dome-shaped papule measuring 5–7 mm. A characteristic but not constant feature is the presence of a central pore with a tuft of thin white vellus hair shafts (Pinkus sign). Multiple trichofolliculomas are rarely seen.

---

Trichofolliculoma is rare. It shows a slight male predominance and a predilection for middle-aged adults. Rare congenital cases may occur.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Signalling pathways involving BMPs and PYGO2 are associated with the experimental development of trichofolliculoma-like proliferations.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a dome-shaped papule with a central dilated pore.
microscopic: Trichofolliculoma is a symmetrical, well-circumscribed lesion, with its larger axis perpendicular to the skin surface and a central dilated follicular infundibulum connected to the epidermis. Emanating radially from this cystic infundibulum are numerous vellus hair follicles showing differentiation towards the lower hair follicle segment, in different stages of development. The central cystic infundibulum contains infundibular keratin and occasional hair shafts. Sebaceous glands may be associated with the hair follicles, and in some lesions they are the dominant component. Surrounding each miniature hair follicle is a well-developed perifollicular connective tissue sheath, and in the vicinity there are well-circumscribed collections of fibrocytes that represent miniature follicular papillae. Morphological variations have been reported according to the age of the lesion, because the vellus hair follicles of the periphery may undergo the phases of the hair follicular cycle. Incidental findings described in lesions of trichofolliculoma include epidermolytic hyperkeratosis and focal acantholytic dyskeratosis. Immunohistochemical studies demonstrate that each component of trichofolliculoma expresses characteristic markers of the corresponding segment of the normal hair follicle.
differential_diagnosis: Folliculocystic sebaceous hamartoma, with large, voluminous sebaceous glands rather than miniature villous hair follicles at the periphery, is considered by some authors to be a late-stage trichofolliculoma (previously called sebaceous trichofolliculoma), but this suggestion has recently been questioned.
prognosis_and_prediction: Trichofolliculoma is a benign lesion with recurrence only in exceptional cases.
related_terminology: None

definition: Trichoadenoma is a benign neoplasm with infundibular and trichilemmal follicular differentiation.
clinical:
Trichoadenoma usually appears as a small, slowly growing, solitary nodular lesion with a telangiectatic surface. Multiple milia-like cystic structures surrounded by thin linear vessels on an erythematous-yellowish background of poorly defined borders have been described as characteristic dermoscopic features of trichoadenoma.

---

Trichoadenoma may appear at any age from birth to 80 years. In 1 reported case the lesion was congenital. The incidence seems similar in both sexes.
pathogenesis:
The term trichoadenoma is misnomer, because it is not a glandular neoplasm but a neoplasm with mostly infundibular follicular differentiation. LRIG1-positive stem cells have been proposed as the cells of origin for trichoadenoma.

---

One example of trichoadenoma has been studied by DNA flow cytophotometry, and a normal diploid DNA content was found in the tumour cells.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a well-circumscribed dermal nodule.
microscopic: Trichoadenoma appears as a well-circumscribed dermal nodule composed of epithelial and mesenchymal components. The epithelial component consists of numerous infundibulocystic structures, which may be connected to each other, but without connections to the epidermis. These cystic structures are small infundibular cysts, lined by squamous epithelium with a basal layer, an eosinophilic squamous layer of variable thickness, and a well-developed granular layer. The content of the cysts is basophilic and orthokeratotic keratin, similar to the keratin present in the infundibulum of hair follicles. Sometimes the epithelial lining of these cysts is similar to the epithelium of the sebaceous duct, resembling steatocystoma. Finally, some cystic structures of trichoadenoma may be lined by an eosinophilic epithelium with peripheral palisading on a basement membrane; the cyst wall cells show pale pink cytoplasm and keratinization without a previous granular layer resulting in eosinophilic compact orthokeratotic keratin, resembling tiny trichilemmal cysts. Some solid epithelial aggregates of infundibular epithelium are also present in most lesions. Foreign body granulomas are frequently observed in the vicinity of ruptured cystic structures. The stroma of trichoadenoma is much less abundant than the epithelial component and consists of a densely vascularized fibrohistiocytic component and fibrillary collagen. Stains for elastic tissue demonstrate abundant elastic fibres arranged concentrically around both the solid epithelial and the cystic components. Warty trichoadenoma shows a hyperkeratotic and papillomatous surface.
ancillary_studies: Scattered CK20-positive Merkel cells are detected in the epithelial aggregates of trichoadenoma. Immunoprofile studies for cytokeratins support the hypothesis that trichoadenoma differentiates mainly towards the follicular infundibulum and follicular bulge of the outer root sheath. Trichoadenoma in association with intradermal melanocytic naevus supports the notion that trichoadenoma and columnar trichoblastoma (formerly desmoplastic trichoepithelioma) represents the two ends of a spectrum of lesions.
differential_diagnosis: With an inadequate and too-superficial biopsy, differential diagnosis with syringoma, columnar trichoblastoma (formerly desmoplastic trichoepithelioma), and microcystic adnexal carcinoma may be impossible, and a larger and deeper sample should be requested. Syringoma is composed of small ductal structures lined by two layers of epithelial cells embedded in a sclerotic stroma. Infundibular cysts are less numerous in syringoma than in trichoadenoma, and in difficult cases, immunostains for EMA and CEA demonstrate that ductal structures of syringoma express these two markers in the luminal border of the ducts, whereas infundibular cysts of trichoadenoma are negative. Columnar trichoblastoma (formerly desmoplastic trichoepithelioma) with abundant infundibular cysts may resemble trichoadenoma, but it is mostly composed of elongated thin cords of basaloid follicular germinative cells expressing PHLDA1 and a prominent desmoplastic stroma. Microcystic adnexal carcinoma is a malignant and poorly circumscribed neoplasm that often extends to subcutaneous tissue. In superficial areas, the histopathological picture may be similar to that of trichoadenoma, because there are numerous small infundibular cysts, but microcystic adnexal carcinoma is also composed of small round solid aggregates of pale cells and elongated tubular structures in deeper areas. Perineural involvement is also frequently seen in these deeper areas of microcystic adnexal carcinoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Trichoadenoma shows a quite benign biological behaviour, and simple excision is curative.
related_terminology: None

definition: Trichilemmoma is a benign epithelial proliferation associated with the hair follicle infundibulum and showing trichilemmal differentiation.
clinical:
Patients with trichilemmoma present with a (usually) solitary, small (3–8 mm in diameter), hemispherical papule with a smooth or verrucous surface. Trichilemmoma frequently develops in a pre-existing naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn. Multiple trichilemmomas may be associated with Cowden syndrome.

---

Most trichilemmomas arise in middle-aged to elderly adults, with a slight male predilection. Multiple lesions, especially if there is involvement of the oral mucosa, can be a cutaneous marker of Cowden syndrome.
pathogenesis:
Some PCR studies have demonstrated HPV DNA in both solitary and multiple lesions in patients with Cowden syndrome. Cowden syndrome is caused by germline mutations in PTEN, a tumour suppression gene located on chromosome 10q23.

---

Solitary trichilemmomas have no genetic associations. Multiple trichilemmomas are a major diagnostic criterion for Cowden syndrome, which is part of the PTEN hamartoma tumour syndrome spectrum. The high frequency of HRAS activating mutations in trichilemmomas, including the HRAS c.182A>G substitution, suggests that these lesions are true neoplasms.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a small papular lesion with a smooth or verrucous surface.
microscopic: Most lesions are vertically oriented, show an exophytic and endophytic component, and are usually associated with one or more pre-existing hair follicles. Prominent digitated to bulbous thickening of the follicular infundibulum is seen, with superficial hypergranulosis and hyperkeratosis. A collarette of adnexal epithelium often surrounds the lesion. The main bulk of the lesion is composed of lobules of monomorphic epithelial cells with pale eosinophilic or clear cytoplasm (the latter due to abundant glycogen) and round, vesicular, and eccentrically located nuclei, reminiscent of cells of the outer root sheath (trichilemma) of the lower segment of hair follicle. Frequently, the cells in the periphery display palisading and rest on a thick basement membrane similar to the vitreous membrane of normal hair follicles. Central foci of infundibular keratinization, squamous eddies, and droplets of basement membrane material are occasionally found. In desmoplastic trichilemmoma there is sclerotic collagen and an increased deposition of basement membrane–like material, in a desmoplastic-looking stroma associated with small, irregular epithelial strands of pale cells that may be mistaken for invasive carcinoma.
ancillary_studies: PTEN expression may be lost, more commonly in lesions from patients with Cowden syndrome. Both conventional and desmoplastic trichilemmomas commonly express p16 and CD34.
differential_diagnosis: The histopathological differential diagnosis of trichilemmoma includes other clear cell proliferations, especially the clear cell subtype of apocrine hidradenoma. In contrast with trichilemmoma, clear cell hidradenoma is a mostly solid neoplasm, which often occupies the entire thickness of the dermis with little or no contact with the epidermis. Inside the aggregates of clear cells of clear cell hidradenoma, there is evidence of ductal differentiation. Often, mucinous cells are observed in some of these ductal structures, forming part of the layer of luminal cells. In general, in clear cell hidradenoma there is no peripheral palisading, and the peripheral cells are not apposed on a thick basement membrane as in trichilemmomas.
prognosis_and_prediction: Trichilemmoma is a benign lesion.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Not clinically relevant in most cases
related_terminology: None

definition: Melanocytic matricoma is a benign adnexal neoplasm recapitulating the bulb of the anagen hair follicle, composed of neoplastic aggregates of matrical and supramatrical cells and numerous intratumoural pigmented dendritic melanocytes.
clinical:
Melanocytic matricoma appears as a solitary, pigmented, purple or brownish-black papule or nodule. The surface may be ulcerated or crusted, and the lesion may be painful.

---

Melanocytic matricoma is rare, with only about 25 cases reported, predominantly in elderly men.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: Patients with melanocytic matricoma present with a well-circumscribed dermal nodule composed of solid aggregates of basophilic matrical and supramatrical cells with scant cytoplasm, round nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and frequent mitotic figures. Small clusters of shadow cells may be seen at the centre of the aggregates. Neoplastic cell aggregates contain numerous scattered pigmented dendritic melanocytes and deposits of melanin. With rare exceptions, there is no connection with the epidermis or hair follicles, although consumption of the epidermis overlying the tumour has been described. Rare tumours contain atypical melanocytes or epithelial cells.
ancillary_studies: The matrical cells express PHLDA1 and nuclear β-catenin, but not BerEP4. Intratumoural melanocytes express S100, HMB45 antigen (PMEL [gp100]), melan-A, and SOX10.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes pigmented pilomatricoma / pilomatrical carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma with matrical differentiation.
prognosis_and_prediction: Melanocytic matricoma is benign. A few cases with more-prominent melanocytic and matrical atypia have been reported as malignant melanocytic matricoma, but their biological behaviour has not yet been well characterized.
related_terminology: None

definition: Pilomatricoma is a benign cutaneous adnexal neoplasm that shows differentiation towards matrical cells and the hair cortex.
clinical:
Patients with pilomatricoma present with a solitary, mobile, often hard (due to calcification) papule or nodule, measuring 10–30 mm. The overlying skin may look normal, show red or bluish discolouration, or be anetodermic or bullous/lymphangiectatic. Giant lesions and perforating tumours due to the transepidermal elimination of neoplastic cells have been reported. Approximately 5% of patients have multiple pilomatricomas, usually in association with genetic syndromes (see below), although rare non-syndromic cases have been described.

---

Pilomatricoma is common, accounting for about 1% of all pathologically diagnosed benign skin lesions. It is the most common non-melanocytic cutaneous tumour excised in children. Pilomatricomas occur across a wide age range (3 months to 93 years) with two peaks of incidence, the first in children and adolescents (between the first and second decade of life) and the second in adults and elderly patients. Nearly half of all cases are diagnosed during the first two decades of life. Most studies have noted a slight female predominance.
pathogenesis:
The majority of pilomatricomas are sporadic; however, pilomatricomas can also be familial or multiple, often in the setting of complex genetic syndromes such as myotonic dystrophy, Gardner syndrome, Turner syndrome, Rubinstein–Taybi syndrome, Goldenhar syndrome, Kabuki syndrome, Sotos syndrome, trisomy 9, gliomatosis cerebri, panhypopituitarism, MUTYH-associated polyposis, and DICER1-related tumour predisposition syndrome.

---

Most pilomatricomas harbour activating mutations in exon 3 of the gene encoding β-catenin (CTNNB1); the 92 kDa protein encoded by this gene is involved in cell–cell adhesion and in the WNT signalling pathway, which regulates cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival. Matrical cells often harbour trisomy of chromosome 18, which carries the antiapoptotic gene BCL2, suggesting that the BCL2 oncoprotein may play a role in the growth and differentiation of pilomatricoma. Germline mutation of PLCD1 contributes to familial multiple pilomatricomas through the PKD / ERK1/2 cascade and TRPV6.
macroscopic: Pilomatricomas are nodulocystic and often hard due to calcification/ossification.
microscopic: Pilomatricomas consist of one or multiple well-circumscribed dermal nodules, often involving the subcutis. Neoplastic cells have a variable appearance. Peripheral cells are monomorphic, round, small, and deeply basophilic, with indistinct borders, central vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli, and they are mitotically active. These peripheral matrical cells keratinize towards shadow (or ghost or mummified) cells. In rare examples, acantholysis between matrical cells has been described. Shadow cells show distinct borders, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and an empty space where the nucleus was once located. Aggregates of shadow cells show yellow-orange staining and are refractile under polarized light. The transition from matrical cells to shadow cells occurs via intermediate cells characterized by a small, pyknotic, basophilic nucleus and pale cytoplasm. The ratio of matrical cells to shadow cells decreases with increasing age of the lesion. Pilomatricomas are often cystic (most commonly those associated with Gardner syndrome). Calcification and ossification occur in longstanding lesions; in some of these, very few shadow cells remain. The surrounding dermis is fibrotic and often contains foreign body granulomas around shadow cells and calcium deposits. Rare cases are connected to the surface epidermis. Pathological patterns include pigmented and proliferating pilomatricoma (consisting predominantly of mitotically active matrical cells). In cases with bone metaplasia, extramedullary haematopoiesis may occur. Basaloid matrical cells express nuclear β-catenin.
prognosis_and_prediction: Pilomatricomas are benign tumours, and simple excision is curative. Rarely, tumours may persist, usually when incompletely excised.
cytology: FNAB produces smears with recognizable clusters of basaloid cells and foreign body–type multinucleated cells. Ghost cells can be difficult to find.
related_terminology: Acceptable: pilomatrixoma. Not recommended: calcifying epithelioma of Malherbe.

definition: Signet-ring cell / histiocytoid carcinoma is a rare, aggressive adnexal neoplasm preferentially affecting the eyelid and histopathologically resembling a metastatic lobular carcinoma of the breast and/or some adenocarcinomas arising in the gastrointestinal tract.
clinical:
Patients with eyelid lesions present with a diffuse thickening of the involved lid, which is covered by normal or erythematous skin. Cases are often misinterpreted as inflammatory disorders, which can delay the correct diagnosis and worsen the prognosis. Extension into the adjacent eyelid results in a monocle appearance. A case with involvement of both eyes (a binocle presentation) has also been described. The reported age range is 42–87 years, with a median patient age of 66 years.

---

Signet-ring cell / histiocytoid carcinoma is a rare neoplasm, with < 60 cases reported. The tumour mainly affects men, with an M:F ratio of about 4:1.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Apocrine differentiation and an origin from the glands of Moll have been proposed, on the basis of the location and immunophenotype. Somatic mutations in CDH1, PIK3CA, NTRK3, CDKN1B, and TP53 were detected in several studied cases, but their diagnostic significance is to be confirmed in larger series.
microscopic: The tumour is composed of sheets or cords of single rows of cells arranged interstitially between collagen bundles. The cells have eccentric nuclei displaced by vacuolated cytoplasm (in the signet-ring cell pattern) or exhibit eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (in the histiocytoid pattern). Both cell types can be found in a single lesion, but one type usually predominates. Immunohistochemically, the neoplastic cells express high- and low-molecular-weight pancytokeratins, CK7, E-cadherin, CEA, EMA, GCDFP-15, and human milk fat globule.
differential_diagnosis: The main differential diagnoses are metastatic lobular carcinoma of the breast and adenocarcinomas with a signet-ring cell morphology originating from the gastrointestinal tract. Immunohistochemistry (i.e. lack of CK5/6, CDX2, and ERBB2 [HER2] expression) can be helpful in some cases, but careful clinicopathological correlation with a full clinical workup is mandatory to rule out a primary internal malignancy.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: This is an aggressive neoplasm (often persisting after incomplete surgical excision) with the potential to involve the adjacent eyelid and orbit or for regional lymph node or distant metastasis. Axillary lesions appear to be less aggressive, with reports of metastasis only to the adjacent lymph nodes.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not clinically relevant unless tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy is contemplated.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Signet-ring cell / histiocytoid carcinoma. The neoplasm involves the whole dermis.
Signet-ring cell / histiocytoid carcinoma. The tumour is composed of sheets of large so-called histiocytoid cells with abundant cytoplasm; some cells contain intracytoplasmic vacuoles.

definition: Secretory carcinoma is a rare adnexal carcinoma that is histopathologically identical to homologous lesions in the salivary gland and breast.
clinical:
The neoplasm presents as a nondescript solitary small papule or nodule.

---

Secretory carcinoma is a rare and probably underrecognized neoplasm, with < 40 cases reported. There is slight female preponderance. The reported age range is wide (22–71 years).
pathogenesis:
Because of the localization in the axillae and lips, a relationship with mammary tissue (ectopic) and salivary glands (minor) has been suggested. However, the lack of direct connection to (and lack of residua of) mammary tissue or salivary glands argues against this theory.

---

Similarly to homonymous neoplasms of the breast and salivary glands, cutaneous secretory carcinoma is associated with the characteristic balanced t(12;15)(p13;q25) ETV6::NTRK3 translocation. A single case with NFIX::PKN1 fusion has been reported.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a relatively well demarcated or poorly circumscribed nodule.
microscopic: Tumours present as intradermal, circumscribed, unencapsulated nodules composed of bland neoplastic cells arranged in microcystic, tubular, and solid growth patterns, with characteristic abundant secretion within the microcystic and tubular spaces. Cells in the tubular areas may have a cuboidal appearance. Necrosis, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular involvement are not seen. The mitotic rate is low. Immunohistochemically, the neoplastic cells are diffusely positive for S100, mammaglobin, and STAT5A, and they are variably positive for anti-NTRK antibody.
differential_diagnosis: Primary cutaneous secretory carcinoma appears identical to its extracutaneous counterparts; therefore, clinical correlation is essential to distinguish it from a metastasis from a breast or salivary gland primary. The presence of prominent intraluminal secretions sometimes resembling thyroid colloid may occasionally raise the possibility of a metastasis from a thyroid carcinoma, but secretory carcinoma is negative for thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF1). Of note, there are thyroid gland neoplasms histologically resembling secretory carcinoma, as well as tumours with different morphology but harbouring the ETV6::NTRK3 translocation. Microsecretory adenocarcinoma (with MEF2C::SS18 fusion) has recently been reported in skin [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Head and neck tumours. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2024. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 9). https://publications.iarc.who.int/629.]]. Cribriform carcinoma of the skin composed of solid areas punctuated by small round spaces arranged in a cribriform pattern may occasionally resemble a secretory carcinoma, in particular when abundant eosinophilic secretion that gives a homogeneous positive PAS reaction is evident in the lumina of the cystic and tubular spaces. However, in cribriform carcinoma, the cells in the tubular areas are not cuboidal, the glands are not distributed back-to-back, and all tumours are characterized by peculiar thin, thread-like intraluminal bridging strands resembling those seen in adenomatoid tumours of the urogenital tract. Adenoid cystic carcinoma displays a cribriform pattern, but the presence of true ductal structures with limited secretions, pseudolumina filled with mucin, or homogeneous basophilic and basaloid tumour cells are distinguishing features.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Secretory carcinoma has an apparently indolent disease course, but studies with long follow-up are limited. Lymph node or distant metastases are exceptional.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: ETV6::NTRK3 translocation is detected in most cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: primary cutaneous mammary analogue secretory carcinoma; mammary-type secretory carcinoma of the skin.

media.legend: Secretory carcinoma of the skin. The neoplasm usually occurs as an intradermal circumscribed nodule.
Secretory carcinoma of the skin. The neoplasm usually occurs as an intradermal circumscribed nodule.

Secretory carcinoma of the skin. The tumour is composed of bland neoplastic cells arranged in microcystic, tubular, and solid growth patterns, with characteristic abundant secretion within the microcystic and tubular spaces.

definition: Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum is a rare adnexal neoplasm evolving (in most cases) from a pre-existing syringocystadenoma papilliferum, usually in the setting of naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn.
clinical:
The lesion appears clinically as a nodule, inflammatory plaque, or tumour (sometimes ulcerated), 20–60 mm in size. It is sometimes associated with a sebaceous naevus.

---

Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum is extremely rare, with < 100 reported cases.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

In a benign precursor, syringocystadenoma papilliferum, mutation of BRAF and HRAS has been found. A case of syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum with in-frame alteration in MAP2K1 has been reported.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a solitary nodule, mass, or plaque with a papillary surface. Ulceration and exudates can be present.
microscopic: In most cases, the tumour shows the overall papillary architecture of syringocystadenoma papilliferum (or direct transition from syringocystadenoma papilliferum can be seen), with areas exhibiting nuclear and cellular atypia, abnormal mitotic figures, loss of polarity, and a focal disorderly proliferation of the neoplastic cells, resulting in solid areas and/or cribriform structures. In situ tumours are associated with an intact myoepithelial cell layer. The invasive adenocarcinomatous component usually appears as a well-differentiated or moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma; rarely, an intradermal proliferation of small ductal structures composed of a single cell layer involving the full thickness of the dermis or sarcomatoid (metaplastic) carcinoma is seen [[Kazakov DV, Michal M, Kacerovska D, et al., editors. Cutaneous adnexal tumors. Philadelphia (PA): Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 2012.]]. Intravascular invasion is extremely rare. Other rare appearances of the invasive component include well-differentiated to moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, such as verrucous carcinoma, lesions resembling lymphoepithelioma-like carcinoma, and tumours with a basaloid component. Other findings include various ductal changes in the intradermal component, pagetoid spread of the neoplastic cells within the adjacent/overlying epidermis or hair follicles (or both), and atypical stroma. Features of a pre-existing sebaceous naevus or other secondary neoplasm occurring in the naevus can sometimes be recognized.
ancillary_studies: The in situ component can be highlighted by staining for myoepithelial cell markers. The epithelial cells, in both the pre-existing benign lesion and the carcinoma (including areas with pagetoid spread), stain for CK7 and CAM5.2. BRAF p.V600E can be detected by VE1 immunohistochemisty in both the precursor lesion and the carcinoma component.
differential_diagnosis: Areas of hyperplasia of luminal cells with mild architectural disorder, nuclear crowding, and formation of solid or cribriform areas may sometimes be seen in otherwise benign syringocystadenoma papilliferum; however, unless unequivocal cytological atypia and abnormal mitotic figures are present, such lesions should not be diagnosed as syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum (in situ). Rare cases of syringocystadenoma papilliferum associated with florid pseudocarcinomatous hyperplasia in the overlying or adjacent epidermis or adnexal epithelium should be distinguished from syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum in which an invasive component is represented by a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Pagetoid spread of the neoplastic cells in syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum should not be misinterpreted as extramammary Paget disease, especially in small specimens. Clinicopathological correlation is essential in such cases.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Surgical excision appears to be sufficient for preventing recurrence and metastasis. Metastatic disease has rarely been reported, but one study documented a high rate of lymph node metastasis. Large tumours and those with a short disease course may behave more aggressively.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum. The tumour shows a papillary architecture.

Syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum. There are areas exhibiting nuclear and cellular atypia, abnormal mitotic figures (arrows), loss of polarity, and a focal disorderly proliferation of the neoplastic cells. The atypical epithelium is delineated from the adjacent dermis by an intact basal/myoepithelial cell layer, qualifying this tumour as syringocystadenocarcinoma papilliferum in situ.

definition: Squamoid eccrine ductal carcinoma (SEDC) is a biphasic malignant tumour showing squamous and ductal differentiation.
clinical:
The tumours present as large nodules and plaques (as large as a few centimetres).

---

With only about 60 cases reported, these tumours appear to be rare, but they are probably underrecognized. They occur in sun-damaged skin of elderly (median age: 80 years) White individuals, with a male predominance.
pathogenesis:
Ultraviolet (UV) radiation–induced damage and immunosuppression may play a role.

---

Many cases of what is currently recognized as SEDC were formerly called adenosquamous carcinoma. Molecular studies have shown that SEDC has a global transcriptome profile intermediate between those of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and sweat gland tumours. UV radiation signature mutations were found in the majority of cases, including frequent TP53 and NOTCH mutations.
microscopic: SEDC is a poorly marginated and frequently ulcerated dermal-based neoplasm with diffusely infiltrative margins and frequent invasion of the subcutis. The median tumour thickness is 4.3 mm (range: 1.5–18 mm), and the tumour has a biphasic appearance. In the superficial aspects, the tumour is composed of lobules and nests with overt squamous differentiation and multifocal epidermal connection, closely resembling well-differentiated to moderately differentiated SCC. In the deeper areas, the tumour is characterized by a diffusely infiltrative growth pattern of irregular cords and strands of cuboidal cells with prominent cytological atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, and ductal differentiation in a desmoplastic stroma. Perineural infiltration is relatively common. Lymphovascular invasion and tumour necrosis may be additional findings. Immunohistochemically, the tumour cells express cytokeratins, and ductal differentiation can be confirmed by staining for EMA and CEA.
differential_diagnosis: On superficial biopsies, SEDC may be indistinguishable from invasive SCC if the deeper-seated ductal component is not represented in the biopsy. This may be one reason for the underrecognition of this entity. However, this distinction is of little clinical consequence, because the prognosis and treatment recommendations are similar. Similarly, porocarcinoma may show squamous differentiation. It lacks zonation, and the tumour cells show poroid features. The presence of a pre-existing poroma is helpful. The behaviour and treatment are similar to those of squamoid eccrine carcinoma. Microcystic adnexal carcinoma shows follicular and ductal differentiation, with zonation similar to that seen in squamoid eccrine carcinoma. It is cytologically bland, lacks prominent cytological atypia, and does not show areas resembling outright SCC.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Despite complete surgical excision, local recurrence rates are high (25%), and there is a 13% chance of regional lymph node metastasis. However, distant metastasis and disease-related mortality are rare, occurring in only 3% of cases. Adverse prognostic factors have not been comprehensively studied but may include subcutaneous tissue invasion, perineural invasion, and lymphovascular invasion.
related_terminology: Not recommended: adenosquamous carcinoma of the skin.

media.legend: Squamoid eccrine ductal carcinoma. There are deeper strands of atypical cells with clear ductal formation and desmoplastic stroma in this example.
Squamoid eccrine ductal carcinoma. CEA highlights ductal structures within the tumour.

Squamoid eccrine ductal carcinoma. Biphasic infiltrative dermal and subcutaneous tumour with a superficial component with features of a squamous cell carcinoma and a deeper component with ductal differentiation. A desmoplastic stroma is also seen.

definition: Apocrine carcinoma is a rare cutaneous adnexal neoplasm that manifests unequivocal signs of apocrine secretion, lacks the defining microscopic features of other well-defined lesions with apocrine differentiation, and has no evidence of a specific cutaneous glandular origin.
clinical:
The neoplasm occurs as a solitary nodule or multinodular mass measuring ≥ 20 mm. Ulceration and haemorrhage may be present. The lesions usually grow slowly and have often been present for a long time before the diagnosis.

---

Apocrine carcinoma predominantly affects adults in their fifth or sixth decade of life, with no sex or race predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The finding of an in situ ductal component in apocrine carcinoma suggests that the neoplasm is best compared to invasive breast carcinoma of no special type (also known as invasive mammary ductal carcinoma). ER mRNA has been demonstrated by RT-PCR in some cases, including cases that were immunonegative for ER.
macroscopic: The neoplasm is usually an asymmetrical, unencapsulated lesion with irregular borders, involving the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.
microscopic: The most common growth patterns are papillary, tubular, and solid, which usually indicate an invasive component. The neoplastic cells have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, which may be granular and sometimes partly vacuolated. Small lumina or intracytoplasmic vacuoles resulting from abortive ductal differentiation may be present, but decapitation secretion is usually less conspicuous than in an associated in situ component. There is variable nuclear pleomorphism and mitotic activity. Perineural invasion and intravascular involvement may rarely be seen. The in situ component, if present, displays different ductal proliferations, analogous to those in mammary pathology (i.e. typical ductal hyperplasia, atypical ductal hyperplasia, and ductal carcinoma in situ with various patterns). In some tumours, only an invasive component is evident, suggesting either that an in situ lesion has become overgrown by the invasive tumour mass or that the whole neoplasm developed de novo. Rare reported features include conspicuous signet-ring or histiocytoid cells in the invasive component, identical to those seen in signet-ring cell / histiocytoid carcinoma of the periorbital region and other sites.
ancillary_studies: The neoplastic cells express cytokeratins (including CK7), are usually positive for GCDFP-15, and are variably positive for CEA. S100, EMA, ER, PR, and AR are variably expressed. An in situ component is best identified by an intact peripheral basal/myoepithelial cell layer.
differential_diagnosis: Mammary ductal carcinoma metastatic to the skin, or involving it by contiguous extension in axillary lesions, can be difficult or even impossible to distinguish from primary cutaneous apocrine carcinoma. However, in situ precursor lesions or evidence of transition from pre-existing apocrine glands, if present, identify the neoplasm as a primary cutaneous tumour. Immunohistochemistry can also be helpful; EGFR (HER1), podoplanin (recognized by D2-40), and p63 are more frequently expressed in primary tumours than in metastatic adenocarcinomas. A panel of several antibodies may have some utility in the distinction; metastatic breast carcinoma is adipophilin+, ER−, PR−, ERBB2 (HER2)+, CK5/6+/− (weak), and mammaglobin+/− (weak), whereas primary apocrine carcinoma is adipophilin−, ER+, PR+/−, ERBB2 (HER2)−, CK5/6+/− (strong and diffuse), and mammaglobin+/− (strong and diffuse). However, full clinical investigation remains the gold standard. Axillary tumours with histiocytoid cells must be distinguished from invasive lobular carcinoma located in the axillary tail of the mammary gland or ectopic mammary tissue. Malignant tumours essentially representing apocrine carcinoma have been reported to arise from pre-existing benign lesions including spiradenoma, apocrine mixed tumour, and naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn. Carcinomas with apocrine secretions occurring in the anogenital areas usually represent lesions of anogenital mammary-like glands.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Apocrine carcinoma metastasizes to regional lymph nodes in about 40% of cases, and less commonly to visceral organs. In one study, 24% of the patients died of metastatic tumour. It has been proposed that invasive apocrine carcinomas be classified according to the modified Bloom–Richardson grading system for breast carcinomas (also called the Nottingham system). This system grades tumours on the basis of three criteria: mitotic count (number of mitoses/mm2), degree of pleomorphism (mild, moderate, or severe), and tubule formation. A score of 1, 2, or 3 is assigned for each criterion, and the three scores are combined to give an overall tumour grade of 1, 2, or 3. Statistically significant differences in survival have been found between grade 3 and grade 1–2 tumours. No significant association with survival has been found with any of the other variables studied, including sex, age, anatomical site, tumour size, morphological pattern (solid, tubular, or tubulopapillary), immunohistochemical profile, and hormone receptor expression.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Acceptable: apocrine adenocarcinoma; apocrine gland carcinoma.

media.legend: Apocrine carcinoma. Part of this tumour constitutes ductal carcinoma in situ; it has a cribriform appearance, with atypical epithelial cells showing abnormal mitotic figures and intact peripheral basal/myoepithelial cells. Focal apocrine secretion is evident.

Apocrine carcinoma. Part of this tumour constitutes ductal carcinoma in situ; it has a cribriform appearance, with atypical epithelial cells showing abnormal mitotic figures (arrows) and intact peripheral basal/myoepithelial cells. Focal apocrine secretion is evident.
Apocrine carcinoma. In situ component in apocrine carcinoma. Staining for α-SMA reveals a myoepithelial cell layer around atypical glands.
Apocrine carcinoma NOS. Clinical appearance of a lesion in the axillary skin, raising the differential diagnosis with breast cancer.

definition: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (AdCC) of the skin is a rare, malignant neoplasm histologically identical to homonymous tumours in the salivary gland and other glandular tissues.
clinical:
Patients with AdCC present with a solitary nodule averaging 30 mm (range: 5–80 mm), often present for several years before diagnosis. Pain and hyperaesthesia have rarely been reported with skin tumours.

---

An incidence rate of 0.23 cases per 1 million person-years has been reported. This neoplasm generally affects middle-aged to elderly individuals (average age: ~60 years). There is a slight female predilection (M:F ratio: 1:1.5).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

About 60% of AdCCs harbour MYB gene activations, either through MYB chromosomal abnormalities or (less commonly) by MYB::NFIB fusion. The MYB::NFIB fusion oncogene, which results from the recurrent chromosomal translocation t(6;9)(q22-23;p23-24), activates the transcription of genes involved in cell-cycle control, DNA repair, and apoptosis. The t(6;9) translocation appears to be tumour-type–specific; it has been identified in AdCCs arising in various anatomical locations. In rare cases, alterations of the MYBL1 gene have been found.
macroscopic: AdCC is a poorly circumscribed, firm, solid mass that is tan, grey, or white, without necrosis and/or haemorrhage in most cases.
microscopic: AdCCs are characterized by a mixture of cribriform, tubular, and solid patterns forming variably shaped nodules in the dermis and/or subcutis. The essential diagnostic feature is the coexistence of true small bilayered ducts and pseudocysts. The true ductal structures are usually sparse, have small round lumina, and are composed of inner epithelial cells with uniform round nuclei (sometimes with small nucleoli) surrounded by an outer layer of basal/myoepithelial cells. Intraluminal secretion can be seen. The pseudocystic structures are usually larger than ducts, and they contain abundant basophilic mucinous material that stains positively with Alcian blue at pH 2.5 and/or hyalinized eosinophilic material that gives a positive PAS reaction. The pseudocysts are often surrounded on the luminal edge by a thin layer of hyalinized connective tissue. The solid areas are composed of small basaloid cells with hyperchromatic, slightly angulated nuclei and scant cytoplasm. Mitotic activity is typically low in AdCC, and cellular pleomorphism is usually not a feature, although rare cases with high-grade atypia have been reported. Perineural invasion is a common feature, whereas intraneural invasion is rare. The stroma is hyalinized and paucicellular. Occasional tumours display myxoid change, and fibrosis may be seen. Rare changes include cystic alteration, papillary formation, spilling or pinching off of epithelial or myoepithelial cells into a prominent myxoid stroma, and high-grade transformation.
ancillary_studies: The neoplastic cells show diffuse cytoplasmic positivity for broad-spectrum keratins, CAM5.2, and CK7. Staining with CK5/6 and D2-40 is variable. The basaloid and myoepithelial cells display nuclear staining for SOX10. EMA, CEA, and CK15 label the luminal cells surrounding the true ducts. The myoepithelial component is highlighted by staining for SMA, p63, and calponin. Most tumours express MYB, and all tumours are positive for KIT (CD117).
differential_diagnosis: Cutaneous secretory carcinoma consists of back-to-back tubules and microcysts with conspicuous intraluminal secretions and shows a distinctive positivity for S100, mammaglobin, STAT5A, and NTRK. Adenoid basal cell carcinoma is distinguished from AdCC by its lack of true ductal structures with myoepithelial cells, the presence of peripheral palisading of neoplastic cells and retraction artefact (often associated with stromal mucin), and at least focal areas of conventional basal cell carcinoma. Cribriform carcinoma is composed of more eosinophilic cells; lacks myoepithelial cells; and focally manifests solid areas and peculiar thin, thread-like intraluminal bridging strands. Rare cases of spiradenoma and spiradenocylindroma display areas resembling AdCC by virtue of a cribriform pattern; homogeneous, eosinophilic, or granular basophilic material; and/or ductal structures with a recognizable peripheral myoepithelial cell layer. The proportion of the AdCC-like pattern varies from 5% to 30% of the tumour volume; therefore, the identification of typical areas of spiradenoma/cylindroma, as well as the absence of nuclear pleomorphism, perineural growth, and increased mitotic activity, facilitates the recognition of this spiradenoma/spiradenocylindroma with an AdCC-like pattern. MYB immunoexpression alone does not equate with the diagnosis of AdCC; other adnexal tumours have also been found to significantly express MYB.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: AdCC of the skin has a propensity for local recurrence, which has been reported to occur in > 50% of cases. Rare cases metastasizing to regional lymph nodes or distant sites (lung, pleura, or liver) have been reported. Lesions located in the vulva may behave more aggressively, but larger studies are needed to validate this supposition. No statistically significant association has been found between tumour grade and local recurrence. In a multivariate analysis of 451 cases, a more recent year of diagnosis, advanced patient age, and advanced stage were associated with poorer outcomes.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Identification of mutually exclusive MYB::NFIB or MYBL1::NFIB fusions may be helpful in selected cases.
related_terminology: None

Adenoid cystic carcinoma. Perineural and intraneural invasion.

Adenoid cystic carcinoma. Monomorphic basaloid cells arranged in tubules, nests, and cords. Many nests display a cribriform growth pattern.

definition: Digital papillary adenocarcinoma is a malignant adnexal tumour with a marked predilection for acral sites and a solid and/or papillary architecture.
clinical:
The neoplasm presents as a slow-growing, asymptomatic, deep-seated nodule in most cases, measuring an average of 17 mm (range: 4–43 mm). The reported duration of symptoms before excision is between 2 months and 15 years. The tumour can sometimes be clinically confused with a ganglion or a cyst. Ulceration is rare. Pain may occur if the neoplasm involves the underlying bone, joint, or nerves. Rarely, patients present with metastatic disease.

---

A population-based study revealed an incidence of 0.08 cases per 1 million person-years for digital papillary adenocarcinoma. The patient age at presentation is 14–83 years (average: 52 years), with a clear male preponderance.
pathogenesis:
Oncogenic HPV42 has been detected in digital papillary adenocarcinoma.

---

A study using transcriptome analyses suggested an involvement of crucial oncogenic driver pathways, highlighting an activation of cell-cycle and ribosomal pathways in the tumour. Significant overexpression of FGFR2 mRNA was found. In another study, however, no significant expression of FGFR2 was found immunohistochemically. In rare cases, a BRAF p.V600E mutation has been found; other oncogenic mutations (i.e. of EGFR, PIK3CA, KRAS, NRAS, HRAS, and MET) have not been identified.
macroscopic: This is a lobular or poorly circumscribed solid-cystic unencapsulated neoplasm.
microscopic: Historically, aggressive digital papillary adenomas and digital adenocarcinomas were both recognized, but cases originally classified as aggressive digital papillary adenoma later developed metastases; therefore, the term adenoma has now been abandoned in this setting, and all such lesions are classified as digital papillary adenocarcinoma. Digital papillary adenocarcinoma is usually a multinodular, poorly circumscribed or well-circumscribed lesion located within the dermis and often the subcutaneous tissue, without a connection to the epidermis. A mixture of solid, cystic, and papillary growth patterns is usually seen. In the areas with papillary structures, both true papillae with a supportive fibrous core and pseudopapillae lacking a core protruding into or lying free within the cystic spaces may be seen. A typical feature is the presence of fused back-to-back glands lined by cuboidal to low columnar epithelial cells, occasionally showing apocrine secretion. At the periphery of the glands, basal/myoepithelial cells can sometimes be recognized. Cytological atypia is mild to moderate in most cases; high-grade lesions are less common. The mitotic rate is extremely variable. In a subset of cases, more-solid areas dominate, and as many as 20% of these neoplasms are essentially solid, with areas of necrosis. Squamous metaplasia and focal clear cell change may be present. The stroma is paucicellular, hyalinized, and (rarely) myxomatous. Involvement of lymphatic vessels is uncommon.
ancillary_studies: The tumour cells are diffusely positive for pancytokeratin and CK7. Staining for EMA and CEA highlights the glands and luminal borders of the papillae. Immunostaining for S100 is variable in both luminal cells and myoepithelial cells. The myoepithelial cells stain for SMA, calponin, p63, and (focally) podoplanin (recognized by D2-40). Demonstration of the HPV42 virus by in situ hybridization provides further diagnostic certainty in diagnostically challenging examples.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: The reported rates of local recurrence and metastasis are 5–21% and 26–50%, respectively. Complete excision, or a partial amputation of the affected digit, considerably decreases the risk of recurrence and metastasis. The most common site of metastasis is the lung, followed by the lymph nodes. Metastases have been reported to develop as late as 20 years after excision of the primary neoplasm. In one series, half of the patients with metastatic disease died. Histopathological features appear not to be predictive of metastatic potential.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Mutation detection and HPV detection may be relevant in cases with metastasis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: aggressive digital papillary adenocarcinoma; digital papillary carcinoma. Not recommended: aggressive digital papillary adenoma.

definition: Mucinous carcinoma of the skin is a rare adnexal carcinoma identical to homologous lesions in the breast, characterized histopathologically by nests and strands of neoplastic cells floating in lakes of extracellular mucin.
clinical:
Patients with primary cutaneous mucinous carcinoma present with a solitary, slow-growing nodule or cyst-like lesion that is flesh-coloured, blue, or erythematous and 5–80 mm in size, with most cases measuring 15–20 mm. Multicentric presentation is rare.

---

The age-adjusted incidence rate is 0.04 cases per 100 000 person-years. A systematic review of 159 published cases found that 122 (~77%) of the patients were White, 20 (~13%) were Asian, and 16 (~10%) were Black. However, a recent study suggested that mucinous carcinoma may be more common in African Americans. There is no sex predominance, and the majority of patients are elderly (mean age: 63–65 years).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Mucinous carcinoma appears to result from progression of an in situ neoplasm. Inverse cell polarity, where tumour cells facing the stroma acquire apical secretory properties, is suggested to account for accumulation of the mucus. Although electron microscopic studies have suggested an eccrine lineage, about 50% of cases exhibit apocrine secretion, supporting apocrine differentiation. ERBB2 was not found to be amplified in the few tumours in which it has been investigated. Endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma is considered by some authors to be a precursor entity.
macroscopic: The tumours are soft nodules or masses with a gelatinous or mucinous appearance; they are unencapsulated, often poorly circumscribed, and without lobulation.
microscopic: The stereotypical presentation is that of neoplastic cells arranged in nests, strands, or individual units floating in lakes of extracellular mucin, sometimes separated by variably thick fibrous septa. The histopathological spectrum of primary cutaneous mucinous carcinoma is wide, and it is analogous to that seen in its mammary counterparts, with at least two distinguishable patterns: a more common pure tumour, in which extracellular mucin constitutes > 90%; and a rare mixed form, in which there is an invasive ductal component in addition to the mucinous element. The floating neoplastic epithelial cells are usually relatively monomorphic, although some tumours may show substantial nuclear pleomorphism. Mitoses are generally scarce. An essential feature, which should be looked for, is an in situ component; it is detected in most cases (60–70%) and defines the neoplasm as primary cutaneous. In situ lesions usually constitute the minor moiety, and they include (using mammary pathology terminology) ductal hyperplasia, atypical ductal hyperplasia, and ductal carcinoma in situ (cribriform, micropapillary, papillary, and solid), occurring individually or (more rarely) in combination. Some tumours are solid, have a minimal mucinous component, and express neuroendocrine markers (similarly to endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma).
ancillary_studies: The in situ component may be highlighted by staining for myoepithelial markers (including p63 and calponin). The epithelial neoplastic cells express low-molecular-weight cytokeratins, EMA, CEA, E-cadherin, GATA3, MYB, and GCDFP-15. ER and PR are expressed in most cases. The typical CK7+/CK20− phenotype can sometimes be useful in the differential diagnosis with metastatic lesions. Neuroendocrine differentiation can be encountered in cutaneous mucinous carcinomas of both pure and mixed types, without a prominent solid component.
differential_diagnosis: Because histologically identical neoplasms can occur in other organs, primary cutaneous mucinous carcinoma must be differentiated from a metastasis or direct invasion from an underlying extracutaneous neoplasm. The presence of an in situ component qualifies the tumour as primary cutaneous; however, its absence does not necessarily imply an extracutaneous origin, because disrupted myoepithelial cells may no longer be identifiable during disease progression. For such cases, a full clinical workup is needed to establish the origin. Potential pitfalls related to in situ lesions include mammary carcinoma originating from an intradermal lactiferous duct (which could be indistinguishable from a primary cutaneous lesion) and the misinterpretation of normal-looking pre-existing ducts and glands as an in situ lesion. Localization of the tumour on the chest wall and axilla is a strong indicator of mammary origin, whereas microscopic identification of dirty necrosis (disruption of cells resulting in cellular debris) and goblet cell differentiation is a clue to intestinal origin. Rare cases of primary mucinous carcinoma with numerous signet-ring cells, lesions associated with extramammary Paget disease, and lesions in which the mucinous component is scant also pose particular pitfalls. For lesions in which the mucinous component is scant, serial sections or other blocks may reveal the typical mucinous appearance.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Primary cutaneous mucinous carcinoma has a propensity to recur, but the recurrence rate is lower after surgery with intraoperative evaluation of surgical margins (i.e. either Mohs surgery or excision with frozen section control). Tumours located on the trunk tend to have a worse outcome than those on the head and neck; however, some trunk lesions involve the axilla, raising the possibility of a misdiagnosed breast primary. Increased rates of recurrence and metastasis have been associated with White ethnicity, younger age at presentation, and large tumour size (> 15 mm). In a large study, 67% of patients had local disease, 10.5% had regional disease, and 5.8% had distant disease.
related_terminology: Acceptable: mucinous adenocarcinoma.

media.legend: Mucinous carcinoma. There is an invasive ductal component in addition to the mucinous component (the mixed type of mucinous carcinoma).

Mucinous carcinoma. An in situ component in mucinous carcinoma of the skin is a strong indicator of primary cutaneous origin; in situ lesions range from various types of ductal hyperplasia to ductal carcinoma in situ. The in situ component corresponds to ductal carcinoma in situ of micropapillary type.

Mucinous carcinoma. Neoplastic cells are arranged in nests, strands, or individual units floating in lakes of extracellular mucin, separated by variably thick fibrous septa. In this lesion, extracellular mucin constitutes > 90% (the pure type of mucinous carcinoma).

Mucinous carcinoma. An in situ component in mucinous carcinoma of the skin is a strong indicator of primary cutaneous origin; in situ lesions range from various types of ductal hyperplasia to ductal carcinoma in situ. Staining for calponin highlights preserved basal/myoepithelial cells in the ductal carcinoma in situ.

Mucinous carcinoma. Small basaloid nests with ducts and intracytoplasmic lumina dispersed in lakes of mucinous stroma that extend into the subcutis. Mucin is compartmentalized by delicate fibrous stoma, creating a honeycomb appearance. Little pleomorphism and few mitosis are seen.

definition: Endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma (EMPSGC) is a low-grade mucin-producing neuroendocrine neoplasm of sweat gland origin with a predilection for the eyelid and periorbital skin. It is a precursor to mucinous adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation.
clinical:
Patients with EMPSGC present with a slow-growing, skin-coloured or bluish nodule, papule, or cyst. Sometimes, it may be multifocal.

---

The true incidence is unknown. Most cases occur in the sixth and seventh decades of life. Women are affected twice as often as men.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

EMPSGC is a cutaneous analogue of solid papillary carcinoma of the breast. In some cases, it is associated with adjacent mucinous sweat gland carcinoma with neuroendocrine features, and most likely represents a precursor lesion.
microscopic: EMPSGC typically grows as one or more well-demarcated, expansile nodules with cystic, solid, papillary, pseudopapillary, or cribriform architecture. Tumour cells are polygonal to round, small to intermediate-sized ductal cells, about 1.5 times the size of sweat gland luminal ductal cells. They have amphophilic or bluish cytoplasm and round to oval nuclei with finely stippled chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli. Mild cytological pleomorphism can be noted in some cases. Small amounts of intracellular and extracellular mucin can be demonstrated by mucicarmine or PAS staining. EMPSGC is frequently seen within dilated eccrine ducts as it spreads between the benign luminal ductal epithelium and the myoepithelial layer. At this (the earliest) stage, the tumour represents carcinoma in situ. Careful evaluation is needed so as not to mistake such a lesion for hidrocystoma. As EMPSGC grows, tumour cells begin to fill the ductal lumina, forming papillae, cribriform arrangements, and/or solid nests, which later become large expansile nodules. The nodules show variable proportions of solid, cystic, papillary, or pseudopapillary architecture. The myoepithelial rim around the larger tumour nests becomes incomplete or lost entirely, consistent with invasive carcinoma with pushing invasion. An infiltrating growth pattern is not seen. The presence of infiltrating tumour nests associated with pools of stromal mucin indicates progression to invasive mucinous adenocarcinoma. Mitotic activity is low, and the Ki-67 proliferation index is seldom greater than 5–10%. Tumour necrosis is usually absent. Atypical patterns with increased size, pleomorphism, solid growth, and increased mitotic activity can be encountered. Lesions with even the smallest component of mucinous adenocarcinoma should be diagnosed as invasive mucinous carcinoma.
ancillary_studies: Synaptophysin or chromogranin expression can be focal, or even absent on a small biopsy, and does not rule out the diagnosis. INSM1, a most sensitive neuroendocrine marker, is usually positive. All EMPSGCs strongly express ER, PR, and CK7. In contrast, expression of these receptors in apocrine carcinoma is variable. Markers such as p63 or calponin can highlight the myoepithelial layer at the carcinoma in situ stage. EMA shows stronger staining of the surface of the luminal cells. EMPSGC has also been shown to express CK8, CK18, AE1/AE3, CAM5.2, GATA3, GCDFP-15, WT1, and RCCm.
staging: The Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system for non-melanoma eyelid carcinoma applies.
prognosis_and_prediction: EMPSGC has an excellent prognosis after excision with clear margins, recurring in < 10% of cases. The recurrence rate of EMPSGC-associated mucinous sweat gland carcinoma is about 20%. Rarely, metastases may occur many years after surgery.
cytology: Not described
related_terminology: Not recommended: cutaneous analogue of papillary solid carcinoma of the breast.

media.legend: Endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma. Low-magnification view showing expansile nests of bluish cells forming solid, cystic, and pseudopapillary patterns.
Endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma. Tumour nest with a cribriform and cystic pattern.

Endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma. A papilla with a vascular core. The tumour cells are intermediate-sized round, oval, and polygonal epithelial cells with bluish cytoplasm and oval nuclei showing inconspicuous nucleoli and finely stippled chromatin. Only rarely do tumours show more pleomorphism than in this lesion.
Endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma in situ. An early tumour arising in a dilated eccrine duct / hidrocystoma.
Endocrine mucin-producing sweat gland carcinoma. The presence of infiltrating nests associated with stromal mucin indicates early progression to mucinous carcinoma.

definition: Hidradenocarcinoma is a rare adnexal neoplasm constituting the malignant counterpart of hidradenoma, a residuum of which can be detected in some cases. Tumours in which no benign residuum is seen may have occurred de novo, or the carcinoma might have overgrown the benign parent lesion.
clinical:
Hidradenocarcinoma is a solitary tumour varying in size from 10 to 60 mm. Rare patients with metastatic disease present with multiple cutaneous lesions. The reported duration of the symptoms is 1–40 years. The very rapid growth of some longstanding neoplasms is consistent with the malignant transformation of a pre-existing hidradenoma.

---

There is a slight male predominance, and most patients are in their fifth to seventh decade of life.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The t(11;19) translocation involving the genes CRTC1 (MECT1) and MAML2 has been identified in hidradenocarcinoma, but this finding is significantly less common than in hidradenoma, in which about 50% of cases harbour the translocation. Fewer than 20% of hidradenocarcinomas harbour a mutation in TP53.
microscopic: Hidradenocarcinoma is composed of the same cell types as hidradenoma, including clear cells, squamoid cells, oncocytic cells, mucinous cells, eosinophilic polygonal cells, and transitional elements in variable proportions, usually with a predominance of clear cells or squamoid cells. The malignant cells show nuclear pleomorphism, increased mitotic activity, an infiltrative growth pattern, necrosis, and perineural and lymphovascular invasion. Both low-grade and high-grade tumours are recognized, and some neoplasms contain frankly anaplastic areas. In about one third of cases, a residuum of a benign hidradenoma is observed. However, in low-grade cases, the pre-existing hidradenoma can be difficult to recognize, because cytologically bland areas blend imperceptibly with the atypical cells. The stroma is often sclerotic and hyalinized; foci of desmoplastic stromal reaction, as well as clefts between the aggregates of the neoplastic cells and the stroma, are common. An example of apocrine hidradenocarcinoma with mucinous cells showing intraepidermal pagetoid spread of neoplastic cells has been reported.
ancillary_studies: CEA and EMA decorate the luminal borders of ductal structures. Overexpression of ERBB2 (HER2) has occasionally been documented and has not been associated with ERBB2 gene amplification as demonstrated by FISH. Ki-67 and p53 have been assessed for their value in distinguishing between hidradenoma and hidradenocarcinoma, with inconclusive results. However, the pre-existing benign hidradenoma is always p53-negative, a feature that can aid in diagnosis.
differential_diagnosis: For clear cell–predominant cases, the differential diagnosis includes metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma, which is usually richly vascularized (often with blood lakes or intratumoural haemorrhage) and typically coexpresses vimentin, PAX8, and CAIX. Regional lymph node involvement may be seen in cases of histologically benign hidradenomas with lymphatic involvement or evidence of a tumour diagnosed simultaneously with the cutaneous primary. Because follow-up of such cases has not revealed any adverse outcomes, it has been suggested that these tumours constitute so-called benign metastases. However, a longer follow-up and more cases are needed to prove or disprove this theory.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: The available data are limited and vary across studies. The aggressive course (with distant metastasis to skin, lymph nodes, bones, and lungs) and poor prognosis found in some studies have not been supported by others. Metastatic disease has been documented in both low-grade and high-grade tumours.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: CRTC1::MAML2 fusions are diagnostic but rare.
related_terminology: Not recommended: clear cell eccrine hidradenocarcinoma; clear cell hidradenocarcinoma; malignant clear cell acrospiroma; carcinoma; apocrine hidradenocarcinoma; malignant eccrine acrospiroma.

media.legend: High-grade hidradenocarcinoma. This neoplasm has a predominance of relatively bland clear cells admixed with highly pleomorphic, sometimes multinucleated bizarre cells exhibiting abnormal mitotic figures.

High-grade hidradenocarcinoma. This neoplasm has a predominance of relatively bland clear cells admixed with highly pleomorphic, sometimes multinucleated bizarre cells exhibiting abnormal mitotic figures. High-power view shows frankly anaplastic areas.

definition: Cutaneous malignant mixed tumour is a very rare neoplasm resulting from malignant transformation of a pre-existing benign mixed tumour and showing microscopic heterogeneity.
clinical:
The neoplasms occur as a solitary nodule or tumour and may reach a large size (as large as 100 mm). There is sometimes a history of sudden rapid growth. Multiple cutaneous lesions have been reported in rare patients who presented with metastatic disease.

---

This neoplasm occurs predominantly in the elderly, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Malignant mixed tumours are thought to progress from a benign precursor. Although some cases show no evidence of a benign residuum, it is disputed whether these tumours can occur de novo [[Requena L, Hiromano K, Ackerman AB, et al., editors. Neoplasms with apocrine differentiation. Philadelphia (PA): Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 1998. (Ackermans histologic diagnosis of neoplastic diseases series).]]. The tumours have been shown to be composed of epithelial cells and myoepithelial cells on electron microscopy.

---

By FISH, recurrent rearrangements of PLAG1 are detected in about 33% of benign (precursor) mixed tumours. Next-generation sequencing studies revealed NDRG1::PLAG1 and TRPS1::PLAG1 fusions. Similar data for malignant mixed tumours are lacking. Array-based comparative genomic hybridization performed on samples from benign and malignant areas of 1 tumour demonstrated additional loss of 17p and 19p, gain of 19q, and loss of heterozygosity on 16q, supportive of malignant transformation.
macroscopic: Patients present with variably sized, poorly demarcated nodules or tumours with an inconspicuous or focally necrotic cut surface.
microscopic: A pre-existing benign mixed tumour (usually an apocrine mixed tumour) in association with a malignant component is a prerequisite for the diagnosis of malignant mixed tumour. The remnants of the benign neoplasm are either juxtaposed with the malignant tissue or blend gradually with it. The malignant component shows heterogeneity from case to case and can display the following patterns: adenocarcinoma (apocrine), myoepithelial carcinoma, carcinoma NOS, and sarcomatoid (metaplastic) carcinoma. Adenocarcinoma is composed of sheets of tumour cells arranged in nodules, with glands and papillary structures in which apocrine secretion can be identified. In the absence of convincing apocrine features, the malignant component may be referred to as a carcinoma NOS. Myoepithelial carcinoma is usually diagnosed in lesions in which the pre-existing apocrine mixed tumour displays prominent myoepithelial cell differentiation (i.e. hyaline cell–rich tumours). Like the benign residual tumour cells, the malignant myoepithelial cells have eccentric nuclei and abundant eosinophilic hyaline cytoplasm but display marked pleomorphism, atypical mitoses, and (sometimes) vascular involvement. Sarcomatoid (metaplastic) carcinoma is characterized by a gradual transition from a carcinomatous element to sarcomatoid tissue, which has the appearance of pleomorphic or spindle cell sarcoma NOS or of chondrosarcoma [[Kazakov DV, Michal M, Kacerovska D, et al., editors. Cutaneous adnexal tumors. Philadelphia (PA): Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 2012.]].
differential_diagnosis: As strictly defined, the diagnosis of cutaneous malignant mixed tumour should only be made when a neoplasm has a clearly identifiable pre-existing benign component. However, in most reports published to date, this diagnosis was instead based on the biphasic (so-called mixed) appearance of a neoplasm in the absence of a recognizable pre-existing benign mixed tumour. In some cases, the benign neoplasm may have been completely overgrown by the evolving malignant neoplasm, but it is likely that tumours of different lineages were also included in these reports. Approximately 10% of cases of benign apocrine mixed tumour show focal atypical cytological features, including enlarged hyperchromatic cells and multinucleated bizarre cells, which are mainly seen in the areas with squamous cell metaplasia, among hyaline cells, or in foci of oxyphilic metaplasia. However, most of these lesions manifest benign architectural features and follow a benign course. An important diagnostic pitfall is the presence of intravascular tumour deposits in an otherwise benign apocrine mixed tumour, which occurs in 1–2% of the neoplasms. An origin in another anatomical structure should be considered for tumours developing in skin overlying salivary glands, orbital tumours, and external auditory meatus tumours.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: There have been reports of recurrences and metastases to lymph nodes and distant sites in cases fulfilling the strict definition given above.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not clinically relevant as yet.
related_terminology: Not recommended: malignant chondroid syringoma; malignant apocrine mixed tumour.

media.legend: Malignant mixed tumour. This part of the neoplasm exhibits features of apocrine mixed tumour (the pre-existing lesion).
Malignant mixed tumour. There is transformation to adenocarcinoma. Note the atypical cells in the tubular areas.
Malignant mixed tumour. In this example, the malignant component has a sarcomatous appearance.

entity_name: Malignant neoplasms arising from spiradenoma, cylindroma, or spiradenocylindroma
definition: Malignant neoplasms arising from spiradenoma, cylindroma, or spiradenocylindroma are rare sweat gland carcinomas whose diagnosis depends on the recognition of a pre-existing benign spiradenoma, cylindroma, or spiradenocylindroma. These carcinomas show a wide morphological spectrum.
clinical:
The tumours usually are large nodules, several centimetres in size (median: 40 mm). In some cases, recent rapid growth is seen in a longstanding lesion. The lesions typically occur as sporadic solitary neoplasms or as a component of Brooke–Spiegler syndrome, an inherited autosomal dominant disease characterized by the development of multiple adnexal cutaneous neoplasms (most commonly spiradenoma, cylindroma, spiradenocylindroma, and trichoepithelioma). In the syndromic setting, large, rapidly growing, bleeding or ulcerated tumours occur in a background of multiple smaller pre-existing benign neoplasms.

---

Adults are affected (median age: 63.5 years), with no significant sex bias.
pathogenesis:
The tumours may arise in the setting of Brooke–Spiegler syndrome.

---

Despite immunoexpression of p53, TP53 mutation appears to be rare. CYLD mutation appears to be limited to tumours arising in the setting of Brooke–Spiegler syndrome. A study showed a recurrent missense mutation in the kinase domain of the ALPK1 gene in spiradenomas and spiradenocarcinomas.
macroscopic: Patients present with a poorly circumscribed, firm, solid mass that is tan, grey, or white in colour, with or without necrosis or haemorrhage.
microscopic: The tumours are large and multinodular, involving the dermis and subcutis. A pre-existing benign spiradenoma, cylindroma, or hybrid spiradenocylindroma is at least focally present, with gradual or abrupt transition. Morphologically low-grade tumours are easily mistaken for spiradenoma or cylindroma. Loss of the dual cell population, cytological atypia, increased mitotic activity, and loss of intratumoural lymphocytes are evident upon careful examination. Other clues include infiltrative growth with neoplastic aggregates located far away from the main bulk of the tumour, and less conspicuous basement membrane surrounding neoplastic aggregates (in malignant tumours evolving from cylindroma). The microscopic appearances of the malignant component are quite variable. They include the low-grade basal cell adenocarcinoma–like (BCAC-LG) pattern, the high-grade basal cell adenocarcinoma–like (BCAC-HG) pattern, invasive adenocarcinoma NOS, and sarcomatoid (metaplastic) carcinoma. The BCAC-LG and BCAC-HG patterns resemble low-grade and high-grade salivary gland basal cell adenocarcinoma, respectively. The BCAC-LG pattern is characterized by infiltrative areas composed of small to medium-sized basaloid cells with mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism and increased mitotic activity. Lesions manifesting the BCAC-HG pattern are composed of medium-sized to large pleomorphic basaloid cells with numerous atypical mitotic figures and necrotic cells, presenting as confluent sheets and nodules with an infiltrative growth pattern. Invasive adenocarcinoma NOS is characterized by infiltrative sheets of large pleomorphic cells with ample pale to eosinophilic cytoplasm, sometimes displaying poorly developed glands with apocrine secretion. These gland-like structures are devoid of a peripheral myoepithelial cell layer. Sarcomatoid (metaplastic) carcinoma is a biphasic lesion, with epithelial and sarcomatoid malignant components. The epithelial component manifests varying combinations of the BCAC-HG and BCAC-LG patterns or invasive adenocarcinoma NOS. Areas of squamous cell carcinoma may also be found. The appearances of the sarcomatoid component include unspecified pleomorphic sarcoma; spindle cell sarcoma; low-grade or high-grade chondrosarcoma; and tumours with osteosarcomatous, rhabdomyosarcomatous, and leiomyosarcomatous differentiation, sometimes occurring conjointly.
ancillary_studies: The tumours express cytokeratins, and ductal differentiation is highlighted by staining for EMA and CEA. Although staining for MYB is seen in benign spiradenoma, cylindroma, and spiradenocylindroma, MYB expression is lost in the malignant counterparts. The Ki-67 (MIB1) proliferation index may be increased in the malignant areas, and there is variable expression of p53.
differential_diagnosis: Rare spiradenomas focally display an atypical adenomatous/adenomyoepitheliomatous component, which may be a precursor adenocarcinoma in situ, but this component is not sufficient to qualify the neoplasm as malignant. Rare patterns of HPV-induced basaloid (cloacogenic) squamous cell carcinoma in the perianal area must be considered in the differential diagnosis.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Morphologically low-grade tumours have potential for local recurrence and can (rarely) extend into the underlying bone (on the scalp). Metastatic disease and mortality have been reported only with morphologically high-grade tumours. The behaviour of sarcomatoid (metaplastic) carcinomas appears to be favourable.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Acceptable: spiradenocarcinoma; cylindrocarcinoma; spiradenocylindrocarcinoma; carcinoma ex spiradenoma, cylindroma, or spiradenocylindroma.
subtypes: Malignant neoplasm arising from spiradenoma; malignant neoplasm arising from cylindroma; malignant neoplasm arising from spiradenocylindroma
