The malignant portion is composed of medium-sized to large pleomorphic basaloid cells with numerous atypical mitotic figures and necrotic cells, presenting as confluent sheets and nodules with an infiltrative growth pattern (basal cell adenocarcinoma–like pattern, high grade).

High-grade basal cell adenocarcinoma arising in a pre-existing spiradenoma. The malignant portion is composed of medium-sized to large pleomorphic basaloid cells with numerous atypical mitotic figures and necrotic cells, presenting as confluent sheets and nodules with an infiltrative growth pattern (basal cell adenocarcinoma–like pattern, high grade).
Invasive adenocarcinoma NOS arising from pre-existing spiradenoma. This tumour shows highly atypical cells arranged in an alveolar pattern, with occasional lumina.
Several malignant patterns, including sarcomatoid carcinoma, in a pre-existing spiradenoma. Note the transition from the atypical basaloid component to a sarcomatoid component.
Several malignant patterns, including sarcomatoid carcinoma, in a pre-existing spiradenoma. Note the transition from the atypical basaloid component to a sarcomatoid component.
Malignant neoplasm arising in pre-existing spiradenoma. The transition between the benign parent lesion and the evolving malignant neoplasm.

Malignant neoplasm arising in pre-existing spiradenoma. Higher magnification shows that the low-grade malignant area is characterized by loss of the dual cell differentiation, mild to moderate cytological atypia with nuclear crowding, and mitotic activity.

Spiradenocarcinoma. Adenocarcinoma arising from a spiradenoma (one focus is seen at the bottom left of the slide). Markedly atypical epithelioid cells with brisk mitotic activity and inflammation within the infiltrating tumoural lobules.

definition: Primary cutaneous NUT carcinoma, with rearrangements of BRD3 or NSD3 with a member of the NUT family, is a provisional and rare tumour entity that is distinct from NUTM1-rearranged porocarcinoma and has some phenotypic similarities to homonymous tumours described in the thorax and in other organs.
clinical:
The tumour may arise as a cutaneous papule or nodule, which in some cases may have been present for years. Regional metastatic spread might be present at the time of diagnosis.

---

NUT carcinoma of the skin is a very rare and probably underrecognized tumour entity.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

NUT carcinoma is characterized by the fusion of the NUTM1 gene either with BRD4 or with genes encoding interacting partners of BRD4, i.e. BRD3 and NSD3. So far, only fusions involving BRD3 and NSD3 have been detected in primary cutaneous NUT carcinoma cases. Such fusion proteins lead to the expression of key transcription factors, such as MYC, SOX2 and p63, and result in proliferation maintenance and differentiation blockage. One case harbouring a BRD3::NUTM2B fusion has been reported. The cell of origin of NUT carcinoma is unknown.
macroscopic: No consistent macroscopic features have been described.
microscopic: This infiltrating neoplasm is located in the dermis and/or subcutaneous tissue, usually without apparent connection to the epidermis (which may be ulcerated). Tumour cells are organized in strands, tubules, or solid aggregates and display round nuclei with vesicular clear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus. Characteristic features are small round ducts with eosinophilic cuticles and foci of abrupt keratinization. Clear cell changes and high-grade areas may be observed. Ductal structures are positive for EMA and CEA. Diffuse positivity for CK5/6, CK7, p40, and SOX10 has been reported. Positivity of p63 without p40 expression might be observed. NUT expression is detected in tumours with NUTM1 rearrangement.
differential_diagnosis: This includes metastasis of extracutaneous NUT carcinoma and YAP1::NUTM1-rearranged poroma and porocarcinoma, the latter displaying NUT positivity by immunohistochemistry.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: NUT carcinomas of the skin have metastatic potential, but they behave less aggressively than classic NUT carcinomas with BRD4::NUTM1 fusions. No predictive factors have yet been described in cutaneous tumours.
cytology: The features of these tumours in cytology preparations have not yet been described.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: BRD3::NUTM1, NSD3::NUTM1, and BRD3::NUTM2B gene fusions are detected in this setting.
related_terminology: Acceptable: NUT adnexal carcinoma. Not recommended: NUT midline carcinoma; t(15-19) translocated carcinoma; BRD3::NUTM1 adnexal carcinoma; NSD3::NUTM1 adnexal carcinoma; BRD3::NUTM2B adnexal carcinoma.

media.legend: NUT carcinoma. In this BRD3::NUTM1-rearranged NUT adnexal carcinoma (HPS), the tumour cells are organized in strands, tubules, or solid aggregates with foci of abrupt keratinization.
NUT carcinoma. This BRD3::NUTM1-rearranged NUT adnexal carcinoma (HPS) shows the characteristic features of the presence of small round ducts and foci of abrupt keratinization.
NUT carcinoma. This BRD3::NUTM1-rearranged NUT adnexal carcinoma consists of tumour cells with round nuclei and a prominent single nucleolus (HPS).
NUT carcinoma. This BRD3::NUTM1-rearranged NUT adnexal carcinoma consists of tumour cells with round nuclei and a prominent single nucleolus (HPS).
NSD3::NUTM1-rearranged primary cutaneous NUT carcinoma. The main diagnostic feature is the coexistence of ducts and abrupt keratinization foci.

definition: Porocarcinoma is the malignant counterpart of poroma. Porocarcinoma may develop de novo or, less commonly, from a pre-existing poroma.
clinical:
Patients with porocarcinoma present with an ulcerated nodule. Rapid growth, ulceration, and bleeding of a longstanding pre-existing poroma may also be observed.

---

In one large series, the prevalence of porocarcinoma was 18 cases in 450 000 consecutive skin biopsy specimens (0.004%). In large series, the mean age at presentation has varied from 61.5 to 73 years (range: 12–91 years). Demographic data vary greatly in the literature, and there is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is poorly understood. Molecular evidence suggests that ultraviolet (UV) radiation signature mutations are present in at least some cases.

---

Porocarcinomas may arise de novo or as malignant transformation of pre-existing poromas, possibly related to tumour suppressor loss. Activating mutations in HRAS have been described, as well as YAP1::MAML2, YAP1::NUTM1, and (more infrequently) WWTR1::NUTM1 fusions. Oncogene mutations in EGFR, ERBB2, FGFR3, KRAS, NRAS, and PIK3CA, as well as mutations in the tumour suppressor genes TP53, RB1, and CDKN2A, have also been reported. Recently, porocarcinomas with PAK1/PAK2/PAK3 fusions have been described.
microscopic: Porocarcinoma in situ is confined to the epidermis and usually shows the pattern of classic poroma accompanied by cytological features of malignancy. About 10% of all porocarcinomas are in situ lesions. Invasive porocarcinoma additionally displays an intradermal proliferation with infiltrative borders and atypical cytological features that vary from moderate to frankly anaplastic. At least focal ductal differentiation is usually found. Perineural invasion, intravascular invasion, and necrosis en masse are variable features. Rare features include clear cell change, focal squamous cell differentiation, sarcomatoid transformation, intratumoural melanin deposits, melanocytic colonization, and focal sebaceous differentiation. There is no completely sensitive and specific immunohistochemical marker for porocarcinoma. Immunohistochemical expression of the fusion partner NUT has been reported, with a sensitivity of 50–58%. Ductal differentiation, including abortive attempts in the form of intracytoplasmic lumina, can be highlighted by staining for EMA or CEA.
differential_diagnosis: Porocarcinomas with low-grade atypia can be very difficult to distinguish from poroma. Focal enlarged, atypical-appearing p53-positive cuticular cells can be observed in some poromas. Porocarcinomas, as opposed to poromas, often show diffuse or focal loss of RB1 expression. Poorly differentiated porocarcinoma may be difficult to classify as such, because the typical composition of poroid cells and cuticular cells is often no longer recognizable. Single-cell necrosis in other neoplasms may result in pseudoductal structures that can mimic porocarcinoma. In such cases, the distinction can be made by using CEA and EMA to highlight true ductal structures. Porocarcinoma can manifest variable histopathological features (squamous cell areas, clear cells, etc.) that raise a broad histopathological differential diagnosis. Identifying a parent lesion (i.e. a pre-existing poroma or porocarcinoma in situ) is the best way to avoid misinterpretation in such cases. NUT immunohistochemistry is highly specific for porocarcinoma as compared with other cutaneous malignancies, but it is not completely sensitive.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: A meta-analysis of 105 published cases showed both local recurrence and regional metastatic rates to be approximately 20% and the distant metastatic rate to be 12%. However, no distinction between in situ and malignant lesions was made. In another study, of 54 invasive lesions, 9 (17%) recurred locally, 10 (19%) metastasized to regional lymph nodes, and 6 (11%) metastasized to distant sites and/or caused the death of the patient. In a meta-analysis of 453 cases, the metastatic rate was 31%; of the metastatic cases, 57% displayed regional lymph node metastasis. A high mitotic index (> 8 mitoses/mm2) and lymphovascular invasion are strongly predictive of death; a high mitotic index also correlates with lymph node involvement. The gross size of the tumour has no significant relationship with prognosis, but a tumour depth of > 7 mm predicts death or lymph node involvement. An infiltrative tumour margin has been found to be associated with increased local recurrence.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Although not clinically relevant, fusions (of YAP1, NUTM1, PAK2) have been described in poromas.
related_terminology: Acceptable: malignant eccrine poroma. Not recommended: malignant hidroacanthoma simplex.

media.legend: Porocarcinoma. An infiltrative neoplasm with a prominent epidermal connection.
Porocarcinoma. There is prominent infiltration of the dermis by strands and nests of poroid tumour cells.
Porocarcinoma. The tumour contains nests and strands of variable pleomorphic poroid cells connected to the epidermis.
Porocarcinoma. CEA highlights ductal differentiation.

definition: Cribriform tumour is an indolent adnexal neoplasm composed of epithelial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm forming solid and cribriform structures with small lumina, devoid of a myoepithelial cell layer. Although this tumour was originally reported as a carcinoma, its malignant potential is uncertain.
clinical:
Cribriform tumour manifests as a solitary skin-coloured nodule of 10–30 mm in diameter, often having a firm consistency on palpation. The duration of symptoms ranges from several months to several years [[Kazakov DV, Michal M, Kacerovska D, et al., editors. Cutaneous adnexal tumors. Philadelphia (PA): Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 2012.]].

---

Cribriform tumour is a rare neoplasm. The M:F ratio is 1:2, and the reported age range is 20–77 years, with a median patient age of 47 years.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. No associated hereditary syndromes, susceptibility genes, or SNPs have been reported to date.

---

The histogenesis is unknown. Because of evidence of apocrine secretion in some cases, the neoplasm is considered to be apocrine.
macroscopic: There is a relatively well-demarcated unencapsulated nodule.
microscopic: Most tumours are well circumscribed, although the borders are occasionally jagged and there may be small, satellite-like aggregates of tumour cells seemingly separated from the main lesion. The neoplasm is composed of multiple interconnected solid nests of epithelial cells with round or oval, hyperchromatic nuclei; inconspicuous or absent nucleoli; granular chromatin; and scant eosinophilic cytoplasm. In addition to the solid areas, there are also small round lumina that are either empty or filled with an eosinophilic substance that gives a homogeneously positive PAS reaction, giving rise to a cribriform pattern. The ratio of solid to cribriform areas varies both within a given neoplasm and among tumours. Common features are larger ductal spaces (sometimes with decapitation secretion); intraluminal micropapillary projections; and thin, thread-like intraluminal bridging strands. Mitotic figures, especially atypical ones, are rare. Individual necrotic cells or foci of necrosis can be evident focally. The small, satellite-like aggregates, composed of a single cell to three or four cells, usually display more-pronounced cytological atypia and nuclear hyperchromasia than the main tumour bulk, but perineural or lymphovascular invasion is not a feature. The stroma is scant and fibrotic, often containing nodular lymphoid aggregates at the periphery of the neoplasm. The neoplastic cells are positive for various cytokeratins (MNF116, AE1/AE3, CAM5.2, CK5/6, and CK7) and BerEP4, and variably positive for KIT. Staining for CEA and EMA highlights the ductal component. CK20, GCDFP-15, CD15, CD31, GATA3, and PR are negative. Immunoreactivity for S100 and p63 is variable. ER can be positive, as can ERBB2. No myoepithelial cell component is identified by staining for α-SMA, MSA, or calponin, which is an important differential diagnostic feature.
differential_diagnosis: Adenoid cystic carcinoma shows a cribriform pattern but is composed of basaloid epithelial cells arranged around pseudolumina (pseudocysts) filled with mucin or eosinophilic or basophilic material. In addition to the pseudocystic structures, there are small true ducts with myoepithelial cell differentiation. These dual-type lumina are never seen in cribriform tumour; neither are the deposits of basement membrane material or perineural invasion that are typical of adenoid cystic carcinoma. Cutaneous secretory carcinoma also shows cribriform areas but consists of back-to-back proliferations of tubules and microcysts with conspicuous intraluminal secretions. Coexpression of S100, mammaglobin, STAT5A, and pan-TRK helps to distinguish the neoplasm from cribriform tumour. Rare cases of tubular adenoma may show overlap with cribriform tumour, but the presence of basal/myoepithelial cells in tubular adenoma distinguishes it.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cribriform tumour is an indolent neoplasm of uncertain malignant potential, with no cases of recurrent or metastatic disease reported to date. A few cases have been reported to persist at the site secondary to incomplete excision.
cytology: Not reported
related_terminology: Acceptable: primary cutaneous cribriform carcinoma. Not recommended: solid-cribriform carcinoma.

definition: Microcystic adnexal carcinoma is an infiltrative adnexal carcinoma showing follicular and sweat duct differentiation and bland cytology.
clinical:
Most cases arise as a sclerotic plaque, with an average diameter of 20 mm; less commonly, they can arise as a nodule, or a cyst-like tumour. Ulceration is unusual.

---

There is no sex predilection. Patients are usually affected in their fifth or sixth decade of life, but the reported age range is wide. The neoplasm predominantly affects White populations.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown, but rare cases have been associated with radiation therapy.

---

Unknown
microscopic: Microcystic adnexal carcinoma is an infiltrative neoplasm that involves the dermis and often extends to underlying tissues, commonly showing horizontal stratified zonation. It is composed of various proportions of cornifying cysts with compact or laminated keratinous material, usually distributed in the upper part of the lesion; solid nests, strands, and columns of small monomorphic epithelial cells in the midzone; and ductal structures composed of two layers of small cuboidal cells (empty or filled with eosinophilic material) in the lower part. Perineural invasion is common, but there is no pleomorphism or necrosis, and mitoses are exceptional. The stroma is sclerotic, hyalinized, and paucicellular, and granulomatous inflammation induced by ruptured cysts may be seen. Focal clear cell change is frequent. Less common features include other types of adnexal differentiation (e.g. follicular or sebaceous), the occurrence of metaplastic bone, and conspicuous single-file cell infiltration resembling a metastatic lobular carcinoma of the breast. A solid pattern of the neoplasm has been described and consists of larger solid nests of cells that are poroid or associated with more abundant pink cytoplasm or clear cell change. Exceptionally, neoplasms with areas displaying high-grade morphology are seen. The immunoprofile is nonspecific. The neoplasm stains for various cytokeratins and p63; expression of PHLDA1 is variable. Ductal differentiation can be highlighted by staining for EMA or CEA. The proliferation rate is very low.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: The tumours are locally aggressive and capable of involving deep underlying tissue, including bone. When incompletely excised, microcystic adnexal carcinoma is associated with frequent recurrence, but regional lymph node and distant metastases are rare.
related_terminology: Not recommended: sclerosing sweat duct carcinoma; syringomatoid carcinoma; eccrine epithelioma; malignant syringoma.

media.legend: Microcystic adnexal carcinoma. Deeply infiltrative tumour.
Microcystic adnexal carcinoma. Strands and nests of bland epithelial cells infiltrate the dermis and subcutis and are associated with desmoplasia.
Microcystic adnexal carcinoma. Nests of bland epithelial cells with a keratocyst.38887

Microcystic adnexal carcinoma. Infiltrative, poorly circumscribed eccrine neoplasm with focal pilar differentiation (bilineage/divergent differentiation). Stratified growth pattern with microcysts in upper portion and smaller nests, trabeculae, and single cells at base. Nests of squamoid cells with minimal cytological atypia and duct formation in a sclerotic stroma. Perineural invasion and lymphoid aggregates are seen.

definition: Adnexal adenocarcinoma NOS is a primary carcinoma of the skin with ductal/glandular differentiation but lacking specific histological features that would allow further classification.
clinical:
Patients with adnexal adenocarcinoma usually present with a solitary nodule or plaque of variable size and colour, which may be longstanding and slow-growing.

---

Most cases occur in the elderly, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
macroscopic: Patients usually present with a non-ulcerated papule/nodule.
microscopic: The lesions are asymmetrical, poorly circumscribed, and infiltrative. They often involve the full thickness of the dermis and extend into the subcutaneous and deeper tissues. Tumour cells are arranged in tubules, cords, and nests, with ductal/glandular structures devoid of an obvious myoepithelial cell layer. There may be solid areas. Tumour cells exhibit abundant eosinophilic or granular cytoplasm and pleomorphic nuclei, occasionally with numerous mitotic figures. There may be squamous differentiation. Lumina may contain homogeneous eosinophilic material, foamy histiocytes, and necrotic debris. The ductal structures are highlighted with EMA and CEA. p63 and p40 are at least focally expressed in adnexal adenocarcinoma (generally in > 25% of the cells). CK5/6, CK7, calretinin, and podoplanin (recognized by D2-40) may also be expressed. A number of these lesions express ERBB2 and thus may be amenable to targeted therapy.
differential_diagnosis: Microcystic adnexal carcinoma has a superficial component with keratin-filled (follicular) cysts, as well as a deeper glandular component that has less atypia than is seen in adnexal adenocarcinoma. Apocrine carcinoma shows glandular and ductal structures, with cytologically malignant cells showing decapitation secretion. Basal cell carcinoma with eccrine differentiation shows obvious basal cell carcinoma (i.e. basaloid cells with peripheral palisading, clefting, and myxoid stroma) and focal ductal differentiation. Squamoid eccrine ductal carcinoma shows malignant squamous epithelium in the superficial regions, occasionally resembling squamous cell carcinoma, while the deeper areas of the lesion display ducts expressing CEA and EMA. Secretory carcinoma has the characteristic secretion contents in the lumen. The primary importance of this entity is its similarity to adenocarcinomas metastatic to the skin. Distinguishing primary from metastatic cutaneous adenocarcinoma may present a diagnostic conundrum. Adnexal adenocarcinoma NOS may resemble skin metastasis, typically from the breast, lung, gastrointestinal tract, kidney, or ovary [[Scolyer RA, Thompson JF, Mahar A, et al. Metastatic tumors involving the skin. In: Busam KJ, editor. Dermatopathology. 2nd ed. London (UK): Elsevier; 2015. pp. 674–88.]]. Internal malignancies tend to metastasize to the skin of the region (e.g. lung carcinomas to the skin of the trunk; gastrointestinal, genitourinary, and gynaecological carcinomas to the skin of the abdomen, in particular the umbilicus). On histology, multifocality or lymphovascular invasion favours metastasis. For further details, including an immunohistochemical algorithm, see section Chapter 8: Metastases to the skin.
staging: Staging follows the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM classification.
prognosis_and_prediction: Adnexal adenocarcinoma NOS can recur and metastasize.
cytology: FNAB smears show malignant appearances with pleomorphic epithelial cells in clusters, as well as glandular structures [[Devanand B, Vadiraj P. Fine needle aspiration cytology of eccrine skin adnexal tumors. J Cytol Histol. 2011;2:129. doi:10.4172/2157-7099.1000129]].
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Not established
related_terminology: Not recommended: sweat gland carcinoma; sweat duct carcinoma; eccrine carcinoma; high-grade eccrine syringomatous carcinoma.

media.legend: Adnexal adenocarcinoma. Low-power view of a large, deeply invasive lesion involving most of the eyelid.
Adnexal adenocarcinoma. Deep invasion involving skeletal muscle.
Adnexal adenocarcinoma. Ducts and glands with high-grade atypia, infiltrating among skeletal muscle fibres.

definition: Myoepithelial tumours are neoplasms composed exclusively of myoepithelial cells, similar to their soft tissue and salivary gland counterparts. Syncytial myoepithelioma is a distinctive cutaneous subtype. (Although considered soft tissue tumours, myoepitheliomas are morphologically similar to mixed tumours and are therefore discussed with appendageal tumours.)
clinical:
Patients with cutaneous myoepithelioma present with a painless, slow-growing papule or nodule.

---

Myoepithelioma usually arises in adults, with a peak incidence in the third through fifth decades and an M:F ratio of 3:1.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

More than 80% of syncytial myoepitheliomas harbour an EWSR1::PBX3 fusion. EWSR1 rearrangements are less common in other cutaneous myoepitheliomas. Cutaneous mixed tumours harbour PLAG1 rearrangements, as do a small subset of myoepitheliomas lacking ductal differentiation.
macroscopic: Cutaneous myoepitheliomas are well circumscribed and range from 3 to 27 mm (mean: 10 mm).
microscopic: Cutaneous myoepitheliomas are well circumscribed, occasionally with an epidermal collarette. Some tumours are lobulated and composed of a trabecular or nested arrangement of epithelioid, spindled, plasmacytoid, or clear cells, usually within a myxoid or hyalinized stroma, with areas of solid, sheet-like growth. Extension into the subcutis may be seen. Cutaneous syncytial myoepitheliomas (accounting for 50% of cases) are composed of sheets of histiocytoid to short spindle cells with pale eosinophilic cytoplasm; one third show adipocytic metaplasia, whereas chondroid differentiation is rare. Myoepithelial carcinomas are exceptionally rare and often show marked nuclear atypia and a high mitotic rate; the minimal criteria for malignancy have not been established in the skin. Cutaneous myoepitheliomas are consistently positive for EMA and S100. Expression of keratins, GFAP, SOX10, p63, and SMA is variable. Syncytial myoepitheliomas are negative for keratins.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cutaneous myoepitheliomas are benign and rarely recur. Myoepithelial carcinomas may metastasize and follow an aggressive course.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Rearrangements of EWSR1 can be detected.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Cutaneous syncytial myoepithelioma. This distinctive, often exophytic subtype shows a sheet-like growth pattern; note the adipocytic metaplasia in the deep aspect of the tumour.
Cutaneous syncytial myoepithelioma. The tumour shows an irregular interface with the dermis.
Cutaneous syncytial myoepithelioma. The histiocytoid to short spindle cells contain abundant, pale eosinophilic, syncytial cytoplasm.
Cutaneous myoepithelioma. The tumour is composed of uniform epithelioid cells showing a trabecular and nested growth pattern, within a prominent myxoid stroma.

definition: Mixed tumour is a benign sweat gland neoplasm composed of epithelial, myoepithelial, and mesenchymal elements; it is the cutaneous analogue of pleomorphic adenoma.
clinical:
Mixed tumours are solitary (rarely multiple), well-circumscribed nodules with a smooth surface. They are typically 5–30 mm, but can be as large as 120 mm. Tumours with an osteocartilaginous component may be firm.

---

Mixed tumour is most common in middle-aged men (median age: 53.5 years); the reported age range is 10–96 years.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Pluripotent cells are probably the source of glandular and myoepithelial cells. PLAG1 and EWSR1 are rearranged in cutaneous mixed tumours. PLAG1 is a developmentally regulated zinc-finger proto-oncogene; rearrangements of PLAG1 are detected by FISH in fewer than half of cutaneous mixed tumours. PLAG1 activation through gene fusion typically occurs due to promoter swapping from various fusion partner genes that are ubiquitously expressed, such as CTNNB1, LIFR, and CHCHD7.
microscopic: Mixed tumour has two main patterns: eccrine and apocrine. The apocrine pattern presents as a well-circumscribed lesion with three components: epithelial, myoepithelial, and mesenchymal (i.e. mucinous, chondroid, osseous, adipocytic, or fibrotic). The epithelial component is composed of elongated, branched tubules and cystic spaces. These epithelial structures are lined by two cell layers; the peripheral layer is composed of cuboidal myoepithelial cells, and the inner layer is formed by columnar cells. The luminal cell layer may exhibit secretion by decapitation. Cystic areas often contain homogeneous eosinophilic material. Solid aggregates of epithelial cells, as well as isolated polygonal and plasmacytoid epithelial cells, may be also seen. Tumours with a prominent myoepithelial component may show focal cytological atypia; such cases have been called hyaline cell–rich mixed tumour. Follicular and/or sebaceous differentiation can be present. The eccrine pattern of mixed tumour is less common and lacks the PLAG1 gene rearrangement. It is composed of numerous non-branching, round ductal elements lined by a single layer of cuboidal cells embedded in a predominantly myxoid or chondromyxoid stroma. Small solid epithelial aggregates may be seen. Unusual findings include cribriform areas, clear cell change, hyaline cells, pseudorosette-like structures, prominent osseous metaplasia, and striking intracytoplasmic vacuolization of the neoplastic cells, resulting in physaliphorous-like cells. Acral mixed tumours are nodular and characterized by sheet-like growth of plasmacytoid myoepithelial cells in a myxoid or angiomatous stroma. Duct differentiation is often a focal finding only.
ancillary_studies: Mixed tumours express SOX10, p63, S100, calponin, SMA, EMA, KIT, CEA, various cytokeratins, and PLAG1 (although the eccrine pattern does not express PLAG1).
differential_diagnosis: Myoepithelioma is a related entity, distinguished by a lack of ductal structures. When the mesenchymal component is prominent, the differential diagnosis of mixed tumour includes chondroma, but chondromas do not contain epithelial cells.
prognosis_and_prediction: These are benign neoplasms that grow slowly, but over the course of years they can reach several centimetres in size.
cytology: FNAB smears show fibrillary chondromyxoid material, with a prominent cellular component composed of epithelial and myoepithelial cells.
related_terminology: Not recommended: chondroid syringoma.

media.legend: Mixed tumour (apocrine). A well-circumscribed dermal neoplasm composed of tubules embedded in a myxoid stroma.
Mixed tumour (apocrine). The tumour is composed of tubules lined by two or more rows of cuboidal cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm.
Mixed tumour (eccrine). A well-circumscribed deep dermal neoplasm composed mainly of round tubules embedded in a chondroid stroma.
Mixed tumour (eccrine). Detail of the tubules and the chondroid stroma.

definition: Syringocystadenoma papilliferum (SCAP) is a benign apocrine neoplasm that arises either as an isolated lesion or in association with naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn.
clinical:
Most lesions appear as a solitary papule or nodule. Less frequently, they present as multiple grouped, oozing, crusted papules or nodules forming a plaque or horn. Many cases are associated with naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn.

---

The tumours have a female predilection and occur across a wide age range.
pathogenesis:
None

---

Pathogenesis is due to activating mutations in the MAPK signalling pathway, affecting BRAF, KRAS, and HRAS. Syringocystadenoma papilliferum can develop sporadically or (more frequently) in the genetic setting of a cutaneous mosaic RASopathy, such as naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn. In sporadic tumours, HRAS p.G13R mutations are found in a few cases. KRAS p.G12D mutations are less frequent.
microscopic: SCAP is an endophytic crateriform lesion, connected focally to the epidermis/hair follicle and composed of two layers of cells forming dilated papillary and cystic structures. The luminal cells are columnar, with rounded or oval nuclei near the basal pole of the cell and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm with decapitation secretion. Mucinous metaplasia may be observed. The outer layer consists of basal/myoepithelial cells. The overlying squamous epithelium often displays prominent hyperplasia. The epidermis surrounding SCAP is often papillomatous or wart-like, particularly in cases associated with naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn. The stroma contains numerous plasma cells.
ancillary_studies: BRAF p.V600E mutation can be shown, with excellent sensitivity and specificity, using the anti–BRAF p.V600E antibody (clone VE1). The luminal cells of the tubules are positive for CEA and EMA, whereas the outer cell layer is typically reactive for myoepithelial markers (SMA, calponin, SOX10, and p63) [[Requena L, Sangüeza O. Cutaneous adnexal neoplasms. Cham (Switzerland): Springer; 2017.]]. A focal lack of myoepithelial cells can be seen in areas with prominent squamous metaplasia or intraluminal secretions.
differential_diagnosis: The histopathological differential diagnosis of SCAP includes hidradenoma papilliferum and nipple adenoma. Hidradenoma papilliferum has papillary formations similar to those of SCAP, and the epithelial cells lining these structures also show evidence of secretion by decapitation; however, hidradenoma papilliferum is not connected to the epidermis, lacks plasma cells, and is localized in the vulva. In adenoma of the nipple, proliferation of tubular structures is more prominent, connections with follicular infundibula are less obvious, and there are no plasma cells.
prognosis_and_prediction: SCAP is a benign neoplasm.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Syringocystadenoma papilliferum is associated with BRAF p.V600E and HRAS mutations.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Syringocystadenoma papilliferum. A broad and ulcerated papillary neoplasm on the skin surface.
Syringocystadenoma papilliferum. The tumour consists of tubular structures lined by two or more layers of cuboidal epithelium. The stroma shows an associated inflammatory infiltrate.
Syringocystadenoma papilliferum. Detail of the lining and inflammatory infiltrate composed of numerous plasma cells.

Syringocystadenoma papilliferum. A cystic lesion opening onto surface. Epidermis shows hyperplasia and papillomatosis. Tumour shows a papillary growth pattern, with papillae composed of fibrovascular cores with numerous plasma cells. The fibrovascular core is surrounded by two layers of cells: inner tall columnar cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm and decapitation secretion and an outer layer of small cuboidal cells.

definition: Tubular adenoma is a benign dermal neoplasm composed of tubules and glandular structures with or without papillae.
clinical:
The lesions appear as asymptomatic, single, well-circumscribed nodules with a smooth surface. In some cases, they show a papillated surface and can be ulcerated. Their size ranges from < 10 mm to 70 mm, although most cases are < 20 mm.

---

Tubular adenoma most frequently occurs in middle-aged women.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Similar to syringocystadenoma papilliferum, tubular adenoma can develop sporadically or (more frequently) in the genetic setting of a cutaneous mosaic RASopathy, such as naevus sebaceus of Jadassohn.
microscopic: Tubular adenomas are well-circumscribed dermal neoplasms that may extend into the subcutis. They have an overall lobular architecture and are typically encased by a fibrous stroma. The lobules consist of multiple irregularly shaped tubular structures that have a double- to several-layered epithelial lining. The peripheral epithelial layer consists of cuboidal to flattened (myoepithelial) cells, and the luminal layer consists of columnar cells that sometimes demonstrate decapitation secretion. In some tubules, papillary cellular extensions that are devoid of stroma project into the lumina. Cellular debris and eosinophilic granular material are found within some lumina. The neoplasm lacks cytological atypia and mitotic activity. Overlying epidermal hyperplasia may be present. In cases that occur in conjunction with syringocystadenoma papilliferum, the tubular adenoma component is typically present, underlying the syringocystadenoma component.
ancillary_studies: Immunohistochemistry with the anti–BRAF p.V600E antibody (clone VE1) can be used successfully to detect cases with BRAF p.V600E mutation. The luminal cells of the tubules are positive for CEA and EMA, whereas the outer cell layer is typically reactive for myoepithelial markers including SMA, calponin, SOX10, and p63 [[Requena L, Sangüeza O. Cutaneous adnexal neoplasms. Cham (Switzerland): Springer; 2017.]]. A focal lack of myoepithelial cells can be seen in areas with prominent squamous metaplasia or intraluminal secretions.
differential_diagnosis: Tubular adenoma and syringocystadenoma papilliferum show overlapping morphological features.
prognosis_and_prediction: Tubular adenoma is a benign neoplasm.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Some cases of tubular adenoma carry mutations in the MAPK signalling pathway, affecting BRAF, KRAS, and HRAS. Tubular adenomas associated with naevus sebaceus almost always harbour HRAS or KRAS mutations. Activating mutations of BRAF, HRAS, and KRAS increase cell growth, differentiation, and survival. In sporadic tumours, HRAS p.G13R mutations are found in a few cases. KRAS p.G12D mutations are less frequent.
related_terminology: Acceptable: tubular papillary adenoma; tubular apocrine adenoma. Not recommended: papillary eccrine adenoma; tubular syringoadenoma.

media.legend: Tubular papillary adenoma. A well-circumscribed neoplasm composed of numerous tubular and ductal structures.
Tubular papillary adenoma. There are papillary projections inside the tubules, with necrosis and calcification.

Tubular adenoma. Duct-like structures in dermis within a fibrovascular stroma. Ducts lined by two or more layers of polyhedral cells, some of them forming papillary projections into a lumen. Overlying epidermal papillomatous hyperplasia.

definition: Cylindroma is a benign adnexal neoplasm with a mosaic microscopic pattern. Cylindroma commonly occurs as a hybrid with spiradenoma, a phenomenon that has been referred to as cylindrospiradenoma or spiradenocylindroma.
clinical:
Cylindromas are typically smooth, dome-shaped, hairless, reddish-brown papules or nodules. Multiple cylindromas located on the scalp have historically been referred to as turban tumours.

---

Cylindromas can be solitary or multiple. They can arise sporadically or as part of Brooke–Spiegler syndrome. There is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Multiple cylindromas are seen in patients with Brooke–Spiegler syndrome, an inherited autosomal dominant disease characterized by the development of multiple adnexal cutaneous neoplasms, most commonly spiradenoma, cylindroma, spiradenocylindroma, and trichoepithelioma. The gene implicated in the pathogenesis of Brooke–Spiegler syndrome is CYLD, a tumour suppressor gene located at 16q12.1. Germline CYLD mutations are found in about 80–85% of patients with the classic Brooke–Spiegler syndrome phenotype. Loss of heterozygosity at 16q has also been found in sporadic cylindromas and spiradenomas.

---

Several genetic studies have identified mutations of the tumour suppressor gene CYLD in patients with Brooke–Spiegler syndrome. Like CYLD, DNMT3A has been described as a driver gene in sporadic cylindroma. Sporadic cases can also harbour a MYB::NFIB fusion. Spiradenoma and cylindroma are related to oncogenic activation of the NF-κB pathway, triggered by mutually exclusive mutations of ALPK1 and CYLD. A wide range of CYLD mutations affect coding and splicing, resulting in CYLD inactivation.
microscopic: Cylindroma is a symmetrical, well-circumscribed lesion. It consists of multiple aggregates of basaloid cells in a jigsaw-puzzle arrangement and surrounded by a prominent basement membrane that gives a positive PAS reaction. Two types of cells form the epithelial collections: small basaloid cells and larger pale cells. There are also ductal structures. Many neoplasms show findings of both spiradenoma and cylindroma in the same lesion (spiradenocylindroma). Malignant transformation is rare.
ancillary_studies: The tumour cells usually express KIT (CD117) and SOX10. MYB overexpression has also been reported and does not attest to the presence of a fusion gene.
differential_diagnosis: Adenoid cystic carcinoma with a prominent jigsaw-puzzle arrangement can enter the differential diagnosis, as can rare examples of basal cell carcinoma in which a thick basement membrane surrounds the aggregates of basaloid cells.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cylindroma is a benign neoplasm.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: CYLD mutation analysis may be helpful, particularly if a germline genetic disorder is suspected.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Cylindroma. There are collections of basaloid epithelial cells in the dermis, surrounded by prominent basement membrane material, which has been described as a jigsaw-puzzle arrangement.
Cylindroma. Detail of the basaloid cells and areas of ductal differentiation.
Solitary spiradenocylindroma. The lesion appears as a firm, erythematous nodule with a smooth surface.
Solitary spiradenocylindroma. By dermoscopy, solitary spiradenocylindroma shows a nonspecific vascular pattern.

Cylindroma. Islands of basaloid nests are arranged as a jigsaw puzzle. Tumour nests exhibit a biphasic cellular pattern: small basaloid cells in periphery and large pale cells in centre. Eosinophilic basement membrane material is present within the nodules, as well as lining the nodules.

definition: Spiradenoma is a (multi)nodular, solid, benign sweat gland neoplasm showing substantial morphological overlap with cylindroma.
clinical:
Spiradenomas are rare neoplasms that usually appear in adulthood, although congenital cases have been described. Most spiradenomas are solitary subcutaneous nodules; however, multiple lesions can occur in both syndromic and sporadic settings, sometimes in a linear distribution. Pain is a common clinical feature associated with spiradenoma. The cause of pain is unknown, although various theories have been proposed, including the contraction of myoepithelial cells and an abnormal distribution of sensory nerves inside the neoplasm.

---

Spiradenomas are quite rare benign tumours occurring in younger adults. There is no predilection for sex or ethnicity.
pathogenesis:
Multiple spiradenomas, which are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, are often associated with multiple trichoepitheliomas, cylindromas, and tumours of the parotid gland, an association known as Brooke–Spiegler syndrome. The gene responsible for this syndrome, CYLD, is located at 16q12.1 and shows sequence mutations or loss of heterozygosity at 16q typical of this tumour suppressor gene.

---

Germline CYLD mutations are present in syndromic spiradenoma. Mutations in ALPK1 (p.V1092A) and, less often, in CYLD are observed in sporadic spiradenoma, and these are mutually exclusive. MYB overexpression has been identified in spiradenoma in the absence of a MYB::NFIB fusion. Spiradenoma and cylindroma are related to oncogenic activation of the NF-κB pathway, triggered by mutually exclusive mutations of ALPK1 and CYLD. A wide range of CYLD sequence variants affect coding and splicing, resulting in inactivation of CYLD.
microscopic: Spiradenomas consist of single or several round nodules of basaloid cells with smooth borders. They are centred in the dermis and occasionally extend into subcutaneous tissue. The stroma is oedematous, with numerous dilated blood and lymph vessels. The tumour is often populated by numerous lymphocytes. Spiradenomas are composed of two types of cells: light (or clear) and dark. The clear cells tend to occupy the centre of the neoplastic nodules, and the dark cells form the peripheral layer. Ductal structures are frequently seen inside the solid areas of spiradenoma. Rarely, true adenomatous or atypical adenomatous areas may be seen. Basement membrane material can be seen in the form of a thick basement membrane surrounding the islets of tumour cells or in the form of round deposits inside the aggregates, although such deposits are not as abundant as they are in cylindromas. Perineural growth has been reported exceptionally rarely. Cystic degeneration can resemble tumour necrosis.
ancillary_studies: SOX10 is intensely expressed. Myoepithelial cells express calponin, SMA, and p63. Luminal cells express KIT (43%), EMA, CEA, and cytokeratins.
differential_diagnosis: Rarely, spiradenoma shows prominent cystic change from which immature basaloid cells emanate in a fenestrated pattern, simulating trichoblastoma. Some cases show features overlapping those of cylindroma, emphasizing the close relationship between these tumours. Spiradenomas can focally resemble adenoid cystic carcinoma. Spiradenocarcinoma can be distinguished by the lack of dual cell differentiation and mitotic activity in low-grade spiradenocarcinoma, and the presence of a high-grade carcinoma adjacent to a benign-appearing spiradenoma. MYB expression is lost in the malignant tumours, which is diagnostically helpful.
prognosis_and_prediction: Spiradenoma is a benign neoplasm.
cytology: FNAB smears contain dense cell clusters, smaller loose cell aggregates, single cells, and bare nuclei. Most cells have round to oval nuclei, scant cytoplasm, and indistinct cell borders. A second population of cells with spindled nuclei, often dispersed as single cells, is present. Two cases showed the presence of pseudorosettes composed of hyaline globules of basement membrane–like material with a surrounding row of basaloid cells. However, to avoid confusion with other basaloid neoplasms, ancillary immunohistochemistry is mandatory.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: CYLD mutation analysis may be helpful, particularly if a germline genetic disorder is suspected.
related_terminology: Acceptable: eccrine spiradenoma. Not recommended: cystic epithelioma of the sweat glands.

media.legend: Spiradenoma. A section showing two well-circumscribed neoplastic nodules.
Spiradenoma. Detail of the basaloid cells with admixed basement membrane material and numerous ductal structures.

Spiradenoma. Blue balls in the dermis. Basaloid nests within the dermis with two types of cells: one with dark nuclei and another with pale nuclei. Scattered and admixed lymphocytes. Deeply eosinophilic basement membrane material is present within the nodules.

definition: Hidradenoma is a benign solid and cystic sweat gland neoplasm with ductal and glandular differentiation.
clinical:
Hidradenoma is an asymptomatic, solitary, firm nodule, usually < 20–30 mm in diameter, although it can be > 100 mm. Occasionally, lesions may be ulcerated.

---

Hidradenoma can affect people of any age, both male and female.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Hidradenomas harbour a t(11;19) translocation, which results in the fusion of CRTC1 (MECT1) at 19p13.1 with MAML2 at 11q21. The CRTC1::MAML2 fusion gene is not exclusive to hidradenoma; it has also been identified in salivary gland mucoepidermoid carcinoma. This translocation leads to aberrant activation of downstream cAMP/CREB signalling genes. Half to 75% of the cases of hidradenoma have CRTC1::MAML2 fusion, and CRTC3::MAML2 fusions occur more rarely.
microscopic: Hidradenomas are well-circumscribed dermal neoplasms that may extend into the subcutaneous tissue. Most hidradenomas are solid lobular proliferations, but some contain large cystic spaces filled with homogeneous eosinophilic material. The majority of hidradenomas are composed of pale or clear cells (hence the synonym clear cell hidradenoma). However, other cell types, including polygonal, mucinous, squamoid, oxyphilic/oncocytic, and epidermoid cells, can also be present. The proportion of various cell types and their combinations vary from case to case. The characteristic cytoplasmic clarity is due to abundant intracellular glycogen. The nuclei are small, round, and (usually) eccentrically located. In some examples of hidradenoma, polygonal and epidermoid cells are the most prominent component. Mucinous cells usually appear in small groups and can be recognized by the presence of ample granular bluish cytoplasm. When polygonal cells with ample eosinophilic cytoplasm predominate, hidradenomas have an appearance reminiscent of oncocytoma. Squamoid cells have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and are separated by well-defined intercellular bridges; some may keratinize individually and appear as dyskeratotic keratinocytes. Areas of ductal and glandular differentiation are usually present, even in solid neoplasms. These structures are lined by cuboidal cells that elaborate an eosinophilic luminal cuticle. In some cases, glandular structures lined by columnar cells with evidence of secretion by decapitation in the luminal border are also seen. Myoepithelial cells are not present in ductal or glandular structures of hidradenoma. The stroma in hidradenoma is characteristically hyalinized, separating epithelial islands; in lesions of long evolution, this hyalinization may be very marked, leaving only small aggregates of neoplastic cells. Focal cytological atypia can be encountered (hidradenoma with atypical features). Immunostaining for EMA and CEA highlights ductal differentiation; p40, p63, CK5/6, and AE1/AE3 are strongly and diffusely expressed, whereas S100 and SMA are usually negative.
differential_diagnosis: Poroid hidradenoma has two cell types (poroid and cuticular), both of which are very different from the cells of hidradenoma. In poroid hidradenoma, tubular structures are only seen in the areas of cuticular cells. Like other poromas, poroid hidradenoma frequently shows areas of necrosis en masse. Trichilemmomas consist of pale or clear cells showing signs of trichilemmal differentiation; they often expand the follicular infundibulum and exhibit peripheral palisading surrounded by a thick and prominent basement membrane. In contrast, hidradenoma can connect with pre-existing infundibular structures, but the neoplastic epithelial islands form solid aggregates in the dermis and subcutis. Hidradenomas with a predominantly solid pattern must be distinguished from glomus tumour that shows SMA positivity. Hidradenoma must also be distinguished from a cutaneous metastasis of renal carcinoma, which is characterized by an abundant blood supply, numerous atypical mitoses and areas of necrosis (of both individual neoplastic cells and groups of cells), and extracellular blood lakes. A combination of PAX8 and CAIX staining may be used to solve the differential diagnosis. A particular diagnostic pitfall is posed by cases of histologically benign hidradenomas with lymphatic involvement or evidence of a tumour in a regional lymph node diagnosed simultaneously with the cutaneous primary. Histopathologically, such tumours are well circumscribed and show a lobular and cystic architecture, ductal differentiation, and a hyalinized stroma. There is no significant cytological atypia. Mitoses are rare and necrosis is absent. The lymph nodes show an essentially identical proliferation, with more cellular and extensive cystic changes containing pink amorphous material. Because follow-up of such cases has not revealed any adverse outcomes, it has been suggested that these tumours constitute so-called benign metastases. However, a longer follow-up and more cases are needed to prove or disprove this theory. Complete excision is recommended.
prognosis_and_prediction: Hidradenoma is a benign neoplasm. Exceptional cases of benign-looking hidradenomas may present with lymphatic invasion or single regional lymph node deposits; limited follow-up suggests that this is a benign phenomenon.
cytology: FNAB shows amorphous background material with epithelial duct-like cells, foam cells, and tubular structures. There may be a biphasic cytoplasmic staining pattern (eosinophilic and clear/basophilic cells) in Pap-stained sections.
related_terminology: Acceptable: clear cell hidradenoma; solid-cystic hidradenoma; nodular hidradenoma. Not recommended: eccrine acrospiroma.

media.legend: Hidradenoma. A well-circumscribed neoplasm composed mainly of clear cells admixed with ductal structures.
Hidradenoma. The tumour is composed of a mixture of clear and eosinophilic cells.

Atypical hidradenoma metastatic to lymph node. The primary tumour and the lymph node show overlapping features, consisting of a proliferation with a lobular architecture and extensive cystic changes containing pink amorphous material.

Hidradenoma. A well-circumscribed nodular proliferation in dermis and subcutis. Nodules show a solid and cystic configuration and are composed of small squamoid cells that appear polyhedral to fusiform. Duct formation and squamous metaplasia are seen.

definition: Syringofibroadenoma is a proliferative lesion derived from the intraepidermal eccrine duct, characterized by a proliferation of cords and strands of epithelial cells with ductal differentiation. Syringofibroadenoma should be better regarded as a reactive eccrine syringofibroadenomatous hyperplasia, rather than a tumour.
clinical:
Solitary syringofibroadenomas have variable morphology. Multiple lesions (eccrine syringofibroadenomatosis) present as small papules or plaques of > 50 mm, which in some cases have a linear distribution. The surface is usually hyperkeratotic and often shows features of chronic lymphoedema. Rare associations include Schöpf–Schulz–Passarge syndrome and Clouston syndrome.

---

Syringofibroadenoma affects older patients, with an average age of 60 years.
pathogenesis:
In most non-syndromic settings, this is considered to be a reactive process.

---

Eccrine syringofibroadenomas are reactive hyperplasias, or they may be neoplasms, although evidence for the latter is insufficient.
microscopic: There is ductal epithelial hyperplasia in a fenestrated pattern, oriented perpendicularly to the surface of the skin. The cords of epithelium are interconnected. The stroma shows loose fibrillary collagen containing abundant mucin and a lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate. Venules and thick-walled capillaries are abundant. In some syringofibroadenomas, the ductal cells give a positive PAS reaction and stain positively with colloidal iron. Immunohistochemical studies have demonstrated the presence of CEA, EMA, and filaggrin in the lumina of the small ducts, as well as a pattern of cytokeratin expression similar to that seen in the distal portion of the eccrine duct.
differential_diagnosis: Poromas contain more solid areas and different stroma. Fibroepithelial basal cell carcinoma shows a reticular proliferation of epithelial cells; however, focally there is stromal retraction and nuclear palisading, as well as primitive follicular germinative buds.
prognosis_and_prediction: Syringofibroadenoma is a benign condition.
related_terminology: Acceptable: eccrine syringofibroadenomatous hyperplasia. Not recommended: acrosyringeal naevus.

media.legend: Syringofibroadenoma. The tumour consists of cords of epithelial cells in a fenestrated pattern and anastomosing with each other. The stroma is oedematous, with loose collagen.
Syringofibroadenoma. Detail of the cords of epithelial cells and the loose collagen making up the tumour.

definition: Poromas are benign neoplasms with differentiation towards the intradermal portion of the sweat gland.
clinical:
The classic pattern of poroma typically arises as a solitary sessile or pedunculated papule or an asymptomatic nodule ranging from 2 to 20 mm in size, but they can also be cup-shaped, papillomatous, or wart-like. The colour of the lesion varies from red to the normal skin colour. Some neoplasms have an angiomatous, fleshy appearance resembling pyogenic granuloma. Pigmentation has also been described. Multiple poromas have been described after radiotherapy or allogeneic bone marrow transplantation and immunosuppression. The hidroacanthoma simplex pattern of poroma usually appears as a verrucous or flat keratotic plaque or erythematous patch with well-defined borders.

---

The age at presentation is 60–80 years.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Poromas are thought to derive from the basal keratinocytes of the sweat duct ridge and the lower acrosyringium. Some poromas show loss of heterozygosity in the APC gene, but the significance of this genetic anomaly is uncertain. Most poromas harbour recurrent YAP1::MAML2 or YAP1::NUTM1 gene fusions.
microscopic: All poromas are composed of poroid and cuticular cells. Poroid cells have a rounded or oval nucleus and scant cytoplasm. Cuticular cells have ample eosinophilic cytoplasm and a central nucleus, sometimes with moderate atypia. Ductal differentiation is seen, in the form of small intracytoplasmic vacuoles or the formation of authentic intracytoplasmic ductal structures. Additional findings include areas of necrosis, cystic areas, foci of keratinization, pale cells, dendritic melanocytes, melanin pigment, and keratohyalin granules. Superficially traumatized lesions may show focal cytological atypia and increased mitotic activity. The hidroacanthoma simplex pattern is mainly intraepidermal. The classic pattern includes cords and aggregates of poroid cells that connect with the epidermis in the superficial dermis. Poroma with a dermal duct tumour pattern is composed of small nodules of similar cells scattered within the upper dermis, without connection with the epidermis. Poroma with a poroid hidradenoma pattern has one or several nodules with solid and cystic areas. Areas of necrosis en masse within neoplastic aggregates may be observed. The stroma surrounding poromas is often richly vascular and may resemble granulation tissue. Apocrine- and eccrine-pattern poromas are similar. However, apocrine poromas may connect to follicular structures. Focal decapitation secretion, sebocytes, and focal follicular germinative differentiation may also be seen. CEA staining highlights the luminal border of ductal structures; EMA decorates the neoplastic cells. NUT is expressed in poromas driven by YAP1::NUTM1 gene fusion.
differential_diagnosis: Clonal-type seborrhoeic keratosis can be confused with the hidroacanthoma simplex pattern, but the ductal structures and two populations of cells in the hidroacanthoma simplex pattern facilitate correct diagnosis. Hidradenomas are composed mainly of cells with pale cytoplasm, whereas poromas include both poroid and cuticular cells.
prognosis_and_prediction: Poromas are benign neoplasms.
related_terminology: Not recommended: acrospiroma.

media.legend: Poroma. A well-circumscribed neoplasm composed of basaloid cells and widely connected to the epidermis.

Poroma. At high power, the neoplasm is composed of two populations of poroid and cuticular cells. Poroid cells have a rounded or oval nucleus and scant cytoplasm. Cuticular cells have ample eosinophilic cytoplasm and a central nucleus, sometimes with moderate atypia.
Poroma. Dermoscopy shows a brown-red plaque with focal arborizing vessels.
Poroma. A darker, brown macular lesion with less distinct vessels by dermoscopy.
Poroma forming a flesh-coloured nodule in an 88-year-old woman.

definition: Syringoma is a small, benign sweat gland tumour, thought to arise from eccrine ducts.
clinical:
Syringoma manifests as skin-coloured or slightly yellow smooth papules. Eruptive syringoma manifests as several scattered small papules (mostly on the anterior chest wall and flexural areas of the limbs), which may coalesce to form plaques. They can have a linear and one-sided distribution. Vulvar syringomas are usually pruritic. Multiple syringomas may resemble milia cysts. When the lesions are pigmented, they may simulate urticaria pigmentosa or confluent and reticulated papillomatosis of Gougerot–Carteaud. Dermoscopy of syringoma is said to show reticular brown lines on a light-brown background, with reticular vessels.

---

Syringomas most commonly affect elderly women, but the eruptive pattern is most common in young women. Clear cell syringoma, which is more common in people with diabetes, is histopathologically characterized by ducts and solid aggregates of epithelial cells with optically clear cytoplasm.
pathogenesis:
Syringomas of the eyelids may be sporadic, but they are common in patients with Down syndrome. They have also been described in patients with hyperthyroidism, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome, and Nicolau–Balus syndrome. In familial forms, multiple syringomas affect several family members.

---

Syringomas resemble the ductal portion of the eccrine gland, from which they are thought to arise. The hedgehog pathway may be involved, and high expression of sonic hedgehog has been reported.
microscopic: Syringomas are well-circumscribed lesions more frequently located in the upper half of the dermis. Syringoma has two components: epithelial cells forming ducts, cords, tubules, and cysts; and a homogeneous and sclerotic stroma. The lumina of the ductal and tubular structures are lined by a double layer of cuboidal cells, sometimes containing granular basophilic material. The ducts often show characteristic extensions resembling a tadpole tail. Solid collections of epithelial cells are also observed, often containing multiple confluent cytoplasmic vacuoles. Small cysts are often present, filled with basket-weave, basophilic, and orthokeratotic keratin and lined by squamous epithelium. The stroma consists of thick bundles of compact and sclerotic collagen. In eruptive syringoma, the stroma is less prominent.
differential_diagnosis: In superficial biopsies, the differential diagnosis includes microcystic adnexal carcinoma, sclerosing/morphoeic basal cell carcinoma, and columnar trichoblastoma (formerly desmoplastic trichoepithelioma), from which distinction may be impossible without complete removal and clinicopathological correlation. Ductal proliferations in cicatricial alopecia, alopecia areata, and prurigo nodularis may resemble syringoma; however, in such cases, the stroma is different. Eruptive hamartomas of clear cells of the eccrine duct (or so-called clear cell metaplasia of the eccrine duct) resemble clear cell syringomas, but these lesions affect only the excretory ducts of pre-existing eccrine glands.
prognosis_and_prediction: Syringomas are benign lesions.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Syringoma. Multiple, regular cystic spaces embedded in a sclerotic stroma.
Syringoma. Cystic spaces lined by cuboidal epithelium.
Eruptive syringoma. Multiple small papules below the eyebrows and the eyes.
Eruptive syringoma. Multiple papules across the skin of the neck.

Syringoma. Small superficial dermal lesion composed of ducts lined by two rows of epithelioid cells and a central lumen with eosinophilic cuticle in a fibrotic stroma. Comma-shaped configuration of ducts is common, called tadpole tails.

definition: Hidrocystoma/cystadenoma constitutes a spectrum of benign cystic lesions of predominantly ductal sweat gland origin, with architecture ranging from simple cystic (hidrocystoma) to more complex (cystadenoma).
clinical:
Hidrocystomas are solitary, asymptomatic, bluish, cystic, and translucent lesions, usually located on the face. They typically measure 5–10 mm but can reach 70 mm in size. Multiple lesions (Robinson-type hidrocystomas) are rare. Schöpf–Schulz–Passarge syndrome, a form of ectodermal dysplasia, is associated with multiple hidrocystomas at the edges of the eyelids. Multiple hidrocystomas may also be associated with bilateral keratoconus, oesophageal papillomas, and hiatal hernias in patients with Goltz syndrome. Occasionally, multiple facial hidrocystomas of the face have been reported in patients with Graves disease.

---

Hidrocystoma affects middle-aged adults of both sexes [[Requena L, Sangüeza O. Cutaneous adnexal neoplasms. Cham (Switzerland): Springer; 2017.]].
pathogenesis:
Hidrocystomas usually increase in size during the summer or after exposure to heat; they decrease in size or disappear in winter.

---

Most hidrocystomas result from obstruction of the duct, but some may be neoplastic. Most appear to be of apocrine origin, but some may be eccrine.
macroscopic: Hidrocystomas are usually received for histology as small, thin-walled, collapsed cysts with surrounding skin or connective tissue.
microscopic: Hidrocystomas typically present as round to oval solitary cystic structures. They are lined by columnar epithelium, often showing decapitation secretion, surrounded by myoepithelial cells and a basement membrane. Mucin may be present in the columnar cells. Most cases contain abundant mucin in the lumen, but the content is sometimes homogeneous and eosinophilic. Accumulation of secretion material can compress and flatten the epithelium. Rare hidrocystomas with papillary-like epithelial projections or more-complex architecture are regarded as cystadenoma.
ancillary_studies: Immunohistochemically, luminal cells are positive for EMA and CEA; the myoepithelial elements are immunoreactive for S100, SOX10, and p63. Other markers include GCDFP-15, as well as various keratins in a pattern similar to that seen in the secretory portion of the eccrine glands [[Requena L, Sangüeza O. Cutaneous adnexal neoplasms. Cham (Switzerland): Springer; 2017.]].
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes lacrimal gland cysts.
prognosis_and_prediction: Hidrocystomas are benign lesions.
cytology: Insufficient information available
related_terminology: Not recommended: apocrine gland cyst; eccrine ductal cyst.

media.legend: Hidrocystoma. A cystic tumour containing large amounts of mucin.
Hidrocystoma. Detail of the cuboidal epithelium lining the cystic spaces.
Hidrocystoma/cystadenoma. Clinically, the lesion appears as a solitary, bluish to black, small dome-shaped papule.
Hidrocystoma/cystadenoma. Dermoscopy of a hidrocystoma.

Hidrocystoma. A multilocular cystic cavity lined by two layers of epithelial cells, in this case with predominant apocrine differentiation with characteristic luminal protrusions and decapitation secretions in lumen.

definition: Subungual keratoacanthoma is a rapidly growing squamoproliferative nail bed tumour with histological overlap with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC).
clinical:
These painful tumours may affect fingers and, less commonly, toes. They arise in the distal nail bed or occasionally in the proximal nail fold; in the latter, they present as paronychia. Solitary, multiple, eruptive, and familial forms occur. Patients often present with a painful nodule with subungual hyperkeratosis and/or nail spicule. Unlike keratoacanthoma at other sites, they may have an earlier onset, rarely resolve spontaneously, and often require surgery. Bone erosion or osteolysis may occur. Subungual keratoacanthoma and STIP are indistinguishable histologically, although their occurrence in young women should trigger a search for possible incontinentia pigmenti. STIPs correlate with late-stage, verrucous disease and typically arise between the ages of 15 and 35 years; such lesions may present more subtly, with nail dystrophy or destruction or paronychia, which may be the sole manifestation of the disease. Subungual hyperkeratosis may precede tumours. Although some lesions involute, the extreme pain associated with these tumours has driven patients to amputation as treatment, although retinoids have been used successfully more recently.

---

Subungual keratoacanthoma is a rare tumour that occurs most commonly in middle-aged, light-skinned individuals, in a slightly younger age group than keratoacanthoma elsewhere. STIPs occur in women on average aged between 15 and 35 years.
pathogenesis:
HPV15 has been implicated in a small series of STIPs.

---

STIPs develop in the late verrucous phase of incontinentia pigmenti.
macroscopic: Both tumours may appear as nodular or nodulocystic lesions.
microscopic: The features overlap with those of cutaneous keratoacanthoma, with a lobular proliferation of eosinophilic keratinocytes and a crateriform to cystic contour, with adjacent and central hyperkeratosis. A cystic configuration may be evident even in lesions that do not regress. However, distinguishing features include a more vertical orientation, multiple and often clustered dyskeratotic keratinocytes (often numerous in areas of hyperkeratosis), and fewer eosinophils and neutrophils. They may lack fibrosis at their bases. Rarely, calcifying keratinocytes and corneocytes may be observed. The higher expression of p53 and Ki-67 in subungual SCC can be useful in distinguishing it from subungual keratoacanthoma. In STIP, the tumour may displace the nail plate, leading to dystrophy. The differential diagnosis includes conventional SCC, subungual epidermoid inclusions, and onycholemmal carcinoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: These tumours do not have a tendency to resolve spontaneously like other cutaneous keratoacanthomas, and they are usually removed surgically. Retinoids have been used in treatment of STIP.
cytology: Not applicable
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Incontinentia pigmenti is caused by an X-linked mutation in IKBKG, the gene encoding NEMO, required for activation of NF-κB. One report of a small number of cases studied via multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis demonstrated that amplification of the genes encoding NF-κB1 (NFKB1) and cortactin (CTTN, previously EMS1) occurs in subungual keratoacanthoma but not in digital/subungual SCC. This amplification of NF-κB1 was confirmed by immunohistochemistry.
related_terminology: None

definition: Onychocytic matricoma is a benign nail plate–producing tumour that usually presents as longitudinal pachymelanonychia.
clinical:
Most reported cases of onychocytic matricoma have clinically presented as longitudinal pachymelanonychia (a longitudinal hyperpigmented streak in the nail unit associated with thickening of the nail plate). Rare cases with hypopigmentation have also been reported, where the thickened nail plate demonstrates longitudinal pachyxanthonychia (a yellow discolouration of the nail, with a thickened nail plate).

---

Onychocytic matricoma is an unusual condition, and epidemiological studies have not been performed.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: Three main histopathological patterns have been described. The acanthotic pattern demonstrates acanthosis of the matrix epithelium and includes whorls of epithelium that may show differentiation into onychocytes (nail plate cells); the associated nail plate is thickened. The papillomatous pattern demonstrates papillomatous projections of matrix-derived epithelium associated with a thickened nail plate; there are cavities within the nail plate. The keratogenous pattern demonstrates a thickened keratogenous zone and forms a channel along the nail plate. The cells in the keratogenous zone show delayed maturation into onychocytes, which occurs in the channel at the distal aspect of the nail unit. None of these patterns have any dermal component, which helps in the differentiation from onychomatricoma and other nail unit tumours.
prognosis_and_prediction: Onychocytic matricoma is a benign lesion, and the prognosis is excellent.
related_terminology: Acceptable: longitudinal subungual acanthoma.

definition: Ungual fibrokeratoma is a benign fibrokeratotic lesion occurring in the periungual areas. Patients with tuberous sclerosis often develop multiple ungual fibrokeratomas, and in this clinical context they are known as a Koenen tumour.
clinical:
The clinical appearance of ungual fibrokeratoma varies, and lesions have been described as rod-shaped, dome-shaped, flat, and branching. The most common types are the dome-shaped and branching types. A longitudinal groove in the nail plate is a very common associated finding with the ungual fibrokeratoma. Other features that have been described as associated with ungual fibrokeratoma include trachyonychia, chromonychia, onycholysis, subungual hyperkeratosis, dissected nail plates, and haemorrhagic crust.

---

Ungual fibrokeratoma is an unusual condition, and epidemiological studies have not been performed.
pathogenesis:
The causes of ungual fibrokeratomas are unknown. However, a minority of cases are associated with trauma, which may be an inciting factor.

---

Although a definitive pathogenesis has not been established, factor XIIIa–positive dermal dendritic cells are thought to be a factor in the development of collagen in ungual fibrokeratomas.
microscopic: Ungual fibrokeratomas are composed of fibrovascular tissue. The low-power view often shows a sausage-shaped tumour that may include serum at the tip of it. Sporadic ungual fibrokeratomas have shown epidermal features including hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, focal hypergranulosis, and irregular rete ridges. Kint et al. classified ungual fibrokeratomas into three patterns: pattern 1, a core with thick, dense, closely packed, and irregularly arranged collagen bundles; pattern 2, a core with an increase in grouped fibroblasts and reduced elastic fibres; and pattern 3, a core with a poorly cellular and oedematous structure with completely absent elastic tissue. In a study evaluating the histopathological patterns of periungual fibromas in patients with tuberous sclerosis, the ungual fibrokeratomas were divided into three histopathological patterns, depending on the ratio of the vascular component to the fibrous component. From most vascular to least vascular, these types are angiomatous, mixed, and fibrous. Generally, immunohistochemistry is not required for the evaluation of ungual fibrokeratoma. A potential pitfall in diagnosis is that cellular angiofibroma and superficial acral fibromyxoma are highlighted with CD34 and may cause diagnostic confusion with other CD34-positive entities.
prognosis_and_prediction: Ungual fibrokeratoma is a benign lesion.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Koenen tumour; acral angiofibroma.

media.legend: Ungual fibrokeratoma. The sections show a sausage-shaped lesion that demonstrates a fibrovascular core and has epidermal acanthosis and hyperkeratosis.
Ungual fibrokeratoma. The sections show a sausage-shaped lesion that demonstrates a fibrovascular core and has epidermal acanthosis and hyperkeratosis.

Ungual fibrokeratoma. This patient with tuberous sclerosis shows multiple ungual fibrokeratomas / Koenen tumours affecting the fingernails. The tumours are associated with longitudinal grooves in the affected nail plates.

definition: Onychopapilloma is a benign epithelial proliferation originating in the distal nail matrix.
clinical:
Onychopapilloma usually occurs in adults, with only rare paediatric cases reported. These lesions typically present with longitudinal erythronychia, a reddish nail streak and/or yellowish discolouration, sometimes beginning in a wedge-shaped contour in the distal matrix. Splinter haemorrhage is also common, as is distal subungual hyperkeratosis, often forming a spicule. These are as large as 5–6 mm in width and are often more centrally placed. Distal nail plate splitting, fissuring or notching, and onycholysis can occur. Punctate haemorrhage has also been described. Onychopapilloma can show different patterns, including pigmented (often due to melanocytic activation) and those presenting with leukonychia.

---

Onychopapilloma is a relatively common and probably underreported benign epithelial proliferation of the nail unit; its incidence has not been formally studied.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: The best method of sampling to observe diagnostic features is a full-thickness longitudinal nail unit excision encompassing the lesion, which is also sectioned or oriented in this plane for processing. Diagnostic features may remain attached to the nail plate during nail plate avulsion or reflection, which also often avulses the superficial nail unit epithelium. Proximally, there may be slight hyperplasia of nail matrix epithelium, and so-called matrical metaplasia of the nail bed, consisting of a pattern of maturation similar to matrix, with retained keratinocyte nuclei over eosinophilic superficial keratinocytes. More distally, there is nail bed hyperplasia (which is often papillated most distally) with hypergranulosis, mimicking verruca vulgaris, which is the main entity in the differential diagnosis. Some cases demonstrate multinucleate keratinocytes in the mid to distal nail bed as well, giving rise to the original name for this entity. Subungual haemorrhage may be present. Distal subungual parakeratosis and hyperkeratosis is characteristic, and it may indent the overlying nail plate undersurface. These features, as well as haemorrhage, can be seen in nail plate clippings. A single case of malignant onychopapilloma has been described, with histological features that overlap with those of squamous cell carcinoma in situ.
prognosis_and_prediction: This is in general a benign entity, which does not tend to recur upon complete longitudinal excision. A single malignant case has been described.
related_terminology: Not recommended: localized multinucleate distal subungual keratosis.

definition: Onychomatricoma is a benign fibroepithelial proliferation, usually of the nail matrix.
clinical:
Patients with onychomatricoma typically present with a nodular area under the proximal nail fold. The corresponding nail plate is thickened, in a sharply demarcated manner, and is often yellowish with transverse overcurvature and splinter haemorrhage. The width of the altered nail plate may vary, with giant lesions rarely reported. Dorsal pterygium may occur. Pigmented patterns display melanonychia. Cavities can be seen when viewing the distal nail plate end-on, and are seen on the proximal nail plate as wormwood-like or honeycomb-like holes when avulsed.

---

This is a relatively uncommon nail tumour (< 200 cases, with underreporting likely) largely of middle-aged adults, with a female predominance and a rare paediatric case reported.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
macroscopic: A gross specimen may consist of a nodular portion of tissue in the area of the nail matrix, with an interdigitating, markedly thickened nail plate with overcurvature. When the nail plate is detached and examined, many cavities can be seen proximally.
microscopic: The proximal portion originates in the nail matrix and rarely the proximal nail fold, and consists of a variably fibrocellular and rarely myxoid stroma with CD34-positive spindle cells, surmounted by reduplicated matrical epithelium. This interdigitates in a finger-and-glove pattern with the nail plate, forming many V-shaped keratogenous zones. The nail plate is thickened, with loculated serum, haemorrhage, and some papillated epithelium, often containing dilated blood vessels. The proliferative pattern with exaggerated epithelium may represent the same entity as onychoblastoma. The pleomorphic pattern contains multinucleate to pleomorphic nuclei. Some such cases have been reported as subungual pleomorphic fibroma or unguioblastic fibroma. Pigmented patterns may display epithelial and nail-plate melanin. An origin from the nail bed has also been reported, although whether such cases are the same entity is unclear. Onychomycosis may occur secondarily.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis of the fibrocellular portion includes other CD34-positive entities such as superficial acral fibromyxoma (also variably expressing EMA and CD99), angiofibroma, neurofibroma, and perineurioma. Nail clippings can be used to make the diagnosis, with a thick nail plate, loculated serum, haemorrhage, and sometimes an epithelial lining.
prognosis_and_prediction: This is benign tumour with a low rate of recurrence upon complete excision.
related_terminology: Acceptable: onychomatrixoma. Not recommended: unguioblastic fibroma; subungual pleomorphic fibroma.
