definition: EBV-positive mucocutaneous ulcer (EBVMCU) is an immune deficiency/dysregulation–associated B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder with a polymorphous infiltrate that includes EBV-positive atypical large and Hodgkin/Reed–Sternberg (HRS)-like cells and involves the mucosal surfaces and the skin.
clinical:
EBVMCU typically manifests as a well-circumscribed, often painful ulcer in mucosal or cutaneous sites, without systemic symptoms, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or bone marrow involvement. Multifocal lesions within one anatomical region may be seen.

---

No significant data are currently available on the incidence of EBVMCU. Presentation is generally in elderly patients (> 70 years). EBVMCU occurs in a variety of inborn and acquired immune deficiency/dysregulation contexts, including autoimmunity, therapy-related immune dysregulation (including with methotrexate), HIV infection, post–organ transplantation, and immunosenescence.
pathogenesis:
EBV is present in all cases.

---

The pathogenesis is for the most part unknown. IG gene rearrangements are detected in 50% of cases and are most likely due to clonal expansions of EBV-infected B cells; rare clonal TR gene rearrangements can occur.
microscopic: A shallow mucosal or cutaneous ulcer is seen with a polymorphous infiltrate ranging from small to large immunoblasts and HRS-like cells. There are admixed plasma cells, histiocytes, and eosinophils. Angioinvasion, thrombosis, and necrosis are often prominent. Vague granulomatous changes can be present. The overlying epithelium may show pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia. The base of the lesion is sharply demarcated by a dense rim of small lymphocytes. One study (of 26 cases) reported that a nearly constant finding is the presence of apoptotic cells with plasmacytoid features. At least four histological patterns have been reported: polymorphous; large cell–rich; classic Hodgkin lymphoma–like; and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma–like. The polymorphic infiltrate consists of a mixture of CD20-positive and CD3-positive lymphoid cells. CD8-positive T cells may predominate in some cases. The atypical large B cells and HRS-like cells are EBV-positive, express B-cell markers (PAX5 dim or strong, OCT2, BOB1), and are frequently positive for CD30 and IRF4 (MUM1), but they only rarely express CD15 or PDL1 (CD274). Small T cells typically form a boundary with the uninvolved adjacent tissue.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis of EBVMCU includes polymorphic lymphoproliferative disorders (LPDs), EBV-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, and classic Hodgkin lymphoma, especially when there are increased large immunoblasts and HRS-like cells. The presence of necrosis and angiocentric infiltrates containing EBV in nasal or oropharyngeal locations may morphologically mimic extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma. The differential diagnoses are summarized in #36578Table 6.21 .
staging: Formal staging procedures for EBVMCU are not indicated; however, when there is clinical suspicion for more extensive LPDs in a patient with known or suspected immune deficiency disease, including suspected inborn errors of immunity, staging workup should be performed to exclude additional and/or more aggressive LPDs at other sites. Imaging should also be undertaken to exclude mass lesions or deep-seated lesions.
prognosis_and_prediction: The majority of EBVMCUs regress spontaneously or respond to withdrawal of immunosuppression where immune reconstitution is possible. Localized therapy may be needed in some cases. Occasional cases may have a relapsing and remitting course without progression.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Monoclonal BCR or TR gene rearrangements are found in more than 30–40% of cases and therefore do not separate EBVMCU from polymorphic LPDs and overt lymphomas.
related_terminology: None

definition: T-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma (T-ALL/LBL) arises from haematopoietic progenitors committed to T-cell lineage. By convention, the term leukaemia (T-ALL) is used when peripheral blood and bone marrow are the primary site of involvement, and the term lymphoma (T-LBL) when the primary involvement is of the lymph nodes, thymus, or other extranodal sites. The distinction becomes arbitrary when both marrow and non-marrow sites are involved, although many treatment protocols use > 25% marrow blasts to define leukaemia.
clinical:
Cutaneous involvement usually occurs at the time of original diagnosis with bone marrow or nodal disease. Solitary leukaemia cutis is exceedingly rare. Patients typically show one or multiple subcutaneous, erythematous to violaceous, firm, painless nodules. Presentation as a maculopapular eruption is rare.

---

T-ALL accounts for about 15% of child­hood acute lymphoblastic leukaemia cases; it is more common in adolescents than in younger children, and more common in males than in females. Cutaneous involvement occurs in < 5% of T-ALL/LBL cases.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown; however, one report of T-ALL cases in monozygotic twins suggested an in utero origin of the earliest genetic lesions.

---

T-ALL/LBL develops through a multistep accumulation of genetic and epigenetic alterations in oncogenic and tumour suppressor pathways, ribosomal genes, and deregulated expression of oncogenic microRNAs or long non-coding RNAs leading to altered cell growth, survival, and differentiation.
microscopic: T-ALL/LBL most commonly presents as a prominent monotonous infiltrate of blasts involving the dermis and subcutis, and sparing the epidermis with a grenz zone. Adnexal structures are intact; however, focal infiltration of the adnexa can occur. An infiltrative single-file pattern of blasts dissecting collagen bundles can occur. T-ALL/LBL rarely shows subtle periadnexal and perivascular distribution, or epidermotropism, which can present a diagnostic challenge. Blasts are small to medium-sized, with high N:C ratios, round to irregular nuclei, finely dispersed chromatin, inconspicuous nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm. A starry-sky pattern has been described. Mitoses and apoptotic debris are associated with a high proliferation rate. The immunophenotype has been extensively studied in bone marrow, peripheral blood, and lymph nodes. Blasts are positive for CD3, CD7, and CD5 in 84–97% of cases. CD3 antigen defines T-cell lineage. The intensity of immunohistochemical CD3 expression varies and can be weaker than in mature T cells, especially in cases with only cytoplasmic CD3 expression. CD7 expression is often uniform. The expression of CD5 is variable and may be absent, particularly in more immature precortical stages including an early T-precursor stage. The expression of CD2 and CD10 is common, and CD4 and CD8 are coexpressed in approximately 50% of cases. TdT is present in the majority of cases. Additional markers of immaturity include CD1a, CD34, KIT (CD117), and CD99. TAL1 and LMO2 are frequent. Rarely, heterogeneous expression of CD79a, CD19, CD13, and CD33 has been reported.
differential_diagnosis: Because of similar cytomorphological features, the differential diagnosis includes other examples of leukaemia cutis, such as rare cases of B-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma and acute myeloid leukaemia (specifically, acute myeloid leukaemia with minimal differentiation and without maturation).
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: T-ALL/LBL is an aggressive disease with favourable outcomes when treated with systemic chemotherapy. The long-term response rates approach 85% in children and adolescents, and 60% in adults. Outcomes of relapsed T-ALL/LBL are poor, because of limited therapeutic options.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Clonal TRB and/or TRG gene rearrangements are seen in > 90% of cases, and IGH gene rearrangements in approximately 20% of cases. The chromosomal abnormalities are seen in 50–70% of bone marrow samples but are rarely studied in cutaneous lesions. The most common genetic alterations are mutations in the NOTCH1 pathway, translocations of transcription factors to chromosomal regions of TR loci, and mutations in epigenetic regulators and chromatin modifiers. In addition, the JAK/STAT, PI3K/AKT, and RAS/MAPK signalling pathways, as well as cell-cycle regulatory genes, are frequently involved. Several genetic subgroups and molecular markers have been shown to correlate with prognosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: precursor T-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma; T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia.

definition: T-prolymphocytic leukaemia (T-PLL) is a clonal proliferation of small to medium-sized prolymphocytes with a mature postthymic T-cell phenotype, characterized by juxtaposition of TCL1A or MTCP1 next to a TR locus – most commonly the TRA/TRD locus.
clinical:
There is extreme lymphocytosis (with > 100 lymphocytes × 109/L in 75% of cases) with anaemia and thrombocytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration. Frequently, hepatosplenomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy with only slightly enlarged lymph nodes are observed. Approximately 30% of patients present with cutaneous manifestations, including generalized eruptions, purpuric vasculitic lesions, oedema, nodules, and erythroderma mimicking Sézary syndrome, which often involve the head and neck area. The lesions show a predilection for the face and upper trunk regions. About 30% of patients may present at an asymptomatic and indolent phase, but these eventually progress to active disease with exponentially rising blood lymphocytosis. Serum immunoglobulins are normal.

---

T-PLL predominates in the elderly, with a median age of 65 years (range: 30–94 years) and an M:F ratio of 1.33:1.
pathogenesis:
A subset may arise in the context of ataxia–telangiectasia, characterized by germline mutations in ATM (see section Chapter 9: Genetic tumour syndromes associated with skin malignancies).

---

The chromosomal rearrangements inv(14)(q11q32) and t(14;14)(q11;q32), juxtaposing TCL1A and homologous MTCP1, respectively, to the TRA/TRD TR gene locus, are considered initiating events. These rearrangements result in dysregulated expression of members of the TCL1 oncoprotein family, which enhance T-cell receptor and AKT signalling to increase cell proliferation and inhibit activation-induced cell death. Hypomorphic (reduced function) ATM resulting from mutations and/or deletions leads to impaired DNA damage repair and cooperates with TCL1 deregulation to accumulate DNA lesions, contributing to leukaemogenesis. Activating mutations of IL2RG, JAK1, JAK3, and STAT5B leading to constitutive STAT5 signalling are highly recurrent (75%) in T-PLL. Mutations in EZH2, FBXW10, and CHEK2 further contribute to the pathogenesis through their functions in epigenetic regulation, proteasome degradation, and DNA-repair pathways, respectively. Complex karyotypes are observed in 70–80% of cases. Abnormalities of chromosome 8 including idic(8)(p11), t(8:8)(p11-12;q12), and trisomy 8q are seen in 70–80% of cases. Deletions in 12p13 and 22q, gains in 8q24 (MYC), and abnormalities of chromosomes 5p, 6, and 17 have also been described.
microscopic: Skin biopsy shows a predominantly non-epidermotropic, perivascular and periadnexal infiltrate of prolymphocytes in most cases. Limited epidermotropism is seen in some cases. The cells are small to medium-sized, with basophilic cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. A small cell pattern (~25%) and a cerebriform pattern (~5%) of the disease have been described. The neoplastic cells are positive for CD2, CD3, CD7, CD52, S100, and cytoplasmic TCL1, and negative for TdT, CD1a, CD16, and CD30. The expression of CD4 and CD8 varies: CD4+/CD8− (60%), CD4+/CD8+ (25%), and CD4−/CD8+ (15%).
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma, T-cell large granular lymphocytic leukaemia, T-lymphoblastic leukaemia, and other mature T-cell leukaemias.
staging: At diagnosis, about 30% of cases are in the inactive stage, while approximately 70% of patients present with active disease.
prognosis_and_prediction: Patients have an early stable condition for 1–2 years, followed by rapid progression. The median overall survival time from diagnosis is 19–20 months, and the poor prognostic factors include low haemoglobin (< 9.3 g/dL), a high serum LDH level (≥ 1668 IU/L), an increased white blood cell count (≥ 208 × 109/L), the presence of pleural effusion, and a complex karyotype.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Clonal TR gene rearrangements (of TRB or TRG) are detected, but without prominent clonotypic biases. Rearrangements involving TCL1 (T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma 1 family) genes (TCL1A, MTCP1) and the TRA/TRD locus are detectable in 90% of cases.
related_terminology: Acceptable: T-cell prolymphocytic leukaemia. Not recommended: T-cell chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.

definition: Systemic anaplastic large cell lymphomas (ALCLs), both ALK-positive and ALK-negative, are a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous mature T-cell lymphomas characterized by highly pleomorphic tumour cells with uniform strong expression of CD30, which may involve the skin.
clinical:
The macroscopic appearance of skin localization of systemic ALCL is mostly similar to that of primary cutaneous ALCL. Skin lesions are often generalized and may manifest as papules, nodules, or (ulcerating) tumours; they may be present at diagnosis or develop during disease progression.

---

ALK-positive ALCL is rare, accounting for 10–15% of paediatric and adolescent cases of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and approximately 3% of adult non-Hodgkin lymphomas. There is a male predominance (M:F ratio: 3:1). ALK-negative ALCL represents 5.5–15% of mature T-cell neoplasms. Most occur in adults, with a median age of 54 years (range: 18–89 years) and an M:F ratio of 1.6:1.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The aberrant expression of ALK is a consequence of chromosomal rearrangements that fuse the 3′ portion of ALK on chromosome 2p23 and the 5′ portion of a partner gene that leads to constitutive expression of the chimeric oncoprotein. The major fusion partner in ALK-positive ALCL is NPM1, which is involved in the t(2;5)(p23;q35) translocation. The NPM1::ALK oncogenic tyrosine kinase activates numerous cellular pathways, including the PLCγ, PI3K/AKT, Cdc42/Rac1, JNK/JUN, RAS/ERK/MAPK, mTOR, JAK/STAT3, and STAT5B pathways, to promote cancer. NPM1::ALK controls T-cell identity by epigenetic silencing of many T-cell–associated antigens. Activating mutations of JAK1 and STAT3 lead to constitutive activation of the JAK/STAT3 pathway. Rearrangement of 6p25.3 (harbouring DUSP22) occur in about 30% of cases, and these cases appear to be distinct from other ALK-negative ALCLs in that they lack STAT3 activation, resulting in a DNA hypomethylation state and enhanced immunogenicity. Rearrangement of TP63 occurs as an inversion of 3q28 in about 5% of cases, involving the partner gene TBL1XR1. Copy-number abnormalities, including loss of 17p13 (TP53), are seen in a subset.
microscopic: The tumour cells show an infiltrative, diffuse growth pattern that can be associated with necrosis. Cases with classic morphology demonstrate a variable number of characteristic hallmark cells that show abundant cytoplasm and large horseshoe-shaped nuclei with multiple nucleoli. The large lymphoma cells show abundant basophilic cytoplasm with occasional vacuoles and large pleomorphic nucleoli with prominent nucleoli. However, the morphological spectrum is broad. Some may have a plasmacytoid appearance with a prominent perinuclear hof and cytoplasmic vacuoles. Systemic ALCLs with cutaneous involvement can show mild epidermotropism and frequently have a component of small cells, like the primary cutaneous small cell pattern of ALCL. The neoplastic cells exhibit strong uniform expression of CD30 highlighting the cell membrane and Golgi region, and they are frequently positive for EMA, especially ALK-positive cases. Immunohistochemistry for ALK highlights the neoplastic cells and is reflective of aberrant expression of ALK secondary to ALK rearrangements. There is variable loss of T-cell–associated antigens. CD2, CD5, and CD4 are most commonly expressed (40–70% of cases), whereas CD3 is negative in > 75% of the cases. CD43 and CD45RO are commonly observed. The tumour cells express cytotoxic markers, including TIA1, granzyme B, and perforin, even when they lack T-cell antigens including CD8. They typically express strong uniform CD25, clusterin, and BCL6. CD15 and PAX5 are almost always absent. The tumour cells may also lack CD45 and T-cell receptor molecules such as βF1 or TCRδ; in addition, occasional cases aberrantly express epithelial markers such as cytokeratins, myeloid antigens such as CD13 and CD33, NK cell markers such as CD56, and stem cell transcriptional factors including SOX2. EBV is negative. ALCLs with DUSP22 rearrangement, however, have a different immunoprofile, in that they frequently lack cytotoxic markers.
differential_diagnosis: Distinguishing between skin involvement by systemic ALCL and primary cutaneous ALCL is important because of differences in their management and clinical outcome. Cases with large, cohesive tumour cells may simulate metastatic carcinoma. Plasmablastic lymphoma and primary effusion lymphomas (solid) may show cohesive sheets of large pleomorphic cells resembling the tumour cells of ALK-positive ALCL. Other neoplasms that express ALK, such as ALK-positive large B-cell lymphoma, inflammatory myofibroblastic tumours, histiocytic neoplasms, and carcinomas must be excluded.
staging: The Cotswold modification of the Ann Arbor staging system is the standard anatomical staging system used for patients with systemic ALCL.
prognosis_and_prediction: In patients with ALK-positive ALCL patients, long-term survival rates are about 80% and significantly better than ALK-negative ALCL, except for those that harbour the DUSP22 rearrangement. There is an approximate failure rate of 30% regardless of treatment strategy. Small molecule inhibitors that target ALK may modify the prognosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: ALK-positive ALCLs express the ALK fusion protein secondary to chromosomal translocations of the ALK gene at the 2p23 locus. ALK-negative ALCLs are a heterogeneous group comprising several cytogenetic subtypes with prognostic implications, including those with 6p25 rearrangements at the locus involving DUSP22 and the TP63 gene located on chromosome 3q28. Most cases of ALK-positive ALCL are diagnosed on the basis of aberrant expression of ALK protein by immunohistochemistry. Demonstration of clonal T-cell populations by TR gene rearrangement may confirm the neoplastic process.
related_terminology: None

definition: Severe mosquito bite allergy is an Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)-positive NK-cell (or occasionally T-cell) lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by high fever and severe skin manifestations after mosquito bites.
clinical:
Severe mosquito bite allergy is characterized by a high fever and severe skin manifestations after a mosquito (or rarely other insect) bite. The bite area develops blisters, bullae, indurations, necrosis, and ulceration, leaving a scar that heals in 2–3 weeks. Transient systemic symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, and hepatic dysfunction may occur, but persistence of systemic symptoms indicates systemic chronic active EBV disease. Patients have high levels of IgE, and EBV-infected large granular lymphocytes in the peripheral blood. Some patients also exhibit hydroa vacciniforme–like eruptions in sun-exposed areas.

---

The disease is extremely rare and has mostly been reported from eastern Asia, Mexico, and Central and South America. Most cases occur before the age of 20 years, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Genetic and environmental factors and EBV strains may play etiological roles.

---

In the event of a mosquito bite, CD4-positive T cells respond to mosquito salivary secretions and induce reactivation of EBV-infected NK cells, causing inflammation. Somatic mutations (including DDX3X mutations) have been detected in EBV-positive cells.
microscopic: There is a variably dense infiltrate of small to large atypical lymphocytes with a perivascular distribution in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue. An angiocentric and angiodestructive growth pattern is typically present in more advanced lesions, triggering necrosis, ulceration, and bulla formation. Most cases exhibit an NK-cell immunophenotype, but some have a T-cell phenotype. NK cells are negative for sCD3 and T-cell receptor proteins, and positive for CD3ε, CD16, CD56, and cytotoxic markers (e.g. TIA1 and granzyme B). Lymphoid cells are positive for EBV-encoded small RNA (EBER) by in situ hybridization.
differential_diagnosis: Mosquito bites may occasionally cause severe erythema, swelling, and blistering in healthy individuals, but unlike in severe mosquito bite allergy, there is usually no fever or ulceration. Hydroa vacciniforme lymphoproliferative disorder is morphologically identical to severe mosquito bite allergy but is distinguished by the clinical manifestations. Patients with persistent systemic symptoms are classified as having systemic chronic active EBV disease.
prognosis_and_prediction: The disease is protracted and associated with an increased risk for haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, chronic active EBV disease, aggressive NK-cell leukaemia, and extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma. Late-onset disease (> 9 years of age) and BZLF1 expression correlate with a poor prognosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: There is not currently a clinical assay to determine NK-cell clonality. In clinical practice, clonality testing for TR genes is performed and an absence of TR gene rearrangement provides indirect support of an NK-cell origin. However, identification of a clonal expansion (e.g. with the detection of an abnormal karyotype or the presence of a mutation) is indicative of a malignant evolution.
related_terminology: Not recommended: hypersensitivity to mosquito bites.

entity_name: Primary cutaneous peripheral T-cell lymphoma NOS
definition: Primary cutaneous peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PCPTCL-NOS) is a very rare and still poorly characterized group of T-cell lymphomas, which does not correspond to any of the specifically defined entities of primary cutaneous T-cell lymphomas (CTCLs) (i.e. it is a diagnosis of exclusion).
clinical:
Most patients present with disseminated plaques, papules, or tumours. About one third show (initially) solitary lesions. Ulceration can be found (~15%). PCPTCL-NOS is skin-limited at the time of diagnosis, but systemic involvement is common during the later disease course.

---

PCPTCL-NOS is exceedingly rare. Most cases of PCPTCL-NOS occur in adults in their sixth decade of life, but it can also occur in children. There is a male predominance (M:F ratio: 3:1).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The pathogenesis is largely unknown, although gain of chromosomes 7q, 8, and 17q, and loss of chromosome 9p21 have been reported.
microscopic: Since PCPTCL-NOS is a diagnosis of exclusion, distinct and characteristic histopathological and immunophenotypic features are lacking; however, any such features of other cutaneous T-cell lymphoma entities can be observed, albeit outside their typical context. There is a diffuse or nodular dermal infiltrate consisting of cohesive sheets of mostly medium-sized to large tumour cells, although cases consisting of small to medium-sized cells are also reported. The subcutis is commonly involved. Limited and focal epidermotropism of lymphocytes is found in approximately one third of cases. Angiocentric/angiodestructive features and folliculotropism are rare. The tumour cells are positive for CD3 and CD2. The most common phenotype is CD4+/CD8−. About one third of cases show a CD4−/CD8− phenotype, and approximately 10% are CD4+/CD8+. EBV is negative. Cytotoxic markers (TIA1 and granzyme B) are mostly negative (75%). Aberrant expression of CD20 can occur. The proliferative activity is moderate to high (30–90%). PD1 expression (> 40%) can be found. Very rare cases of primary CTCLs with a T follicular helper (TFH) cell phenotype have been described; further data are needed to clarify whether these should be recognized as a separate pattern, subtype, or entity in the future. Therefore, primary CTCLs with a TFH cell phenotype (defined by the expression of at least two to three TFH cell markers: PD1, ICOS, CD10, BCL6, CXCL13) should currently be mentioned in this group, i.e. as PCPTCL-NOS with TFH phenotype.
staging: PCPTCL-NOS is staged according to the International Society for Cutaneous Lymphomas (ISCL) and Cutaneous Lymphoma Task Force of the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) guidelines.
prognosis_and_prediction: In general, the prognosis of PCPTCL-NOS is poor, with mean overall survival rates between 27 months and 5.6 years. Some studies reported a better prognosis for solitary lesions. This might provide a rationale for radiotherapy in such cases. B symptoms, multifocal lesions, and systemic involvement are unfavourable prognostic criteria. In disseminated lesions, multiagent chemotherapy is used, even if not very effective.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not generally relevant. TR gene rearrangements can be informative but are not disease-specific.
related_terminology: Acceptable: primary cutaneous peripheral T-cell lymphoma, unspecified.

entity_name: Primary cutaneous CD8-positive aggressive epidermotropic cytotoxic T-cell lymphoma
definition: Primary cutaneous CD8-positive aggressive epidermotropic cytotoxic T-cell lymphoma (PCAETL) is a neoplastic proliferation of T lymphocytes usually expressing CD8 along with other cytotoxic molecules, characterized by striking epidermal involvement, with epidermal necrosis, a high proliferative index, and aggressive clinical behaviour.
clinical:
PCAETL is characterized by roundish, localized, well-defined plaques and tumours or, more commonly, by generalized papules and nodules, showing central–peripheral erosive or necrotic evolution. Localized cases rapidly develop more widespread disease. Ulcerated tumours appear at advanced stages, and the presence of a large ulcer may mimic pyoderma gangrenosum. Typically, PCAETL is not associated with immunosuppression. Differential diagnosis from cytotoxic primary cutaneous peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PCPTCL) NOS may be considered in cases with localized plaques and tumours. In some patients, lesions may be preceded by chronic poorly defined patches similar to those of mycosis fungoides. Cases of CD8-positive PCAETL in transformed mycosis fungoides are also reported. PCAETL may disseminate to visceral sites (lung, CNS); superficial lymph nodes are usually spared. Blood involvement is exceedingly rare.

---

PCAETL is extremely rare (< 1% of cutaneous T-cell lymphomas [CTCLs]) and can occur at any age, but it occurs more commonly in adults and in males.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Overactivation of JAK-2 through gene fusion events is observed in virtually all cases expressing CD8 (not detected in other cytotoxic CTCLs). In fusion-negative cases, gain-of-function mutations in JAK2, STAT3, and STAT5B and loss of negative regulators of the JAK/STAT pathway, particularly SH2B3, can be observed. Immunohistochemistry can be used to detect activation of the JAK/STAT pathway.
microscopic: Infiltrates are monomorphic to pleomorphic and are formed by atypical T lymphocytes. Tumour cells are medium-sized, with large pleomorphic lymphocytes often seen in tumoural lesions. Nuclei are often indented, with scant cytoplasm. In some cases, the infiltrate is composed of immunoblastic cells. Cytotoxic T cells show striking pagetoid epidermotropism, especially in cases with diffuse generalized lesions, and marked adnexotropism may be seen. Spongiosis can lead to blister formation. In tumours, the infiltrate involves the whole dermis with a patchy or diffuse pattern. Histological signs of cytotoxicity (epidermal, adnexal, and dermal necrosis; haemorrhage; karyorrhexis) are common, while angiocentricity is rare. Rimming of subcutaneous fat spaces has been reported. Most cases show a CD3+, CD8+, CD4− phenotype, but CD8 may be very weak and occasionally negative. βF1+ (TCRβ) expression with cytotoxic markers (TIA1, granzyme B, perforin) and a high Ki-67 proliferation index (> 75%) are expected. A significant subset of cases express CD45RA and lack CD2 and CD5, suggesting a naïve T-cell phenotype. TCRδ and EBV-encoded small RNA (EBER) are negative; CD7 and CD56 are variably expressed. These cases tend to be CCR4− (~90%). Immunohistochemistry can also be used to detect activation of the JAK/STAT pathway with phosphorylated STAT3 and phosphorylated STAT5.
differential_diagnosis: Clinical correlation and extensive immunophenotypic studies (see #34538Table 6.17, and #38297Table 6.18) are necessary to differentiate this entity from other epidermotropic CD8-positive CTCL, such as mycosis fungoides, lymphomatoid papulosis type D, and the cytotoxic pattern of PCPTCL-NOS.
staging: PCAETL is staged according to the TNM classification system for CTCL other than mycosis fungoides and Sézary syndrome.
prognosis_and_prediction: PCAETL has an aggressive course (median survival time: 12 months). No significant prognostic differences have been found between cases with small or large cell morphology and localized or diffuse lesions.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The presence of clonal TR gene rearrangement and the detection of JAK2 gene fusions or mutations activating the JAK/STAT pathway may help in the diagnosis of PCAETL.
related_terminology: Not recommended: Berti lymphoma; Ketron–Goodman/disseminated pagetoid reticulosis.

definition: Primary cutaneous gamma-delta T-cell lymphoma (PCGD-TCL) is a clonal proliferation of mature, activated γδ T cells of the Vδ1 or Vδ2 subsets, arising within the skin and subcutaneous tissues.
clinical:
The clinical presentation and disease course of PCGD-TCL are variable, so a definitive diagnosis may not be achieved on the initial biopsy. Some patients present with generalized scaly patches and plaques suggestive of mycosis fungoides, while others present with deep dermal and/or subcutaneous nodules or tumours. Ulceration and rapid evolution can be seen in either presentation. Both patterns may be present in the same patient. Haemophagocytic syndrome and spread to extranodal (visceral) sites cause significant morbidity. Involvement of lymph nodes or bone marrow is uncommon. B symptoms, including fever, night sweats, and weight loss, occur frequently. Findings on CT and PET-CT commonly signal cutaneous and extracutaneous sites of involvement.

---

PCGD-TCLs comprise < 1% of primary cutaneous lymphomas. SEER Program data (2006–2015) showed a cumulative incidence of 0.40 cases per 10 million population, a median patient age of 63 years, and a male predominance.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Immune dysfunction associated with chronic antigenic stimulation may play a role in the origin of PCGD-TCL. TR gene chain usage is non-random, suggesting common antigenic drivers.

---

Studies show a heterogeneous genomic landscape, with recurrent mutations of putative driver genes within the JAK/STAT, MAPK, MYC, and chromatin modification pathways, as well as mutations in consensus cancer genes and in tumour suppressor genes. The heterogeneity of PCGD-TCL may be related to different cells of origin with distinct roles in the immunity of their originating skin compartments: delta 1 expression (Vδ1) associates with the superficial cutaneous or mucosal epitheliotropic lymphomas, and delta 2 expression (Vδ2) with the subcutaneous lymphomas. Ultraviolet (UV) radiation signature mutation profiles are more common in delta 1 cases, whereas senescence-related mutagenesis is noted in subcutaneous cases. Patients with deep dermal and subcutaneous lesions show enrichment in interferon-γ and other inflammatory cytokines, which probably drives the haemophagocytic syndrome.
microscopic: Malignant cells are predominantly medium-sized but can range from small to large, with elongated nuclei and coarse chromatin. Any skin compartment (epidermis, dermis, subcutis, or any combination thereof) may be involved by PCGD-TCL, and sequential and contemporaneous biopsies may show different compartmental infiltration. Epidermal and intraepithelial (adnexal) infiltrates can be subtle, negligible, or exuberant and pagetoid. Angiotropism is occasionally observed. Dermal involvement may be nodular/perivascular or diffuse. Subcutaneous extension involves lobular and septal sites, with rimming of adipocytes, apoptosis, and karyorrhexis. Additional cytotoxic tissue alteration includes vacuolar interface alteration at the dermoepidermal junction, coagulative necrosis, and angioinvasion. Tumour cells are positive for TCRγ and TCRδ, and negative for TCRβ. A CD3+, CD2+, CD7+/−, CD5− immunophenotype with expression of at least one cytotoxic protein, including granzyme B, perforin, and/or TIA1, is typical. The majority of cases are negative for both CD4 and CD8, although CD8 positivity may be seen. CD56 expression is present in almost half of PCGD-TCL cases. CD30 is expressed in a minority of cases. EBV is negative.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes, in particular, gamma-delta lymphoproliferative cutaneous disorders (e.g. gamma-delta subtypes of mycosis fungoides and lymphomatoid papulosis), as well as lupus profundus.
staging: PCGD-TCL is staged according to the TNM classification system for primary cutaneous lymphomas other than mycosis fungoides and Sézary syndrome.
prognosis_and_prediction: PCGD-TCLs are generally aggressive lymphomas, with a median survival of < 2 years. Decreased survival is described in patients with histological evidence of panniculitic rather than superficial involvement. Haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, metastatic disease, and infections are associated with poor survival. PCGD-TCL responds poorly to chemotherapies. Allogeneic transplantation may provide the best option for prolonged remission.
cytology: FNAB is not recommended in this diagnosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Demonstration of clonal TR gene rearrangement can be helpful.
related_terminology: None

definition: Subcutaneous panniculitis-like T-cell lymphoma (SPTCL) is a lymphoproliferative disorder with adipotropism that mostly involves the subcutaneous tissue but occasionally involves other sites. It is predominantly composed of CD8-positive lymphocytes expressing the TCRαβ heterodimer. Other cytotoxic lymphomas frequently involving the subcutaneous tissue, like gamma-delta and NK/T-cell lymphomas, are excluded from this category.
clinical:
Patients present with tender, non-ulcerated nodules. A sequela of lipoatrophy is occasionally observed. Constitutional symptoms, including fever and malaise, are commonly observed, while approximately 20–30% of cases may evolve to haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis. A minority of cases present with a single nodule that can trigger similar systemic symptoms.

---

SPTCL is rare. The incidence rate is approximately 1.5 new cases per 10 million person-years in the USA, but it is more common in Asia. There is a female predominance (M:F ratio: 1:3–4). The median age at presentation is 35–42 years, with a significant number of paediatric and adolescent cases. Autoimmune comorbidities are observed in at least 25% of cases; in particular, lupus erythematosus is a common comorbidity, which may cause difficulties in differentiating SPTCL from an associated lupus panniculitis.
pathogenesis:
Autoimmunity and immune dysregulation may play a role in many cases. The constellation of findings may overlap with lupus erythematosus, raising the differential diagnosis of lupus panniculitis in cases presenting with lymphocyte-rich lobular infiltrates with adipotropic features. SPTCL is not associated with EBV.

---

Germline mutations of HAVCR2 altering the HAVCR2 protein (also known as TIM3), a negative membrane modulator of immune response, have been identified in 25% of patients of European descent and 51–85% of patients of Asian descent. Protein misfolding abrogates membrane expression of this negative immune checkpoint, regulating peripheral tolerance. Low levels of T regulatory (Treg) cells (FOXP3+, CCR4+) may lead to immune activation. Various triggers have been proposed for patients without germline mutations, including viral infections and autoimmunity.
microscopic: The infiltrate is typically composed of medium-sized lymphocytes with irregular and hyperchromatic nuclei, involving the subcutaneous lobules and often extending into the periadnexal fat pad. The atypical cells may display a rimming pattern around adipocytes with variable fat necrosis, karyorrhectic debris, and haemorrhage. Lipid-laden macrophages are abundant and may show haemophagocytosis. Plasma cells, granulocytes, and plasmacytoid dendritic cells are inconspicuous. Tumoural large cell transformation is typically not observed.
ancillary_studies: This reveals CD8-positive mature T cells with αβ heterodimer expression (BF1+) and retention of pan–T-cell markers (CD2+, CD5+, CD7+). The cells display foci of high Ki-67 proliferative activity and typically express the cytotoxic markers TIA1, perforin, and granzyme B. CD30 and EBV-encoded small RNA (EBER) are negative. A small subset of reactive T cells expressing TCRγδ may be observed, but markers for Treg cells (FOXP3, CCR4) are typically low. Clusters of plasmacytoid dendritic cells are not present in SPTCL, in contrast to lupus panniculitis.
differential_diagnosis: This includes lupus panniculitis, gamma-delta T-cell lymphomas, and EBV-positive NK/T-cell lymphomas (see #36592Table 6.15).
staging: SPTCL is staged according to the TNM classification system for primary cutaneous lymphomas other than mycosis fungoides and Sézary syndrome.
prognosis_and_prediction: SPTCL carries a good prognosis, often responding to a variety of therapies including systemic steroids and immunosuppressive drugs (e.g. ciclosporin or methotrexate). Single-agent or multiagent chemotherapies are also effective and tend to be used when immunomodulatory agents fail. Life-threatening haemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, particularly in patients with HAVCR2 mutations (approximately 20–30% of patients), may require chemoablative therapy followed by stem cell transplantation.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Clonal rearrangements of TR genes (in particular TRB and TRG) are detected in most cases. EBV in situ hybridization is negative.
related_terminology: None

entity_name: Primary cutaneous CD30-positive T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder: Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma
definition: Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma (C-ALCL) is a mature T-cell lymphoma characterized by anaplastic, pleomorphic, or immunoblastic cells, with CD30 expression in > 75% of tumour cells.
clinical:
Most patients present with solitary or localized skin nodules or tumours, rarely papules, often with ulceration. Multifocal lesions are seen in about 20% of patients. Lesions may show partial or complete regression (~20–25%). Relapse in skin is common. Regional lymph nodes are involved in approximately 10%.

---

C-ALCL is the second most common form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. The median age is 60 years; children can be affected. The M:F ratio is 2–3:1.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Rearrangement of the DUSP22 locus at 6p25.3 occurs in 20–25% of C-ALCL. Rearrangements of the TP63 gene are rare in C-ALCL. Frequent chromosomal aberrations are gains of 7q31 and losses at 6q16-q21 and 13q34. NPM1::TYK2 fusion, resulting in constitutive STAT signalling, has been described in sporadic cases of C-ALCL. TYK2 fusions were found in 15%, leading to upregulation of PI3K, MAPK, and G protein pathways. Gene expression profiling revealed high expression of the skin-homing chemokine receptor genes CCR10 and CCR8, possibly explaining skin tropism and infrequent extracutaneous dissemination. The vast majority of C-ALCLs do not show translocations involving the ALK gene at chromosome 2. Rare cases of ALK-positive C-ALCL, including cases with the t(2;5) chromosomal translocation and cases with variant ALK fusion partners have been reported both in children and in adults, usually with an excellent prognosis.
microscopic: The dermis is infiltrated by tumour cells with anaplastic morphology, with round / oval / irregularly shaped nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm. Less commonly, the tumour cells show a pleomorphic or immunoblastic appearance. Epidermotropism may be present, particularly in cases with DUSP22 rearrangement. Ulcerated lesions may show a lymphomatoid papulosis–like histology, with abundant reactive T cells (mostly at lesion borders); admixed histiocytes, eosinophils, and neutrophils; and relatively few CD30-positive cells. In such cases, epidermal hyperplasia may be prominent. The inflammatory background is prominent in the rare neutrophil-rich (pyogenic) and eosinophil-rich patterns. Cases with prominent angiocentric and angiodestructive growth have been described. Rare cases of intralymphatic and intravascular C-ALCL occur. Mucosal lesions show a similar spectrum of features. A more recent sarcomatoid pattern has been reported, which can be confused with mesenchymal skin tumours. The neoplastic cells show variable loss of CD2, CD3, CD5, and CD7, and frequent expression of cytotoxic proteins such as TIA1, perforin, granzyme M, and granzyme B. Some may show a CD4+/CD8−, CD4−/CD8+, or CD4+/CD8+ T-cell phenotype. CD43 expression is usually seen, and most cases are negative for EMA. CD30 is expressed by > 75% of tumour cells. CD15 is expressed in approximately 40% of cases. Cases can be TCRβ+, TCRβ−/TCRδ−, and rarely TCRδ+. LEF1 expression is associated with DUSP22 rearrangement. In contrast to systemic anaplastic large cell lymphoma, almost all cases of C-ALCL lack expression of ALK, except for exceedingly rare cases of ALK-positive C-ALCL.
differential_diagnosis: The distinction between C-ALCL and lymphomatoid papulosis may be challenging and is usually established on clinical grounds. The term borderline lesions may be used in those cases where, despite careful clinicopathological correlation, a definite distinction between C-ALCL and lymphomatoid papulosis cannot be made. CD30-positive large cell transformation of mycosis fungoides should also be excluded. Reactive CD30-positive disorders (viral or arthropod) may be included in the differential diagnosis, although it is often more relevant to consider these for lymphomatoid papulosis, and very rarely for C-ALCL.
staging: The TNM classification system for primary cutaneous lymphomas other than mycosis fungoides is applied. Staging includes extensive history (including history of lymphoid neoplasms and duration of skin lesions), laboratory studies, and imaging studies (contrast-enhanced CT with and without PET, or whole-body integrated PET). Bone marrow examination has limited value unless there are multifocal lesions or unexplained abnormal haematological values.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis is favourable, with a 10-year disease-related survival rate of approximately 90%. Presentation with multifocal skin lesions or regional lymph node involvement does not influence the prognosis. Worse outcome has been associated with extensive skin lesions on the legs, or patient age > 60 years.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Clonal rearrangements of TR genes are detected in most cases.
related_terminology: None

entity_name: Primary cutaneous CD4-positive small or medium T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder
definition: Primary cutaneous CD4-positive small or medium T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder (PCSM-LPD) is characterized by a predominance of small to medium-sized CD4-positive pleomorphic T cells, and by a solitary skin lesion without evidence of the plaques typical of mycosis fungoides.
clinical:
Because PCSM-LPD cases have the same benign clinical course as cutaneous reactive T-cell–rich lymphoid proliferations (see section Reactive T-cell–rich lymphoid proliferations), the term primary cutaneous CD4-positive small or medium T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder rather than lymphoma is preferred. PCSM-LPD affects adults in the majority of cases, but paediatric cases have been described. The most frequent clinical presentation is an asymptomatic erythematous solitary nodule, followed by tumour, papule, macule, or plaque. The size ranges from 4 mm to 60 mm. In patients with multifocal lesions, a diagnosis of peripheral T-cell lymphoma NOS must be ruled out.

---

This is the second most common cutaneous T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder following mycosis fungoides, accounting for 6% to 7.5% of primary cutaneous lymphomas.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

PCSM-LPD may reflect a response to an antigen stimulus, with both B-cell and T-cell recruitment, including a signifying T follicular helper (TFH) cell population.
microscopic: There are two common architectural patterns (see #38258Table 6.13): mostly (78% of cases) a nodular and/or diffuse lymphoproliferation infiltrating the entire dermis and sometimes expanding into the subcutis; and less frequently, a subepidermal band-like infiltrate filling the superficial dermis (resembling mycosis fungoides / Sézary syndrome), often associated with a periadnexal distribution. Epidermotropism may be present focally, but if epidermotropism is conspicuous, the diagnosis of mycosis fungoides should be considered. Adnexotropism (with follicular destruction) is very characteristic. A predominance of small to medium-sized pleomorphic T cells with no more than 40% of large cells is characteristic.
ancillary_studies: PCSM-LPD has a CD3+, CD4+, CD8−, CD30− phenotype but includes an admixed B-cell component (the latter can account for up to 60% of cells, sometimes with large immunoblasts). Small reactive CD8+ T cells as a minority admixed population are almost ubiquitous (arranged in a starry-sky pattern), and sparse CD30+ T or B cells, plasma cells, eosinophils, and histiocytes (including multinucleated giant cells) may be present. Lymphoid follicles are uncommon. Plasma cells are sometimes light chain–restricted. The loss of pan–T-cell antigens (except for CD7) is uncommon. Cytotoxic proteins are not expressed. Atypical CD4+ T cells express TFH markers: PD1 (by medium-sized to large cells forming clusters or rosettes), ICOS, CXCL13 (few positive cells), and BCL6 (sparse medium-sized to large lymphocytes), but not CD10. The proliferative rate is often low (Ki-67 index: ~25%), but it can (rarely) reach 40%.
differential_diagnosis: The major differential diagnosis is marginal zone B-cell lymphoma. The differential diagnosis also includes cutaneous reactive T-cell–rich lymphoid proliferation (but reactive T-cell–rich lymphoid proliferation and PCSM-LPD belong to a common spectrum of diseases), mycosis fungoides, and lymphomatoid papulosis (in case of multiple skin lesions). Rare cases presenting with widespread skin lesions, > 40% large pleomorphic T cells, and/or a high proliferative fraction do not belong to this group and are better classified as peripheral T-cell lymphoma NOS.
prognosis_and_prediction: Patients have an excellent prognosis; local or distant recurrences are uncommon, and there is no long-term risk of secondary lymphoma. Intralesional steroids, surgical excision, and radiotherapy are the preferred modes of treatment. Spontaneous regression after biopsy is frequent (reported in 32% of cases).
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: TR genes are clonally rearranged in most cases (70%), with no impact on prognosis. A coexisting B-cell clone may occur (26%).
related_terminology: Not recommended: primary cutaneous CD4+ small/medium pleomorphic T-cell lymphoma; pseudolymphomatous folliculitis.

definition: B-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma (B-ALL/LBL) is a neoplasm of precursor lymphoid cells committed to the B-cell lineage.
clinical:
Cutaneous involvement of B-LBL typically occurs concurrently with B-ALL and manifests as solitary or multiple rapidly growing, firm, erythematous to violaceous nodules. Rare cases of primary cutaneous disease have been reported. Patients with lymphoma presentation are often aleukaemic.

---

B-LBL is a rare malignant neoplasm most often found in children and adolescents; B-LBL accounts for 20% of all cases of lymphoblastic lymphoma in children. As many as one third of cases of B-LBL may involve the skin.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The postulated normal counterpart is a haematopoietic precursor cell committed to the B lineage. Multiple molecular pathways seem to be affected for leukaemogenesis.
microscopic: Skin biopsy demonstrates a dense, monotonous dermal infiltrate with sheets of neoplastic cells sparing the upper dermis and surround appendages, dissecting collagen fibres of small to medium-sized blastic cells with a high N:C ratio, thin nuclear membranes, finely stippled chromatin, and inconspicuous nucleoli. The neoplastic cells vary from small blasts with scant cytoplasm, condensed nuclear chromatin, and indistinct nucleoli to medium-sized blastic cells with a high N:C ratio. The tumour cells have moderate amounts of bluish-grey cytoplasm, occasional vacuoles, thin nuclear membranes, finely stippled chromatin, and multiple variably prominent round or convoluted nucleoli. Mitoses and apoptotic debris are often present. Tumour-infiltrating lymphocytes are rare. CD19, CD79a, CD22, TdT, CD34, CD10, CD24, and PAX5 are commonly expressed by the tumour cells. CD20 is typically negative.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes T-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, acute myeloid leukaemia, chronic lymphocytic leukaemia or chronic myeloid leukaemia in blast phase, B-prolymphocytic leukaemia, mantle cell lymphoma, plasma cell leukaemia, and small blue round cell tumours (e.g. Ewing sarcoma / primitive neuroectodermal tumour). Non-malignant entities, including HIV and infectious mononucleosis, may also be considered.
prognosis_and_prediction: Although highly aggressive, B-LBL may be curable if diagnosed early, particularly in children.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Genetic abnormalities are now the fundamental basis for subclassification of B-ALL/LBL. For details, see the Haematolymphoid tumours volume of this series [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Haematolymphoid tumours. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2024. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 11). https://publications.iarc.who.int/637.]].
related_terminology: Acceptable: B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (B-ALL); precursor B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia; B-precursor or B-lymphoblastic leukaemia of defined precursor maturational stage (pro-B, pre-pre-B, pre-B, common, etc.).

B-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma. The neoplastic cells have blastoid features, with open chromatin and variably prominent nucleoli. Mitotic figures are identified readily. Numerous tingible-body macrophages are present, imparting a starry-sky pattern.
B-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma. The neoplastic cells are positive for CD19.
B-lymphoblastic leukaemia/lymphoma. The neoplastic cells are positive for TdT.

entity_name: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia / small lymphocytic lymphoma
definition: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) / small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) is a B-cell lymphoma comprising monomorphic small mature B cells that frequently coexpress CD5 and CD23. A peripheral blood diagnosis of CLL requires a B-cell count of ≥ 5 × 109/L with the characteristic morphology and immunophenotype. A tissue-based diagnosis of SLL requires organ enlargement (e.g. lymphadenopathy > 15 mm) and its infiltration by the above neoplastic B cells. Although CLL and SLL represent the same disease, the name SLL is used for cases with < 5 × 109/L circulating B cells and nodal, splenic, or other extramedullary involvement.
clinical:
Skin involvement by CLL/SLL usually occurs in patients with known CLL; only rarely is CLL/SLL first detected in the skin. Cutaneous lesions can be single, aggregated but localized, or (rarely) generalized. The lesions are erythematous papules, plaques, nodules, or large tumours. CLL/SLL is frequently associated with a second skin disease observed in the same biopsy and may involve sites of herpes simplex virus or varicella zoster virus or other infections, foci of trauma, or surrounding epithelial or non-epithelial malignancies. Rarely, the skin is the site of transformation of CLL to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (Richter transformation).

---

The incidence of CLL rises with age (median age: 58–70 years), and there is a male predominance. The skin is the most common extramedullary, extranodal site of involvement.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Family members of patients with CLL have a 5–8-fold increased risk of CLL.

---

CLL cells most closely resemble antigen-experienced, memory-like B cells. Cytogenetic and molecular genetic abnormalities, epigenetic factors, and the tumour microenvironment influence disease evolution.
microscopic: CLL/SLL takes the form of a perivascular/periadnexal, nodular, diffuse, or (rarely) band-like infiltrate of small, monotonous lymphocytes with clumped chromatin in the dermis with extension to the subcutis. Proliferation centres are uncommon. An underlying associated second skin disease possibly obscured by the CLL infiltration should be investigated.
ancillary_studies: The neoplastic lymphoid cells typically express CD19, CD20, CD5, CD23, CD43, and LEF1, and are negative for CD10, cyclin D1, and SOX11.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes reactive small lymphoid infiltrates and other neoplastic infiltrates predominantly composed of small lymphoid cells.
staging: For CLL, the Rai and Binet systems are used [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Haematolymphoid tumours. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2024. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 11). https://publications.iarc.who.int/637.]]. The stage of SLL is determined with the Lugano modifications to the Ann Arbor system.
prognosis_and_prediction: Although del(13q) as a sole aberration is associated with indolent disease, TP53 deletion and/or mutation predicts resistance to chemoimmunotherapy. The status of somatic hypermutation of IGHV genes is a key prognostic marker (see #32195Table 6.11).
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Cytogenetics, FISH, and molecular investigations are typically undertaken on peripheral blood in patients with CLL/SLL.
related_terminology: Acceptable: B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukaemia / small lymphocytic lymphoma.

definition: Burkitt lymphoma (BL) is a mature, aggressive B-cell neoplasm composed of monomorphic, medium-sized cells with basophilic cytoplasm, multiple small nucleoli, a germinal-centre B-cell phenotype, a high proliferation index, and IG::MYC rearrangement.
clinical:
Cutaneous involvement can be seen at presentation or relapse, with subcutaneous nodules or (less often) macules, papules, or large plaques, typically along with extracutaneous disease. The lesions are usually multiple and widespread, suggesting haematogenous dissemination. The skin can be involved via extension from underlying lymphoma and postsurgical procedures such as excisions of lymph nodes involved by BL. Although rare, BL of the skin may mimic herpes zoster infection clinically.

---

Cutaneous BL occurs in the setting of HIV infection, as well as in individuals who are otherwise healthy. Only 2% of HIV-positive patients with BL have cutaneous involvement. Nearly all patients with cutaneous BL are male, and adults are affected more commonly than children.
pathogenesis:
Risk factors for endemic BL are Plasmodium falciparum (malaria) and EBV infections. Factors causing BL in low incidence areas, such as Europe, Asia, and South America, are not well understood. The presence or absence of EBV better correlates with distinct biological subtypes of BL. EBV is detected in, at most, 20% of patients with sporadic BL. A subset of cases are related to immunodeficiency. HIV infection is the most common cause of immunodeficiency in patients with BL.

---

All subtypes of BL carry MYC translocations that probably occur as mistakes in immunoglobulin heavy chain switching or IGV somatic hypermutation. EBV may be essential early in BL pathogenesis by allowing B cells with genetic defects to evade apoptosis. The presence of ID3 and TCF4 mutations in BL results in tonic B-cell receptor signalling. These mutations are nearly mutually exclusive with EBV infection, suggesting a dual mechanism of BL pathogenesis: mutational versus virus-driven.
microscopic: A diffuse infiltrate of medium-sized, monotonous lymphoid cells with round nuclei, finely clumped chromatin, multiple medium-sized basophilic nucleoli, and deeply basophilic cytoplasm involves the dermis and/or subcutis, sparing the epidermis. Mitoses are numerous. Interspersed apoptotic debris is often abundant. Tingible-body macrophages typically impart a starry-sky appearance.
ancillary_studies: The neoplastic cells are positive for CD20, CD10, BCL6, and MYC and negative for BCL2 and TdT. EBV, as demonstrated by in situ hybridization for EBV-encoded small RNA (EBER), can be positive or negative, and the Ki-67 proliferation index is nearly 100%.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes other aggressive B-lineage lymphomas, such as diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, high-grade B-cell lymphoma with concurrent MYC and BCL2 rearrangements, the blastoid subtype of mantle cell lymphoma, plasmablastic lymphoma, and lymphoblastic lymphoma. Strict adherence to diagnostic criteria is required to exclude other entities in the differential diagnosis.
staging: The predominantly extranodal distribution of BL makes Ann Arbor staging suboptimal. The system proposed by Murphy in 1980 and revised in 2015 is used routinely for cases in children.
prognosis_and_prediction: Patients usually present with advanced-stage disease. With appropriate therapy, the prognosis is good. Disseminated cutaneous involvement appears to be an unfavourable prognostic factor.
cytology: If amenable to FNA, skin lesions consist of medium-sized lymphoid cells with deeply basophilic cytoplasm, often containing some fine lipid vacuoles. Nuclei are round, and multiple basophilic nucleoli are noted.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Translocation involving MYC and IGH, or less often IGK or IGL, is characteristic. Translocations of BCL2 and BCL6 are absent.
related_terminology: Not recommended: Burkitt cell leukaemia; atypical Burkitt lymphoma; Burkitt-like lymphoma.
subtypes: Traditional subtypes: endemic Burkitt lymphoma; sporadic Burkitt lymphoma; immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt lymphoma. Recommended subtypes: EBV-associated Burkitt lymphoma; EBV-negative Burkitt lymphoma.

media.legend: Burkitt lymphoma. The patient was an adult woman from Africa. This skin lesion corresponds to a dense, diffuse lymphoid infiltrate filling most of the dermis and sparing the epidermis.

Burkitt lymphoma. The tumour cells are medium-sized, with round or slightly irregular nuclei, coarsely stippled chromatin, small nucleoli, and a small amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are frequent (oil immersion).

definition: Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is a neoplasm of small to medium-sized monomorphic B cells typically expressing CD5, cyclin D1, and SOX11; CCND1 translocation is present in > 95% of cases, leading to aberrant expression of cyclin D1.
clinical:
MCL involves skin at presentation or relapse, typically with widespread extracutaneous disease. There is insufficient support for the existence of MCL as a primary tumour of the skin. Lesions are usually nodules but may manifest as infiltrated plaques or macular lesions.

---

Approximately 2–12% of cases of MCL involve the skin. Cutaneous involvement is more common in men and older adults (median age: > 60 years).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The genetic hallmark of MCL is t(11;14)(q13;q32), present in ≥ 95% of cases. This translocation juxtaposes CCND1 at 11q13 to IGH on chromosome 14q32 and results in overexpression of cyclin D1. Activation of the cyclin D1–dependent kinase pathway overcomes the cell-cycle suppressive effects of RB1 and p27. MYC translocations and TP53 mutations are often associated with disease progression. The neural transcription factor SOX11 also plays an important oncogenic role in MCL.
microscopic: MCL produces a nodular, diffuse, or perivascular and periadnexal dermal infiltrate separated from the epidermis by a grenz zone. The tumour may extend into the subcutaneous fat. Classic MCL has small to medium-sized cells with slightly irregular nuclear contours, inconspicuous nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm. Most cases of MCL involving the skin present with a blastoid or pleomorphic cytology. The blastoid subtype shows medium-sized cells with dispersed chromatin, frequent mitoses, and Ki-67 > 40%. The pleomorphic subtype has larger, pleomorphic nuclei.
ancillary_studies: MCL is typically CD20+, CD5+, CD10−, BCL6−, BCL2+, CD23−, cyclin D1+, and SOX11+. Occasionally, MCL is CD5−, CD10+, CD23+, or (infrequently) cyclin D1− or SOX11−.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes other B-cell neoplasms. Importantly, plasma cell myeloma may also have CCND1 rearrangements and express cyclin D1. Since cutaneous MCL is often the blastoid or pleomorphic subtype, it may mimic diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and lymphoblastic lymphoma.
staging: Staging is performed according to the Lugano criteria.
prognosis_and_prediction: In general, the prognosis of MCL is worse with older patient age, blastoid and pleomorphic subtypes, and high proliferation index. TP53 mutation analysis may help to define a high-risk MCL cohort. Detailed guidelines for Ki-67 and TP53 assessment in MCL have been established.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: In the context of the appropriate morphology and immunophenotype, demonstration of uniform nuclear overexpression of cyclin D1 is sufficient to confirm the diagnosis. If the morphology or the immunophenotype are not diagnostic, demonstration of CCND1 rearrangement or CCND1:IGH translocation and an extended immunohistochemistry panel is recommended. Common secondary changes include deletion and/or mutation of ATM and TP53, deletion of CDKN2A, and abnormalities of MYC.
related_terminology: Not recommended: mantle zone lymphoma; centrocytic lymphoma; malignant lymphoma, lymphocytic intermediate differentiation, diffuse.
subtypes: Morphological subtypes: see #38136Table 6.10 . Molecular subtypes: cyclin D1–positive mantle cell lymphoma; cyclin D1–negative mantle cell lymphoma.

This patient relapsed with widespread disease 6 years after being diagnosed with mantle cell lymphoma and after receiving aggressive therapy including bone marrow transplant. There is a diffuse dermal proliferation of blastoid cells separated from the epidermis by a grenz zone of uninvolved papillary dermis. The patient died within 1 week of this skin biopsy.

Mantle cell lymphoma (blastoid subtype). The neoplastic cells are mitotically active, medium-sized atypical cells with oval and irregular nuclei, finely dispersed chromatin, occasional small nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm.

The neoplastic cells are mitotically active, medium-sized atypical cells with oval and irregular nuclei, finely dispersed chromatin, occasional small nucleoli, and scant cytoplasm.

definition: Intravascular large B-cell lymphoma (IVLBCL) is an aggressive extranodal B-cell lymphoma characterized by the proliferation of large neoplastic B cells virtually restricted to the lumina of blood vessels. The skin is most commonly affected, with diverse dermatological manifestations.
clinical:
The cutaneous subtype is by definition restricted to the skin at presentation. A wide range of appearances are described, including peau dorange–like lesions, palpable blue-red discolouration, solitary or clustered plaques, and ulcerating nodules and tumours. In the cutaneous subtype, as many as 30% of patients present with systemic symptoms. Most patients present with fever of unknown origin (50–70%), pain, local organ-specific symptoms, or multiorgan failure. The most common site of presentation is the skin (30–40%), but by definition this is associated with the involvement of other organs. A random deep skin biopsy (with the inclusion of subcutaneous fat tissue), even in the absence of clinically overt cutaneous lesions, can be helpful in the diagnosis. Presenting symptoms are dominated by those related to haemophagocytic syndrome, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia (> 75%), and the onset and clinical course are generally rapid. Skin involvement often spares the dermis but may be present in the subcutaneous tissue, even when there is no skin eruption.

---

The cutaneous subtype occurs in patients with a median age of 59 years, is virtually restricted to women, and is more frequent in countries in the Western Hemisphere. The classic subtype of IVLBCL occurs in adults with a median age of 70 years and has no sex predilection. The haemophagocytic subtype is predominantly reported in Asian countries and has a similar mean age at presentation and age distribution to the classic subtype. Overall, the incidence of the disease is 0.095 cases per 1 million person-years, without important geographical differences, in contrast to the geographical distribution seen in the subtypes.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Viral associations are not described.

---

Tumour cells are confined to the intravascular space by various mechanisms that allow them to adhere to endothelial cells but render them unable to migrate across the blood vessel wall. MYD88 and CD79B hotspot mutations are reported in 50% and almost 70% of cases, respectively. SETD1B (57%) and HLA-B (57%) mutations are also common. Structural variants affecting CD274 (encoding PDL1) and PDCD1LG2 (encoding PDL2) are reported to be recurrent. Together, the genetic landscape suggests that constitutive NF-κB activation and immune evasion are dominant pathogenetic mechanisms in IVLBCL.
microscopic: Large lymphoid cells with vesicular nuclei and single or multiple prominent nucleoli, often showing mitotic figures, are observed within the lumina of small vessels, especially capillaries. A free-floating (discohesive), cohesive, or marginating/adherent growth pattern may be observed. Rarely, the lymphoid cells can be anaplastic. In the haemophagocytic subtype, a varying infiltrate of non-neoplastic histiocytes with signs of haemophagocytosis is present. Pan–B-cell markers are expressed (CD20, CD79a), often with coexpression of CD5 and PDL1 (CD274; 20–40%). Most cases express IRF4 (MUM1) (75–80%) and have a non–germinal-centre B-cell immunophenotype; however, approximately 13% are CD10-positive.
differential_diagnosis: Various systemic B- and T-cell lymphomas, such as KSHV/HHV8-positive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma, may show a dominant intravascular presentation. Specifically in the skin, IVLBCL should be differentiated from intravascular T-cell–rich lymphoid proliferation, in which large heterogeneously CD30-positive blastoid cells are present in and around lymphatic vessels (see section Reactive T-cell–rich lymphoid proliferations) and from intralymphatic ALK-positive and ALK-negative anaplastic large cell lymphomas that may present with isolated skin localizations.
staging: After exclusion of systemic involvement, staging should be performed according to the International Society for Cutaneous Lymphomas (ISCL) / European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) guidelines for primary cutaneous lymphomas other than mycosis fungoides.
prognosis_and_prediction: IVLBCL is an aggressive lymphoma that is often diagnosed late during the disease course, contributing to a poor prognosis. The cutaneous subtype has a better outcome, possibly related to earlier detection. Chemotherapy with rituximab improves the outcome, with a 3-year overall survival rate of 60–81%.
cytology: Not applicable
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: In equivocal cases restricted to the skin, DNA analysis on cutaneous biopsy samples may be interrogated for genes recurrently mutated or for clonality. In cases with systemic presentation, similar analyses using cell-free DNA by liquid biopsy may be considered.
related_terminology: Not recommended: angiotropic lymphoma; intravascular lymphomatosis.
subtypes: Cutaneous intravascular large B-cell lymphoma; classic intravascular large B-cell lymphoma; haemophagocytic intravascular large B-cell lymphoma

definition: Reactive B-cell–rich lymphoid proliferations (rB-LPs) are defined by a B-cell–predominant lymphocytic infiltrate. Histologically, and in some cases also clinically, rB-LPs can resemble cutaneous B-cell lymphomas.
clinical:
rB-LP manifests with solitary red, brown, or bluish nodules. Sometimes a few nodules or papules are arranged in clusters. Disseminated papules or nodules rarely occur. The miliarial subtype is characterized by multiple small semitranslucent papules, a few millimetres in diameter.

---

The exact incidence is unknown. The Borrelia-associated form is found particularly in areas where Borrelia is endemic (e.g. North America, Europe, Asia). Data about sex predominance are heterogeneous. rB-LP can occur at any age, including in childhood.
pathogenesis:
Many causes have been implicated, including drugs, antigen injection for allergy treatment or vaccination, tick bites, arthropod bites, herpes zoster, hair dyes, piercing, tattoo pigment, and Borrelia sp.. However, identification of a trigger is often not possible.

---

The pathogenesis is poorly understood. The above-mentioned causes can produce a direct or indirect proliferation of B cells.
microscopic: A nodular or (in incisional biopsies) diffuse dermal lymphocytic infiltrate predominantly composed of B cells is present. The subcutis can also be affected. T lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages/histiocytes, and eosinophils are admixed in variable degrees. Plasmacytoid dendritic cells are found in 75% and closely resemble T cells and plasma cells. Reactive germinal centres are common. They can be well defined with clear mantle zones, or irregular with reduced to absent mantle zones. A polarization of the reactive germinal centres is only found in a minority of cases. Tingible-body macrophages are common (50–83%). Borrelia-associated rB-LP often shows confluent large germinal centres with small or absent mantle zones, and a lack of polarization in 82%. Tingible-body macrophages are a constant finding. Plasma cells (99%) and eosinophils (84%) are very common. The miliarial subtype shows a more superficial and less dense infiltrate, with a diffuse, nodular, or follicle-accentuated growth pattern.
ancillary_studies: The B cells express B-cell markers (e.g. CD20, CD79a, PAX5). Reactive germinal centres are positive for CD10 and BCL6 but negative for BCL2. CD21 and CD23 highlight follicular dendritic cell networks, which are sharply restricted to the germinal centres. The proliferative activity outlined by Ki-67 (MIB1) is high (> 90%) and relatively well limited to the reactive germinal centres. The data on the discriminatory value of CD1a in rB-LP versus primary cutaneous marginal zone lymphoma are conflicting.
differential_diagnosis: The key histological features of rB-LP and its differential diagnosis are summarized in #33671Table 6.07 .
prognosis_and_prediction: rB-LP is a reactive and benign proliferation of B lymphocytes. The prognosis is excellent. Progression in a B-cell lymphoma has been rarely reported, but it remains unclear whether these cases may account for B-cell lymphomas from the beginning.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Clonality studies reveal a polyclonal result in most cases for immunoglobulin heavy chain (IGH) and light chain (IGK) rearrangement. Nevertheless, clonality can be detected in about 10–20% of rB-LP cases. Immunoglobulin light chain κ and λ shows a ratio of < 5:1 in most cases, but rarely light chain restriction can also be found in rB-LP. This highlights the importance of interpreting clonality results only in the context of the pathological and clinical findings. Next-generation sequencing appears to be a more sensitive assay. Detection of Borrelia sp. in Borrelia-associated rB-LP by PCR is useful, but in some cases the number of microorganisms is very low and thus Borrelia PCR can show false negative results.
related_terminology: Acceptable: cutaneous lymphoid hyperplasia. Not recommended: lymphadenosis cutis benigna (restricted to Borrelia-associated form); lymphocytoma cutis; benign lymphadenosis cutis; cutaneous B-cell pseudolymphoma.
subtypes: Borrelia-associated reactive B-cell–rich lymphoid proliferation; miliarial-subtype reactive B-cell–rich lymphoid proliferation

definition: Indeterminate dendritic cell tumour (IDCT) is a clonal proliferation of cells expressing dendritic cell markers (CD1a, S100) and lacking CD207 (langerin), with prominent cutaneous involvement.
clinical:
IDCT is generally a skin-limited disorder presenting with single, multifocal, or generalized papules, nodules, or tumours. These lesions are usually soft, erythematous to brownish papules that may be ulcerated and tend to coalesce. Infrequently, patients may present with single large lesions. Patients with extracutaneous IDCT present with symptoms related to the mass lesion.

---

IDCT is rare, with about 100 cases reported in the literature. The median age at diagnosis is 48 years; IDTC rarely occurs in children. The M:F ratio is 1.4:1.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. A fraction of IDCT cases may represent unusual cases of Langerhans cell histiocytosis lacking CD207 expression. About 20% of cases are associated with haematological neoplasms such as non-Hodgkin lymphomas and chronic or acute myeloid neoplasms. Cases associated with myeloid neoplasms may represent a cutaneous manifestation of the underlying and sometimes clonally related malignancy.

---

The cell of origin was formerly considered to be an immature Langerhans cell or veiled cell. However, the existence of veiled cells has never been confirmed in immunological studies. Some cases have been reported to show mutations in BRAF (p.V600E), KRAS, or KMT2A (MLL). Cytogenetic anomalies including t(1;1), t(14;18), and trisomy 21, as well as recurrent ETV3::NCOA2 gene fusion, have been reported.
microscopic: In cutaneous lesions the epidermis is usually spared. The dermis and/or subcutis is infiltrated by sheets of monomorphic mononuclear cells resembling Langerhans cells, with kidney-shaped and deeply grooved nuclei and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. Rarely, the cells can appear spindled or show a blastic morphology. Extracutaneous involved sites show infiltration by similar lesional cells, which may exhibit variable degrees of nuclear atypia and mitotic activity.
ancillary_studies: The tumour cells are S100-positive, CD1a-positive, and CD207 (langerin)-negative; ultrastructurally, no Birbeck granules are recognizable. There is often an inflammatory infiltrate at the periphery of the lesion. Eosinophils and lymphocytes may be prominent, as can be reactive CD68+, CD163+, S100+/−, CD1a− macrophages.
differential_diagnosis: Interdigitating dendritic cell sarcoma lacks CD1a expression (which is positive in IDCT). Reticulohistiocytoma, characterized by histiocytes with epithelioid morphology and abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, is negative for CD1a, rarely positive for S100, and positive for macrophage markers (CD68, CD163, factor XIIIa).
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: Upon diagnosis, it is important to exclude the involvement of other organs/tissues with a whole-body imaging technique, complete blood counts, liver and kidney function tests, and neurological examination. In the presence of blood cell count anomalies and/or hepatomegaly or splenomegaly, a bone marrow biopsy is warranted, to exclude associated haematological neoplasms. Blastic morphology is considered to be of prognostic value in IDCT, and there is evidence to suggest the existence of two clinicopathological subgroups among patients with IDCT. Most cases of cutaneous IDCT show complete remission after treatment or even spontaneous regression. As many as 25% of cases may show disease progression and/or malignant behaviour; such cases often show atypical cytological features, a high proliferation index (Ki-67 index: > 20%), or association with other haematological neoplasms. Outcome data on extracutaneous IDCT are limited. Targeted therapy for disseminated IDCT exhibiting BRAF p.V600E mutation has been reported to produce a good response.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular analysis of BRAF may be helpful to exclude other diagnoses.
related_terminology: Acceptable: indeterminate cell histiocytosis; indeterminate dendritic cell histiocytosis.

definition: Histiocytic sarcoma (HS) is a malignant tumour showing morphological and immunophenotypic features of macrophages. Tumorous proliferations of acute monocytic leukaemia are excluded.
clinical:
Patients present with plaques, nodules, and tumours at any site on the body. It can be localized or disseminated.

---

HS is rare. It occurs over a wide age range, with a slight male predominance.
pathogenesis:
Some cases of HS are associated with prior or metachronous lymphoma. A subset of cases are associated with primary mediastinal germ cell tumours, especially in young male patients.

---

Some cases of HS show clonal IG gene rearrangement, particularly when associated with lymphoid neoplasms. This is postulated to represent the transdifferentiation process. The most frequent genomic alterations are mutations in the MAPK pathway, including KRAS, NRAS, BRAF, MAP2K1, PTPN11, NF1, and CBL. Mutations in tumour suppressors such as CDKN2A and TP53 are common.
microscopic: HS shows a diffuse infiltrate of oval to round, and sometimes spindled, non-cohesive large tumour cells with variable pleomorphism. The cytoplasm is abundant and eosinophilic, and often vacuolated. The nuclei are oval, grooved, or irregularly folded, often with distinct nucleoli. Haemophagocytosis is occasionally observed. Variable numbers of reactive cells are often admixed.
ancillary_studies: HS shows expression of multiple histiocytic markers, including CD163, CD68, and lysozyme. There can be heterogeneous expression of S100. Langerhans cell markers (CD1a, CD207), follicular dendritic cell markers (CD21, CD35), and myeloid cell markers (myeloperoxidase, CD13) are negative, as is ALK. Melanocytic markers (SOX10, HMB45), epithelial markers (cytokeratins), and specific mature B-cell/T-cell markers (CD20, PAX5, CD3) are also negative.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnoses include various large cell neoplasms, such as lymphoma (especially large B-cell lymphoma and anaplastic large cell lymphoma), Langerhans cell sarcoma, follicular dendritic cell sarcoma, melanoma, carcinoma, and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. A relatively non-cohesive growth pattern and an abundance of eosinophilic cytoplasm are clues to the diagnosis of HS, which has to be further supported by expression of the relevant immunohistochemical markers.
prognosis_and_prediction: HS is usually aggressive, with a limited response to therapy and a high mortality rate. Some patients with a localized neoplasm have a more favourable outcome.
related_terminology: Not recommended: histiocytic lymphoma.
