definition: ALK-positive histiocytosis is a histiocytic neoplasm lacking high-grade cytological atypia and characterized by anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) immunoreactivity, usually due to ALK gene rearrangement.
clinical:
The skin lesions take the form of solitary or multiple nodules or papules, representing sole lesions or part of a multisystem disease.

---

ALK-positive histiocytosis is rare. The multisystem systemic form occurs in infancy, while the multisystem (others) and single-system forms can occur in any age group, including children and adults. Patients are more commonly female than male.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

ALK-positive histiocytosis is characterized by ALK gene translocation, with the commonest partner gene being KIF5B, and uncommon ones being CLTC, TPM3, TFG, EML4, DCTN1, COL1A2, and TRIM33. ALK rearrangement can lead to the activation of many different signalling pathways, including the MAPK pathway.
macroscopic: Skin lesions are macules, papules, nodules, or plaques, with whitish-yellow cut surfaces.
microscopic: The skin shows a non-circumscribed, non-epidermotropic infiltrate comprising sheets of histiocytes, which may be accompanied by a variable degree of fibrosis. The histiocytes range in appearance from large oval (epithelioid), foamy, spindle cells to multinucleated cells, which frequently show irregular nuclear contours but no significant pleomorphism. They have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm that may show fine vacuolation, haemosiderin deposition, and emperipolesis. There can be admixed Touton giant cells. The morphology can be indistinguishable from that of juvenile xanthogranuloma.
ancillary_studies: The histiocytes are ALK-positive and show variable positivity for histiocytic markers, such as CD68, CD163, CD14, CD4, and lysozyme. Some cases may show staining for S100, cyclin D1, or OCT2. Fascin and factor XIIIa are commonly positive, while CD30, CD1a, and CD207 (langerin) are negative. The Ki-67 proliferation index is low.
differential_diagnosis: See #36272Table 6.05 in section Rosai–Dorfman disease for differential diagnosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: The outcome is variable depending on the pattern of disease involvement. Patients with multisystem disease may benefit from systemic chemotherapies or ALK inhibitors. Single-system involvement can be cured by surgical ablation where complete removal is possible. Skin lesions may regress spontaneously.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Demonstration of ALK translocation is helpful.
related_terminology: Acceptable: ALK-related histiocytosis; ALK-rearranged histiocytosis.

definition: Erdheim–Chester disease (ECD) is a systemic chronic histiocytic neoplasm characterized by infiltration of mature macrophages in different organs. The diagnosis of ECD requires the integration of clinical, histopathological, radiological, and molecular findings.
clinical:
Patients display systemic symptoms (e.g. fever) and other symptoms related to local inflammation, fibrosis, and tissue infiltration by histiocytes (e.g. bone pain in nearly 50%). Diabetes insipidus and CNS involvement (e.g. ataxia) are also frequently observed (30–40%). Hydroureteronephrosis (ureteric compression) is frequent, while cardiac tamponade is rarer. About 10% of cases are associated with myeloid neoplasms (chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia). The most frequent skin localization of ECD is xanthelasma (25%). Xanthelasmas are usually normolipaemic, are large and/or periocular, relapse after surgical ablation, and may reveal ECD. Cutaneous lesions include patches or papulonodules. Other skin lesions may reveal Langerhans cell histiocytosis, which occurs in about 10% of patients. The radiological hallmark of ECD is symmetrical metadiaphysial osteosclerosis of long bones, especially the distal femur and proximal tibia. Retroperitoneal/perinephric infiltration (hairy kidneys) and periaortic soft tissue involvement (coated aorta) are highly suggestive of ECD.

---

ECD is a rare disorder of adulthood (median age at diagnosis: 40–60 years; M:F ratio: 3:1).
pathogenesis:
The majority of patients with ECD have a somatic molecular alteration activating the MAPK cell signalling pathway. Clonal haematopoiesis has been described in 40% of patients.

---

ECD often displays an oncogenic mutation in MAPK pathway genes, with BRAF p.V600E being observed in 50–60% of cases. Other mutations are described in ARAF, NRAS, KRAS, PIK3CA, or MAP2K1 genes. MAPK pathway mutation can also be observed in myeloid progenitors in some patients with ECD. A model with sequential acquisition of driver mutations leading to the development of myeloid neoplasms and ECD from underlying clonal haematopoiesis has been proposed. However, some ECD cases can occur in the absence of clonal haematopoiesis.
microscopic: Histology alone is not diagnostic. Indeed, the histopathological findings of ECD are identical to those observed in the histiocytoses of the xanthogranuloma family. The most typical picture is an infiltrate of foamy macrophages, associated with Touton giant cells, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and neutrophils. In xanthelasma, Touton cells are more abundant in ECD than in xanthelasmas with other etiologies. Tissue fibrosis is frequently observed and may predominate, leading to a misdiagnosis of reactive fibroinflammatory process. Admixed Langerhans cell histiocytosis may be present in the same biopsy or other tissues, in cases of mixed histiocytosis. Occasionally, a morphological and immunophenotypic overlap with Rosai–Dorfman disease or with reticulohistiocytosis may be seen.
ancillary_studies: ECD histiocytes are positive for CD163, CD68 (KP1 and PGM1), CD14, and CD4, and at least partially positive for factor XIIIa, fascin, and S100; they are negative for CD1a and CD207 (langerin). Expression of phosphorylate ERK is frequent. Strong cytoplasmic positivity for VE1 may correlate to the presence of BRAF p.V600E.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis is broad and includes Rosai–Dorfman disease, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, adult-onset xanthogranuloma, juvenile xanthogranuloma, necrobiotic xanthogranuloma, metastatic tumours, and malignant histiocytosis. In the eyelid and orbit, it also includes adult-onset asthma and periocular xanthogranuloma and xanthelasma. However, some clinical settings may help to exclude them easily.
prognosis_and_prediction: ECD is generally a chronic, progressive disorder. Prognosis depends on site and extent of the disease. Baseline assessment includes CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis; FDG PET of the entire body; MRI of the brain with gadolinium; and cardiac MRI. CNS involvement is linked to a worse prognosis. Targeted therapies (BRAF or MEK inhibitors) are very efficient in patients with severe forms. Approximately 10–15% of patients with ECD co-develop an additional haematological malignancy, negatively affecting their prognosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: BRAF p.V600E or other MAPK pathway gene mutations are frequently observed. The allele frequency of BRAF p.V600E mutations may be < 5% in a quarter of cases, thus not detectable by less sensitive molecular methods.
related_terminology: Not recommended: lipogranulomatosis; lipoid granulomatosis; polyostotic sclerosing histiocytosis.

definition: Xanthelasmas are benign, subcutaneous, localized lesions composed of foamy histiocytes and Touton giant cells with a variable degree of lipid deposition, in the absence of a metabolic disorder.
clinical:
Xanthelasma appears as flat or minimally elevated yellow lesions, commonly in the medial aspect of the eyelids; the lesions are often bilateral and symmetrical. A tuberous xanthoma is an elevated and nodular xanthelasma. It appears as solitary or multiple placoid or papular lesions of the eyelids and is usually associated with hyperlipidaemia type II and type III.

---

Xanthelasma has a reported incidence of 0.56–1.5% in European countries and North America and represents approximately 6% of eyelid lesions. The age of onset varies from 15 to 75 years, with a peak between the fourth and fifth decades of life. Some studies suggest a female predilection. Xanthoma may occur in individuals of any age and shows no sex predilection. Xanthoma disseminatum shows a male predilection, and the age of onset is < 25 years in up to a third of cases.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Xanthelasma and xanthoma are reactive developmental or inflammatory lesions rather than true neoplasms.

---

The pathogenesis is unknown. The inflammatory milieu in xanthelasma is considered analogous to early stages of cardiac atherosclerotic plaque formation.
microscopic: Xanthelasma shows focal collections of lipid-laden histiocytes distributed mainly around blood vessels and adnexal structures in the eyelid dermis, with chronic inflammation and fibrosis. Tuberous xanthoma is more deeply located in the dermis and displays foamy histiocytes, Touton giant cells, extracellular cholesterol deposits, chronic inflammation, and fibrosis.
ancillary_studies: The foamy histiocytes typically express CD68, CD163, and factor XIIIa, but they lack CD21, CD35, S100, CD1a, and Birbeck granules.
differential_diagnosis: This includes necrobiotic xanthogranuloma, Erdheim–Chester disease and adult-onset xanthogranuloma with periocular xanthogranuloma, Langerhans cell histiocytosis, Rosai–Dorfman disease, and crystal-storing histiocytosis (see related sections). Clinicopathological correlation may be necessary for challenging cases.
prognosis_and_prediction: Xanthelasma is benign and is commonly observed. Surgical excision may be considered for larger lesions or for cosmetic reasons.
related_terminology: Acceptable: xanthomatous lesion. Not recommended: histiocytomas; non–Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

definition: Blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm (BPDCN) is a haematological neoplasm consisting of immature cells with plasmacytoid dendritic cell (pDC) differentiation, characterized by a high frequency of cutaneous involvement and systemic dissemination.
clinical:
Patients most commonly present with skin lesions, which vary in size, colour (violaceous, contusiform, brown, xanthochromic), and form (solitary or multiple patches, plaques, and nodules). The lesions are usually non-pruritic, and they tend to involve the upper thorax, head and neck, and upper extremities. Mucosal lesions are uncommon but may be identified, particularly in the oral cavity.

---

BPDCN is rare, with an estimated annual incidence of 0.04 cases per 100 000 individuals in the USA. Although the disease can affect all ages, and a bimodal age distribution pattern has been observed, it most commonly occurs in elderly men in the seventh decade of life (median age: 62–70 years), with an M:F ratio of 4–6:1.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

BPDCN cells derive from resting, non-activated pDCs with aberrant activation of the NF-κB pathway, and they appear to have defective type I interferon signalling postulated to be related to E-cadherin expression. The E-box transcription factor TCF4 (previously E2-2) plays an obligatory role as a master regulator in BPDCN cells under the control of the BET protein BRD4. In the Japanese population, translocation of 8q24 (the MYC locus), most frequently with 6p21 (the RUNX2 locus), is found in 38% of patients and is associated with immunoblastoid cytomorphology and MYC overexpression.
microscopic: In the skin, the neoplastic infiltrate of BPDCN is usually centred in the dermis with extension to subcutaneous tissue, while sparing the epidermis and adnexal structures. BPDCN is characterized by a diffuse monotonous infiltrate of medium-sized immature blastic cells. These cells usually have scant cytoplasm, eccentric nuclei with slightly irregular nuclear contours, fine chromatin, and one to several inconspicuous nucleoli. In some cases, neoplastic cells may have an immunoblastoid morphology, whereas in others they may have lymphoid features. Mitotic figures are variable, and necrosis can be present. Intratumoural erythrocyte extravasation is a consistent finding. CD123 (IL-3RA) expression is a characteristic feature of BPDCN, as is strong, uniform expression of TCF4. Although rare, some cases of BPDCN lacking CD123 or other markers (e.g. CD5, CD56) have been reported. Other commonly expressed pDC antigens include TCL1, CD2AP, SPIB, CD303, CD304, E-cadherin, and MX1. BPDCN cells are usually positive for CD4, CD56, and HLA-DR. The Ki-67 proliferation index is typically high. Absence of strong expression of lymphoid or myeloid lineage–specific markers is expected, specifically CD3, CD14, CD19, lysozyme, and myeloperoxidase. CD1a, CD15, CD25, CD34, CD41, CD64, CD113, and MNDA are usually negative.
differential_diagnosis: A subset of acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) may show clinical, morphological, and immunophenotypic overlap with BPDCN, including high-level coexpression of CD4, CD56, and CD123. Demonstration of TCF4, CD303, and/or TCL1 expression in this context, coupled with an absence of strong expression of lineage-specific markers, usually helps establish the diagnosis of BPDCN.
prognosis_and_prediction: There is no significant difference in outcomes between patients who present with skin-only BPDCN and those who present with BPDCN with systemic involvement. Treatment with CD123-targeted agents has improved overall response rates and overall survival; however, treatment with cytotoxic chemotherapy remains a mainstay, in combination with targeted therapy.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: No specific molecular or cytogenetic tests are required to make a diagnosis of BPDCN.
related_terminology: Not recommended: blastic NK-cell lymphoma; agranular CD4+/NK leukaemia; blastic NK leukaemia/lymphoma; agranular CD4+/CD56+ haematodermic neoplasm/tumour.

entity_name: Mature plasmacytoid dendritic cell proliferation associated with myeloid neoplasm
definition: Mature plasmacytoid dendritic cell proliferation (MPDCP) associated with myeloid neoplasm is a clonal proliferation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) with low-grade morphology identified in the context of a defined myeloid neoplasm.
clinical:
MPDCP in the skin manifests as rash, macules, papules, and (rarely) nodular lesions.

---

Patients are predominantly male, and the median age is 69–72 years. MPDCP has been described in association with chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia (CMML) most frequently, as well as with acute myeloid leukaemia (AML), myelodysplastic neoplasms, and myeloproliferative neoplasms. MPDCP is present in 4.9% of cases of AML.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Clonal MPDCP cells accumulate in the bone marrow of patients with myeloproliferative CMML harbouring activating RAS pathway mutations. In patients with AML, clonal MPDCP (pDC-AML) shares the same mutation landscape as CD34-positive blasts and frequently arises in association with RUNX1 mutations. It is unknown whether the pathogenetic mechanisms leading to MPDCP in association with CMML and with AML are the same. Nevertheless, while the concept of MPDCP currently pertains to the detection of mature pDCs in these diseases, it is recognized that in some AMLs there might be continuity between such cells and the dominant AML clone. In contrast to CMML, where pDCs in nodules are typically mature, in pDC-AML the pDCs show a spectrum from early immature pDCs (CD34+, CD303 dim/−) to mature pDCs (CD34−, CD303+). Additional studies are needed to further elucidate the spectrum of MPDCP and its relationship to blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm and/or associated myeloid neoplasms.
microscopic: MPDCP consists of medium-sized cells with eccentrically located round or oval nuclei showing clumped chromatin. Cutaneous involvement is characterized by a dermal infiltrate that may be nodular, with or without a diffuse component, consisting of mature pDCs admixed with small lymphocytes and sometimes a few plasma cells and eosinophils. The epidermis is usually spared, and mitotic figures are absent. The immunophenotype of MPDCP recapitulates that of mature pDCs (e.g. positive for CD123, TCF4, CD4, CD2AP, SPIB, CD303, CD304, and MX1). Aberrant loss of markers expressed on normal pDCs (e.g. CD303 and TCL1) may be detected, and CD56 is typically negative or weak/partial. The Ki-67 proliferation index in MPDCP associated with CMML is usually low.
differential_diagnosis: Reactive types of mature pDC proliferation often seen in conditions such as infections, systemic lupus erythematosus, Kikuchi–Fujimoto disease, and Castleman disease should be excluded.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: The presence of MPDCP has been shown to correlate with adverse outcomes of the associated myeloid neoplasms in most studies. Its recognition may have therapeutic implications.
cytology: See above.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: No specific molecular or cytogenetic tests are required to make a diagnosis of MPDCP.
related_terminology: Acceptable: mature plasmacytoid dendritic cell proliferation.

definition: Mast cell sarcoma (MCS) is a rare and clinically aggressive form of mastocytosis characterized by the presence of a locally destructive solid tumour comprising highly atypical mast cells.
clinical:
MCS arises de novo in most cases. Transformation of a previous mast cell neoplasm is rare and should be best regarded as MCS-like progression. MCS may appear concomitantly with systemic disease, often fulfilling criteria for mast cell leukaemia. The clinical presentation varies depending on the location of the mass. As many as 30% of patients present with symptoms of mast cell activation syndrome, including flushing, fever, malaise, diarrhoea, and tachycardia. Serum tryptase levels are frequently increased.

---

MCS is exceedingly rare in humans. Most patients are adults, but children can also be affected. The median age of adults with MCS is 55 years (range: 1–77 years), and there is a slight female predominance (M:F ratio: 1:1.3).
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. MCS is almost exclusively sporadic. Only one familial case of MCS has been reported.

---

KIT mutations are rarely demonstrated in MCS, as compared with systemic mastocytosis. KIT is wildtype in 50% of the reported cases, and the canonical KIT p.D816V mutation is found in only 21% of patients. Other KIT mutations have been described in single cases. The paucity of KIT p.D816V mutations suggests that MCS is molecularly distinct from systemic mastocytosis.
microscopic: MCS manifests as a localized tumour of immature and often highly atypical cells showing an infiltrative and destructive growth pattern. Neoplastic mast cells are difficult to recognize unless special stains are performed. They are usually medium-sized to large pleomorphic or epithelioid cells, with oval or bilobed nuclei. Multinucleated mast cells are sometimes present. Cytoplasmic metachromatic granules can be seen on Giemsa and toluidine blue staining. Increased mitotic activity is sometimes noted, and the tumour is frequently infiltrated by eosinophils. Mast cells with striking nuclear pleomorphism, including bilobed and multilobed forms (promastocytes), have been reported in biopsies of cutaneous childhood-onset mastocytosis and in an adult case. Such a finding does not seem to represent a malignant phenotype and should not be interpreted as cutaneous MCS. Progressive cytological pleomorphism and an unusually high proliferation rate have been reported in an adult with a recurrent cutaneous lesion but without evidence of systemic involvement.
ancillary_studies: Neoplastic mast cells express mast cell tryptase, and KIT (CD117) is positive in most cases. Mast cells variably express CD2, CD25, and CD30. Positivity for other nonspecific antigens, like CD68, CD45, CD43, and MITF, may cause differential diagnostic problems. Ki-67 is variably increased, ranging from 3% to 50%.
differential_diagnosis: MCS needs to be differentiated from sarcomas, metastatic carcinoma, melanoma, histiocytic or myeloid neoplasms, and lymphomas, particularly ALK-negative anaplastic large cell lymphoma.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis of patients with MCS is dismal. Locally destructive growth and quick progression to aggressive systemic mastocytosis or mast cell leukaemia occur in most cases. The median survival time of patients with MCS is 17 months (range: 1–45 months). The terminal phase of MCS is often indistinguishable from mast cell leukaemia.
cytology: Cytology of the primary lesion is not usually obtained. In cases with bone marrow infiltration, the neoplastic mast cells share features with other subtypes of mastocytosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Whole KIT sequencing is recommended, given the low frequency of MCSs harbouring the typical KIT p.D816V mutation that confers resistance to imatinib.
related_terminology: Not recommended: malignant mast cell tumour; malignant mastocytoma.

definition: Muir–Torre syndrome (MTS) is an autosomal dominant tumour predisposition disorder characterized by cutaneous neoplasia (sebaceous tumours and keratoacanthomas) and visceral malignancies. MTS is a subset of Lynch syndrome, due to mutations affecting the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2. A similar phenotype can also be seen in patients with inherited MUTYH pathogenic mutations.
clinical:
Patients with MTS usually develop cutaneous neoplasms and visceral malignancies. MTS-associated cutaneous tumours include sebaceous adenoma, sebaceoma, and sebaceous carcinoma, but not sebaceous hyperplasia. The strongest association is with sebaceous adenoma. Multiple sebaceous neoplasms and sebaceous neoplasms outside the head and neck region are strong indicators. Cystic keratoacanthomas (sometimes multiple and usually showing sebaceous differentiation) in younger patients, at sites without chronic sun exposure, can also be a feature, but these have been less frequently reported. The visceral malignancies of MTS include tumours of the colorectum, endometrium, stomach, small bowel, ovary, gallbladder, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, urinary tract (renal pelvis, ureter, and bladder), kidney, brain, and prostate; in particular, colonic adenocarcinomas occur in about 50% of patients with MTS. Colonic adenomas are found in about one quarter of patients with MTS.

---

MTS has been identified in at least 9% of Lynch syndrome cases.
pathogenesis:
MTS is caused by a constitutional pathogenic mutation affecting a DNA MMR gene (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, or PMS2). The risk of tumour formation (for visceral malignancies) varies depending on the affected MMR gene, and these risks are set out in the Prospective Lynch Syndrome Database, available from https://plsd.eu/. MSH2 mutations are most commonly associated with the MTS phenotype. MLH1, MSH6, and PMS2 mutations confer a considerably lower risk of cutaneous sebaceous neoplasms.

---

Cells lose MMR function when both alleles of a given MMR gene are inactivated. A normal cell in a patient with MTS carries one inherited mutated MMR gene and acquires a second somatic mutation to the corresponding normal MMR allele, rendering that cell deficient for MMR. This deficiency has several important consequences: it leads to an increase in the point mutation rate of MMR-deficient cells, escape from the normal control of apoptosis (conferring gain of a relative growth advantage), increased mutations affecting repetitive DNA sequences (microsatellites) – resulting in microsatellite instability, and abnormal MMR protein expression.
macroscopic: See the sections about the individual tumour types included in the syndrome.
microscopic: See the sections about the individual tumour types included in the syndrome.
staging: Tumours are staged according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system, depending on the tumour type.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis is consistent with the type and stage of the tumours at the time of their appearance, similar to for sporadic types.
cytology: See the sections about the individual tumour types included in the syndrome.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The integrity of the expression of MMR proteins (MLH1, PMS2, MSH2, and MSH6) can be assessed by immunohistochemistry. Preserved expression of all four proteins strongly suggests microsatellite stability, whereas loss of nuclear staining for any of the proteins indicates deficient MMR, suggests the candidate gene, and indicates the need for further testing. Loss of MSH2 alone (or MSH2 and MSH6) suggests a mutation in MSH2. Similarly, loss of MLH1 alone (or MLH1 and PMS2) suggests a mutation or acquired promoter methylation in MLH1. Concomitant loss of MSH2 and MSH6 (or MLH1 and PMS2) reflects the heterodimeric binding and stability relationships in MMR complexes. Approximately 3–10% of tumours with MMR deficiency show preserved protein expression due to mutations that disable protein function but not protein stability. By immunohistochemistry, approximately one half to two thirds of unselected sebaceous neoplasms show deficient DNA MMR protein expression. However, most are sporadic cases, and MMR immunohistochemistry is not routinely used unless there is a history of a previous visceral neoplasm. Rates of MMR protein deficiency vary according to the anatomical site (> 80% outside the head and neck area vs 30–40% in the head and neck) and tumour type (sebaceous adenomas show loss more commonly than sebaceous carcinomas). PCR amplification of discrete microsatellite loci in tumour-extracted DNA is a functional assessment of microsatellite instability and strongly correlates with immunohistochemistry. As many as a third of MTS cases display an apparent microsatellite-stable phenotype on DNA microsatellite instability testing (microsatellite markers developed for colorectal cancer are less sensitive for detecting microsatellite instability in sebaceous neoplasms). Genetic testing and clinical correlation are critical. The positive predictive values for immunohistochemistry alone in the detection of germline DNA MMR defects range from 22% to 37%, although the negative predictive values are as high as 95%, emphasizing a critical need to integrate clinical features (age, family history and personal history of MTS-related cancers, and number of sebaceous tumours) before further testing.
related_terminology: None

definition: Carney complex (CNC) is an autosomal dominant tumour predisposition syndrome whose cardinal features include spotty skin pigmentation, naevi, myxomatosis, secretory endocrine tumours, and pigmented schwannomas.
clinical:
CNC is an indolent disease with symptoms and tumours accumulating over time. CNC is typically diagnosed in the patients early 20s. Skin pigmentation and heart problems caused by myxomas are usually the first signs of the condition. The characteristic spotty skin pigmentation develops on the lips, inner and outer corners of the eyes, and conjunctiva (membrane lining) of the eye, as well as around the genital area. Other common features of CNC are ACTH-independent Cushing syndrome (due to primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease), acromegaly, and multiple thyroid nodules. With increasing age, patients may develop CNC-associated tumours, including primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease, thyroid carcinomas (follicular or papillary), gonadal tumours (large cell calcifying Sertoli cell tumour, ovarian cystadenoma or cystadenocarcinoma), cutaneous myxomas, melanocytic naevi, psammomatous melanotic schwannomas, osteochondromyxomas of the bone, tubular adenomas, myxomas and myxoid fibroadenomas of the breast, intraductal mucinous tumours of the pancreas, and fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinomas.

---

Fewer than 1000 cases have been described in the literature. There is an M:F ratio of 1:2.
pathogenesis:
Germline inactivating genomic aberrations of PRKAR1A are identified in 62% of cases. Mutations in PDE8B or PDE11A and germline amplification of PRKACA are less common.

---

Inactivation of PRKAR1A is observed in the majority of CNC-related tumours. It leads to increased activity of catalytic subunits of PKA (PKA Cα or PKA Cβ), key components of the cAMP signalling pathway, which regulates the proliferation of tissues susceptible to developing CNC-associated tumours. Activation of PKA Cα due to PRKACA fusions or microinsertions was shown to have a similar effect in fibrolamellar carcinoma of the liver and cardiac myxoma and suggests that aberrations involving components of the cAMP signalling pathway other than PRKAR1A may be responsible PRKAR1A-wildtype CNC-associated tumours. PRKAR1A inactivation is usually superimposed on other background genetic abnormalities specific for the individual tumours.
macroscopic: Tumours in CNC have a macroscopic appearance similar to those of their sporadic counterparts.
microscopic: See the dedicated tumour sections in this or other volumes of the fifth-edition WHO Classification of Tumours series.
staging: Individual malignant tumours are staged according to the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: With the exception of pigmented melanotic schwannoma, which often metastasizes and can be lethal, the tumours associated with CNC are usually benign and slow-growing. Cardiac myxomas, although histologically benign, can cause catastrophic cardiac problems due to their location and/or complications from the open heart surgery necessary to treat them.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: CNC can be diagnosed by the detection of pathogenic germline mutation of PRKAR1A or (less commonly) of PDE8B or PDE11A. Molecular diagnosis also includes gene copy testing for PRKACA or PRKACB.
related_terminology: Not recommended: NAME syndrome (naevi, atrial myxoma, myxoid neurofibromas, and ephelides); LAMB syndrome (lentigines, atrial myxoma, mucocutaneous myoma, and blue naevus).

entity_name: Naevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (Gorlin syndrome)
definition: Naevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (NBCCS) is an autosomal dominant disease associated with developmental disorders and predisposition to benign and malignant tumours.
clinical:
The most frequent manifestations of NBCCS are multiple BCCs (in sun-exposed and non-exposed skin), as well as jaw OKCs, found together in > 90% of affected individuals by the age of 40 years. OKCs most commonly occur in the posterior mandibular ramus, and they may be multifocal when syndrome-associated. The overall prevalence of OKCs in NBCCS is 66–86%, but OKCs have an age-dependent onset, and by the age of 40 years the prevalence is reported to be > 90%. Cysts commonly arise relatively early, at a mean age of 15.5 years, but they may also occur much later in life. Other frequent manifestations include calcification of the falx cerebri, tentorium cerebelli, and/or sella turcica; palmar and plantar pits; and bifid or fused ribs. These findings are considered major diagnostic criteria (see #38440Box 9.03). Minor criteria include medulloblastoma, ovarian fibroma, macrocephaly, congenital facial abnormalities (e.g. cleft lip or palate, frontal bossing, and hypertelorism), skeletal abnormalities (e.g. digit syndactyly), and radiological bone abnormalities (e.g. bridging of the sella turcica, flame cysts in digits, long bone cysts). The clinical features manifest at different ages: macrocephaly and rib anomalies can be detected at birth; medulloblastoma typically develops within the first 3 years of life; OKCs usually manifest after 8 years; and BCCs are usually found after 10 years of age. Radiation treatment of medulloblastoma may induce multiple BCCs, as well as various other tumour types (e.g. meningioma) within the radiation field. NBCCS-associated medulloblastoma usually develops in children aged < 5 years, with the majority identified in patients aged < 2 years, nearly always showing desmoplastic/nodular histopathology. Therefore, it is proposed that desmoplastic/nodular medulloblastoma in young children should serve as a major criterion for the diagnosis of NBCCS. About 1–2% of patients with NBCCS with germline PTCH1 pathogenic sequence variants develop medulloblastoma, compared with about 20% of patients with germline SUFU pathogenic sequence variants.

---

Disease prevalence varies by reporting country. In the United Kingdom, it is 1 case per 18 976 population; in Australia, 1 case per 164 000; in Japan, 1 case per 235 800; and in Italy, 1 case per 256 000. Of 131 children with medulloblastomas in one study, 6% had germline SUFU mutation.
pathogenesis:
NBCCS results from inactivating constitutional sequence variants in the human homologue of the Drosophila segment polarity patched gene (PTCH1) located on chromosome 9q22, SUFU on 10q24, and (in exceptional cases) GPR161 on 1q24.2. Numerous different PTCH1 constitutional pathogenic sequence variants associated with NBCCS have been reported. The detection rate of specific pathogenic variants has increased significantly in recent years, owing to the development of improved methods. The mostly truncating mutations are distributed over the entire PTCH1 coding region, with no mutation hotspots. Missense mutations cluster in a highly conserved region (the sterol-sensing domain), and particularly in transmembrane domain 4. The rate of new PTCH1 pathogenic variants has not been precisely determined, but it is estimated that a high proportion (14–81%) of cases are the result of de novo alterations. SUFU pathogenic sequence variants are detected in only about 5–6% of tested probands, and they are mostly truncating, with most cases inherited from an unaffected, healthy parent; the remaining cases show a de novo variant. Constitutional pathogenic variants in GPR161 have been detected in sonic hedgehog (SHH) subgroup medulloblastomas, suggesting possible NBCCS association.

---

PTCH1 encodes a 12-pass transmembrane protein expressed on many progenitor cell types that functions as a receptor for members of the secreted hedgehog protein family of signalling molecules (SHH, IHH, and DHH) and acts through downstream factors to repress transcription of genes encoding members of pathways active in poorly differentiated cells, such as TGF-β and WNT. PTCH1 controls another transmembrane protein, SMO. In the absence of ligand, PTCH1 inhibits the activity of SMO. Hedgehog signalling takes place in the primary cilium. Binding of hedgehog proteins to PTCH1 can relieve its inhibition of SMO, allowing its translocation to the tip of the primary cilium, which results in the activation and translocation of GLI transcription factors into the cell nucleus and transcription of a set of specific target genes controlling the survival, differentiation, and proliferation of progenitor cells. In vertebrates, this pathway is critically involved in the development of various tissues and organ systems, such as the limbs, gonads, bone, and CNS. SUFU is located downstream in the hedgehog pathway; it has been found to directly interact with GLI proteins and is a negative regulator of hedgehog signalling. PTCH1 and SUFU are classic tumour suppressor genes; the second allele of the mutant gene is lost in most NBCCS-related tumours. The inactivation of PTCH1 or SUFU leads to pathological activation of the SHH signalling pathway.
macroscopic: Syndromic tumours appear grossly similar to their sporadic counterparts.
microscopic: Practically all medulloblastomas associated with NBCCS have the morphological features of nodular tumours, including desmoplastic/nodular medulloblastoma and medulloblastoma with extensive nodularity. BCCs do not show any unique histological features, with all subtypes represented, including pigmented subtypes. Basaloid neoplastic cells with peripheral palisading, epithelial–stromal clefting, stromal mucin deposition, and infundibulocystic differentiation are characteristic. NBCCS-associated OKCs are typically multifocal and develop in younger patients than non–syndrome-associated cases. The thin epithelium typically lacks rete ridges and shows a surface with corrugated parakeratin, and the basal cells are palisaded and have hyperchromatic nuclei. Basal budding and microcysts in the wall are more likely in syndromic cysts.
staging: Malignancies are staged in accordance with the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system.
prognosis_and_prediction: The life expectancy of patients with NBCCS is 73.4 years, only slightly reduced from unaffected populations (in contrast to some other genetic tumour syndromes); however, there is considerable impact on quality of life. Surveillance guidelines are well established; for SUFU pathogenic sequence variant carriers, they include a recommendation for repeated brain MRI screening for medulloblastoma development within the first 5 years of life. The prognosis of NBCCS-associated medulloblastomas seems to be better than that of sporadic cases, and it has been suggested that therapy protocols be adjusted in patients aged < 5 years with NBCCS, to prevent radiation-induced secondary tumours. Medulloblastoma patients with SUFU germline pathogenic sequence variants are said to have a poor prognosis, although no difference in survival was found between patients with medulloblastoma carrying a PTCH1 versus a SUFU pathogenic variant in other studies. The cumulative BCC burden (> 100 BCCs in about a third of children), requires careful treatment optimization in terms of methods and timing of tumour removal to achieve a good cosmetic result and the best quality-of-life outcomes. Statistical modelling suggests earlier syndrome diagnosis if certain cardinal features are identified and result in genetic testing (i.e. OKCs, BCCs, palmoplantar pits).
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Comprehensive mutation analysis of the PTCH1 and SUFU genes by DNA sequencing and a search for deletions/duplications by appropriate methods (e.g. multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification [MLPA], targeted array-based analysis) identifies most NBCCS-related constitutional pathogenic variants. To detect more complex alterations, additional analysis at the transcript level may be necessary in some cases. Despite improved detection rates, in 15–27% of index cases, neither PTCH1 nor SUFU pathogenic variants can be identified. Because constitutional pathogenic variants are frequent in children younger than 5 years with extensive nodular or desmoplastic/nodular medulloblastomas, genetic counselling should be offered to the families, and early pathogenic variant analysis of PTCH1 and SUFU should be performed. The detection of a constitutional condition is important for appropriate treatment planning to avoid unnecessary radiation therapy.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Gorlin syndrome; Gorlin–Goltz syndrome. Not recommended: basal cell naevus syndrome; fifth phakomatosis.

definition: Metastases to skin are usually epithelial, melanocytic, or mesenchymal malignant lesions that metastasize to involve the skin (epidermis to subcutaneous tissue). Involvement of the skin by systemic haematolymphoid lesions is not considered metastasis.
clinical:
Cutaneous metastases are more common in elderly individuals, although young children may also be affected. In approximately 1–12% of the cases the cutaneous metastasis is the first symptom of the malignancy. Overall, the most common origin is breast cancer in women and melanoma in men, followed by lung, colon, head and neck, and ovarian cancers, and others. Cutaneous metastases commonly manifest as isolated nodules or papules. Less common are large plaques and grouped papules in a zosteriform pattern. Secondary extramammary Paget disease (epidermotropic metastatic carcinoma) may arise as eczematous plaques, most commonly in the genital region (see also section Extramammary Paget disease). Rare cases of breast and salivary gland carcinomas present extensive vascular invasion with an en-cuirasse morphology. Metastases from primary cutaneous lesions may be satellites (within 50 mm of the primary lesion), in transit (between the primary lesion and the regional lymphatic basin), or distant (all others).

---

The incidence of cutaneous metastasis is 1–10% in autopsies and ranges from 1.2% to 10% in surgical and biopsy specimens. Some of these studies have indicated that cutaneous metastasis is more common in White people than in Asians, although more studies are needed.
pathogenesis:
The cause is that of the primary tumour type.

---

Most cutaneous metastases appear to correspond to haematogenous spread. There is also lymphatic and angiotropic extravascular spread and, rarely, iatrogenic implantation, such as transfer of squamous carcinoma cells through a needle administering an analgesic used both in the tumour and the grafting area. The mechanisms by which some tumours more frequently metastasize to the skin than to other organs is not fully determined. However, as proposed by Dr Paget in 1889 with his seed and soil theory, there is a likely exchange of information between the metastatic tumour cells (seed) and the microenvironment of the recipient tissue (soil).
macroscopic: Metastases to skin are mostly nodular or erythematous lesions.
microscopic: The morphology will depend on the primary lesion. In general, metastases present as relatively well-circumscribed lesions involving either the dermis or the subcutaneous tissue. Vascular invasion is usually more frequent than in primary cutaneous lesions. Differential diagnosis The lesions tend to have the same morphology as the primary. Breast carcinoma has a ductular or (less commonly) lobular pattern. Some breast lesions may have prominent vascular invasion (inflammatory carcinoma). Occasionally the stroma is markedly desmoplastic and may resemble a dermatofibroma. Most metastases tend to resemble their primary lesions (e.g. lung adenocarcinoma shows similar a glandular arrangement both in the skin and in the lung, and colon adenocarcinoma metastatic to the skin may show dirty necrosis). However, in some cases the metastases may mimic a primary lesion (e.g. clear cell renal carcinoma metastatic to the skin may be confused with cutaneous xanthomas). Similarly, some metastatic melanomas have a prominent intraepidermal component that even extends beyond the dermal component or appears to be just in situ melanoma, thus mimicking a primary lesion. Immunohistochemistry may be helpful. Metastatic adenocarcinomas to the skin tend to be negative for p63, calretinin, and D2-40. Several authors have proposed algorithms to try to determine the primary tumour in metastasis of unknown origin. Molecular analysis has been proposed to try to detect a genetic signature compatible with an internal malignancy or to provide possible treatments even if the primary origin is unknown.
staging: Staging is related to the primary lesion.
prognosis_and_prediction: Detection of metastasis to the skin conveys a poor prognosis. When the lesions are discovered at the same time as the primary tumours, they are considered poor prognostic indicators.
cytology: The morphological features will depend on the histological type of the metastasis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The diagnostic molecular pathology is related to the primary lesion.
related_terminology: Acceptable: cutaneous metastasis; secondary involvement of the skin.
subtypes: The tumour type will depend on the primary site of the tumour. A strategy for the workup of epithelioid tumours is given in #42077Fig. XXX .

definition: Ewing sarcoma is a small round cell sarcoma showing gene fusions involving one member of the FET family of genes (usually EWSR1) and a member of the ETS family of transcription factors. Superficial / primary cutaneous lesions are rare but well described.
clinical:
Ewing sarcoma manifests as dermal or subcutaneous nodules that may be painful, polypoid, and/or ulcerated. The median tumour size is 23 mm (range: 5–120 mm).

---

Cutaneous Ewing sarcoma tends to occur in children and young adults, but it has been reported in older individuals. The median age at diagnosis is 17 years (range: 2–77 years); 67% of patients are female, and 33% are male.
pathogenesis:
The majority of cases appear to be sporadic, but germline mutations in genes predisposing to cancer have been described.

---

As with their deeper counterpart, the pathogenesis of cutaneous Ewing sarcomas is driven by transcription factors encoded by chimeric FET::ETS gene fusions, most commonly EWSR1::FLI1 and EWSR1::ERG. Chimeric fusion genes encode transcription factors that serve as master regulators that activate and repress thousands of genes. Expression of these transcription factors in the correct tumour microenvironment is ostensibly required for the development of Ewing sarcoma. Proteins bind both GGAA microsatellites and canonical ETS binding sites in the genome and recruit chromatin regulators. Binding of the fusion proteins to GGAA microsatellites results in transition from a closed to open chromatin state that establishes de novo enhancers which activate genes. Conversely, binding to canonical ETS binding sites displaces wildtype ETS factors and represses gene expression. In combination, these events establish an oncogenic gene expression programme that underlies tumour initiation.
macroscopic: The cut surface of untreated Ewing sarcoma specimens is grey to white and soft. Foci of haemorrhage and necrosis are common.
microscopic: Tumours are composed of sheets of mitotically active, uniform small blue round cells with indistinct cell borders and round nuclei with fine stippled chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli. Constituent cells have a high N:C ratio and scant, lightly eosinophilic to clear glycogenated cytoplasm that gives a positive PAS reaction. Immunohistochemistry Membranous CD99 immunoreactivity is a highly sensitive but nonspecific finding in nearly all cases. Neural markers (e.g. NSE, S100, PGP9.5, and CD57) and epithelial markers (AE1/AE3, CAM5.2) may occasionally be expressed, but desmin positivity is rare and typically only very focal. FLI1 and ERG are often expressed in cases with the corresponding translocation; some cross-reactivity has been reported. NKX2-2 is sensitive but imperfectly specific. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes a very rare subset of superficially located Ewing-like undifferentiated small blue round cell sarcomas such as CIC-rearranged and BCOR-rearranged sarcomas, representing distinct entities.
staging: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM systems may be applied.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cutaneous and superficial Ewing sarcomas have a better prognosis and outcome than their deep-seated soft tissue and bony counterparts. Long-term survival has been reported both with and without adjuvant therapy. The overall survival rate is 93% and the 10-year probability of survival is estimated at approximately 90%.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular confirmation is often required for a diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma, as round cell morphology is common to other sarcomas, carcinomas, and lymphomas. All cases of Ewing sarcoma harbour FET::ETS fusions. The EWSR1::FLI1 fusion is seen in > 95% of cutaneous and superficial Ewing sarcomas. Rarely, an EWSR1::ERG fusion is present.
related_terminology: Not recommended: Askin tumour (Ewing sarcoma arising in the chest wall); primitive neuroectodermal tumour.

definition: Dermal clear cell sarcoma (CCS) is a malignant neoplasm of uncertain histogenesis displaying melanocytic differentiation and associated with a gene fusion involving EWSR1 and ATF1 or CREB1.
clinical:
Most superficial cutaneous (i.e. primary dermal) tumours manifest as small amelanotic nodules. They may be confused with melanocytic neoplasms, such as Spitz naevi.

---

CCS tends to affect young adults, most often during the third to fourth decade of life. Very rarely the tumour may also occur in children or older individuals.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The majority (70–90%) of CCSs harbour an EWSR1::ATF1 fusion secondary to the reciprocal translocation t(12;22)(q13;q12). The oncogenic fusion constitutively activates the promoter of MITF (microphthalmia-associated transcription factor), resulting in melanocytic differentiation and tumour growth. A variant translocation, t(2;22)(q32.3;q12), which results in an EWSR1::CREB1 fusion, is rare, accounting for approximately 5% of tumours. CCS may be associated with additional chromosomal aberrations, such as extra copies of chromosomes.
macroscopic: Gross examination typically reveals a firm, amelanotic, often white or cream-coloured nodule.
microscopic: The tumour is characterized by fascicles and nests of usually amelanotic spindle and epithelioid cells. A few cells may display clear cytoplasm. Multinucleate wreath-type giant cells are often seen. The degree of nuclear atypia and number of mitoses are variable. The tumour often displays collagenous septa separating tumour cell aggregates. Most tumours have a grenz zone. On rare occasion a tumour may involve both the dermis and the epidermis (compound CCS), often as junctional nests, and is therefore more likely to be confused with a primary cutaneous melanoma or a melanocytic naevus. Immunohistochemistry The tumour cells express S100, SOX10, and melanocyte differentiation antigens such as PMEL (gp100), TYRP1 (gp75), melan-A, and MITF. In contrast to cutaneous melanomas, PRAME expression is usually absent or only focal. Differential diagnosis Dermal CCS may be confused with spitzoid melanocytic tumours, cellular blue naevus, primary nodular or metastatic melanoma, epithelioid sarcoma, or other sarcomas.
staging: The eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system applies.
prognosis_and_prediction: The tumour is clinically characterized by a propensity for local recurrences with late metastases. Patients with cutaneous CCS may have a more favourable outcome than those with deep soft tissue tumours. An analysis of 23 cutaneous CCSs showed an association with local recurrence in 46% (median relapse-free survival time: 15 months), while 2 patients died of disease, one at 38 months and the other at 60 months. Small tumour size and negative sentinel lymph node status have been associated with longer disease-free survival.
cytology: Aspiration specimens show hypercellular aggregates of monomorphic amelanotic spindle and epithelioid cells, often with multinucleated cells.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Identification of EWSR1 gene rearrangement and/or documentation of an EWSR1::ATF1 or EWSR1::CREB1 gene fusion may be helpful, in particular to differentiate CCS from malignant melanoma.
related_terminology: Not recommended: melanoma of soft parts.

definition: CRTC1::TRIM11 cutaneous tumour (CTCT) is a dermal spindled and epithelioid cell tumour with partial melanocytic differentiation and CRTC1::TRIM11 translocation.
clinical:
The tumours occur as a discrete, slowly growing, skin-coloured nodule. Mild pain and tingling have been noted.

---

Nearly 50 cases have been reported in the literature, without an obvious sex bias and across a broad age range (11–87 years, median: 44 years).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Although the precise molecular function of the CRTC1::TRIM11 fusion protein has not been proved, CRTC1 (CREB-regulated transcription coactivator 1, 19p) is thought to enhance cell proliferation, differentiation, and expression of the oncogene MITF through activation of CREB1 (the cAMP response element-binding transcription factor).
macroscopic: The tumours are circumscribed, with a pale, firm cut surface without pigmentation. The size ranges from 5 to 35 mm (mean < 10 mm).
microscopic: The morphology is highly uniform and resembles that of clear cell sarcoma. Tumours are dermal-based, well-circumscribed, unencapsulated nodules with a pushing border and no pigment. They can abut, but only very rarely involve, the epidermis. Cells are arranged in nests and streaming long and short intersecting (at times herringbone to vaguely palisaded) fascicles with intervening thin fibrous bands; they are fusiform with abundant pale cytoplasm, smooth nuclear membranes, vesicular chromatin, and prominent nucleoli. Mitoses are typical, although not conspicuous. Immunohistochemistry All tumours express diffuse SOX10. Diffuse S100 staining is seen in only 50% of cases; melan-A (MART1) and HMB45 are only focally expressed. Pan-TRK expression can be observed (60% diffuse). TRIM11 immunohistochemistry is typically positive in nuclei at the periphery of the nodule. Differential diagnosis The main differential diagnosis includes clear cell sarcoma and metastatic melanoma.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: CTCT has been reported to show indolent behaviour, with rare (~10%) recurrence or metastasis following complete excision, although follow-up is limited.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Demonstration of CRTC1::TRIM11 fusion is necessary for the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Not recommended: TRIM11 melanocytoma.
