definition: Epithelioid sarcoma (ES) is a malignant soft tissue tumour with hybrid mesenchymal and epithelial morphological and immunophenotypic features. Two subtypes are described: classic ES tends to arise in acral skin, with a palisading, pseudogranulomatous growth pattern; proximal ES occurs in deep truncal locations as nests and sheets of larger epithelioid cells.
clinical:
Classic ES manifests as superficial, slow-growing, painless, firm nodules. Sporotrichoid spread is characteristic. Non-healing skin ulcers mimic other processes. Soft tissue ES is larger and more infiltrative. ES may metastasize to lymph nodes and distant sites.

---

ES represents < 1% of adult soft tissue sarcomas and 4–8% of childhood non-rhabdomyosarcomatous soft tissue sarcomas. Classic ES is reported twice as often as proximal ES. The M:F ratio is 2:1 for classic ES and 1.6:1 for proximal-type ES. Classic ES occurs mainly in adolescents and young adults. Proximal-type ES affects a somewhat older population of young to middle-aged adults.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The SMARCB1 gene (also known as BAF47, INI1, and SNF5) encodes a component of the SWI/SNF chromatin-remodelling complex present in normal cells. SWI/SNF has ATPase activity and functions to shift the position of nucleosomes modulating transcription of genes involved in cell differentiation. Loss of nuclear SMARCB1 protein expression is characteristic of ES, but an extreme minority retain SMARCB1 (INI1) expression, instead exhibiting abnormal expression of other SWI/SNF chromatin-remodelling complex members, such as SMARCA4 (BRG1), SMARCC1 (BAF155), or SMARCC2 (BAF170). Genomic analysis has revealed complex copy-number aberrations and relatively high mutation burden. RNA sequencing shows a unique profile that does not cluster with any particular tissue type or other SWI/SNF-aberrant system.
macroscopic: Classic ES presents as indurated, poorly defined, dermal or subcutaneous nodules measuring a few millimetres to 50 mm. Deep-seated tumours are multinodular. The cut surface is glistening grey and punctuated by necrotic and haemorrhagic foci. Proximal ES presents as whitish nodules ranging from 10 to 200 mm, with areas of haemorrhage and necrosis.
microscopic: Classic ES consists of infiltrative, pseudogranulomatous nodules of epithelioid and spindled tumour cells palisading around foci of necrobiosis. Constituent cells are large, with deeply eosinophilic cytoplasm and atypical nuclei with vesicular chromatin and small nucleoli. Mitoses are inconspicuous. Dystrophic calcification and metaplastic bone are seen in 20% of cases. Proximal ES is characterized by sheet-like growth of larger epithelioid cells with vesicular nuclei with nucleoli. Tumour necrosis is frequently seen. Rhabdoid cells occur in both forms but are more frequent in proximal ES. ES is high-grade by definition. Immunohistochemistry Both subtypes show immunoreactivity for cytokeratins and EMA. Most express CK8/19 but are negative for CK5/6. CD34 is expressed in > 50% of cases. Loss of nuclear SMARCB1 expression occurs in the vast majority of ESs. ERG expression is observed in 40–67% of ESs. Differential diagnosis This includes granulomatous processes, carcinomas, and epithelioid vascular tumours.
staging: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) or Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system may be used.
prognosis_and_prediction: Reported 5- and 10-year survival rates are 45–70% and 45–66%, respectively. Localized disease has an overall survival rate of 62–88%. Overall survival drops to 24% with metastasis. Location in the hand correlates with good outcome. Deep location correlates with lower overall survival. Rates of local recurrence, lymph node dissemination, and metastasis for localized ES are 14–25%, 34–52%, and 33%, respectively. Management relies on surgery aiming for R0 margins. About 22–30% of cases are metastatic at diagnosis. EZH2 inhibitors have been approved for ES. Responses to checkpoint inhibitors have been described. Unresectable ES has a poor response to chemotherapy and short progression-free survival.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: In challenging cases, panel sequencing may detect mutations inactivating SMARCB1.
related_terminology: None
subtypes: Classic epithelioid sarcoma; proximal epithelioid sarcoma

media.legend: Classic/conventional epithelioid sarcoma. A granulomatous lesion composed of atypical epithelioid and spindled cells palisading around a focus of necrobiosis.
Classic/conventional epithelioid sarcoma. Polygonal epithelioid tumour cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.
Classic/conventional epithelioid sarcoma. Tumour cells reveal loss of SMARCB1 nuclear expression, while endothelial and inflammatory cells show retained expression.
Proximal epithelioid sarcoma. A sheet-like proliferation of poorly differentiated rhabdoid tumour cells with pleomorphic vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli.

definition: Pleomorphic dermal sarcoma (PDS) is a rare tumour occurring in elderly patients, in chronically ultraviolet (UV) radiation–exposed skin. It is genetically, morphologically, and clinically related to atypical fibroxanthoma, but subcutaneous invasion and lymphovascular/perineural invasion are not features of atypical fibroxanthoma and confer an increased risk of aggressive behaviour.
clinical:
This malignancy typically manifests as a rapidly growing nodule with a diameter of 5–50 mm (median: 25 mm). Ulceration is observed in at least 50% of the lesions.

---

PDS occurs on severely sun-damaged skin of White patients in their seventh or eighth decade of life, with a male predominance.
pathogenesis:
Actinic damage is a mandatory precondition. The malignancy can be associated with iatrogenic immunosuppression and haematological comorbidities, including chronic lymphocytic leukaemia or paraproteinaemias.

---

PDS is an undifferentiated tumour of uncertain histogenesis that does not express epithelial, melanocytic, vascular, or muscle differentiation markers. Similarly to atypical fibroxanthoma, PDS occurs in chronically UV radiation–exposed skin, frequently with or after UV radiation–dependent cutaneous epithelial malignancies including actinic keratosis or squamous cell carcinomas, sometimes on chronic radiodermatitis. Next-generation sequencing consistently showed a high mutation load, with a UV radiation signature; mutations in TP53, NOTCH family genes, and the TERT promoter; and alterations in CDKN2A and CDKN2B responsible for cell-cycle control. This mutation profile widely overlaps with that of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma.
macroscopic: PDS is a reddish to yellow nodular lesion, frequently ulcerated.
microscopic: The tumours are centred within the dermis, with an expansile nodular or plaque-like growth pattern, poor demarcation, and irregular borders. Ulceration is frequently seen (> 50% of cases). A diffusely infiltrative growth with invasion of subcutaneous adipose tissue, skeletal muscle, or fascia is common and may be relevant for local relapse risk. The tumour cells vary in size and shape. Most frequent are pleomorphic spindle cells with hyperchromatic or vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli. In addition, epithelioid, spindled, and multinucleated giant cells may be admixed. Mitotic activity is brisk and includes atypical forms. Tumour necrosis, perineural infiltration, and lymphovascular invasion may also be seen. The next most common morphological pattern shows atypical spindle cells in a fascicular arrangement. Other less common features include myxoid, desmoplastic, or keloidal stromal change; pseudoangiomatous features; a storiform growth pattern; and admixed osteoclast-like multinucleated giant cells. Immunohistochemistry The tumour cells are consistently negative for S100, SOX10, PMEL (gp100), cytokeratins, CD34, ERG, and desmin. SMA and CD31 may be focally positive, and aberrant melan-A expression is occasionally seen. Immunoreactivity for CD10, CD99, and PDGFRB is typically detected. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes atypical fibroxanthoma, desmoplastic melanoma, poorly differentiated carcinoma, leiomyosarcoma, and angiosarcoma. Negative staining for ERG can be useful for excluding angiosarcoma in diagnostically difficult cases.
staging: Staging is not relevant, except in the setting of metastasis, in which case the eighth edition of the Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) / American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system may be helpful.
prognosis_and_prediction: PDS has a certain (~20%) risk of local recurrence if not completely resected. In 10% of cases, local metastases or metastases to locoregional lymph nodes occur. Distant metastases were reported in 12% of the tumours in a recent study after locoregional relapse. Immunosuppression is a major risk factor for metastatic spread.
related_terminology: Not recommended: undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma of the skin; cutaneous sarcoma NOS; superficial malignant fibrous histiocytoma.

media.legend: Pleomorphic dermal sarcoma. This large and cellular tumour is based within dermis and extends to the overlying epidermis.
Pleomorphic dermal sarcoma. Tumour cells are epithelioid and spindled, showing marked nuclear atypia; multinucleated tumour giant cells are admixed.
Pleomorphic dermal sarcoma. This tumour is characterized by infiltrative growth, with invasion of subcutaneous adipose tissue and the underlying galea.
Pleomorphic dermal sarcoma. There is focal necrosis on the right.

definition: Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour (SCD34FT) is a distinctive low-grade neoplasm of the skin and subcutis, characterized by a proliferation of spindled cells with characteristic morphological features and diffuse expression of CD34. PRDM10 rearrangements are often but not always present.
clinical:
The tumour typically presents as a slow-growing, painless mass of the superficial soft tissues. A long prebiopsy duration (> 5 years) is often noted. Rare cases present as deep-seated lesions. Tumour size varies from 15 to 100 mm, but it is usually < 50 mm.

---

Slightly more than 100 cases have been reported. Most have occurred in middle-aged adults (median age: 38 years), with a slight male predominance.
pathogenesis:
None

---

The morphological, immunohistochemical, and molecular genetic features of SCD34FT and tumours referred to as PRDM10-rearranged soft tissue tumour are identical, strongly supporting their unity. The terminology superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour is preferred, because not all tumours harbour demonstrable PRDM10 rearrangements. PRDM10 rearrangements have been identified and have been reported in close to 60% of cases previously classified as SCD34FT or PRDM10-rearranged soft tissue tumour. Specific identified fusions have included MED12::PRDM10, CITED2::PRDM10, PRDM10::ARHGAP32, and PRDM10::RAB30.
macroscopic: The tumours are circumscribed, firm, yellow to tan soft tissue masses with a variably gelatinous appearance.
microscopic: The lesions grow in a relatively circumscribed (but at least partially infiltrative) fashion and are composed of cellular fascicles and sheets of spindled and pleomorphic cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, often having a granular or glassy appearance. Lipidized tumour cells are commonly present. The neoplastic cells show moderate to marked nuclear pleomorphism, often with bizarre, hyperchromatic nuclei containing prominent nucleoli and intranuclear cytoplasmic pseudoinclusions. Mitotic activity is very low, and necrosis is rarely seen. A mixed inflammatory cell infiltrate is often present. Rarely, myxoid stroma and metaplastic bone are reported in PRDM10-rearranged soft tissue tumours. Immunohistochemistry These tumours invariably express CD34, and they are focally immunoreactive for keratins in close to 70% of cases (most often with the AE1/AE3 clones). SMARCB1 (INI1) expression is retained, and p53 expression shows a wildtype pattern. The Ki-67 (MIB1) proliferation index is very low (< 5%). PRDM10 immunohistochemistry is consistently positive. CADM3 (SynCam3) immunopositivity is reported in 95–100% of cases. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis of SCD34FT includes pleomorphic dermal sarcoma, dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, plaque-like CD34-positive dermal fibroma, myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma, superficial solitary fibrous tumours, inflammatory myofibroblastoma, superficial myxofibrosarcoma, fibrous histiocytoma, and epithelioid sarcomas. It may also include atypical fibrous histiocytoma, atypical fibroxanthoma, and undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis for patients with this tumour is excellent, with only a single lymph node metastasis and no local recurrences reported in 45 cases with follow-up. All patients with this tumour have been reported to be alive and disease-free at the time of last follow-up.
cytology: Cytology shows cellular smears composed of large, pleomorphic cells with granular to glassy cytoplasm.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Demonstration of PRDM10 rearrangement is useful in selected cases.
related_terminology: Acceptable: PRDM10-rearranged soft tissue tumour.

media.legend: Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour. Well-circumscribed, cellular tumour in the dermis and subcutis, with peripheral lymphoid aggregates.
Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour. Highly cellular fascicles of spindle-shaped and pleomorphic cells with intervening inflammatory cells.
Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour. Pleomorphic spindle cells with abundant granular to glassy eosinophilic cytoplasm and an occasional intranuclear pseudoinclusion.
Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour. There are several pleomorphic cells with bizarre nuclear shapes, but no mitotic figures, and a mixed inflammatory infiltrate.
Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour. Pleomorphic spindle cells with glassy cytoplasm and intranuclear pseudoinclusions.
Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour / PRDM10-rearranged soft tissue tumour. Lipid-laden histiocytes and pleomorphic spindled cells.
Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour. Diffuse CD34 expression is consistently present.
Superficial CD34-positive fibroblastic tumour. Diffuse CADM3 expression is invariably present.

definition: Atypical fibroxanthoma (AFX) is a dermally based neoplasm of uncertain histogenesis that generally behaves in a low-grade fashion when strict diagnostic criteria are used. Most cases arise on sun-damaged sites in elderly individuals. The diagnosis requires the evaluation of multiple immunostains.
clinical:
AFX often manifests as a solitary, localized nodule up to 20 mm in diameter, on sun-damaged skin. Ulceration is common, often with a short history of rapid growth. Although there are no specific clinical features, the diagnosis can sometimes be suspected from the context and lack of pigmentation or features pointing to a diagnosis of basal or squamous cell carcinoma.

---

The tumours are rare, mostly occurring in sun-damaged skin of elderly White patients, especially those living in areas of high solar radiation. Men are more often affected than women. AFXs have been reported in young patients with Li–Fraumeni syndrome with germline mutation of TP53 and xeroderma pigmentosum.
pathogenesis:
A role for ultraviolet (UV) radiation exposure is supported by clinical factors and by the observed associations with Li–Fraumeni syndrome and xeroderma pigmentosum. Some cases have occurred in the field of radiotherapy and in the context of immunosuppression and organ transplantation. Associated trauma has been rarely reported. A role for UV radiation exposure is also supported by evidence of multiple UV radiation–related genetic changes, including UV radiation signature mutations in TP53. Studies, including comparative genomic hybridization, show genomic changes including 9p and 13q deletions, TERT mutations, and many abnormalities in common with pleomorphic dermal sarcoma. AFXs have been seen in Li–Fraumeni syndrome (with germline TP53 mutation) and xeroderma pigmentosum. One patient with xeroderma pigmentosum showed TP53 mutation and germline mutation of CDKN2A (p16INK4a/p14ARF).

---

The origin of AFX remains unclear, but electron microscopy and immunohistochemistry suggest a histogenesis from undifferentiated dermal mesenchymal cells.
macroscopic: An often ulcerated, circumscribed tumour as large as 20 mm in diameter is present in the dermis, with a firm cut surface and sometimes with haemorrhage.
microscopic: A circumscribed dermal tumour is present with no involvement of the subcutis. The neoplasm is typically highly cellular, with striking nuclear enlargement, pleomorphism, and atypia. Mitoses are frequent, with atypical forms. Enlarged spindle or epithelioid cells are seen, some with histiocyte-like appearances. Irregular fascicles may be present with scattered inflammatory cells and occasional haemorrhage. Ulceration is common, sometimes with an epidermal collarette or atrophy. Necrosis is absent in AFX. Plaque-like growth is occasionally seen with a band of cells parallel to the epidermis. These plaque-like lesions may be less well circumscribed. AFX with a spindle cell pattern shows exclusively spindle-shaped cells in fascicles with eosinophilic cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. Sometimes the cytological features of this pattern are relatively bland. AFX with a clear cell pattern exhibits cells with clear to foamy cytoplasm and hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei. Glycogen is of limited extent or absent. Further patterns include granular cell, keloidal, myxoid, and sclerotic forms. Regression is sometimes seen, which can be extensive, making diagnosis on a partial biopsy challenging. Pigmented AFX show haemosiderin deposition and haemorrhage. Some AFXs contain osteoclast-like giant cells, which may be multinucleated tumour cells (demonstrating nuclear atypia) or background histiocytes (CD163-positive with bland nuclei). Immunohistochemistry Immunohistochemistry is vital to exclude other malignancies, especially melanoma, leiomyosarcoma, and poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. A metastasis should always be considered. A broad panel of immunostains is essential. In particular, melanocyte markers (e.g. SOX10, S100) and keratinocyte markers (e.g. MNF116, AE1/AE3, 34βE12, p63, p40) should be negative. Included S100-positive Langerhans cells can be numerous and confirmed with CD207 (langerin) or CD1a. Many AFXs are MITF-positive, and occasionally there may be focal expression of melan-A. In some studies, most tumours stain with SMA, but allied desmin or h-caldesmon staining would suggest leiomyosarcoma. Desmin positivity has been reported in AFX, but these tumours may represent leiomyosarcoma, particularly if staining is prominent. CD10 is almost invariably strongly and diffusely expressed in AFX and may be the only positive stain. Although this is nonspecific and can be seen in some melanomas and squamous cell carcinomas, for example, AFX should be diagnosed with great caution if CD10 is absent. CD68 and CD163 are often positive but are of limited diagnostic value and also stain included macrophages. Multinucleated tumour giant cells may non-specifically uptake immunostains including HMB45 and calponin. In vascular-appearing tumours, negative staining for CD34 and ERG may be required to exclude angiosarcoma. Some AFXs express EMA (without evidence of other epithelial marker positivity) and CD31. Differential diagnosis See #34497Table 7.03 .
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: Most AFXs behave in a benign fashion if stringent diagnostic criteria are used. Recent studies suggest that any permeation of the subcutis should be regarded as pleomorphic dermal sarcoma rather than AFX. As many as 5% recur, usually due to incomplete excision. Metastases rarely occur, with occasional fatalities.
cytology: Malignant cells of epithelioid or spindly appearance are seen, but histopathology and immunostaining are essential for definitive diagnosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Diagnostic molecular pathology is not clinically relevant in most cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: superficial malignant fibrous histiocytoma; dermal undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.

media.legend: Atypical fibroxanthoma. Multinucleated tumour cells and mitoses are frequently identifiable.
Atypical fibroxanthoma. This tumour shows keloidal change; in other zones, the lesion was almost entirely composed of eosinophilic collagen fibres, with only very sparse remaining malignant cells.
Atypical fibroxanthoma. This example of atypical fibroxanthoma exhibits granular cells with haemorrhage and pigmentation due to haemosiderin deposition.
Atypical fibroxanthoma. Extensive haemorrhage in atypical fibroxanthoma sometimes raises the differential diagnosis of angiosarcoma.
Atypical fibroxanthoma. Myxoid subtype.

Atypical fibroxanthoma. Plaque-like pattern, with cells lying parallel to the epidermis. Centrally, this tumour showed features more typical of atypical fibroxanthoma, with a nodule invading deep into the dermis.
Atypical fibroxanthoma. SMA positivity is frequent.

definition: This is an emerging group of molecularly defined monomorphic spindle cell neoplasms with activating NTRK or other kinase fusions and displaying a wide spectrum of morphological patterns including lipofibromatosis-like growth.
clinical:
NTRK-rearranged spindle cell tumours present as a palpable mass, 10–60 mm in diameter.

---

NTRK-rearranged spindle cell tumours are predominantly encountered in the paediatric population but may arise at any age (range: 0–77 years, median: 19 years), with both sexes affected equally.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Activation of MAPK signalling occurs through the formation of chimeric proteins, often LMNA::NTRK1, TPR::NTRK1, or TPM3::NTRK1. Other kinase gene fusions include NTRK2, NTRK3, RAF1, BRAF, RET, MET, ROS1, or ALK with various partners.
macroscopic: The tumours manifest as a nodular or multinodular subcutaneous mass.
microscopic: NTRK-rearranged spindle cell tumours have a range of morphological features. Many superficial tumours show a pattern reminiscent of lipofibromatosis, frequently referred to as lipofibromatosis-like neural tumour. In these cases, fibrous septa with increased spindled cells that have small ovoid to tapering nuclei and indistinct cytoplasm extend through adipose tissue. Mitotic activity is inconspicuous. Other tumours may be more cellular, with sheets of spindled to ovoid cells present in fascicles or loosely arranged in a myxoid background. Commonly, however, tumours have a hybrid appearance, with areas of increased cellularity devoid of entrapped adipose tissue intermingling with areas that are adipose-rich. Within this spectrum are tumours with low to high cellularity and a range of mitotic counts. Infrequent tumours may show higher-grade histological features with fascicles of malignant-appearing spindle cells with high mitotic activity. Focal marked nuclear pleomorphism or necrosis may be seen. Other histological features include lymphocytic infiltrate, thin-walled staghorn vessels, perivascular hyalinization, and stromal bands of hyalinized collagen. Immunohistochemistry Tumours show variable coexpression of CD34, S100, and occasionally SMA; however, expression of CD34 or S100 is not required, and tumours may have a nonspecific immunoprofile. There is usually diffuse pan-TRK expression in tumours with activating NTRK fusions. SOX10 is typically absent and H3 p.K27me3 is retained.
staging: Staging is only applicable to the malignant subset. The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) or Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM system may be used.
prognosis_and_prediction: NTRK-rearranged spindle cell tumours are highly infiltrative and may recur after incomplete resection. Hybrid tumours have a low rate of metastasis. The prognostic role of traditional histological grading features is still unclear.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular genetic testing for receptor tyrosine kinase fusions (e.g. NTRK1, NTRK2, NTRK3, RET, MET, EGFR, ROS1, ALK) or downstream effector molecule fusions (ABL1, BRAF, or RAF1) or activating point mutations is required for a conclusive diagnosis and determination of therapy.
related_terminology: Acceptable: lipofibromatosis-like neural tumour; NTRK-positive tumour resembling peripheral nerve sheath tumour.

media.legend: NTRK-rearranged spindle cell neoplasm. Superficial tumour with TPR::NTRK1 fusion, resembling lipofibromatosis.
NTRK-rearranged spindle cell neoplasm. Superficial tumour with TPR::NTRK1 fusion, resembling lipofibromatosis.
NTRK-rearranged spindle cell neoplasm. Superficial tumour with TPR::NTRK1 fusion, resembling lipofibromatosis.
NTRK-rearranged spindle cell neoplasm. Hybrid tumour with TPR::NTRK1 fusion; an area with increased cellularity reminiscent of low-grade malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour.
NTRK-rearranged spindle cell neoplasm. Tumour with TPM3::NTRK1 fusion; an area resembling high-grade spindle cell sarcoma.
NTRK-rearranged spindle cell neoplasm. Tumour with TPM3::NTRK1 fusion and diffuse immunoreactivity for pan-TRK.

definition: Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma is a rare neoplasm of intermediate malignant potential and uncertain differentiation, mostly occurring in the subcutis and histopathologically characterized by nodules of ovoid and spindle cells, haemorrhagic pseudocystic spaces, and a peripheral rim of lymphoplasmacytic cells.
clinical:
Patients typically present with a slow-growing, superficial, painless soft tissue mass simulating a haematoma or a haemangioma.

---

It accounts for 0.3% of all soft tissue tumours, with no sex predilection. A wide age range is reported, with a peak incidence in the first two decades of life.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The most frequent genetic abnormality is the t(2;22)(q33;q12) translocation, resulting in a EWSR1::CREB1 fusion, followed by t(12;22)(q12;q12) translocation, leading to a EWSR1::ATF1 fusion. Rare tumours harbour a FUS::ATF1 fusion.
macroscopic: Grossly, these tumours appear as multinodular and cystic masses, with a size ranging from 7 to 120 mm (median size: 20 mm). The cut surface shows multilocular haemorrhagic to yellowish-white areas.
microscopic: Tumours are circumscribed and lobulated. They contain varying proportions of fascicles or sheets of oval and spindle-shaped cells containing bland vesicular nuclei, and pseudoangiomatous blood-filled spaces. They also have a thick fibrous pseudocapsule with haemosiderin deposition, and a pericapsular cuff of lymphoplasmacytic cells with germinal centres, simulating a metastatic lymph node. Nearly one third of cases have a completely solid appearance. Mitotic figures are few, although atypical mitotic figures may be noted. A variable number of pleomorphic cells may be present. Cellular atypia and increased mitotic figures are not associated with an aggressive clinical outcome. One pattern of angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma is characterized by small blue round cells, resembling an undifferentiated round cell sarcoma. A myxoid pattern has also been described. Immunohistochemistry Most tumours express SOX9. Nearly 50% of cases are immunoreactive for desmin. These tumours are consistently negative for MYOD1 and myogenin. EMA, CD99, and CD68 are variably immunopositive. The Ki-67 proliferation index is invariably low.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: Most cases follow an indolent course, with recurrences in nearly 15% and metastasis in up to 5% of cases, predominantly to locoregional lymph nodes and rarely to the lungs, liver, and brain. Rare deaths have been reported from metastasis, although long-term survival after resection is reported in metastatic cases. Cases with incomplete surgical clearance and those occurring in deeper locations are associated with higher rates of recurrence and metastasis.
cytology: Smears are cellular and composed of loosely arranged ovoid to spindled cells displaying moderate nuclear pleomorphism. Interspersed are blood products and inflammatory cells.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Demonstration of the presence of EWSR1::CREB1 or alternative gene fusions may be helpful for the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Not recommended: angiomatoid malignant fibrous histiocytoma.

media.legend: Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. A well-circumscribed, nodular tumour with a blood-filled pseudocystic space, tumour cells, inflammatory cells, and a peripheral cuff of lymphoid cells (including germinal centres), resembling a lymph node.
Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Pseudocystic haemorrhagic areas surrounded by epithelioid and spindle-shaped tumour cells and intervening lymphocytes and plasma cells.
Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Fascicles of epithelioid and spindled cells with bland nuclei and a variable myxoid stroma.
Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Oval and polygonal cells with distinct areas of myxoid stroma and intervening lymphocytes and plasma cells.
Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Tumour cells have enlarged nuclei and relatively bland chromatin, along with interspersed lymphocytes and few plasma cells.
Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Tumour cells displaying focal desmin positivity.
Angiomatoid fibrous histiocytoma. Using an EWSR1 dual-coloured break-apart FISH probe, several tumour cells show red–green split signals, indicative of EWSR1 gene rearrangement.

definition: Perivascular epithelioid cell tumours (PEComas) are mesenchymal neoplasms composed of perivascular epithelioid cells (PECs) – distinctive epithelioid cells that are often closely associated with blood vessel walls and that express both melanocytic and smooth muscle markers.
clinical:
Patients typically present with painless cutaneous nodules, papules, or plaques.

---

Primary cutaneous PEComas are rare. Tumours most often arise in female patients and occur over a wide age range (15–81 years), with a peak in middle age.
pathogenesis:
Virtually all cutaneous PEComas are sporadic, in contrast to their soft tissue or visceral counterparts, of which a small subset are associated with tuberous sclerosis. However, cutaneous cases of a recently described pattern (fibroma-like PEComa) associated with tuberous sclerosis have been described.

---

Deletion of 16p, the location of the TSC2 gene, is a frequent finding in PEComa; loss of heterozygosity at the TSC2 locus occurs in both sporadic and syndromic tumours. TP53 mutations have been identified in 63% of TSC2-mutated PEComas. A small subset of PEComas harbour TFE3 gene fusions, which correlate with strong nuclear immunoreactivity for TFE3, but in skin, TFE3 rearrangements have not been described.
macroscopic: Cutaneous PEComas are usually smaller than those arising at deep locations (range: 3–40 mm; most are < 20 mm). The tumours are well circumscribed, with a firm yellow or tan cut surface.
microscopic: Tumours are dermal-based but often extend into the subcutis. The edges are typically irregular and may show entrapment of dermal collagen. Most PEComas show a nested or trabecular architecture with a distinctive perivascular pattern of growth, with tumour cells radially arranged around vessels, replacing the vessel wall and approaching the endothelium, and are composed of epithelioid cells with granular, palely eosinophilic, or clear cytoplasm and round nuclei with small nucleoli. A mixed epithelioid and spindle cell morphology is less common. Scattered multinucleated cells may be seen, and occasionally mild pleomorphism, but mitotic figures are usually scarce or absent. Almost all reported cases of cutaneous PEComa lack histological features of malignancy (mitotic activity, necrosis, and pleomorphism), with only rare case reports of malignant forms. The presence of malignant features should raise the possibility of a cutaneous metastasis rather than a true primary tumour. So-called angiomyolipomas of skin probably represent hamartomatous or lipomatous neoplasms with a smooth muscle component, rather than being part of the PEComa family of tumours. Immunohistochemistry PEComas characteristically express both melanocytic markers, such as HMB45 (the most sensitive immunomarker), melan-A, and MITF, and muscle markers, such as SMA, desmin, and caldesmon. However, expression of smooth muscle markers is less common in primary cutaneous PEComas than in soft tissue counterparts, occurring in just over 50% of cases. Nuclear expression of S100 is uncommon and usually focal. Tumour cells lack expression of keratins. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis may include metastatic melanoma or metastatic renal cell carcinoma (there is often a strong and diffuse expression of CD10 by the tumour cells).
prognosis_and_prediction: Virtually all cutaneous PEComas are benign and cured by simple excision. Given the rarity of primary cutaneous malignant PEComas, there are no data for prognostication, but at other sites malignant forms are typically large (> 50 mm) and pursue an aggressive clinical course.
related_terminology: Not recommended: clear cell myomelanocytic tumour; clear cell sugar tumour.

media.legend: Cutaneous PEComa. The tumour cells in the dermis show a trabecular and nested growth pattern and have abundant clear or palely eosinophilic cytoplasm. Scattered multinucleated tumour cells are present.

Cutaneous PEComa. A delicate capillary network surrounds nests of epithelioid tumour cells. The tumour cells have wispy eosinophilic cytoplasm and round or oval nuclei with fine chromatin and mild pleomorphism. No mitotic activity is seen.
Cutaneous PEComa. HMB45 is the most consistently expressed marker and may show diffuse or patchy cytoplasmic positivity.

definition: Non-neural granular cell tumour (NNGCT) is a rare, low-grade neoplasm of mesenchymal cells of unknown lineage with prominent cytoplasmic granularity.
clinical:
The lesions are most commonly non-ulcerated papules or nodules.

---

NNGCT occurs in children and adults.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

In a small series, 3 of 5 NNGCTs (60%) harboured ALK rearrangements. Other pathogenic alterations have not been identified.
microscopic: NNGCTs can be polypoid. Some lesions are gently domed. The lesional cells often extend to the base of the dermis or into the subcutis. The overlying epidermis is usually thin, with epithelial collarettes defining the lateral edges. The granular cells form sheets and are large and oval, with coarse eosinophilic granules. The cellular granularity is due to the accumulation of lysosomes in the cytoplasm of the affected cells. The largest granules are surrounded by clear haloes (pustulo-ovoid bodies of Milian). The nuclei can vary from moderately sized and monomorphic to large, pleomorphic, and heterochromatic. Mitoses can range from few to many (as many as 6 mitoses/mm2), and atypical mitoses can occur. While typically circumscribed, some cases show poorly demarcated deep margins. A few cases have shown lymphatic invasion. Immunohistochemistry The cells of NNGCTs fail to stain for S100 and other neural or melanocytic markers. They usually stain positively for CD68 and CD63 (NKI/C3), probably because of reactivity with lysosomes in the cytoplasm, but such positivity is not lineage-specific; it can also be seen in the cells of many other neoplasms. They are negative for desmin, SMA, and cytokeratin. Differential diagnosis The diagnosis of NNGCT is one of exclusion. While the tumours often resemble conventional granular cell tumour of Schwannian origin, a polypoid configuration, epithelial collarettes, nuclear pleomorphism (including prominent nucleoli), and easily detectable mitoses favour NNGCT. Unlike NNGCTs, conventional granular cell tumours are positive for S100 and SOX10. Granular cell fibrous papules are usually found on the nose, are smaller dome-surfaced lesions, and have nearly clear cytoplasm with paler granules. For NNGCT with cytological atypia and mitotic activity, granular cell patterns of basal cell carcinoma, dermatofibroma, leiomyosarcoma, and dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans are considerations and can usually be distinguished by the expression of lineage-specific markers or by areas in which the conventional aspects of these neoplasms are apparent.
prognosis_and_prediction: Most cases are indolent, despite worrisome histopathological features. Few cases with regional lymph node metastasis have been reported, without further dissemination or recurrence.
related_terminology: Acceptable: primitive polypoid granular cell tumour; primitive non-neural granular cell tumour; dermal non-neural granular cell tumour.

media.legend: Non-neural granular cell tumour. The lesions are often polypoid, with an epithelial collarette.
Non-neural granular cell tumour. Note the large oval cells with abundant cytoplasmic eosinophilic granules.

Non-neural granular cell tumour. Cytological atypia and pleomorphism may be encountered, but they do not correlate with a more aggressive course; note the pustulo-ovoid bodies of Milian in the right side of the field.

Non-neural granular cell tumour. A nodular lesion extending into the subcutis. The granular cells form sheets and are large and oval, with coarse eosinophilic granules, and they display moderate pleomorphism. Mitotic figures are seen.

definition: Epithelioid fibrous histiocytoma (EFH) is a distinctive, usually exophytic and well-circumscribed benign cutaneous neoplasm composed of epithelioid cells, including binucleated forms. ALK rearrangement is present in the vast majority of cases.
clinical:
EFH manifests as an exophytic nodule, often with a vascular appearance.

---

EFH typically arises in young to middle-aged adults (median age: 40 years), with a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Although the histogenesis is unknown, EFH is probably biologically distinct from dermatofibroma (conventional fibrous histiocytoma) and its subtypes. EFHs harbour rearrangements of ALK (in ~90% of cases) or a PRKC gene (rarely), as mutually exclusive events. SQSTM1 and VCL are the most common ALK fusion partners; rare fusions partners are DCTN1, ETV6, PPFIBP1, SPECC1L, TPM3, PRKAR2A, MLPH, CLTC, and EML4.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a well-circumscribed dermal papule.
microscopic: EFH is usually well circumscribed; exophytic examples often have an adnexal collarette. The tumour is composed of uniform plump epithelioid cells with vesicular nuclei, small nucleoli, and abundant pale eosinophilic or amphophilic cytoplasm, often including binucleated forms. Small, thin-walled blood vessels may be prominent, sometimes with perivascular accentuation of tumour cells. Chondroblastoma-like pericellular calcification and lesions mostly composed of spindle cells have been described. ALK is overexpressed in about 90% of cases, with higher positivity with the D5F3 or 5A4 clones than with the ALK1 clone, and EMA is positive in 65%. CD30 expression may be seen. CD31, SMA, and desmin are usually negative. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes Spitz naevus, cutaneous syncytial myoepithelioma, epithelioid sarcoma, and cellular neurothekeoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Epithelioid fibrous histiocytoma is benign; rarely, it recurs locally.
related_terminology: Acceptable: epithelioid cell histiocytoma.

media.legend: Epithelioid fibrous histiocytoma. Scanning magnification showing a well-circumscribed dome-shaped papule with adnexal collarette.
Epithelioid fibrous histiocytoma. Higher magnification showing tumour cells with vesicular nuclei, small nucleoli, and abundant pale eosinophilic or amphophilic cytoplasm.
Epithelioid fibrous histiocytoma. Immunohistochemically, the neoplastic cells show strong ALK positivity.

definition: Cellular neurothekeoma is a benign cutaneous neoplasm of uncertain histogenesis. This tumour type is not related to nerve sheath myxoma (formerly myxoid neurothekeoma).
clinical:
Cellular neurothekeoma manifests as a solitary firm papule or nodule with no distinctive clinical features.

---

Cellular neurothekeoma occurs most commonly in children and young adults, with a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The histogenesis is uncertain, but the gene expression profile is similar to that of cellular fibrous histiocytoma, suggesting myofibroblastic differentiation.
macroscopic: Cellular neurothekeoma appears as a well-circumscribed dermal nodule.
microscopic: Cellular neurothekeoma is a lobulated or micronodular neoplasm composed of nests of usually epithelioid but occasionally spindled cells with a vesicular nucleus, small nucleolus, and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, often separated by dense collagenous stroma. Some tumours contain prominent myxoid stroma, and rare cases may show an infiltrative growth pattern. Occasional neoplastic cells may be multinucleated or may show hyperchromatic nuclei, and mitotic figures are common. In rare cases, areas of calcification, ossification, perineural invasion, and a plexiform pattern with hybrid features of both cellular neurothekeoma and perineurioma can be seen. Immunohistochemistry The most consistent markers expressed in cellular neurothekeoma are CD63 (NKI/C3), NSE, PGP9.5, and S100A6, as well as KBA.62 and PRAME (these last two are also expressed in melanoma). Expression of MITF, SMA, and podoplanin (D2-40) is more variable. Cellular neurothekeoma does not express S100, GFAP, CD57, SOX10, or EMA. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes nerve sheath myxoma, Spitz naevus, cutaneous leiomyoma, and plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumour. Nerve sheath myxomas and Spitz naevi are positive for S100. Cutaneous leiomyoma has an intersecting fascicular pattern and is desmin-positive. Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumour has a biphasic appearance and a plexiform growth pattern.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: Cellular neurothekeoma is benign, and complete surgical removal is curative.
related_terminology: Acceptable: neurothekeoma.

media.legend: Cellular neurothekeoma. Scanning magnification showing a well-circumscribed dermal nodule.

Cellular neurothekeoma. Higher magnification showing nodules composed of epithelioid cells with a vesicular nucleus, small nucleolus, and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm, surrounded by dense collagenous stroma.
Cellular neurothekeoma. Some tumours show prominent myxoid stromal change and can mimic dermal nerve sheath myxoma.

definition: Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour (MPNST) is a malignant spindle cell or epithelioid tumour often arising from a peripheral nerve, from a pre-existing benign nerve sheath tumour, or in a patient with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Cutaneous MPNST is less frequently associated with NF1 than deep MPNST.
clinical:
The most common symptoms are localized swelling and pain, but many cases are asymptomatic. They can occur at any age, but patients with cutaneous MPNST tend to be older than patients with deep-seated tumours. Patients with NF1 are usually younger at the time of diagnosis than patients with sporadic tumours.

---

Cutaneous MPNST is extremely rare, with few reported cases. Only 2% of cutaneous spindle cell malignancies are MPNSTs. Although epithelioid MPNST accounts for < 5% of MPNSTs, this subtype more often involves superficial soft tissues.
pathogenesis:
Conventional MPNST is associated with NF1. Epithelioid MPNST is not associated with NF1 but may arise in association with a schwannoma.

---

Genomic studies of deep-seated conventional MPNSTs demonstrated highly frequent and concurrent inactivating mutations in three pathways: NF1, CDKN2A/CDKN2B, and PRC2 core components (EED or SUZ12), resulting in complete loss of function. In patients with NF1, malignant transformation from pre-existing neurofibromas is often accompanied by progressive genomic alterations that inactivate neurofibromin (NF1), p16/p15 (CDKN2A/CDKN2B), and PRC2 pathways, as well as increased genomic copy-number variations. About 80% of high-grade MPNSTs exhibit complete loss of PRC2 activity and H3 p.K27me3. The loss of H3 p.K27me3 has become a useful diagnostic tool in high-grade MPNST. Given the critical role of PRC2 in development and cell-lineage specification, PRC2 loss may underlie the molecular mechanisms of the histological phenotype of heterologous differentiation in MPNSTs. Given the rarity of cutaneous MPNST, its molecular pathogenesis remains unclear. Epithelioid MPNSTs are distinct from conventional MPNSTs molecularly. SMARCB1 gene inactivation resulting in SMARCB1 loss by immunohistochemistry is observed in approximately 75% of cases. They rarely have genetic alterations in the neurofibromin (NF1), p16/p15 (CDKN2A/CDKN2B), and PRC2 pathways.
macroscopic: MPNSTs are firm, poorly demarcated or well-demarcated tumours that involve the dermis and may extend into the subcutaneous tissue.
microscopic: The classic form is composed of fascicles of spindle-shaped cells, often with a haemangiopericytoma-like vascular pattern, and alternating hypercellular and hypocellular areas (tapestry appearance) and perivascular accentuation of cellularity. Heterologous elements, as observed in deep-seated tumours, rarely occur. Epithelioid MPNST is composed of plump, epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, sometimes embedded in a myxoid or hyalinized matrix, and typically demonstrating a lobulated growth pattern. Immunohistochemistry MPNST may be positive for S100 (< 50% of tumours), SOX10 (< 70%), and GFAP (20–30%). Importantly, expression of S100 and SOX10 is patchy or focal. Diffuse positivity for S100 or SOX10 is not usually compatible with the diagnosis of conventional MPNST. Complete loss of expression of H3 p.K27me3 may be helpful in the diagnosis of MPNST, with high-grade tumours (and radiation-induced MPNST) showing more-frequent loss than low-grade tumours. Epithelioid MPNSTs show strong and diffuse expression of S100 and SOX10 but do not show positivity for melanoma markers. They retain H3 p.K27me3, and most show loss of SMARCB1 expression. Epithelioid MPNST may also be positive for keratin. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes spindle cell melanoma, fibrosarcomatous dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, melanoma, and (myoepithelial) carcinoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: The treatment is complete resection. The tumour may locally recur or metastasize. The 5-year survival rate is approximately 60%, which is twice that of deep-seated tumours. There are no histological parameters that can predict behaviour.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: In diagnostically challenging cases, DNA methylation profiling can identify a specific tumour signature of MPNST. Other supporting molecular data include mutations in NF1 and SUZ12 or EED.
related_terminology: Not recommended: malignant schwannoma; neurofibrosarcoma; neurogenic sarcoma; malignant perineurioma.
subtypes: Epithelioid malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour

media.legend: Epithelioid malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. The cells are epithelioid, with eosinophilic cytoplasm and large nuclei with prominent nucleoli, mimicking a malignant melanoma.

Epithelioid malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. A SOX10 stain shows diffuse expression by the tumour cells. This is in contrast to the spindle cell subtype, which shows very focal or no expression of SOX10. The same staining pattern is seen with S100.
Epithelioid malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. SMARCB1 (INI1) immunohistochemistry shows loss of expression by the neoplastic cells. This is a frequent finding in the epithelioid subtype.

Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. Tumour arising in a patient with neurofibromatosis type 1. The tumour involves the dermis and subcutaneous tissue. It is composed of spindle-shaped cells with alternating hypercellular and hypocellular areas.
Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. Higher magnification demonstrates the alternating hypercellular and hypocellular areas.
Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. A high-power view shows the characteristic “wavy” nuclei.

Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour. A poorly circumscribed, necrotic, atypical spindle cell proliferation with wavy nuclei. Cellular areas alternate with hypocellular myxoid zones, with mild pleomorphism. Slightly increased cellularity is seen adjacent to blood vessels.

definition: Hybrid nerve sheath tumours are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumours with combined features of more than one conventional type (neurofibroma, schwannoma, perineurioma).
clinical:
Hybrid nerve sheath tumours manifest most often as painless masses in subcutaneous tissue or dermis.

---

Hybrid nerve sheath tumours are rare. The most common examples are tumours showing hybrid features of schwannoma and perineurioma, followed by hybrid neurofibroma/schwannoma. These tumours may occur at any age, with a peak in young adults and an equal sex distribution.
pathogenesis:
Hybrid schwannoma/perineurioma occurs sporadically, whereas hybrid neurofibroma/schwannoma is strongly associated with the neurofibromatoses. A high prevalence of hybrid schwannoma/neurofibroma morphology was found in tumours from patients with schwannomatosis (71%), often leading to misdiagnosis as neurofibroma. Hybrid neurofibroma/perineurioma has been described in association with neurofibromatosis type 1.

---

VGLL3 gene rearrangement was found in most cases of hybrid perineurioma/schwannoma in one cohort, suggesting these tumours represent a distinct pathological entity.
macroscopic: Grossly, the tumours are well circumscribed, with a firm cut surface.
microscopic: Hybrid schwannoma/perineurioma shows a storiform or fascicular growth and is usually composed of an intimate admixture of alternating Schwann cells with plump nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm and perineurial cells with slender nuclei and delicate elongated cytoplasmic processes. The Schwann cell component is often prominent. The tumours may show degenerative nuclear atypia (ancient change). Mitoses are rare. The two components can be highlighted by immunohistochemistry: Schwann cells are positive for S100, and perineurial cells for EMA, claudin-1, and GLUT1. Hybrid neurofibroma/schwannoma is composed of schwannomatous nodules or Schwann cell bundles within an otherwise typical neurofibroma. Immunostaining highlights the mixed population of cells in the neurofibromatous component, including fibroblasts (CD34), Schwann cells (S100 and SOX10), and perineurial cells (EMA, claudin-1, and GLUT1), and the monomorphic Schwann cell populations in the Schwann cell solid nodules (highlighted by diffuse expression of S100 and SOX10). Hybrid neurofibroma/perineurioma contains a plexiform neurofibroma with areas of perineurial differentiation. These areas are often only recognizable with the aid of immunohistochemistry. The perineuriomatous areas are immunopositive for EMA, GLUT1, and claudin-1, and the neurofibroma areas show a mixed population of cells including fibroblasts (CD34), Schwann cells (S100 and SOX10), and perineurial cells (EMA, claudin-1, and GLUT1).
prognosis_and_prediction: The tumours are benign and rarely recur locally.
related_terminology: Acceptable: benign nerve sheath tumour NOS.

media.legend: Hybrid schwannoma/neurofibroma. Solid nodule of Schwann cell proliferation surrounded by loose hypocellular tumour.
Hybrid schwannoma/neurofibroma. S100 stain showing diffuse staining in the solid Schwann cell nodule and a mixed population of cells (S100-positive and S100-negative) in surrounding loose areas.
Hybrid schwannoma/perineurioma. The tumour shows a storiform architecture, similar to that of perineurioma of soft tissue.
Hybrid schwannoma/perineurioma. Many of the tumour cells contain plump, tapering nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, typical of Schwann cells. The perineurial cell component is often inconspicuous.
Hybrid schwannoma/perineurioma. Double immunolabelling for S100 (red) and EMA (brown) highlights alternating Schwann cells and perineurial cells, respectively.

definition: Schwannoma is a benign neoplasm composed entirely or nearly entirely of mature neoplastic Schwann cells.
clinical:
Schwannomas are slow-growing and occasionally painful. They are typically solitary, except in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) or schwannomatosis.

---

Sporadic schwannomas typically arise in the fourth to sixth decades of life.
pathogenesis:
The etiology of most schwannomas is unknown, although there are established associations with prior irradiation, NF2, and schwannomatosis.

---

Conventional schwannomas typically harbour somatic loss-of-function mutations in NF2 and complete or partial loss of chromosome 22, including the wildtype NF2 allele. Other recurrently mutated tumour suppressors include ARID1A/ARID1B (mutated in 29% of cases) and TSC1/TSC2 (in 15%). SH3PXD2A::HTRA1 fusions (found in 10% of cases) activate the MAPK pathway and are mutually exclusive with mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase gene DDR1 (found in 11% of cases). Germline pathogenic mutations in NF2, LZTR1, SMARCB1, and DGCR8, all located on chromosome 22q, are associated with schwannoma susceptibility. Vestibular schwannomas are the hallmark of NF2. Schwannomatosis 1 and schwannomatosis 2 are due to germline mutations of SMARCB1 (INI1) and LZTR1, respectively. Schwannomas in these patients typically demonstrate loss of two tumour suppressors (NF2 and either LZTR1 or SMARCB1). DGCR8 point mutations are associated with familial multinodular goitre with schwannomatosis.
macroscopic: Tumours vary in size from a few millimetres to > 80 mm in diameter. Smaller ones are usually white, fusiform, circumscribed, and encapsulated. Larger tumours are lobulated, with greyish-yellowish areas on sectioning, and may rarely contain cystic areas or haemorrhage.
microscopic: Antoni A areas containing spindle cells with wavy nuclei alternate with hypocellular Antoni B areas, which contain a myxoid matrix and a variable lymphohistiocytic infiltrate. Within the Antoni A areas, parallel rows of nuclei (Verocay bodies) may be seen. Mitoses are rare. In ancient schwannoma, there is degenerative nuclear atypia. Rare subtypes include plexiform, epithelioid, cellular, neuroblastoma-like, and microcystic/reticular schwannoma. Immunohistochemistry Schwannomas are strongly positive for S100 and SOX10 and have an EMA-positive perineurial capsule. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes neurofibroma, although this often has a lattice-like CD34 staining pattern not seen in schwannomas, as well as a smaller proportion of S100/SOX10-positive cells. It also includes solitary circumscribed neuroma. Epithelioid schwannoma should be distinguished from melanoma, myoepithelioma, and ossifying fibromyxoid tumour; roughly 40% of epithelioid schwannomas show loss of SMARCB1 (INI1) expression. Cellular schwannomas with increased atypia and/or mitotic activity may raise concern for malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour (MPNST). However, schwannomas typically show diffuse S100/SOX10 staining (unlike MPNST) and express p16 and H3 p.K27me3, which are lost in most MPNSTs.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: Schwannoma recurs infrequently; malignant transformation is extraordinarily rare.
cytology: Schwannomas often yield paucicellular material on cytological preparations. Aspirate smears show cohesive clusters of bland spindle cells with uniform spindled or wavy nuclei and thin cytoplasmic processes.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Chromosome 22q deletion and/or NF2 mutation are frequent but nonspecific alterations. Schwannomas have a distinct DNA methylation pattern, although in the vast majority of cases, molecular testing is not needed.
related_terminology: Not recommended: neurilemoma.
subtypes: Plexiform schwannoma; epithelioid schwannoma; ancient schwannoma; cellular schwannoma; microcystic/reticular schwannoma; neuroblastoma-like schwannoma

media.legend: Schwannoma. An Antoni A area demonstrating palisading Verocay bodies.
Schwannoma. An Antoni B area demonstrating a hypocellular myxoid region adjacent to Antoni A changes.
Cellular schwannoma. Increased cellularity with fascicular architecture.
Neuroblastoma-like schwannoma. A characteristic pseudorosette.
Plexiform schwannoma. Multiple schwannoma nodules in the dermis.
Epithelioid schwannoma. Epithelioid tumour cells.
Cutaneous schwannoma with H&E staining.
Plexiform schwannoma of the skin with H&E staining.
Cellular schwannoma. This schwannoma has areas of high cellularity.

definition: Neurofibroma is a benign tumour of axons, Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and perineurial cells in a collagenous matrix containing mast cells and mucin.
clinical:
Sporadic neurofibromas are solitary, slow-growing, painless, soft, skin-coloured papules or nodules. Subcutaneous (including diffuse) neurofibromas form nodules or deep plaques. Plexiform neurofibromas are congenital, irregular, tortuous, multinodular masses. Diffuse and plexiform neurofibromas usually affect children or young adults.

---

All demographic groups are affected, with no sex predilection and with peak incidence in the third decade of life [[Antonescu CR, Scheithauer BW, Woodruff JM. Tumors of the peripheral nervous system. Washington, DC: Armed Forces Institute of Pathology; 2013. (AFIP atlas of tumor pathology, series 4; fascicle 19).]].
pathogenesis:
Neurofibromas are the most common peripheral nerve sheath tumours, with the majority occurring sporadically as solitary lesions. Less often, they occur as multiple or numerous tumours in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The diffuse cutaneous and plexiform tumours are presumably of congenital origin and, in NF1, the localized cutaneous and localized intraneural neurofibromas begin to appear in the second half of the first decade of life.

---

The originating cell and nosological classification are controversial. Most neurofibromas are sporadic and solitary. Multiple tumours or the plexiform and diffuse subtypes suggest neurofibromatoses (NF1 and NF2), autosomal dominant disorders caused by genetic alterations in the neurofibromin gene (NF1) on chromosome 17 or in NF2 (encoding merlin [NF2, schwannomin]) on chromosome 22. Many affected patients disease reflects new mutations. NF1 encodes neurofibromin (NF1), a negative regulator of the RAS/MAPK pathway. NF1 mutations cause loss of neurofibromin function, resulting in RAS signalling and MAPK activation. Germline plus somatic mutations (NF1−/−) cause loss of functional neurofibromin. Detailed genotype–phenotype correlations have been documented. Subsequent loss of CDKN2A on chromosome 9p21.3 eventuates in atypical neurofibromatous tumour of uncertain biological potential, which may progress to malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour (MPNST).
macroscopic: Neurofibroma appears tan-white, homogeneous, and firm. Diffuse neurofibroma shows subcutaneous thickening. Plexiform neurofibroma expands large peripheral nerve segments. Diffuse and plexiform neurofibromas may be pigmented (melanotic neurofibroma).
microscopic: Neurofibromas are unencapsulated tumours composed of spindle cells, collagen fibres, lymphocytes, and mast cells; skin appendages are usually preserved. Neurofibromas are composed of spindle cells with thin, wavy, hyperchromatic nuclei and delicate, pale, eosinophilic cytoplasm. Several patterns have been described: interstitial mucin is prominent in myxoid neurofibroma. Sclerotic neurofibroma has scant spindle cells in a collagenous matrix. Lipomatous neurofibroma has admixed adipocytes. Diffuse neurofibroma infiltrates dermis and subcutis, entrapping adnexa or adipocytes. Plexiform neurofibroma consists of tortuous nerves distended by axons, Schwann cells, and fibroblasts; multivacuolated, mucin-filled cells express CD34 and GLUT1. Melanotic neurofibroma contains variable melanin. Immunohistochemistry Some cells are positive for S100 and SOX10, and for peripherin in thin axons. EMA is negative except in plexiform neurofibroma. A characteristic fingerprint pattern consists of CD34-positive perineurial fibroblasts anastomosing around Schwann cells. Even non-pigmented diffuse neurofibromas may express melanocytic markers. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes schwannoma, perineurioma, dermatofibroma, sclerotic fibroma, neurotized and sclerotic/desmoplastic melanocytic naevus, dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, fibromatosis, and desmoplastic melanoma.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: Depending on location, solitary sporadic neurofibromas are usually asymptomatic; neurofibromas in neurofibromatosis may cause appreciable morbidity, owing to their number or location. An additional significant concern (especially in NF1) is transformation to MPNST. Although exceedingly rare in sporadic neurofibromas, MPNSTs reportedly arise in 8–29% of patients with NF1. NF1-associated MPNSTs have an earlier onset and reduced survival than sporadic MPNSTs.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular analyses do not have an established role in the diagnosis of neurofibroma. However, chromosomal copy-number profiling (showing CDKN2A/CDKN2B deletion) may be helpful for the evaluation of atypical neurofibroma / atypical neurofibromatous neoplasm of uncertain biological potential (see the relevant section in the WHO classification of tumours of soft tissue and bone [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Soft tissue and bone tumours. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2020. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 3). https://publications.iarc.who.int/588.]]) and its differentiation from MPNST (which shows a complex, highly rearranged genome). Of note, conventional dermal and plexiform neurofibromas, atypical neurofibroma / atypical neurofibromatous neoplasm of uncertain biological potential, and MPNST all exhibit distinct DNA methylation profiles.
related_terminology: None
subtypes: Solitary neurofibroma; diffuse neurofibroma; plexiform neurofibroma; melanotic neurofibroma

media.legend: Cutaneous neurofibroma. A well-circumscribed but unencapsulated, pale eosinophilic tumour centred in the dermis.
Diffuse neurofibroma. Pale eosinophilic tumour infiltrating the dermis (without effacing endogenous structures) and extending into the subcutis.
Diffuse neurofibroma. High-magnification view of tumour cells insinuating within subcutaneous adipose tissue.
Plexiform neurofibroma. Serpiginous, expanded nerve bundles infiltrated by tumour.
Cutaneous neurofibroma. Spindle cells in a matrix composed of strands of collagen.

Mixed-pattern (plexiform and diffuse) neurofibroma. Tortuous nerve bundles expanded by tumour with spillage into the surrounding tissue, without effacement of architecture; note the preservation of glandular structures.

Cutaneous neurofibroma. Spindle cells with thin, wavy, hyperchromatic nuclei and delicate, pale eosinophilic cytoplasmic processes; these spindle cells are embedded in a matrix of thin strands of collagen and interstitial mucin, with an associated infiltrate of small mature lymphocytes, histiocytes, and conspicuous mast cells.
Neurofibroma. A variably circumscribed, nonencapsulated proliferation of spindle cells with wavy nuclei, arranged haphazardly in a loose myxoid stroma, with scattered mast cells.

definition: Perineurioma is a usually benign perineural neoplasm occurring in skin, intestinal mucosa, nerves, and soft tissue.
clinical:
Perineuriomas manifest as well-circumscribed, painless, skin-coloured papules, nodules, or tumours. Ten per cent are dermal, and subcutaneous tissue is more commonly involved than deep soft tissue. They are rarely multiple.

---

Perineuriomas are rare. They have a slight female predilection and a wide age range, with a peak incidence in middle-aged adults. Children are rarely affected. The sclerosing subtype is more common in young men.
pathogenesis:
These tumours are nearly always sporadic; rarely, they are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 and type 2.

---

Perineuriomas share pathogenetic mechanisms with other nerve sheath tumours, similar to schwannoma and meningioma, such as deletion of 22q12, monosomies, and mutations in NF2. Deletion of 17q11 (including NF1) is common in soft tissue perineurioma; other alterations include a three-way chromosome 2, 9, and 4 translocation involving ABL1. Rearrangement involving 10q24 frequently occurs in the sclerosing subtype. Malignant perineuriomas have been reported with loss of chromosome 13q and small deletions of chromosomes 3, 6, and 9.
macroscopic: The tumours are well circumscribed and unencapsulated, with a cut surface that is usually firm to rubbery and yellow, tan, or white. They range in size from 5 to 200 mm.
microscopic: Perineuriomas typically show a storiform to fascicular growth pattern, with a lamellar arrangement, perivascular whorls, and a collagenous to myxoid stroma. Plexiform or lipomatous patterns have rarely been reported. The tumour cells are slender and spindled, with wavy, tapering nuclei and delicate bipolar cytoplasmatic processes. Occasionally, ancient features with degenerative nuclear changes, multinucleated giant cells, and nuclear pseudoinclusions may be seen. The sclerosing subtype shows strands of small epithelioid to spindle cells, rarely showing granular cell changes, in dense collagen. The reticular subtype shows anastomosing cords of elongated spindle cells with reticulate architecture. Malignant perineuriomas have a similar architecture but also show hypercellularity, hyperchromasia, pleomorphism, and a high mitotic count. Immunohistochemistry EMA is positive, from weak and focal to strong and diffuse. Collagen IV, laminin, claudin, and GLUT1 are often positive, and 60% of tumours express CD34. Sclerosing perineurioma shows limited keratin expression. Tumour cells are negative for S100, SOX10, and GFAP. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes epithelioid fibrous histiocytoma, fibroma of tendon sheath, sclerotic fibroma, extracranial meningioma, and low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Perineuriomas are benign and only rarely recur. Malignant perineurioma is less aggressive than conventional malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours (see related section).
related_terminology: Not recommended: perineural cell tumour.
subtypes: Reticular perineurioma; sclerosing perineurioma; malignant perineurioma

media.legend: Cutaneous perineurioma. A well-demarcated, acral pop-out lesion with fine collagen fibres, storiform to fascicular, in a lamellar arrangement, and moderate perivascular whorls, with interspersed monomorphic slender spindle cells.

Perineurioma. EMA immunoreactivity of slender spindle cells with wavy tapering nuclei and delicate bipolar to dendritic reactivity. Note that this reactivity can be quite variable within a given lesion, as well as from lesion to lesion.
Perineurioma, cutaneous sclerotic. Scanning magnification of a well-demarcated, acral lesion with homogeneous, faintly eosinophilic, cell-pure character contrasting with vascular structures.

Sclerotic cutaneous perineurioma. A well-demarcated lesion with fine collagen fibres, storiform, lamellar, and prominently whorled with central sclerosis. There are interspersed monomorphic, small, round/oval to spindle cells.

Cutaneous perineurioma, vascular-rich pattern. A well-demarcated, acral lesion with fine collagen fibres, fascicular and lamellar, and prominent small round dilated to prominently elongated vessels. There are interspersed monomorphic round/oval to slender spindle cells.

Subcutaneous perineurioma. A well-demarcated lesion with fibrosclerotic collagen, lamellar arrangement, and prominent perivascular whorls. There are interspersed monomorphic, inconspicuous, round/oval to spindle cells.

Subcutaneous perineurioma. A well-demarcated lesion with fibrosclerotic collagen, lamellar arrangement, and prominent perivascular whorls, with interspersed monomorphic, inconspicuous, mostly round to oval perineurial cells.

Perineurioma, soft tissue. A perineurioma with a fascicular, lamellar and moderately whorled, more dense character, with fine collagen fibres in the lower-right, while the upper-left is storiform to whorled and looser to myxoid, with beginning reticular arrangement. Note the monomorphic, slender spindle cells with wavy tapering nuclei and delicate bipolar cytoplasmic extensions.
Reticular perineurioma. Myxoid stroma and reticular arrangement of spindle cells.
Soft tissue perineurioma. Tumour with variably myxoid to collagenous stroma, mimicking low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma.

definition: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma is a benign peripheral nerve sheath tumour.
clinical:
The tumours manifest as small, superficial, slow-growing asymptomatic masses; some are painful.

---

Dermal nerve sheath myxomas are rare. The two largest modern series describe 68 tumours arising over a wide age range (8–72 years), with a peak in the mid-thirties and a slight male predominance.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Dermal nerve sheath myxoma was previously called classic or myxoid variant of neurothekeoma. However, pathological and molecular data demonstrated the Schwann cell derivation of dermal nerve sheath myxoma, which is clinically and biologically distinct from neurothekeoma. Thus, the gene signature of dermal nerve sheath myxomas is similar to that of dermal schwannomas, whereas cellular neurothekeomas more closely resemble cellular fibrous histiocytomas.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with rubbery/firm tumours in the dermis or subcutis, ranging from 4 to 45 mm (most < 25 mm). Cut section shows well-demarcated, glistening, white to translucent mucoid nodules.
microscopic: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma characteristically shows a multinodular growth pattern, abundant myxoid matrix, and a dense fibrous border in the dermis, subcutis, or both; it rarely extends to skeletal muscle. Neoplastic cells are small, epithelioid, ring-like, stellate, and spindled Schwann cells in cords, nests, and syncytial-like aggregates, with mild nuclear atypia. Some show ring-like morphology, resembling lipoblasts; rarely, multivacuolated cells with spider-like cytoplasmic processes, nuclear palisading, or Verocay body–like structures are seen. Scattered moderate pleomorphism, similar to that seen in ancient schwannomas, may be present. Mitoses are absent to very few. Immunohistochemistry S100 is diffusely positive, and GFAP and CD57 are also often positive. Rare cells are positive for AE1/AE3, and the fibrous capsule may show scattered EMA-positive cells.
prognosis_and_prediction: Dermal nerve sheath myxomas are benign tumours with high rates of local recurrence, particularly in the fingers. In the largest modern study, local recurrences occurred in 47% of patients, nearly one third experienced two to five local recurrences, and 25% of patients had active disease at last follow-up.
related_terminology: Not recommended: classic or myxoid variant of neurothekeoma.

media.legend: Dermal nerve sheath myxoma. Low/intermediate-power view of a dermal nerve sheath myxoma. Note the multinodularity, the rind of fibrous tissue around the nodules, and the abundant myxoid matrix. The neoplastic Schwann cells are arranged in cords and syncytial-like aggregates. Some have a ring-like appearance and resemble fat cells.
