The neoplastic Schwann cells are arranged in cords and syncytial-like aggregates. Some have a ring-like appearance and resemble fat cells.

Dermal nerve sheath myxoma. Low/intermediate-power view of a dermal nerve sheath myxoma. Note the multinodularity, the rind of fibrous tissue around the nodules, and the abundant myxoid matrix. The neoplastic Schwann cells are arranged in cords and syncytial-like aggregates. Some have a ring-like appearance and resemble fat cells.
Dermal nerve sheath myxoma. The neoplastic Schwann cells express S100.

Dermal nerve sheath myxoma. An ill-defined, unencapsulated and lobulated dermal proliferation. Tumour lobules are separated by fibrovascular stroma and composed of stellate and spindled cells in a myxoid matrix. Individual cells have pale cytoplasm, indistinct borders, and no atypia.

definition: Solitary circumscribed neuroma (SCN) is a benign nodular proliferation of nerve fibres, typically arising as an asymptomatic papule on the face.
clinical:
SCN usually manifests as a small, solitary, asymptomatic, firm, skin-coloured papule. Rare examples of multiple SCNs have been reported in the absence of systemic disease.

---

SCN can occur at any age, most commonly in the fifth to seventh decades of life. There is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

SCN is a benign tumour with slow growth of nerve fibres, unrelated to trauma.
macroscopic: SCN appears as a circumscribed, non-pigmented papule with a firm, pale-grey cut surface.
microscopic: SCN is a dermal-based nodule composed of fascicles of bland spindled cells encased in a delicate, often incomplete, fibrous capsule. Artefactual clefting at the tumour–stroma interface is characteristic. Focal palisading of nuclei within the tumour is usually present but Verocay bodies are less common. Multilobular and plexiform growth patterns are well described. No cytological atypia or conspicuous mitotic activity is seen. Immunohistochemistry Tumoural Schwann cells are strongly and diffusely positive for S100. Tiny axons throughout the tumour can be identified by staining for NFP. The capsular perineural cells stain for EMA, claudin-1, and GLUT1. Differential diagnosis SCN, especially the plexiform subtype, can be mistaken for other benign neural neoplasms, some of which have associations with systemic disease. Neurofibromas are hypocellular tumours with a loose, delicate matrix that are unencapsulated (except in the plexiform subtype). Schwannomas tend to have a more variable cell density (Antoni A and B areas), prominent palisading (Verocay bodies), and hyalinization of vessel walls, and they lack clefting artefact.
prognosis_and_prediction: SCN is a benign tumour with no metastatic potential.
cytology: FNA of SCN shows a nonspecific paucicellular pattern of bland spindle cells.
related_terminology: Acceptable: palisaded encapsulated neuroma.

media.legend: Solitary circumscribed neuroma. A circumscribed dermal tumour is composed of fascicles of bland spindle cells without prominent palisading. Artefactual clefting is a characteristic feature.
Solitary circumscribed neuroma. Schwann cells within the tumour stain diffusely positive for S100.
Solitary circumscribed neuroma. A variable number of axons are distributed throughout the tumour, as highlighted by NFP staining.
Solitary circumscribed neuroma. EMA is expressed by perineural cells in the capsule.
Solitary circumscribed neuroma shows a chicken-wire pattern of staining for CD34.

definition: Dermal hyperneury represents a form of small nerve hypertrophy characterized by unusually large and prominent dermal nerve fibres. Epithelial sheath neuroma has similar histological features, with the added finding of mature squamous epithelium surrounding the perineurium.
clinical:
The lesions are single or multiple and asymptomatic. Rarely, patients may experience itching, intermittent burning, or pain.

---

Mucocutaneous neural proliferations have been described in syndromic patients as young as 5 years old. Most of the patients in the sporadic setting are in their seventh decade of life. There is a slight female preponderance.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. In terms of genetic factors, mucocutaneous neural proliferations have been described in MEN2B, multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A, neurofibromatosis type 2, and Cowden disease. Epithelial sheath neuroma is only sporadic.

---

Not entirely elucidated but may involve PTEN-regulated and RET-regulated signalling pathways, particularly in syndromic cases.
macroscopic: In MEN2B syndrome, enlarged nerve fibres may look like normal skin. When visible, lesions are relatively small, pink or skin-coloured papules and nodules.
microscopic: Increase in nerve fibre–aggregated neural tissue is observed within the dermis or the dermal/subcutaneous interface. Histological changes are identical in syndromic and non-syndromic cases. Nerve fibres are 1.5–4 times as large as normal nerves. Mild neuroma-like internal nerve fibre disorganization can be seen. Lymphoplasmacytic and histiocytic perineurial inflammation or intraneural mucin accumulation may be seen. In epithelial sheath neuroma, enlarged nerve fibres are ensheathed by squamous epithelium. Subcutaneous extension is exceptional. Occasionally, dermal hyperneury presents incidentally to other lesions such as actinic keratosis, basal cell carcinoma, and nodular prurigo.
prognosis_and_prediction: The clinical course is benign.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Multiple lesions in younger patients should prompt investigation for genetic syndromes and pertinent molecular alterations.
related_terminology: Not recommended: multiple cutaneous neuromas.
subtypes: Syndromic dermal hyperneury / epithelial sheath neuroma; sporadic dermal hyperneury / epithelial sheath neuroma

media.legend: Dermal hyperneury. Prominent and enlarged dermal nerve fibres.
Dermal hyperneury. Intraneural mucin accumulation is evident in some cases of dermal hyperneury.
Epithelial sheath neuroma. Enlarged nerve fibres are ensheathed by squamous epithelium.

definition: Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm is a primary dermal neoplasm composed of generally well-differentiated spindled cells closely resembling normal arrector pili smooth muscle but showing nuclear enlargement, hyperchromatism, and mitotic activity.
clinical:
The tumours typically manifest as small (5–30 mm), solitary, and occasionally painful nodules.

---

Cutaneous leiomyosarcomas are rare, with an age-adjusted incidence of roughly 0.2 cases per 100 000 person-years. They most often occur in older men, with a mean patient age of 56 years and an M:F ratio of 3:1 to 4:1.
pathogenesis:
Rare cases have been described in association with Li–Fraumeni syndrome.

---

The genetic events underlying the development of atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm are unknown. Germline FH mutation does not appear to be a predisposing factor.
microscopic: Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasms are typically well differentiated, consisting of fascicles of relatively uniform, eosinophilic spindled cells with perinuclear vacuoles and cigar-shaped nuclei. Compared with normal pilar smooth muscle, these tumours show greater cellularity, nuclear enlargement, and hyperchromatism, and they show mitotic activity. Marked nuclear pleomorphism and necrosis are rare; the presence of such features should raise concern for metastasis from a deeply situated tumour, which may be regarded as cutaneous leiomyosarcoma. Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasms typically grow in an infiltrative fashion into the surrounding dermis, and they may show limited involvement of the subcutaneous fat. Immunohistochemically, these tumours are essentially always positive for SMA and desmin, and almost always positive for caldesmon. Expression of keratins may be seen in as many as 45% of cases.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis of these tumours is excellent, with no metastases documented in the largest series to date (84 cases) for tumours confined to the dermis that are completely excised. Data are limited, but dermal tumours showing subcutaneous involvement may have a low risk of metastasis and recurrence. Grading is not of prognostic value.
related_terminology: Acceptable: cutaneous leiomyosarcoma. Not recommended: pilar leiomyosarcoma.

media.legend: Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm. A dermal-based tumour typically consisting of well-differentiated smooth muscle cells with only moderate atypia.
Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm. As compared with their soft tissue counterparts, these tumours are typically less eosinophilic, resembling normal pilar smooth muscle (right).

Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm. Involvement of subcutaneous fat is the most important adverse prognostic feature in atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm. Tumours with overt infiltration of subcutaneous fat have a metastatic risk and can be labelled cutaneous leiomyosarcoma instead.
Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm. There is moderate nuclear enlargement and hyperchromatism, and easily identified mitotic figures are seen.
Atypical intradermal smooth muscle neoplasm. Caldesmon is the most specific marker of smooth muscle differentiation.

definition: Cutaneous leiomyomas are benign dermal smooth muscle tumours derived from intrinsic dermal arrector pili smooth muscle (pilar leiomyomas) or dartoic/vulvar/areolar smooth muscle (genital leiomyomas).
clinical:
Cutaneous leiomyomas are flesh-coloured to reddish-brown, firm, dome-shaped papules or nodules. Multiple leiomyomas are more often painful and may be distributed in linear, segmental, or zosteriform patterns. Solitary leiomyomas are usually no larger than 20 mm. Genital leiomyomas are usually solitary raised to pedunculated papules or nodules, usually < 20 mm but occasionally larger, and asymptomatic. Vulvar tumours may enlarge during pregnancy.

---

Cutaneous leiomyomas are rare. Cases involving multiple tumours typically have an earlier onset than do solitary leiomyomas. Solitary tumours show a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
Single tumours are sporadic and are not uncommon. Multiple pilar leiomyomas are commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, with variable penetrance. Heterozygous germline loss-of-function mutations in FH, located at 1q43, predisposes individuals to hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome, which manifests as cutaneous and uterine leiomyomas and renal cell carcinoma; this syndrome is very rare.

---

For sporadic tumours, the pathogenesis is unknown. For familial leiomyomas, see the Urinary and male genital tumours volume of this series [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Urinary and male genital tumours. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2022. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 8). https://publications.iarc.who.int/610.]].
microscopic: Pilar leiomyomas are poorly circumscribed dermal nodules of intersecting, well-differentiated smooth muscle bundles composed of spindle cells with elongated, blunt-ended nuclei, perinuclear vacuoles, and eosinophilic cytoplasm. Rare mitotic figures may be seen. Enlarged, hyperchromatic cells similar to those seen in symplastic uterine leiomyomas may be encountered. SMA, desmin, and caldesmon are typically expressed. Demonstration of loss of fumarate hydratase (FH) expression and enhanced expression of 2-succinocysteine (2SC) is useful in identifying possible cases of hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: Pilar leiomyomas are benign. Multiple leiomyomas may be associated with aggressive type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma in hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome, influencing disease management and prognosis.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular testing is not required in sporadic cases. In the familial setting, although FH and 2SC immunohistochemistry identify FH-deficient neoplasms, they do not replace genetic testing, because biallelic FH mutation/inactivation can occur as a purely somatic phenomenon.
related_terminology: Acceptable: piloleiomyoma.

media.legend: Cutaneous leiomyoma. Cutaneous (pilar) leiomyoma, closely resembling non-neoplastic pilar smooth muscle.
Cutaneous leiomyoma. Higher-power view of cutaneous leiomyoma, showing bland spindled cells with cigar-shaped nuclei and somewhat glassy-appearing eosinophilic cytoplasm.
Genital leiomyoma of the scrotum. Also known as dartoic leiomyoma, this is the scrotal counterpart of more common cutaneous lesions.
Genital leiomyoma. Circumscribed growth, low cellularity, and bland nuclear features in a scrotal leiomyoma.

Fumarate hydratase–deficient cutaneous leiomyoma. Fumarate hydratase–deficient leiomyoma occurring in a patient with hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma syndrome. Note the moderate nuclear atypia and perinuclear haloes, characteristic features.
Fumarate hydratase–deficient cutaneous leiomyoma. Complete loss of fumarate hydratase expression in the tumour cells, with retained internal controls.
Fumarate hydratase–deficient cutaneous leiomyoma. Enhanced expression of 2-succinocysteine.

definition: Smooth muscle hamartoma (SMH) represents an anomalous proliferation of haphazardly arranged smooth muscle bundles in the dermis.
clinical:
There is a slightly indurated and pigmented or flesh-coloured plaque, ranging from millimetres to several centimetres in size, with or without perifollicular papules and hypertrichosis. A positive pseudo–Darier sign is present in 80% of congenital SMHs (CSMHs). Most CSMHs are solitary; however, rare multiple, familial, and non-familial cases have been documented. Diffuse CSMH has been described as a component of Michelin tyre baby syndrome, and cases of combined SMH with congenital or blue naevi have also been reported.

---

SMH has a slight male predominance. CSMH is uncommon, affecting approximately 1 in 2600 births. Acquired SMH is extremely rare, with < 20 cases reported to date. Age at presentation ranges from 12 to 64 years.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Abnormal migration and proliferation of arrector pili muscle during fetal development may play a role.

---

A subset of CSMHs result from postzygotic ACTB mutations. These mutations have been previously reported in Becker naevi, suggesting that CSMHs and Becker naevi are biologically related.
microscopic: SMH demonstrates haphazardly arranged, mature smooth muscle bundles in the dermis, often in close proximity to the pilosebaceous units. This is in contrast to pilosebaceous leiomyoma, which demonstrates more orderly smooth muscle bundles arranged in ramifying fascicles. Atypia/pleomorphism and mitoses are absent. Focal retraction artefact may be observed around the smooth muscle bundles. Expression of smooth muscle markers is seen. Overlying epidermal hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and basal hyperpigmentation, reminiscent of Becker naevus, may be encountered.
prognosis_and_prediction: SMH is benign. Treatment may not be necessary, and excision is typically curative. Rare cases of recurrence/persistence following incomplete excision have been reported.
related_terminology: None
subtypes: Congenital smooth muscle hamartoma; acquired smooth muscle hamartoma

media.legend: Smooth muscle hamartoma. A large congenital pinkish plaque on the trunk, with long, thin, light hair emanating from its surface.
Smooth muscle hamartoma. The lesion occupies the full depth of the reticular dermis and, focally, the superficial subcutis. The overlying epidermis is normal.

Smooth muscle hamartoma. The lesion occupies the full depth of the reticular dermis and, focally, the superficial subcutis. The overlying epidermis is normal. There are small and horizontally arranged smooth muscle bundles, surrounded by focal retraction artefact.
Smooth muscle hamartoma. There is focal retraction artefact around the smooth muscle bundles.
Smooth muscle hamartoma. Positive immunohistochemistry with an antibody to SMA.
Smooth muscle hamartoma. Smooth muscle bundles are haphazardly arranged, scattered throughout the dermis and superficial subcutis. The overlying epidermis is acanthotic.
Smooth muscle hamartoma. Strongly positive staining of the smooth muscle bundles with an antibody to calponin.
Smooth muscle hamartoma. Smooth muscle bundles are haphazardly arranged, scattered throughout the dermis and superficial subcutis. The overlying epidermis is acanthotic.

definition: Angioleiomyoma is a benign mesenchymal tumour that typically arises in the dermis or subcutis. Tumours are composed of thick-walled vessels surrounded by well-differentiated perivascular bundles of smooth muscle. It is a member of the perivascular myoid family of tumours and is on a morphological continuum with myopericytoma.
clinical:
The lesions are solitary, small, firm, circumscribed, and slow-growing nodules. Approximately half of angioleiomyomas are painful.

---

Angioleiomyomas affect a wide age range, with peak incidence in the fourth through sixth decades of life. The solid subtype is significantly more common in women, whereas the venous and cavernous subtypes demonstrate a slight male predominance. The overall M:F ratio is 0.7:1.
pathogenesis:
A definitive etiology has not been established. Minor trauma and venous stasis have been proposed as potential causal factors in a subset of lesions.

---

Angioleiomyomas are thought to arise from vascular smooth muscle. Reported cytogenetic abnormalities include monosomy of chromosome 13 and loss of 6p, 21q, and 13q. A very small subset of angioleiomyomas reportedly have NOTCH gene fusions. In contradistinction to myofibromas, angioleiomyomas do not have recurrent somatic PDGFRB mutations.
macroscopic: Angioleiomyomas are solitary, circumscribed, and relatively small (< 30 mm in diameter). Tumours may be seen emanating from an attached blood vessel wall.
microscopic: All angioleiomyomas are composed of bundles of bland, well-differentiated smooth muscle surrounding blood vessels of varying calibre. Mitotic activity is inconspicuous. Three subtypes of angioleiomyoma have been described based on predominant vascular morphology: solid, venous, and cavernous. The solid subtype is composed of compact bundles of smooth muscle surrounding compressed, slit-like vessels. Venous-subtype tumours are made up of thick-walled vessels, with smooth muscle from blood vessel walls blending with intervascular smooth muscle bundles. Cavernous-subtype lesions are composed of dilated vascular channels, with a proliferation of smooth muscle within intervascular spaces. Hybrid lesions have been described. Some tumours share features with myopericytoma, with concentric whorling of less spindled to ovoid myoid cells around vessels. Minor histological patterns include those with adipocytic metaplasia, prominent hyalinization, degenerative atypia, or calcification. Immunohistochemistry Tumour cells are diffusely positive for actins (including SMA), calponin, and h-caldesmon. Desmin expression is variable and may be very focal or completely absent in a small subset of tumours. Melanocytic markers such as HMB45 and melan-A are negative in tumours with adipocytic metaplasia, thus enabling distinction from angiomyolipoma. Similarly to glomus tumours and myopericytomas, angioleiomyomas demonstrate diffuse immunoreactivity for the pericytic antigen RGS5.
prognosis_and_prediction: Angioleiomyoma is a benign tumour that rarely recurs after surgical excision.
related_terminology: Not recommended: angiomyoma; vascular leiomyoma.
subtypes: Solid angioleiomyoma; venous angioleiomyoma; cavernous angioleiomyoma

media.legend: Angioleiomyoma, solid subtype. Well-circumscribed lesion composed of compressed blood vessels surrounded by concentric bundles of smooth muscle.
Angioleiomyoma, venous subtype. Multiple blood vessels surrounded by concentric bland smooth muscle cells that blend with surrounding intervascular smooth muscle.
Angioleiomyoma, venous subtype. Tumour cells are diffusely positive for SMA.
Angioleiomyoma, cavernous subtype. Dilated vascular channels with attenuated walls composed of smooth muscle cells.

Angioleiomyoma. Well-circumscribed dermal nodule, corresponding to a mature smooth muscle cell proliferation associated with variably sized and compressed blood vessels with a perivascular concentric arrangement. No cytological atypia or mitosis.

definition: Myofibroma and myofibromatosis are benign mesenchymal neoplasms of presumed myofibroblastic histogenetic origin/phenotype.
clinical:
Myofibroma occurs in three clinicopathological settings: solitary, multicentric, and generalized. The solitary form of the disease has a male predilection, whereas the multicentric form predominantly affects females. Clinically, patients with myofibroma usually present with a well-circumscribed but unencapsulated violaceous superficial dermal or subcutaneous nodule measuring a few millimetres to several centimetres in maximum diameter, with a firm consistency.

---

Myofibroma represents 12% of paediatric soft tissue lesions. The age range is wide, spanning from the neonatal period (including congenital lesions) to 70 years; however, 90% of cases are paediatric, and 65% occur by the age of 2 years. Multicentric lesions are exclusively paediatric.
pathogenesis:
Germline PDGFRB mutations predispose to myofibromatosis in affected families.

---

Although of presumptive myofibroblastic origin, myofibroma shares with other perivascular myoid cell neoplasms features of modified myopericytes. The presence of vascular balls and myointimal proliferations argues for an analogy to other perivascular myoid cell neoplasms and may explain the morphological overlap between these lesions. Germline mutations in PDGFRB (89%) and NOTCH3 (11%) have been detected in the familial disease. Sporadic solitary lesions have frequent somatic PDGFRB mutations. PDGFRB mutation types differ between familial and non-familial (sporadic) myofibromatosis cases. SRF rearrangements have been documented in tumours with high cellularity.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with small, firm, cutaneous or subcutaneous nodules with irregular margins.
microscopic: Myofibroma is characterized by a biphasic growth, with alternating bundles of primitive, darker-staining, small rounded cells and plump spindled mesenchymal cells. These are associated with numerous thin-walled haemangiopericytoma-like vessels and mature eosinophilic plump spindled myoid cells with frequent myointimal-like nodular proliferations (vascular balls). Foci of calcification may be present. Mitotic activity is usually low but may be increased. Foci of ischaemic-type coagulation necrosis can be seen. The neoplastic cells stain diffusely for α-SMA, but h-caldesmon is absent or only focally positive. Myofibroma is usually desmin-negative.
prognosis_and_prediction: Myofibroma is benign and does not recur after excision. The generalized form, however, is frequently fatal due to extensive visceral involvement and limited options for surgical intervention. Atypical histological features (significant cellularity, inconspicuous or absent myoid nodules, infiltrating borders, intravascular growth, perineural invasion, entrapment of nerves, and increased mitotic rate) do not affect prognosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: infantile myofibroma; infantile myofibromatosis; adult myofibroma.
subtypes: Myofibroma; multicentric myofibromatosis; generalized myofibromatosis (with visceral involvement)

media.legend: Myofibroma. A cellular myofibroma showing moderate to high cellularity (upper left) blending with hyalinized foci (lower right) within vascularized stroma containing thin-walled vessels.
Myofibroma. An example showing almost exclusively myxohyaline myointimal vascular balls, with little intervening cellular primitive myoid stroma.
Myofibroma. Transition from vascular balls (midfield) to more cellular primitive myoid stroma (right).
Myofibroma. An example with prominent vascular balls (upper field) abutting cellular primitive myoid stroma with pericytoma-like vessels (lower field).

definition: Myopericytoma is a benign neoplasm with perivascular myoid cell differentiation.
clinical:
Most arise as solitary painless dermal or subcutaneous nodules. The tumour may occur over a wide age range, from childhood to old age. Multifocal lesions affecting the same or different anatomical sites are uncommon. Rare intravascular lesions may be painful.

---

No epidemiological data are available.
pathogenesis:
There are no known etiological or predisposing factors. Rare myopericytoma-like lesions originating at unusual visceral or intracranial sites have been documented in association with EBV infection in patients with AIDS.

---

Myopericytoma probably differentiates towards myopericytes, intermediate cells between pericytes of Zimmermann and true smooth muscle cells. Neointimal (myointimal) cells may contribute to tumorigenesis. A subset of myopericytomas (15%) harbour BRAF mutations, but available data are still limited. Pericytoma-like neoplasms with recently identified gene fusions such as ACTB::GLI and SRF::RELA are probably unrelated to myopericytoma. The few cases examined for PDGFRB mutations showed contradictory data.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with well-circumscribed superficial nodules with a firm consistency, usually measuring < 20 mm.
microscopic: Myopericytoma is a well-circumscribed but unencapsulated nodule of cytologically bland, oval to spindled cells with concentric multilayered perivascular growth. The cytoplasm is eosinophilic, with myoid features. The nuclei are round to ovoid. The cellularity varies greatly, as does the vasculature. The presence of thin-walled communicating vessels may mimic solitary fibrous tumour, while lesions with thicker vessels result in an appearance reminiscent of angioleiomyoma. Cellular solid patterns are similar to myofibroma. Rare subtypes include diffuse plexiform growth (myopericytomatosis), intramural growth (within vascular walls), and intravascular myopericytoma. Uncommon features include hyalinization, metaplastic bone, ischaemic necrosis, and degenerative atypia. Myopericytoma usually stains for α-SMA and h-caldesmon, and occasionally for MSA, but desmin immunoreactivity is usually absent or focal. Myopericytoma was considered to form a spectrum with myofibroma, angioleiomyoma, and glomus tumour, but recent studies suggest these are rather distinct at the molecular level, albeit having significantly overlapping morphological and phenotypic features. The differential diagnosis includes myofibroma, angioleiomyoma, and solitary fibrous tumour.
prognosis_and_prediction: Myopericytoma is benign and non-recurring, even after marginal excision.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Myopericytoma. Presentation as a small, well-circumscribed subcutaneous nodule.
Myopericytoma. Uniform ovoid cells with concentric (onion skin–like) perivascular growth.
Myopericytoma. Some cases show an admixture of haemangiopericytoma-like and onion skin–like vasculature.
Myopericytoma. High-power view of onion skin–like growth around a vessel.
Myopericytoma. A concentric, perivascular growth of plump, spindled, myoid tumour cells without atypia.

definition: Glomus tumours are mesenchymal neoplasms composed of cells resembling the modified smooth muscle cells of the normal glomus body.
clinical:
Most cutaneous glomus tumours come to clinical attention as solitary, small (< 10 mm), painful nodules or plaques, with a pink to blue hue. Glomuvenous malformations are often multiple or familial.

---

Most glomus tumours occur in the skin. Digital and subungual lesions account for 1–4% of benign hand tumours and have a slight female predominance. Glomus tumours are most common in the fourth to sixth decades of life; paediatric tumours are very rare.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Multiple familial cutaneous glomus tumours appear to have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and are caused by inactivating loss-of-function mutations in GLMN (1p22.1), which encodes the protein glomulin. Rare glomus tumours are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. Sporadic glomus tumours often show rearrangements involving MIR143 and NOTCH genes. BRAF p.V600E mutations have been reported in small numbers of histologically malignant tumours.
macroscopic: Patients typically present with a firm nodule with a greyish-white, greyish-red, or brown cut surface.
microscopic: Glomus cells are small, uniform, and round, with a central round nucleus, amphophilic to lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a sharp cellular outline with peripheral basal lamina. Oncocytic, epithelioid, myxoid, and hyalinized patterns are recognized. Solid glomus tumours, which account for approximately 75% of all cases, are composed of nests of glomus cells surrounding capillary-sized vessels. Small cuffs of glomus cells are often seen around small vessels located outside the main mass. Glomuvenous malformations, which account for 20% of cases, feature dilated vascular channels with intervening small clusters of glomus cells. Glomus tumours may also contain spindled cells resembling smooth muscle (glomangiomyoma) or a branching, haemangiopericytoma-like vasculature (glomangiopericytoma). Glomangiomatosis is an extremely rare pattern of glomus tumour with an overall architectural resemblance to diffuse angiomatosis, but containing nests of glomus cells within vessel walls. Symplastic tumours show striking nuclear atypia in the absence of other worrisome features. Histologically and/or clinically malignant glomus tumours are extremely rare. The diagnosis of malignant glomus tumour should be reserved only for tumours showing marked nuclear atypia (with any level of mitotic activity) and/or atypical mitotic figures. A component of pre-existing benign-looking glomus tumour is often present. Malignant glomus tumours may retain an overall architectural resemblance to normal glomus tumour (but with malignant-looking round cells), or they may consist of a spindled component resembling leiomyosarcoma or fibrosarcoma. In the absence of a clear-cut benign precursor, immunohistochemical demonstration of SMA and pericellular collagen IV is required for diagnosis of round cell forms of malignant glomus tumour, in the absence of a clear-cut benign precursor. Glomus tumours that show atypical features but lack severe nuclear atypia or atypical mitotic activity should instead be classified as glomus tumours of uncertain malignant potential. Glomus tumours of all types typically express SMA, h-caldesmon, and pericellular collagen IV.
prognosis_and_prediction: Typical glomus tumours, glomuvenous malformations, and symplastic glomus tumours are benign. Malignant glomus tumours are aggressive, with metastases and death from disease in as many as 40% of patients. Some large, visceral glomus tumours without other atypical features (uncertain malignant potential) have behaved aggressively. The natural history of histologically malignant glomus tumours in the skin may be favourable, although more data are needed.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Demonstration of MIR143::NOTCH1, MIR143::NOTCH2, or MIR143::NOTCH3 fusions may be helpful in selected cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: glomangioma; glomangiosarcoma.
subtypes: Glomuvenous malformation (glomangiomyoma); glomus tumour of uncertain malignant potential; malignant glomus tumour

media.legend: Glomuvenous malformation. The defining feature of glomuvenous malformation is the presence of increased numbers of benign-appearing glomus cells within the walls of the vascular malformation.
Glomuvenous malformation. Higher-power view of glomus cells within vascular smooth muscle.
Symplastic glomus tumour. Degenerative-appearing nuclear atypia without mitotic activity characterizes symplastic glomus tumour.
Malignant glomus tumour. High nuclear grade and easily identified mitotic activity in malignant glomus tumour.
Malignant glomus tumour. Spindle cell morphology is relatively common in malignant glomus tumour. The cells tend to be somewhat smaller and less distinctly eosinophilic than those of leiomyosarcoma.

Glomus tumour of uncertain malignant potential. This tumour showed clear demarcation between a typical, benign-appearing component (right) and an atypical component (left). The latter showed moderate nuclear pleomorphism and scattered multinucleated cells, but without mitotic activity.

Glomus tumour (typical). The circumscribed edge of this glomus tumour is intimately associated with a rim of small-calibre nerves. The bulk of the lesion is formed by sheets of round glomus cells arranged around scattered small vessels.
Glomus tumour (typical). The typical appearance of glomus cells is seen here, with the cells having a central round nucleus, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a well-defined cytoplasmic membrane.

Glomus tumour of uncertain malignant potential. Coexisting typical and atypical components are present, the latter with moderate nuclear grade but insufficient mitotic activity for a diagnosis of malignant.
Typical glomus tumour. Glomus cells show uniform strong immunostaining for SMA.
Glomangioma. Tumour composed of dilated vascular spaces lined by several layers of glomus cells.

definition: Composite haemangioendothelioma (CHE) is a locally aggressive, rarely metastasizing endothelial neoplasm composed of an admixture of components, each resembling other vascular lesions. Neuroendocrine marker expression may be present.
clinical:
The lesions are longstanding (up to several decades) reddish-blue nodules or plaques. Some patients have a history of lymphoedema.

---

CHE affects young adults, with a female predominance; infants and children are rarely affected.
pathogenesis:
Rarely, CHEs have arisen in the setting of chronic lymphoedema or radiotherapy.

---

CHEs display endothelial differentiation. A subset of tumours (27% in one study) harbour YAP1::MAML2 gene fusions. PTBP1::MAML2 and EPC1::PCH2 gene fusions have been identified in 3 cases and 1 case of neuroendocrine CHE, respectively.
macroscopic: CHE presents as an infiltrative, uninodular or multinodular mass (individual nodules measure 4–300 mm; median size: 32 mm) or as an area of poorly defined swelling. Some of the lesions are associated with reddish-purple skin discolouration, suggestive of a vascular neoplasm.
microscopic: There is a complex and variable admixture of histological patterns, including retiform, spindle cell, epithelioid, lymphangioma, haemangioma, and even well-differentiated angiosarcoma–like components. They most often consist of areas identical to retiform haemangioendothelioma, juxtaposed to foci somewhat resembling epithelioid haemangioendothelioma. Neuroendocrine CHE is characterized by a distinctive admixture of retiform haemangioendothelioma–like areas, epithelioid haemangioendothelioma–like areas, and a component with a striking nested appearance, as well as by expression of neuroendocrine markers (typically synaptophysin). Immunohistochemistry The endothelial markers CD31, CD34, FLI1, and ERG are positive. CHE with YAP1::MAML2 fusions show loss of expression of YAP1 C-terminus. Neuroendocrine CHE is consistently positive for synaptophysin but usually negative for chromogranin. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes retiform haemangioendothelioma, epithelioid haemangioendothelioma, and angiosarcoma. CHEs showing foci resembling high-grade angiosarcoma are extremely rare, and this diagnosis should be made only after conventional angiosarcoma is rigorously excluded on clinical and morphological grounds.
prognosis_and_prediction: The behaviour of CHE in general appears to be much less aggressive than that of conventional angiosarcoma. Multiple local recurrences over a protracted course are common. Several lesions recurred locally between 4 months and 10 years after excision of the primary mass, often with multiple recurrences. There is potential for lymph node metastasis, although it is rare. Neuroendocrine CHE appears to be considerably more aggressive, with distant metastases to bone, lung, liver, or brain reported in half of the patients.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Composite haemangioendothelioma. An example from the arm of a young woman. The most superficial portions of this tumour consisted of infiltrating vascular channels lined by hobnail endothelial cells, reminiscent of retiform haemangioendothelioma.
Composite haemangioendothelioma. Higher-power view of a retiform focus in a composite haemangioendothelioma.

Composite haemangioendothelioma. Sheets of vacuolated, epithelioid endothelial cells, reminiscent of epithelioid haemangioendothelioma, admixed with vascular channels lined by hobnail endothelial cells.
Composite haemangioendothelioma. D2-40 (podoplanin) expression in dermal composite haemangioendothelioma.

Composite haemangioendothelioma with neuroendocrine marker expression. A dermal-based tumour occurring in a middle-aged woman, with superficial vascular channels resembling retiform haemangioendothelioma, as well as deeper collections of nested, epithelioid endothelial cells.
Composite haemangioendothelioma with neuroendocrine marker expression. Retiform and dilated, haemangioma-like vascular channels.
Composite haemangioendothelioma with neuroendocrine marker expression. Epithelioid endothelial cells adjacent to slit-like vascular channels lined by hobnailed cells.
Composite haemangioendothelioma with neuroendocrine marker expression. Synaptophysin expression in neuroendocrine composite haemangioendothelioma.
Composite haemangioendothelioma. Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma–like area composed of sheets of epithelioid cells with occasionally prominent cytoplasmic vacuolization.
Composite haemangioendothelioma. Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma–like component composed of cords and nests of epithelioid cells in a hyalinized stroma.

Neuroendocrine composite haemangioendothelioma. Retiform haemangioendothelioma–like area from a neuroendocrine composite haemangioendothelioma composed of anastomosing vessels lined by hobnailing endothelium with an appearance reminiscent of rete testis.

definition: Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma (PILA) and retiform haemangioendothelioma (RHE) are uncommon, rarely metastasizing vascular neoplasms composed at least in part of hobnail endothelial proliferations with a lymphatic endothelial phenotype.
clinical:
PILA manifests as a slow-growing asymptomatic cutaneous induration, plaque, or nodule. RHE manifests as a red/bluish slow-growing plaque or nodule, usually < 30 mm.

---

All are rare, with < 50 reported cases of PILA and RHE. PILA typically occurs in infants, with a slight female predominance (M:F ratio: ~0.7:1). RHE usually affects young adults or children, without a sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is mostly unknown. Exceptional RHE cases occur in the setting of radiotherapy, lymphoedema, or cystic lymphangioma.

---

PILA pathogenesis is unknown. Subsets of RHE demonstrate YAP1 rearrangements, most often YAP1::MAML2 fusions.
macroscopic: PILAs are poorly defined and usually involve the dermis and/or subcutaneous tissue. Greyish-white to pink streaks or cystic change in otherwise normal skin may be present. Tumour size ranges from 10 to > 400 mm (mean size: 70 mm). RHEs present as a diffuse, sometimes discoloured induration of the dermis, with frequent subcutis involvement.
microscopic: Cytologically, PILA and RHE are identical, being composed of darkly staining columnar or hobnail endothelial cells. PILA appears as a poorly delineated proliferation of slit-like or dilated lymphatic channels, sometimes with an associated cavernous lymphatic malformation, whereas RHE is typified by an infiltrative growth of elongated, branching vascular channels, resembling the rete testis. Associated hyaline fibrosis is often present. Both PILA and RHE may contain intraluminal papillary tufts with a fibrotic core, lined by hobnailed endothelial cells, which are more prominent in PILA. A lymphocytic infiltrate is often present in both. Immunohistochemistry The hobnail endothelial cells of PILA and RHE express pan-endothelial markers (e.g. CD31, ERG, FLI1; less often CD34) and lymphatic endothelial markers (e.g. podoplanin, VEGFR3, and PROX1. Loss of expression of YAP1 C-terminus is seen in the tumours with YAP1 rearrangements. Limited synaptophysin expression may also be seen in PILA and RHE, a finding which in combination with shared YAP1::MAML2 fusions supports a relationship between these hobnailed haemangioendotheliomas and composite haemangioendothelioma.
prognosis_and_prediction: PILA and RHE frequently recur (as many as 60% of cases), but there is only a very low risk of lymph node or distant metastasis. Most patients have an excellent prognosis after complete excision; mortality is extremely rare.
related_terminology: Acceptable: hobnail haemangioendothelioma (for RHE). Not recommended: Dabska tumour; endovascular papillary angioendothelioma.

media.legend: Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma often contains a prominent cavernous lymphatic malformation-like component. Note the deeper irregular vascular spaces.

Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma. Intraluminal papillary tufts with a fibrotic core are a characteristic feature, lined with cells with hyperchromatic, hobnail nuclei. Note the prominent stromal lymphocytes.
Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma. The endothelial cells lining the dissecting channels contain hyperchromatic, hobnail nuclei.
Retiform haemangioendothelioma. An example occurring on the foot of a 26-year-old man. Note the elongated, branching vascular channels, reminiscent of rete testis.

Retiform haemangioendothelioma. Elongated vascular channels, lined by darkly staining, hobnail endothelial cells. Perivascular fibrosis and lymphoid aggregates, both common features in retiform haemangioendothelioma, are also present.
Retiform haemangioendothelioma. Intravascular papillary tufts are often present in retiform haemangioendothelioma, as well as in papillary intravascular angioendothelioma.

definition: Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma (EHE) is a malignant endothelial neoplasm composed of epithelioid cells within a myxohyaline stroma; almost all have a WWTR1::CAMTA1 fusion. A distinctive subtype composed of epithelioid cells with abundant cytoplasm and solid, nested, and/or vasoformative growth has a YAP1::TFE3 fusion.
clinical:
Most are nondescript nodules, sometimes with a thickened epidermis or ulceration.

---

EHE most often arises in middle-aged adults, with a slight female predominance.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

More than 90% of EHEs have t(1;3) with WWTR1::CAMTA1 fusion; a rare subtype has a YAP1::TFE3 fusion.
microscopic: EHE is composed of relatively bland epithelioid cells, often with intracytoplasmic vacuoles, arranged in cords and nests, embedded in a variably myxohyaline stroma. Vasoformative architecture is not seen in conventional EHE. The EHE subtype with YAP1::TFE3 fusion has tumour cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, arranged in a solid or nested growth pattern, often forming vascular spaces. Immunohistochemically, EHE is positive for CD31, FLI1, ERG, and (less often) CD34. Low-molecular-weight cytokeratins are expressed in 20–30% of cases. EHE with WWTR1::CAMTA1 shows diffuse strong nuclear expression of CAMTA1. Tumours with YAP1::TFE3 fusion show diffuse nuclear TFE3 expression; however, staining for TFE3 can also be seen in tumours with WWTR1::CAMTA1 fusion. Loss of expression of the C-terminus of YAP1 is more specific for YAP1::TFE3 fusions.
prognosis_and_prediction: Approximately 20% of EHEs of soft tissues metastasize and pursue an aggressive clinical course. Cutaneous EHE has an excellent prognosis. The clinical behaviour of cutaneous EHE with YAP1::TFE3 is unknown but may be less aggressive.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Identification of WWTR1::CAMTA1 and YAP1::TFE3 gene fusions is useful for subtyping.
related_terminology: None
subtypes: Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma with WWTR1::CAMTA1 fusion; epithelioid haemangioendothelioma with YAP1::TFE3 fusion

media.legend: Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma. Cutaneous epithelioid haemangioendothelioma with overlying epidermal hyperplasia.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma. The tumour is composed of cords of epithelioid cells with pale cytoplasm, infiltrating the dermis.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma. Glassy eosinophilic cytoplasm is a characteristic feature. Note the intracytoplasmic vacuoles.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma. CD31 expression confirms endothelial differentiation.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma. Nuclear CAMTA1 reflects the underlying WWTR1::CAMTA1 fusion of conventional epithelioid haemangioendothelioma.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma subtype with YAP1::TFE3. Cutaneous examples of this subtype are extremely rare. The vascular nature of the tumour can be appreciated.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma subtype with YAP1::TFE3. A nested architecture is characteristic. Note the abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma subtype with YAP1::TFE3. Most examples show focal vasoformative architecture.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma subtype with YAP1::TFE3. Strong nuclear TFE3 expression is typical of this subtype.
Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma subtype with YAP1::TFE3. Loss of expression of the C-terminus of YAP1 is highly specific for YAP1::TFE3 fusion.

definition: Pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma is a rarely metastasizing endothelial neoplasm that often presents as multiple nodules in different tissue planes and histologically mimics a myoid tumour or epithelioid sarcoma.
clinical:
Patients present with painless or painful nodules; ulceration may be present. In about 60% of cases the disease is multifocal, involving multiple tissue planes, most commonly the skin and subcutis, but it may also involve skeletal muscle and bone.

---

Young men (mean age: 30 years) are most commonly affected (M:F ratio: 3.5:1).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma has rearrangements of FOSB, including SERPINE1::FOSB, ACTB::FOSB, WWTR1::FOSB, CLTC::FOSB, and EGFL7::FOSB. This results in upregulation, with FOSB acting as an active transcription factor capable of its own regulation. Tumours with ACTB::FOSB fusions are more likely to be solitary. Tumours with EGFL7::FOSB may be more aggressive.
macroscopic: Grossly, the tumour is poorly defined, with a grey to white firm cut surface. Most are < 30 mm in size.
microscopic: Pseudomyogenic haemangioendotheliomas are variably composed of infiltrative sheets and fascicles of spindled (most commonly) to epithelioid cells with dense, eosinophilic cytoplasm. Atypia is usually mild, and tumour nuclei are vesicular with small nucleoli. Significant nuclear atypia may be seen in about 10% of cases. Admixed neutrophils are seen in approximately 50%. By immunohistochemistry, they are positive for keratins (most often with AE1/AE3 clones, less often MNF116), FLI1, ERG, and FOSB, but negative for CD34. About 50% are positive for CD31, and focal expression of SMAs is seen in as many as one third of cases. SMARCB1 expression is retained.
prognosis_and_prediction: Local recurrence or development of new nodules in the same region is frequent (~60%). Lymph node and distant metastases are uncommon (< 5%). Histopathological features are not predictive.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Detection of FOSB rearrangement may be helpful.
related_terminology: Acceptable: epithelioid sarcoma–like haemangioendothelioma.

Pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma. A tumour composed of sheets and fascicles of atypical spindled cells.

Pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma. In this tumour, there were sheets of atypical epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.

Pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma. A patient presenting with multiple lesions on the leg.
Pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma. The tumour is composed of spindled to epithelioid cells with dense, eosinophilic cytoplasm. Note the admixed neutrophils that may be seen in about 50% of cases.

Pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma. Nuclear immunoreactivity for FOSB can help confirm the diagnosis. Cytoplasmic immunoreactivity for FOSB is also typically present in pseudomyogenic haemangioendothelioma.

definition: Postradiation atypical vascular lesion (AVL) is a benign vascular proliferation arising in irradiated skin, with histopathological features mimicking angiosarcoma.
clinical:
Patients typically present with papules, small vesicles, or erythematous ecchymotic plaques with prominent telangiectasia.

---

Most patients are elderly women. The latency period varies, but it is usually 2–3 years after radiotherapy.
pathogenesis:
Radiotherapy causes AVL. Total radiation doses range from 37.5 to 60 Gy (mean total radiation dose: 50 Gy).

---

AVL is caused by radiation-induced endothelial cell proliferation, the mechanism for which is uncertain. Mutation analysis has demonstrated that AVLs show a low number of HRAS and TERT mutations, whereas postradiotherapy angiosarcomas show a high frequency of EGFR, TP53, HRAS, and TERT mutations. MYC and FLT4 gene amplifications are not found in AVL.
macroscopic: Postradiation AVLs appear as small papules or vesicles.
microscopic: AVL involves the upper and mid dermis and, rarely, the deep dermis. However, in contrast to radiation-induced angiosarcoma, the subcutis is spared. At scanning magnification, an inverted V-shaped architecture is the most common pattern. Less commonly, lesions are poorly defined, lacking the V-shaped pattern and involving only the mid dermis. The proliferation is composed of irregular, branching, anastomosing, thin-walled, empty lymphatic-like vascular channels lined by a single discontinuous layer of endothelial cells with little or no cytological atypia and often displaying hobnail morphology. In places, the vascular channels are back-to-back. Small intravascular papillae are frequently seen. Two histopathological patterns of AVL have been described: the lymphatic type (described above) and the very rare vascular type. In the vascular type, there is proliferation of small capillaries usually lacking a lobular arrangement. Endothelial cells are positive for ERG, CD34, and CD31. They are also positive for podoplanin (D2-40), PROX1, and LYVE1, which gives support to a lymphatic lineage. The Ki-67 proliferation index is low. In lesions of vascular type, endothelial cells express CD31 and CD34, but not lymphatic markers. KSHV/HHV8 is negative. AVL can coexist or progress to radiation-induced angiosarcoma, and superficially sampled radiation-induced angiosarcomas can be indistinguishable from AVLs (see below). Radiation-induced angiosarcoma shows endothelial MYC expression and a high Ki-67 proliferation index (> 10%), whereas AVLs are MYC-negative and show no substantial proliferation. Differential diagnosis The main differential diagnosis is with radiation-induced angiosarcoma. In the latter there is cytological atypia, multilayering, mitotic activity; tumour cells are positive for MYC, and FISH shows MYC amplification. Furthermore, strong cytoplasmic VEGFR3 (FLT4) staining and FLT4 gene amplification by FISH is more frequent in radiation-induced angiosarcoma that in AVL. Hobnail haemangioma can be identical to AVL but the clinical presentation is different and the former is usually associated with prominent haemosiderin deposition. Other differential diagnoses include lymphatic malformations, benign lymphangioendothelioma, and Kaposi sarcoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: AVLs are benign. However, cases with coexistence or progression to angiosarcoma have been reported. Rarely, spontaneous regression has been described.
related_terminology: Not recommended: post–radiation therapy lymphangiectasia; benign lymphangiomatous papule; post–radiation therapy lymphangioma; benign vascular lesion in previously irradiated skin.

media.legend: Atypical vascular lesion. Scanning magnification showing dilated vascular structures in the dermis.
Atypical vascular lesion. Higher magnification showing dilated vascular structures lined by atypical endothelial cells.

definition: Cutaneous epithelioid angiomatous nodule is a distinctive benign cutaneous vascular proliferation with prominent epithelioid cell morphology.
clinical:
The lesions appear as solitary papules and nodules with erythematous to bluish discolouration, measuring < 15 mm (median: 5 mm). Rarely, the tumours are multiple. An eruptive presentation has also been reported.

---

The age of presentation has a wide range, with peak incidence in young to middle-aged adults (median age: 37 years). There is no strong sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

The tumours are endothelial cell neoplasms.
microscopic: The tumours occur as well-circumscribed nodules in the superficial to mid dermis. They are composed of solid sheets of large polygonal epithelioid cells with abundant cytoplasm containing vesicular nuclei with small eosinophilic nucleoli. Intracytoplasmic vacuoles are frequently observed. Mitotic figures are seen, but atypical mitoses and nuclear pleomorphism are absent. Intralesional vascular channels are a focal feature. The tumours show haemosiderin deposition; an inflammatory cell infiltrate composed of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils; and variable perilesional fibrosis. The overlying epidermis may be acanthotic with collarette formation. Rarely, there is involvement of deep dermis and superficial subcutis. Immunohistochemically, the tumour cells express endothelial cell markers (CD31, CD34, and factor VIII), and intralesional SMA-positive pericytes are present. Immunohistochemistry for FOSB is negative. Differential diagnosis Differentiation from epithelioid angiosarcoma is important because of its aggressive behaviour, and both tumours can occur in a similar clinical context. Epithelioid angiosarcoma is larger and involves deeper structures, with infiltrative margins; it is characterized by nuclear pleomorphism with numerous and atypical mitotic figures. Tumour necrosis may also be present. Epithelioid haemangioendothelioma is characterized by epithelioid endothelial cells arranged in cords and strands in a chondromyxoid stroma rather than the solid sheet-like growth seen in epithelioid angiomatous nodule. Epithelioid haemangioma is multinodular and shows more vasoformative elements lined by epithelioid endothelial cells in a fibrous stroma; there is also a variably prominent inflammatory cell infiltrate with eosinophils and lymphoid follicles.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cutaneous epithelioid angiomatous nodule is entirely benign, and no adverse outcome has been documented in the literature.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Cutaneous epithelioid angiomatous nodule. The tumour is nodular and well circumscribed; it is based within the dermis, with surrounding haemosiderin deposition.

Cutaneous epithelioid angiomatous nodule. Epithelioid endothelial cells are arranged in sheets. They have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and contain vesicular nuclei with small eosinophilic nucleoli; intracytoplasmic lumina are focally present. A mitotic figure is visible in the upper-right corner; also note the presence of well-formed intralesional vascular channels.
Cutaneous epithelioid angiomatous nodule. CD31 immunohistochemistry highlights endothelial cells.
Cutaneous epithelioid angiomatous nodule. SMA immunohistochemistry demonstrates pericytes surrounding the endothelial cells.

Cutaneous epithelioid angiomatous nodule. The lesion consists of a well-circumscribed nodule in upper to mid dermis composed of solid sheets of epithelioid endothelial cells. Intracytoplasmic vacuoles are frequent. The overlying epidermis shows acanthosis. A mild to moderate inflammatory infiltrate is observed, comprising lymphocytes and eosinophils.

definition: Arteriovenous malformation (AVM) is a congenital vascular anomaly characterized by abnormal arteriovenous connections and high-flow arteriovenous shunting.
clinical:
AVMs involving skin and deep soft tissue are characterized by a poorly defined bluish or red mass that may be pulsatile, with variably severe arteriovenous shunting, sometimes leading to local tissue necrosis, haemorrhage, or high-output heart failure. The superficial subtype is typically a small red or blue papule. Deep-seated and cutaneous clinical subtypes have been described.

---

AVMs have no sex predilection. They are congenital but may not become clinically evident until later in life. Most are solitary and sporadic.
pathogenesis:
Most cases are sporadic. Inherited lesions occurring as part of the rare capillary malformation–AVM syndrome are associated with germline RASA1 mutations, which are probably causative.

---

Unknown
microscopic: The lesions are histologically heterogeneous but primarily show beds of arterioles, capillaries, and venules set within a fibromyxomatous background, intermixed with larger-calibre arteries and thick-walled veins. In lesions with high-grade shunting, the arteries are tortuous, with fragmented mural elastic laminae, and the veins show irregular intima and/or mural fibrosis, reflective of elevated venous pressure and turbulence. The overlying skin often contains a small-vessel proliferation similar to that seen in ischaemia and stasis. Superficial scalp AVMs, which are limited in depth by cranial bone, are histologically similar. Differential diagnosis Diagnosis typically requires careful clinicopathological correlation and radiological studies, particularly in small samples. Focal cellular small-vessel proliferations in AVM can mimic infantile haemangioma but are GLUT1-negative.
prognosis_and_prediction: Incompletely excised lesions recur, often with recruitment of new collateral flow through the residual AVM nidus.
related_terminology: Not recommended: arteriovenous haemangioma; cirsoid aneurysm; acral arteriovenous tumour.
subtypes: Deep-seated arteriovenous malformation; cutaneous arteriovenous malformation

media.legend: Arteriovenous malformation. Ill-defined dermal and subcutaneous proliferation of variably sized vascular channels.
Arteriovenous malformation. Small and medium-sized vein- and artery-like congested vascular channels.
Arteriovenous malformation. Ill-defined dermal and subcutaneous proliferation of variably sized vascular channels.

definition: Verrucous venous malformation is a distinctive localized vascular malformation associated with overlying prominent epidermal changes.
clinical:
The lesions are slightly raised singular, grouped, or confluent red to purple plaques that become more hyperkeratotic and may ulcerate, bleed, and slowly enlarge over time. Linear lesions have been reported. Local tissue hypertrophy is not a feature.

---

This is a rare congenital lesion with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Not known

---

Verrucous venous malformation is non-familial. A somatic missense mutation in MAP3K3 has been identified in some cases.
microscopic: An epidermis with prominent acanthosis, papillomatosis, hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and crusting overlies an expanded papillary dermis with numerous dilated and congested capillaries and venules, often extending into the investing dermis of the skin adnexa while sparing the reticular dermis. The subcutaneous tissue displays an increased density of variably congested capillaries and venules, with occasionally admixed larger veins. Mitotic activity is rare to absent. There may be focal light endothelial positivity for GLUT1, but the full placenta-like vascular phenotype of infantile haemangioma is lacking. Small dilated lymphatic vessels also may be present but the predominant differentiation is clearly blood vascular. Differential diagnosis The superficial dermal changes closely resemble angiokeratoma. Histological distinction relies on the identification of a deep dermal / subcutaneous component.
prognosis_and_prediction: Verrucous venous malformation shows persistence and slow expansion following incomplete excision.
related_terminology: Not recommended: verrucous haemangioma (obsolete); verrucous venulocapillary malformation; verrucous keratotic haemangioma.

media.legend: Verrucous venous malformation. Warty changes of the epidermis associated with a superficial, deep dermal, and subcutaneous vascular proliferation.
Verrucous venous malformation. Dilated congested vascular spaces in the papillary dermis and a vascular proliferation in the dermis and subcutis.

definition: Acquired elastotic haemangioma (AEH) is a superficial band-like proliferation of small vascular channels arising in sun-exposed skin and associated with solar elastosis.
clinical:
The lesion manifests as an asymptomatic, small papule or plaque developing in sun-exposed skin. Multiple lesions are exceptional.

---

AEH is rare. It occurs in middle-aged and elderly adults, with a slight female predilection.
pathogenesis:
It is likely that chronic sun damage plays a role in the development of lesions.

---

Unknown
microscopic: AEH shows a band-like proliferation of capillaries, each surrounded by a layer of pericytes and oriented parallel to the epidermis in the upper reticular dermis. There is background solar elastosis. Differential diagnosis Microvenular haemangioma involves the mid to deep dermis and is poorly defined and not associated with solar elastosis. Poikilodermatous plaque-like haemangioma is also a superficial plaque-like proliferation but the lesions are larger, the stroma is oedematous, elastic fibres are missing, and there is no solar elastosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: AEH is benign.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Acquired elastotic haemangioma. Plaque-like superficial dermal proliferation of small vascular channels in the background of solar elastosis.
Acquired elastotic haemangioma. Small blood vessels lined by a single layer of endothelial cells surrounded by a layer of pericytes and associated with solar elastosis.

definition: Poikilodermatous plaque-like haemangioma is an acquired band-like vascular proliferation involving the superficial dermis.
clinical:
Patients present with asymptomatic, slowly growing, erythematous or violaceous scaly plaques varying in size between 20 and 70 mm that are often described as poikilodermatous. The plaques are typically solitary, rarely multiple. Although clinically the lesions raise concern for poikilodermatous mycosis fungoides, on histology these two entities share no common features.

---

Most of the patients are elderly men.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: There is a band-like proliferation of small-calibre blood vessels lined by bland endothelium in the papillary and superficial reticular dermis, with no grenz zone and with a concomitant loss or decrease of elastic fibres in the affected area. Most cases exhibit a certain degree of hyperkeratosis or acanthosis and mild lymphocytic inflammation between the vessels. The differential diagnosis includes other vascular neoplasms, such as acquired elastotic haemangioma (smaller and with a similar pattern but with the presence of solar elastosis), microvenular haemangioma (involves the superficial and deep dermis, no absence of elastic fibres, and an absence of a plaque-like architecture), and hobnail haemangioma (wedge-shaped architecture, irregular lymphatic-like channels, lined by hobnail endothelial cells and haemosiderin deposits).
prognosis_and_prediction: Lesions are indolent and persist despite treatment.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Poikilodermatous plaque-like haemangioma. Low-power view showing a dense proliferation of small round vessels within the superficial dermis.
Poikilodermatous plaque-like haemangioma. Small-calibre blood vessels are lined by bland endothelium. The overlying epidermis is hyperkeratotic and acanthotic.
Poikilodermatous plaque-like haemangioma. Absence of elastic fibres in the affected area (Van Gieson).

definition: Lobular capillary haemangioma is a common vascular cutaneous and mucosal neoplasm that consists of a proliferation of capillaries with a lobular architecture.
clinical:
The lesion is a rapidly growing, polypoid, haemorrhagic, and frequently ulcerated blue or red nodule. Multiple lesions occasionally develop; in children, recurrences may be associated with multiple satellites. Lesions can occur in association with port-wine stain and other vascular malformations. They are also associated with many medications and biological agents, including retinoids and BRAF inhibitors. Rare tumours arise in deep dermal / subcutaneous or intravenous locations. A congenital disseminated aggressive lobular capillary haemangioma with a predilection for the skin, brain, viscera, and musculoskeletal system has been described.

---

This haemangioma (including rare congenital cases) occurs over a wide age range, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Because of the prominent secondary inflammatory changes present in the tumour and the frequent association with trauma, lobular capillary haemangioma was previously considered to be a reactive inflammatory process. However, the notion that it is a neoplastic vascular proliferation is now favoured by many.

---

Sporadic lobular capillary haemangiomas and those occurring within port-wine stain may be associated with RAS-family and BRAF mutations (mainly c.1799T>A p.V600E).
microscopic: The tumours are polypoid and have an epidermal collarette, and show frequent ulceration with prominent inflammation consisting of neutrophils, usually restricted to the superficial aspect of the lesion. Variably dilated capillaries lined by plump endothelial cells rimmed by a pericyte layer are arranged in lobules within oedematous stroma. Mitotic activity is common, and focal cytological atypia may be noted, in particular in mucosal lesions. Older lesions show variable fibrosis. Deep-seated and intravenous lesions are identical but lack inflammation. Differential diagnosis Nodular Kaposi sarcoma shows a similar architecture but consists of bundles of spindle-shaped cells with clefting, intracytoplasmic eosinophilic globules, and KSHV/HHV8 positivity. Bacillary angiomatosis (an infectious vascular proliferation caused mainly by Bartonella henselae, formerly called Rochalimaea henselae) is histologically similar, but the vascular channels are lined by pale epithelioid endothelial cells and aggregates of neutrophils, and nuclear dust and amorphous basophilic or amphophilic material consisting of Warthin–Starry stain–positive bacteria are identified.
prognosis_and_prediction: Complete regression is not typical, and local recurrence occurs in approximately 10% of cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: pyogenic granuloma.

media.legend: Lobular capillary haemangioma. Ulcerated polypoid vascular lobular proliferation.
Lobular capillary haemangioma. Small variably dilated vascular channels associated with focal inflammation and oedematous stroma.

entity_name: Congenital non-progressive haemangiomas: Rapidly involuting congenital haemangioma and non-involuting congenital haemangioma
definition: Congenital non-progressive haemangiomas are a distinct group of vascular lesions that arise in utero and are fully formed at birth. There are two clinical subtypes: rapidly involuting congenital haemangioma (RICH) and non-involuting congenital haemangioma (NICH). For cases that regress incompletely, the term partially involuted congenital haemangioma (PICH) has been proposed.
clinical:
The lesions are usually fully formed at birth, typically following either a persistent clinical course (NICH) or a very rapidly regressive course through infarction (RICH) during the first 6 months of life. Initial lesions vary in size and consist of a vascular red or bluish mass with overlying telangiectasia, occasionally associated with ulceration. Rare tumours regress incompletely (PICH). NICH increases in size proportionally as the patient grows, and it does not regress. Exceptional cases show limited postnatal growth.

---

Congenital non-progressive haemangiomas arise at birth, with no sex predilection. They are less common than infantile haemangioma.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Somatic activating mutations in GNAQ and GNA11 at Q209 have been identified in both NICH and RICH.
microscopic: RICH, PICH, and NICH vary along a histopathological spectrum, largely dependent on the degree of infarction. All are composed of variably well-circumscribed capillary lobules within the dermis and/or subcutis. The interlobular stroma is often fibrotic and may contain arteries, veins, and sometimes lymphatic channels of moderate size. Intralobular capillary endothelial cells and pericytes can be plump, but they lack the increased mitotic activity, GLUT1 positivity, and basement membrane multilamination of infantile haemangioma. Persistent lesions (NICHs and PICHs) are more likely to display arteriovenous shunts, hobnail endothelial cells, and a large vessel in the centre of the vascular lobules. The endothelial cells of all subtypes are negative for GLUT1. Differential diagnosis The distinction from infantile haemangioma is usually straightforward, on the basis that congenital non-progressive haemangiomas arise at birth and lack endothelial positivity for GLUT1.
prognosis_and_prediction: Most RICHs involute spontaneously, and NICHs tend to persist. Persistent congenital non-progressive haemangiomas often require surgical or laser intervention.
related_terminology: None
subtypes: Rapidly involuting congenital haemangioma (RICH); partially involuted congenital haemangioma (PICH); non-involuting congenital haemangioma (NICH)

media.legend: Rapidly involuting congenital haemangioma. Lobules of capillaries separated by collagenous septa.
Rapidly involuting congenital haemangioma. Tightly packed capillaries.
Non-involuting congenital haemangioma. Dermal vascular proliferation composed of variably dilated vascular channels.
Non-involuting congenital haemangioma. Dilated, thin-walled, irregular vascular channels.

definition: Infantile haemangioma is a benign tumour characterized by a proliferation of lobules of capillaries with a distinctive immunophenotype arising exclusively in infancy and showing spontaneous slow regression.
clinical:
Nascent tumours may be evident at birth but typically appear in the first 2–6 weeks of life, as a bright-red or blue nodule or plaque, often with a strawberry-like appearance. There is initial rapid growth over a period of months, transitioning to a longer involuting phase of a few years. Lesions arising at certain locations may be associated with underlying malformations and multiple lesions; usually, the presence of > 5 lesions is associated with liver haemangiomas.

---

This haemangioma, which occurs in about 4% of the population, is the most common tumour of infancy. It shows a female predilection and is more common in White populations.
pathogenesis:
Although racial distributions suggest genetic predilections, there is no evidence to support a primary genetic driver. Rare families show an increased incidence.

---

The fact that infantile haemangiomas immunoreactivity for GLUT1, LeY, and other markers is identical to that of placental microvessels suggests that this tumour results from embolization of placental cells or stem cells differentiating towards placental vascular cells. Cultured infantile haemangioma endothelial cells are clonal, a finding consistent with a neoplastic process. No underlying genetic abnormalities have been identified.
microscopic: The histology of infantile haemangioma defines the three stages of the lesion: proliferation, partial involution, and complete involution. These stages form an overlapping continuum. Early proliferative lesions consist of cellular dermal and/or subcutaneous masses of tightly packed capillaries with small lumina, lined by plump endothelial cells rimmed by pericytes. The capillaries are interspersed with immature dendritic-type cells and arranged in lobules separated by delicate fibrous septa or normal intervening stroma. Perineural extension is common, and the feeding and draining vessels may be quite large. During active involution, the lesional capillaries become variably dilated and congested, and gradually disappear. The basement membranes thicken and show apoptotic dust, and the pericapillary mast cells increase in number. Nearing end-stage, the tumour lobules are replaced by loose fibrous or fibrofatty stroma containing a few residual ghost capillaries composed of thickened multilayered rinds of basement membrane material with little or no cellular lining. The endothelial cells show a complex immunophenotype shared only by placental capillaries, including positivity for GLUT1, LeY, CD15, CCR6, IDO1, and IGF2. Differential diagnosis Infantile haemangioma must be distinguished from congenital non-progressive haemangiomas on the basis of careful clinicopathological correlation and GLUT1 immunohistochemistry. All infantile haemangiomas have endothelial GLUT1 positivity, whereas congenital non-progressive haemangioma endothelial cells are negative for this marker.
prognosis_and_prediction: These tumours are benign, but treatment is necessary when there is associated morbidity due to location or size. All cases show spontaneous regression, albeit with variation in rate and degree.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Not recommended: capillary haemangioma; juvenile haemangioma; strawberry naevus; capillary-cavernous haemangioma; infantile haemangioendothelioma.

media.legend: Infantile haemangioma. Early stage consisting of lobules of capillaries.
Infantile haemangioma. Involuting stage. Early fibrosis within tumour lobules.
Infantile haemangioma. Late stage. Prominent perivascular fibrosis.

definition: Angiokeratoma is a superficial vascular ectasia associated with variable overlying epidermal changes.
clinical:
Patients with ACD present with numerous asymptomatic pinpoint papules with minimal epidermal change. Patients with AF or AM present with single or multiple small red keratotic papules. Patients with SA present with a single keratotic (often crusted) papule or nodule.

---

Four clinicopathological types of angiokeratomas have been described. ACD is associated with Fabry disease and arises in late childhood. AF most commonly occurs in adult men. AM most commonly occurs in adults, with no sex predilection. SA or angiokeratoma circumscriptum also occurs in adults, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
The etiology of sporadic angiokeratomas is unknown. In Fabry disease, the lesions seem to develop because of accumulation of globotriaosylceramide in endothelial cells as a result of α-galactosidase deficiency. ACD may also develop as a result of deficiency in other enzymes, including α-L-fucosidase, β-mannosidase, and α-N-acetylgalactosaminidase. Rare cases with no enzyme deficiency may be seen. ACD is associated with Fabry disease, an X-linked genetic disorder of α-galactosidase deficiency.

---

Unknown
microscopic: ACD shows dilated, congested vascular channels in the papillary dermis, with minimal epidermal change. Endothelial cells, pericytes, and fibroblasts show cytoplasmic vacuoles representing lipid. AF, AM, and SA show dilated, thin-walled vascular channels in the papillary dermis associated with overlying epidermal changes consisting of acanthosis and hyperkeratosis. Differential diagnosis SA must be distinguished from verrucous venous malformation (see section Verrucous venous malformation).
prognosis_and_prediction: In ACD, lesions continue to develop throughout life.
related_terminology: None
subtypes: Angiokeratoma corporis diffusum (ACD); angiokeratoma of Fordyce (AF); angiokeratoma of Mibelli (AM); solitary angiokeratoma (SA)

media.legend: Angiokeratoma. Congested and dilated vascular channels lined by a single flattened layer of endothelial cells.
Angiokeratoma. Low-power image demonstrating epidermal changes of angiokeratoma.

definition: Tufted haemangioma is a benign cutaneous vascular tumour sometimes associated with Kasabach–Merritt syndrome and now widely considered part of the kaposiform haemangioendothelioma spectrum.
clinical:
Tufted haemangiomas manifest as slow-growing, poorly defined macules, papules, nodules, and plaques, with rare focal regression. Patients with large cutaneous lesions may develop Kasabach–Merritt syndrome. This and other features, including genetic evidence of a homogeneous methylation pattern, support the widely held opinion that tufted haemangioma is a smaller, more superficial clinical presentation of kaposiform haemangioendothelioma.

---

This rare haemangioma has a strong predilection for infants and children, with no sex predilection. Congenital cases have been reported, and presentation in adult life is exceptional.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: Multiple scattered, tightly packed lobules of capillaries are present throughout the dermis and (more rarely) the subcutis, in a cannonball pattern. The lumina of vascular channels are often difficult to discern, and pericytes are prominent. The endothelial cells are flat and occasionally contain intracytoplasmic hyaline structures. A distinctive feature is the presence of a crescent-like lymphatic channel around many individual tumour lobules. The stroma between tumour lobules may be desmoplastic and contain lymphatic-like channels. Focal fascicles of spindled endothelial cells, which are positive for podoplanin (recognized by D2-40), CD31, ERG, and CD34, may be seen within the capillary lobules. Differential diagnosis Nodular Kaposi sarcoma lacks a cannonball architecture and is positive for KSHV/HHV8.
prognosis_and_prediction: Tufted haemangioma is benign, but patients with large tumours may develop Kasabach–Merritt syndrome, which may be life-threatening.
related_terminology: Not recommended: acquired tufted angioma; angioblastoma.

media.legend: Tufted angioma. Tightly packed small capillary lobules throughout the dermis.
Tufted angioma. Small capillary lobules associated with crescent-like lymphatic spaces.
Tufted haemangioma. Tightly packed small capillary lobules throughout the dermis, associated with crescent-like lymphatic spaces.

definition: Epithelioid haemangioma (EH) is a benign vascular proliferation with vessels lined by epithelioid endothelial cells, often with an associated inflammatory component.
clinical:
EHs manifest as single or multiple, persistent, skin-coloured to erythematous papules and nodules. Peripheral eosinophilia is seen in 15% of patients. Similar lesions may occur in deeper soft tissue, internal organs, and bone.

---

Lesions occur most commonly in young adults (with a slight male predilection), but people of all ages and ethnic groups are affected.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Some cases may be reactive – related to trauma, acquired arteriovenous fistulas, or congenital arteriovenous malformations. EHs may be a heterogeneous group of histologically overlapping disorders, some neoplastic and others reactive to shunting.

---

FOS or FOSB gene rearrangements are commonly present in bone and soft tissue EHs, but they are rare in cutaneous lesions and absent in histologically classic examples of angiolymphoid hyperplasia with eosinophilia, although these are positive for FOSB by immunohistochemistry.
microscopic: There is a lobular proliferation of vascular channels lined by bland epithelioid endothelial cells with abundant eosinophilic or amphophilic cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei that protrude into the lumen.
