A focal intravascular component may be seen, and rare examples are entirely intravenous. Inflammation is typically prominent, consisting of lymphocytes, histiocytes, plasma cells, and numerous eosinophils. Fibrosis occurs in late-stage lesions, which are also characterized by less inflammation and less prominent epithelioid endothelial cells. In many cases, mural damage in a medium-sized to large artery is present. Immunohistochemistry Immunohistochemically, the endothelial cells are positive for blood vascular markers, lack lymphatic markers, and are accompanied by an SMA-positive pericyte layer. The epithelioid endothelial cells do not express EMA or keratins and usually display nuclear staining for FOSB. Differential diagnosis EH must be distinguished from Kimura disease, which occurs mainly in Asian males, presents with larger and deeper lesions and involvement of lymph nodes, and is often associated with systemic symptoms. Histologically, although the composition of the inflammatory cell infiltrate of Kimura disease is similar to that of EH, germinal centres may be seen and the vascular channels are not lined by epithelioid endothelial cells.
prognosis_and_prediction: EH is benign, but recurrences are common.
related_terminology: Not recommended: angiolymphoid hyperplasia with eosinophilia; histiocytoid haemangioma; pseudopyogenic granuloma.

media.legend: Epithelioid haemangioma. Dermal lobular vascular proliferation obscured by prominent inflammation.
Epithelioid haemangioma. Vascular channels with prominent epithelioid cells associated with fibrosis and inflammatory cells, mainly lymphocytes and eosinophils.
Epithelioid haemangioma. Vascular channels lined by prominent epithelioid endothelial cells.

definition: Spindle cell haemangioma is a benign neoplasm composed of spindled cells, ectatic vascular spaces, and vacuolated endothelial cells.
clinical:
The lesions are multiple asymptomatic bluish nodules developing over many years, with little tendency for regression. There is a strong association with Maffucci syndrome, and less common associations with lymphoedema, early-onset varicose veins, and Klippel–Trénaunay syndrome.

---

This rare haemangioma is more common in the second and third decades of life, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Spindle cell haemangioma is associated with Maffucci syndrome.

---

Sporadic lesions and lesions associated with Maffucci syndrome are associated with IDH1 p.R132C hotspot mutations. Frequent somatic alterations in 2p22.3, 2q24.3, and 14q11.2 are also found in spindle cell haemangiomas and enchondromas occurring in patients with Maffucci syndrome.
microscopic: The tumours are relatively well circumscribed, often partially intravascular, or sometimes poorly defined. They occupy the dermis, with frequent extension into the subcutis, and they consist of irregular, dilated, thin-walled, congested, cavernous-like vascular channels mixed with solid areas of vacuolated epithelioid endothelial cells scattered among bland spindle-shaped cells with pericytic and fibroblastic features and poorly defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. The cavernous vascular channels are lined by a single layer of bland endothelial cells. Thrombi, with or without dystrophic calcification, are common. Smooth muscle cells may be seen focally. Degenerative cytological atypia is sometimes present. The endothelial cells within the vascular channels and the epithelioid vacuolated cells show positive immunostaining for endothelial markers. Spindle cells may show focal positivity for SMA. Differential diagnosis Nodular Kaposi sarcoma lacks cavernous vascular channels and epithelioid vacuolated cells and is positive for KSHV/HHV8.
prognosis_and_prediction: Spindle cell haemangiomas are benign and do not usually recur, but multiple new lesions may develop over time.
related_terminology: Not recommended: spindle cell haemangioendothelioma (obsolete).

media.legend: Spindle cell haemangioma. Dilated and congested thin-walled vascular channels with spindle-shaped and vacuolated endothelial cells in the background.
Spindle cell haemangioma. Bland spindle-shaped cells, vascular channels lined by a layer of flattened endothelial cells, and aggregates of vacuolated cells.
Spindle cell haemangioma. Spindle-shaped cells and vacuolated cells with cells displaying intracytoplasmic lumina.
Spindle cell haemangioma. Clinical appearance during surgical removal.

definition: Papillary haemangioma is a distinctive vascular proliferation consisting of dilated vascular channels with prominent intraluminal papillary projections lined by endothelial cells, many of which contain intracytoplasmic globules.
clinical:
Papillary haemangioma appears as a solitary, longstanding, bluish-red papule as large as 11 mm in diameter.

---

It is most common in adult men.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: Papillary haemangioma is characterized by dermal, widely dilated, thin-walled vascular channels with numerous luminal papillary projections containing capillaries lined by plump endothelial cells, surrounded by pericytes, and displaying frequent intracytoplasmic eosinophilic globules. These globules, known as thanatosomes, represent dilated lysosomes containing debris and fat vacuoles. Endothelial cells are positive for CD31, CD34, and ERG and are negative for lymphatic markers. Differential diagnosis The lesions are histologically similar to glomeruloid haemangiomas, which differ in their typical multifocally, involvement of the trunk and extremities, and association with POEMS syndrome.
prognosis_and_prediction: Papillary haemangioma is benign, and recurrences are exceptional.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Papillary haemangioma. Lobulated dermal vascular proliferation composed of vascular channels with papillary projections.
Papillary haemangioma. Dilated vascular channels containing papillary projections and focal thrombosis.
Papillary haemangioma. Intravascular papillae with collagenous cores and eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions (thanatosomes).

definition: Glomeruloid haemangioma is a reactive vascular proliferation associated with multicentric Castleman disease and POEMS syndrome (polyradiculoneuropathy, organomegaly, endocrinopathy, clonal plasma cell disorder, and skin changes).
clinical:
The lesions are multiple erythematous papules.

---

This rare haemangioma shows no sex predilection. Examples occurring outside the setting of multicentric Castleman disease or POEMS syndrome are likely to in fact be papillary haemangioma (see Differential diagnosis, below). A rare association with Erdheim–Chester disease has been reported.
pathogenesis:
Glomeruloid haemangioma is generally considered to be a reactive process.

---

Raised serum levels of VEGF have been described in one study, suggesting that this may play in a role in the development of the vascular lesions.
microscopic: There is dermal proliferation of dilated vascular channels containing clusters of capillaries that resemble renal glomeruli. The endothelial cells often contain intracytoplasmic inclusions that give a positive PAS reaction; these inclusions may be immunoglobulins, enlarged lysosomes, or thanatosomes. Differential diagnosis Papillary haemangioma has a predilection for the head and neck and manifests as a single lesion consisting of dermal dilated channels lined by endothelial cells with frequent papillary projections and lacking glomeruloid architecture.
prognosis_and_prediction: Glomeruloid haemangioma is benign but tends to persist, paralleling underlying systemic disease.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Glomeruloid haemangioma. High-power image demonstrates intravascular capillary proliferation resembling a renal glomerulus.

Glomeruloid haemangioma. Reactive proliferation of vessels in upper and mid dermis, with tufts of proliferating coiled capillaries projecting within the walls of ectatic vessels mimicking renal glomeruli. Capillary loops forming the tufts are lined by plump endothelial cells.

definition: Hobnail haemangioma is a benign vascular malformation of lymphatic lineage, with hobnail endothelial cells and a delayed presentation.
clinical:
Most lesions arise as a small, nondescript erythematous papule. Uncommonly, the lesion is a small reddish-brown or purple papule surrounded by concentric ecchymotic haloes, hence the original name targetoid haemosiderotic haemangioma.

---

This relatively rare haemangioma occurs mainly in young and middle-aged adults, with a male predilection.
pathogenesis:
The underlying etiology of hobnail haemangioma is unclear, but it is currently considered a malformation rather than a neoplasm.

---

Expression of lymphatic markers and negativity for WT1 and mitotic markers supports the conclusion that these are superficial lymphatic malformations that undergo delayed perilesional bleeding and haemosiderin deposition.
microscopic: The lesions are wedge-shaped and consist of scattered, thin-walled, irregular vascular channels lined by bland endothelial cells with a hobnail appearance and focal intraluminal papillary projections. Vessels deeper in the lesion become smaller, flattened, and inconspicuous, without hobnail endothelial cells. Red blood cell extravasation, haemosiderin deposition, and perivascular lymphocytes are common. The endothelial cells are strongly positive for podoplanin (recognized by D2-40) and usually negative or weakly positive for CD34, suggesting a lymphatic lineage. Differential diagnosis Atypical vascular lesions occurring after radiotherapy may be identical, but they usually lack the wedge-shaped architecture. Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma (Dabska tumour) and retiform haemangioendothelioma have hobnail endothelial cells but have a distinctive pattern and are larger and more infiltrative.
prognosis_and_prediction: Hobnail haemangioma is benign, with no tendency for recurrence.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Not recommended: targetoid haemosiderotic haemangioma; superficial haemosiderotic lymphovascular malformation; targetoid haemosiderotic lymphatic malformation.

media.legend: Hobnail haemangioma. Dilated, irregular, thin-walled vascular channels in the superficial dermis, with progressive decrease in the deeper dermis.
Hobnail haemangioma. Dilated, lymphatic-like channels with focal papillary projections. Haemosiderin is seen in the background.
Hobnail haemangioma. Vascular channels lined by bland hobnail endothelial cells.

Hobnail haemangioma. Thin-walled vascular channels in the dermis, lined by hobnail endothelial cells. Perivascular lymphocytic inflammation with interspersed haemosiderin deposits (especially in the deep dermis in this case).

definition: Microvenular haemangioma is a mitotically quiescent vascular lesion, likely to be a type of venous malformation.
clinical:
The lesion is a single, small (or occasionally larger), red, asymptomatic papule or plaque. Exceptional eruptive or multiple lesions have been reported.

---

This rare haemangioma arises mainly in young adults, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: The lesions are poorly defined, usually involve superficial and deep reticular dermis, and consist of elongated (often irregular) small vascular channels resembling venules. The vessels dissect somewhat hyalinized-looking collagen bundles. Extension of channels into arrector pili muscles is common. A single layer of pericytes, which can be highlighted by SMA staining, is consistently present and often conspicuous. The endothelial cells are bland and lack mitotic activity; they are positive for ERG, CD31, and CD34 but negative for podoplanin (recognized by D2-40). Differential diagnosis The dissection of collagen may prompt consideration of angiosarcoma or Kaposi sarcoma. Microvenular haemangioma lacks atypia and multilayering; each vessel is surrounded by a pericyte layer, and it is KSHV/HHV8-negative.
prognosis_and_prediction: Microvenular haemangioma is benign, with only exceptional local recurrence.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Microvenular haemangioma. Ill-defined dermal vascular proliferation composed of numerous small elongated channels.
Microvenular haemangioma. Small venule-like vascular spaces, each of which is surrounded by a layer of pericytes. Infiltration of the arrector pili muscles is often seen.

definition: Sinusoidal haemangioma is a histologically distinctive benign vascular lesion consisting of thin-walled vascular channels with scant smooth muscle in a sinusoidal or sieve-like pattern, and with features resembling those of anastomosing haemangioma (a lesion seen mainly in the kidney).
clinical:
The lesion is a small, asymptomatic, well-demarcated acquired dermal or subcutaneous bluish nodule.

---

These relatively rare lesions occur primarily in middle-aged women. In men, they frequently develop in the setting of gynaecomastia.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown, but many consider this to be a venous malformation with delayed presentation.

---

Unknown
microscopic: The lesions are lobular and relatively well circumscribed. They are composed of irregular, dilated, congested, thin-walled vascular channels with scant smooth muscle in a sinusoidal or sieve-like pattern, with little intervening stroma. The endothelial cells are uniform and mitotically quiescent. Thrombosis and dystrophic calcification are often present. A similar sinusoidal vascular pattern is commonly seen focally in venous malformations. Differential diagnosis In the breast, the differential diagnosis includes well-differentiated angiosarcoma. However, angiosarcoma shows multilayering of endothelial cells, cytological atypia, and mitotic activity.
prognosis_and_prediction: Sinusoidal haemangioma is benign.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Acceptable: sinusoidal venous malformation.

media.legend: Sinusoidal haemangioma. Note the distinctive sinusoidal appearance of the vascular channels.

definition: Cherry haemangioma is a common benign superficial dermal capillary proliferation with a lobular architecture, appearing in adulthood.
clinical:
The lesions are multiple, tiny, bright red, asymptomatic papules that increase in number with age.

---

This haemangioma affects middle-aged to elderly adults, with no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

HRAS and KRAS somatic mutations are found in a small proportion of cases, and frequent somatic mutations of GNA14, GNA11, and GNAQ have also been described.
microscopic: The papillary dermis is expanded by a slightly polypoid lobular proliferation of small congested and dilated capillaries with surrounding loose stroma, often with an epithelial collarette.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cherry haemangioma is benign.
related_terminology: Acceptable: cherry angioma. Not recommended: senile angioma; Campbell de Morgan spot.

media.legend: Cherry haemangioma. The tumour consists of lobules of dilated capillaries.
Cherry haemangioma. At high power, dilated and congested capillaries are lined by a single layer of endothelial cells.
Cherry haemangioma. Lobules of dilated and congested capillaries, lined by a single layer of endothelial cells.

definition: Myxofibrosarcoma is a nodular spindle-to-pleomorphic sarcoma with wide variations in cellularity, nuclear atypia, and a myxoid stroma with curvilinear vasculature.
clinical:
Myxofibrosarcoma is an often slow-growing and painless tumour with frequent local recurrence. Low-grade cases may develop histological progression to higher grades upon recurrence, thus acquiring an increased risk of metastasis.

---

Myxofibrosarcoma, with a slight male predominance, is a rather common sarcoma of elderly patients, occurring usually in the sixth to eighth decades of life; it is rare in patients aged < 30 years.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Myxofibrosarcomas harbour frequent chromosomal structure rearrangements and copy-number alterations, even in low-grade cases, and they exhibit increasing genomic complexity in recurrent lesions with histological progression. Myxofibrosarcomas are predominated by somatic copy-number alterations, where several oncogenes (TRIO, RICTOR, SKP2, and AMACR) on frequently gained 5p are variably coamplified and associated with increased grade. In half of myxofibrosarcomas, the pathogenetic aberrations converge on p53 signalling and the G1/S cell-cycle checkpoint. Tumour suppressor mutations that inactivate TP53 (46%, most frequent), RB1 (18%), and/or CDKN2A/CDKN2B (16%) occur more frequently than oncogene amplifications of CDK6, CCND1, or MDM2. RB1-inactivated and TP53-inactivated myxofibrosarcomas critically rely on SKP2 for survival, while amplifications of TRIO and RICTOR activate the RAC/PAK and AKT/mTOR pathways, respectively.
macroscopic: Superficial myxofibrosarcomas are typically multinodular, variably gelatinous masses involving the subcutis and dermis. High-grade lesions may show necrosis.
microscopic: As the histological grade increases, myxofibrosarcoma exhibits increased cellularity, pleomorphism, and proliferative activity but decreased myxoid stroma; a minimum of myxoid stroma (optimally 5%) is required to distinguish undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcomas. Subcutaneous lesions often have extensive infiltration beyond what can be clinically detected. Low-grade myxofibrosarcoma is hypocellular, prominently myxoid, and composed of mildly atypical spindle-to-stellate cells featuring nuclear hyperchromasia and perivascular cellular condensation with some mucin-containing pseudolipoblasts. The intermediate-grade lesions become more cellular and pleomorphic but lack the solid areas characteristic of high-grade cases. The latter often show necrosis, atypical mitoses, and overlap with undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma. The rare epithelioid subtype typically shows cohesive clusters and/or sheets of epithelioid cells with abundant cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei, simulating carcinoma or melanoma. Immunohistochemistry SMA and/or CD34 reactivity is occasionally seen in myxofibrosarcoma, whereas desmin and S100 are negative. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes superficial angiomyxoma, myxoid spindle cell lipoma, nerve sheath myxoma, myxoid dermatofibrosarcoma, low-grade fibromyxoid sarcoma, and other higher-grade sarcomas with a myxoid matrix.
staging: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) TNM system is applicable.
prognosis_and_prediction: The 5-year overall survival rate is about 77%. Repeated local recurrences, occurring in 30–40%, are unrelated to histological grade, are usually associated with inadequate surgery, and are less common in the lower extremities. Low-grade myxofibrosarcoma has a favourable prognosis, with minimal metastatic potential. Intermediate-grade and high-grade myxofibrosarcomas metastasize in 15–23% of cases, usually to the lung, bone, or lymph nodes. Per cent myxoid component (inversely related to grade), size, and (potentially) CD34 expression are significant predictors of survival, while clear surgical margins mitigate local recurrences. Epithelioid myxofibrosarcomas behave aggressively, with an increased metastatic risk (> 50%).
related_terminology: Not recommended: myxoid malignant fibrous histiocytoma.

media.legend: Subcutaneous myxofibrosarcoma. Superficially located myxofibrosarcoma with a multinodular growth pattern and a gelatinous, myxoid cut surface.
Myxofibrosarcoma, low grade. A hypocellular myxoid neoplasm with mildly atypical, spindle-to-stellate cells with nuclear hyperchromasia and elongated, curvilinear blood vessels.
Dermal myxofibrosarcoma. A typical dermal myxofibrosarcoma with infiltrative, multinodular growth.
Subcutaneous myxofibrosarcoma. A myxofibrosarcoma extensively infiltrating the subcutaneous adipose tissue.
Myxofibrosarcoma, intermediate grade. More cellular and atypical cells and occasional mucin-engulfing pseudolipoblasts surround long curvilinear vessels in myxoid stroma.

Myxofibrosarcoma, high grade. A high-grade solid component resembling undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (left) is juxtaposed to an area with typical histology of myxofibrosarcoma (right). Bizarre giant cells with storiform arrangement are frequent.

Epithelioid myxofibrosarcoma, high grade. An abrupt transition from the low-grade area (right lower) to a high-grade epithelioid component (left upper) presenting cohesive clusters or even confluent sheets.
Epithelioid myxofibrosarcoma, high grade. Note the enlarged epithelioid cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and atypical mitoses.
Myxofibrosarcoma, high grade. A high-grade solid component is associated with myxoid areas of low cellularity. Bizarre giant cells and storiform arrangement are seen.

definition: Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma (MIFS) is an infiltrative, locally aggressive fibroblastic neoplasm with a predilection for acral soft tissue, characterized by prominent inflammation, a myxohyaline stroma, and pleomorphic fibroblastic cells with macronucleoli.
clinical:
MIFS usually manifests as a painless mass. On imaging, it is centred in the subcutis (in about two thirds of cases) or deeper and typically displays infiltration into adjacent tissues, often mimicking infection, tenosynovial giant cell tumour, or ganglion cysts.

---

MIFS is rare. It has a peak incidence in the fourth to sixth decades of life and no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Amplification of VGLL3 on 3p11-p12, resulting in a supernumerary ring chromosome, is reported in > 50% of cases. A t(1;10) with breakpoints around OGA on 10q24 and TGFBR3 on 1p22 is documented in 13% of cases and is also found in pure haemosiderotic fibrolipomatous tumours, in examples with mixed MIFS morphology (where the translocation appears to be more prevalent), and in pleomorphic hyalinizing angiectatic tumour. BRAF fusions or amplifications are also found.
macroscopic: The tumours are lobulated and variably gelatinous, fleshy, or firm, typically attaining a size of about 30 mm.
microscopic: MIFS is infiltrative and multinodular, being centred in the subcutaneous tissue in most cases. Especially in acral sites, these lesions tend to be superficial and to involve the dermis. They are characterized by dense inflammation merging with stroma varying from myxoid to hyalinized and containing sheets and small foci of epithelioid and spindled cells. Some lesions contain foamy histiocytes, giant cells, and haemosiderin. Within the inflammatory background, scattered bizarre cells with large vesicular nuclei and macronucleoli reminiscent of Reed–Sternberg cells are present. Many cells show degenerated (smudged) chromatin. Pseudolipoblasts with cytoplasmic mucopolysaccharide matrix may be seen. The inflammatory infiltrate is mixed, consisting of lymphocytes, plasma cells, histiocytes, and eosinophils in varying proportions. Emperipolesis, often subtle, is a common feature. Mitotic activity is minimal. Immunohistochemistry Immunohistochemistry is unhelpful. The majority of cases exhibit expression of cyclin D1 (BCL1), factor XIIIa, D2-40, and CD10. Variable expression of CD34, CD163, and PRAME is also observed, as well as focal expression of keratin, KIT (CD117), CD68, and actin.
prognosis_and_prediction: Local recurrences are common and often repeated. Metastases are rare, occurring in < 1% of cases after multiple recurrences. Initial complete excision is the best predictor of a favourable outcome. No specific histological criteria predict aggressive behaviour, but one study associated high-grade histological progression with metastatic potential.
related_terminology: Not recommended: inflammatory myxohyaline tumour of the distal extremities with virocyte-like or Reed–Sternberg–like cells; inflammatory myxoid tumour of the soft parts with bizarre giant cells.

media.legend: Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. This tumour type shows infiltrative margins and is often dominated by chronic inflammation, thereby mimicking an inflammatory process. Note the areas with prominent myxoid stroma.
Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. In the myxoid areas, pseudolipoblasts (multivacuolated cells containing mucin) may be prominent.
Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. The tumour cells contain vesicular chromatin and large nucleoli. Note the scattered mixed inflammatory cells.
Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. Binucleated tumour cells with inclusion-like macronucleoli may closely mimic Reed–Sternberg cells.
Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. Alcian blue staining the myxoid stroma of the tumour.
Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. High-power view of pseudolipoblasts (multivacuolated cells containing mucin).

Myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma. Array comparative genomic hybridization profile of a myxoinflammatory fibroblastic sarcoma showing amplification of the VGLL3 gene (arrow) and unbalanced t(1;10) with breakpoints in the OGA gene (10q24) and near the TGFBR3 gene (1p22) (arrowheads).

definition: EWSR1::SMAD3-rearranged fibroblastic tumour is a distinctive benign fibroblastic neoplasm with strong predilection for the hands and feet.
clinical:
Patients usually present with a small, painless, superficial tumour in an acral site.

---

EWSR1::SMAD3-rearranged fibroblastic tumours are rare, with < 20 cases reported to date. Patients have a wide age range (1–68 years, median: 39 years), and most are female (M:F ratio: 1:4).
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

SMAD3 is an important signal transducer in the TGF-β/SMAD signalling pathway, which is involved in extracellular matrix synthesis by fibroblasts.
macroscopic: The tumours are relatively small, measuring 10–20 mm in largest dimension, with a nodular appearance.
microscopic: These tumours are typically well demarcated, but they can infiltrate subcutaneous fat. In particular, in adults, the acellular centre of the tumour appears hyalinized, which can resemble collagen rosettes. The peripheral zones consist of intersecting cellular fascicles of fibroblastic spindle cells within collagenous to more myxoid stroma. However, about half lack this zonation pattern. Lesional cells lack nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic activity. Myopericytomatous growth is rare. There may be focal stippled dystrophic calcification. By immunohistochemistry, the fibroblastic tumour cells consistently show strong diffuse nuclear ERG expression, whereas SMA and CD34 are negative. When EWSR1 rearrangement is detected by FISH, a myoepithelial tumour may be considered in the differential diagnosis. However, immunohistochemistry for cytokeratins, EMA, S100, and SOX10 is negative.
staging: Not established
prognosis_and_prediction: The tumour is benign, but local recurrence may occur after incomplete excision.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The tumour type is defined by a fusion of exon 7 of EWSR1 with exon 5 or exon 6 of SMAD3, which may be confirmed by next-generation sequencing or validated by break-apart FISH assays.
related_terminology: Acceptable: EWSR1::SMAD3-positive fibroblastic tumour.

media.legend: EWSR1::SMAD3 fusion–positive fibroblastic tumour. Peripheral zones consist of intersecting cellular fascicles of fibroblastic spindle cells within collagenous stroma.
EWSR1::SMAD3 fusion–positive fibroblastic tumour. Tumour area with hyalinized collagen rosettes.
EWSR1::SMAD3 fusion–positive fibroblastic tumour. The acellular centre of the tumour may be hyalinized.
EWSR1::SMAD3 fusion–positive fibroblastic tumour. By immunohistochemistry, tumour cells consistently show diffuse nuclear ERG expression.

definition: Nodular fasciitis is a self-limited benign myofibroblastic/fibroblastic neoplasm, classically occurring in the subcutis, arranged in a disorganized tissue culture–like pattern; it usually harbours USP6 rearrangement.
clinical:
Nodular fasciitis presents clinically as a relatively rapidly growing subcutaneous mass that enlarges (typically over the course of 3–6 weeks, but in some cases over a period as long as 3 months) and then regresses. It is typically smaller than 20–30 mm in maximal diameter, although an exceptional 100 mm case has been reported. The mass may be tender or painless.

---

Nodular fasciitis can occur at any age but has a peak incidence in the third and fourth decades of life, with equal distribution between the sexes.
pathogenesis:
Previously thought to be a reactive process, nodular fasciitis is now recognized as a translocation-driven neoplasm that consistently regresses (transient neoplasia).

---

Nodular fasciitis has been shown to harbour a translocation between chromosomes 17 and 22, t(17;22) (p13;q13), which results in MYH9::USP6 fusion and subsequent overexpression of USP6. USP6 encodes a deubiquitinating enzyme with roles in cell trafficking, cell signalling, protein breakdown, and inflammation. MYH9 encodes a non-muscle myosin heavy chain that has roles in cell motility, shape, adhesion, and differentiation. A study of p16, CDK4, MDM2, and p53 implicated the possible involvement of cell-cycle arrest and presumed senescence by p16 in lesional myofibroblastic cells in nodular fasciitis, resulting in its self-limited growth and regression. In addition, USP6 expression creates a negative feedback via TNFSF10 (TRAIL) and interferon-β, resulting in apoptosis and senescence of tumour cells. Rearrangements in USP6 have been shown in approximately 90% of nodular fasciitis cases, and > 65% of these are MYH9::USP6 gene fusions. These are most often detected in earlier (younger) lesions, while the detection of USP6 rearrangements in older lesions can be as low as 20% because of the negative feedback from USP6 expression in tumour cells. Other gene promoters can be substituted for MYH9, sometimes with atypical features: PPP6R3::USP6 and CALD1::USP6 have been reported in exceptional malignant cases, EIF5A::USP6 fusion has been described in a dermal nodular fasciitis of the left forearm with atypical mitosis, and CTNNB1::USP6 fusion was seen in an intraneural nodular fasciitis. USP6 rearrangements have also been reported in aneurysmal bone cyst, fibro-osseous tumour of the digits, and a subgroup of fibroma of tendon sheaths. Tumours in this group (including nodular fasciitis) have morphological and clinical overlap, and it has been suggested that they may represent a spectrum of manifestations of the same disease process in different locations.
macroscopic: Nodular fasciitis is unencapsulated, with variable circumscribed to infiltrative borders and a fibrous to myxoid and occasionally cystic cut surface.
microscopic: Nodular fasciitis is composed of fibroblasts and/or myofibroblasts without overt cytological atypia. Mitotic activity can be frequent, but the mitoses are not atypical. Cellularity varies between and within lesions. Feathery tissue culture–like areas are typical of the lesion, but more-cellular areas can form fascicles. The stroma can be myxoid and/or collagenous, even keloidal. The vasculature is rich and fine, resembling granulation tissue. Extravasated red cells are usually seen, often in the tissue culture–like areas. Osteoclastic giant cells and chronic inflammatory cells can be present. Immunohistochemistry Strong expression of SMA by the neoplastic cells is characteristic. Differential diagnosis The histological differential diagnosis depends on the location, the proportion of collagen and myxoid stroma, and cellularity. Collagenous patterns can be mistaken for fibromatosis, collagenous fibroma (desmoplastic fibroblastoma), or granulation tissue. The differential diagnosis also includes neural tumours, nerve sheath tumours, myositis ossificans, proliferative fasciitis, proliferative myositis, and inflammatory myofibroblastic tumours. Large and/or mitotically active nodular fasciitis can be mistaken for sarcoma.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: Nodular fasciitis can regress spontaneously and may very rarely recur following incomplete excision. Recurrence is rare.
cytology: Tumour cells are bland and spindled with unipolar curved to bipolar processes, round to oval elongated nuclei, and occasional small nucleoli. A tissue culture–like appearance and myxoid stroma can be appreciated. Hypercellular early lesions and mitotically active lesions can lead to a misdiagnosis of sarcoma, and collagenous forms may generate unsatisfactory hypocellular smears.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular testing is usually unnecessary in clinically and histologically typical cases. However, in challenging cases, detection of USP6 rearrangement may be useful to confirm the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Not recommended: pseudosarcomatous fasciitis; nodular pseudosarcomatous fasciitis; subcutaneous pseudosarcomatous fibromatosis.

media.legend: Nodular fasciitis. A nodular subcutaneous mass, which can sometimes involve the overlying dermis.
Nodular fasciitis. Myofibroblastic spindle cells with tissue culture growth pattern, myxoid stroma, and extravasated red blood cells are characteristic.
Nodular fasciitis. Scattered multinucleated giant cells and inflammatory cells can be seen.
Nodular fasciitis. Some tumours may have keloidal-like collagen bundles.
Nodular fasciitis. Schematic representation of the MYH9::USP6 fusion.

Nodular fasciitis. Nodularity, myxoid and cystic changes, and a few haemorrhagic areas are observed in this ill-defined tumour with fascicular architecture. The tumour cells contain ovoid to tapering nuclei, fine chromatin, small nucleoli, and amphophilic cytoplasm. Mitotic figures are seen.

definition: Plaque-like CD34-positive dermal fibroma is a benign tumour of fibroblastic origin characterized histologically by a band-like proliferation of bland CD34-positive spindle cells in the upper dermis, typically sparing the papillary dermis and adnexal structures.
clinical:
The tumour typically presents as a solitary, slowly growing, asymptomatic, well-demarcated, round to oval or medallion-shaped, erythematous to brown-yellow plaque, or (less often) as a nodular or protuberant growth, measuring several centimetres in diameter. The surface is often wrinkled, depressed, and pliable. Some proliferations can be pruritic and painful.

---

The tumour can be either a congenital or an acquired proliferation. It has a wide age distribution but most commonly develops in children and young adults and shows a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
microscopic: The tumour is distinguished by a band-like proliferation of variably cellular and fairly uniform fibroblasts in the upper and mid dermis, characteristically sparing the papillary dermis. Extension into the subcutaneous fatty tissue is rare. Some proliferations display a zonation pattern with perpendicular growth towards the surface and more storiform arrangements of tumour cells in the lower parts. Concentric growth of tumour cells around adnexal structures, vascular channels, and nerves is often seen. The tumour cells are bland, with small nuclei, inconspicuous nucleoli, and rare mitoses. Multiple dilated venules are present throughout the neoplasm. Elastic fibres are often fragmented and reduced in number. Immunohistochemistry The tumour cells are diffusely positive for CD34 and fascin. Staining for factor XIIIa is inconsistent. Differential diagnosis Plaque-like CD34 positive dermal fibroma must be distinguished from dermal dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, dermatomyofibroma, and fibroblastic connective tissue naevus.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: Plaque-like CD34-positive dermal fibroma is a benign tumour. Complete excision is curative. Recurrences have not been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: None
related_terminology: Acceptable: medallion-like dermal dendrocyte hamartoma.

media.legend: Plaque-like CD34-positive dermal fibroma. A flat, slightly indurated circumscribed tumour on the anterior aspect of the neck of a young boy.
Plaque-like CD34-positive dermal fibroma. Characteristic zonation of tumour cells, with perpendicular arrangement in the upper portion and horizontal arrangement in the deeper part.
Plaque-like CD34-positive dermal fibroma. CD34 staining reveals the characteristic fingerprint pattern of a fibroblastic tumour.

definition: Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma is a benign acquired lesion of fibrohistiocytic and vascular lineage.
clinical:
Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma presents as solitary or multiple smooth erythematous papules and nodules.

---

This relatively uncommon lesion arises in middle age. Some studies have demonstrated a female predisposition, whereas others have shown equal incidence between sexes.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Its pathogenesis has not fully been elucidated. Several mechanisms have been hypothesized, including a role for fibroblasts, ERα overexpression, and mast cells.
microscopic: Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma consists of a triad of multinucleated cells, stromal fibrosis, and vascular changes. The multinucleated cells are angulated and stellate, with elongated cytoplasmic extensions. They may be few in number and revealed by deeper tissue levels. Stromal fibrosis is often parallel to the epidermis. Increased numbers of small-calibre vessels within the papillary and reticular dermis show thickened walls with prominent endothelial cells. Immunohistochemistry The multinucleated cells may express CD68 (variable) and factor XIIIa, yet they are generally negative for CD163, CD34, and factor VIII. The vascular proliferation is highlighted by conventional vascular markers (CD31, CD34, ERG, factor VIII). Differential diagnosis Fibrous papule (angiofibroma) of the nose is a close mimic but affects the head and neck and shows concentric perifollicular fibrosis. The atrophic pattern of dermatofibroma can resemble multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma but shows storiform rather than parallel fibrosis and favours the lower extremities. Telangiectasia macularis eruptiva perstans can also display multinucleated stromal cells but usually presents with eosinophils and increased mast cells. Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma should be distinguished from reactive multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma–like changes that may present as a focal histological finding or within another dermatological lesion.
staging: None
prognosis_and_prediction: Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma is a benign lesion that may recur, or it may spontaneously resolve in rare instances.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma. Odd-shaped, angulated multinucleate cells with abundant long cytoplasmic extensions populate the dermis. Blood vessels are telangiectatic, with slightly hyalinized wall and prominent endothelial cells.
Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma. Superficial papillary and reticular dermal vessels, which are mildly increased in number, are telangiectatic with stromal fibrosis parallel to the epidermis.

Multinucleate cell angiohistiocytoma. Superficial papillary and reticular dermal vessels, which are mildly increased in number, are telangiectatic with stromal fibrosis parallel to the epidermis. Odd-shaped, angulated multinucleate cells with abundant long cytoplasmic extensions populate the dermis. Blood vessels are telangiectatic, with slightly hyalinized wall and prominent endothelial cells.

definition: Dermatomyofibroma (DM) is a rare benign cutaneous mesenchymal neoplasm of fibroblastic/myofibroblastic differentiation.
clinical:
DM manifests as an asymptomatic, erythematous, reddish-brown or hypopigmented, longstanding or slowly growing, slightly indurated, flat, plaque-like lesion, or (less often) a nodule. Linear and annular presentations have also been reported. Rarely, the tumour may be congenital, multicentric, or of considerable size.

---

DM most frequently occurs in young females. DM in young children is rare.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

DM is a myofibroblastic tumour.
microscopic: Throughout the dermis, there is a horizontally oriented plaque-like arrangement (except in the deep dermis / subcutis where the arrangement is usually perpendicular to the epidermis) of densely packed slender bundles and long fascicles of cytologically bland fusiform spindle cells showing fibroblastic and myofibroblastic differentiation. The epidermis is generally unaffected. The papillary dermis is typically spared. The adnexal structures are surrounded by the tumour but are usually not disrupted. Elastic fibres are preserved or even slightly increased. DM extension into the superficial subcutis is rare. Immunohistochemistry DM usually expresses vimentin and calponin, while α-SMA and CD34 show variable positivity. Desmin, h-caldesmon, and S100 are negative. Differential diagnosis The main differential diagnosis includes dermatofibroma and plaque-stage dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Unlike in dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, there is no COL1A1::PDGFB rearrangement.
prognosis_and_prediction: DM is a benign tumour. Recurrences are rare even after incomplete excision.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The absence of COL1A1::PDGFB rearrangement may help in challenging cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: plaque-like dermal fibromatosis.

media.legend: Dermatomyofibroma. A dermal neoplasm composed of bundles of myofibroblasts arranged parallel to the epidermis except in the deep dermis/subcutis, where the arrangement is usually perpendicular.
Dermatomyofibroma. Bland myofibroblasts arranged in bundles are seen. Note the sparing of adnexal structures.
Dermatomyofibroma. The tumour cells may be positive for SMA, particularly in early lesions.
Dermatomyofibroma. A plaque-like proliferation of delicate spindle cells.

definition: Cutaneous myxoma (superficial angiomyxoma) is a benign multilobular lesion composed mostly of myxoid material with an arborizing vascular network and spindled or stellate cells.
clinical:
Cutaneous myxomas manifest as slow-growing nodules with a translucent appearance due to abundant mucin content. In patients with multiple lesions, the possibility of Carney complex should be investigated. The syndrome is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and consists of the association of endocrine hyperactivity (Cushing syndrome, testicular tumours, and acromegaly); spotty skin pigmentation; epithelioid blue naevi; psammomatous melanotic schwannoma; and multiple cutaneous, cardiac, and mammary myxomas. Multiple cutaneous myxomas in the absence of any other anomalies associated with Carney complex have also been described.

---

Cutaneous myxoma is an uncommon neoplasm occurring mostly in adults. The sex distribution is equal. Most cases are sporadic, but multiple lesions can arise in the setting of Carney complex.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. About 45–65% of Carney complex–associated cases are related to mutation of PRKAR1A, encoding a regulatory subunit of PKA. Additional genetic studies have identified alternative genetic pathways, including mutation of MYH8, which encodes perinatal myosin.

---

Unknown
microscopic: Cutaneous myxoma (superficial angiomyxoma) manifests as a well-circumscribed multilobular lesion with abundant vascular component. Collagenous septa compartmentalize the lesion, and the vascular component is more prominent at the periphery. Each lobule is composed of abundant myxoid material, with sparse cellularity. The stromal cells have a fusiform or stellate morphology. Adnexal induction in the epidermis covering the lesion is frequently seen in myxomas of patients with Carney complex. A prominence of scattered neutrophils in the stroma is also characteristic of cutaneous myxoma. Immunohistochemistry There is positivity for α-SMA. The spindle and stellate cells are negative for CD34, S100, factor XIIIa, CD57, CD68, and desmin. Immunohistochemically, loss of expression of PRKAR1A has been found in sporadic superficial angiomyxomas. Differential diagnosis Focal mucinosis lacks the cellular and vascular components seen in cutaneous myxoma. Cutaneous myxomas may involve the genital area; therefore, the histopathological differential diagnosis must be established with aggressive angiomyxoma. Aggressive angiomyxoma is a larger lesion that extends deeply to subcutaneous structures and displays a vascular component characterized by variably sized vessels, from small thin-walled capillaries to large thick-walled vessels with perivascular hyalinization.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cutaneous myxomas are benign neoplasms. Simple excision is curative, although persistence after incomplete surgical resection has been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: In cases associated with Carney complex, there are mutations of the PRKAR1A gene.
related_terminology: Acceptable: angiomyxoma.

media.legend: Cutaneous myxoma. Scanning magnification showing a papulonodular lesion with a myxoid appearance.
Cutaneous myxoma. Higher magnification showing myxoid material, with sparse cellularity. The stromal cells have fusiform or stellate morphology.

definition: Superficial acral fibromyxoma is a benign fibroblastic neoplasm typically restricted to acral sites with a marked predilection for the periungual region of the digits and potential for local recurrence.
clinical:
Acral fibromyxomas are slowly growing and often painful, and they range in size from 10 to 50 mm (mean: ~20 mm). Associated nail deformities and lytic lesions of underlying bone may be seen.

---

The age range is wide, but most cases occur in middle-aged adults, with a male predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

RB1 deletions have been reported.
macroscopic: Acral fibromyxomas are dome-shaped, polypoid, or verrucous, often with a lobulated appearance. They have a firm to soft consistency and poorly defined borders.
microscopic: Acral fibromyxomas are lobulated dermal and subcutaneous lesions, sometimes with an epidermal collarette. Most have infiltrative borders and the underlying bone may be involved. Most are relatively hypocellular, composed of bland spindled to stellate cells in a loose growth pattern that can be vaguely fascicular to storiform. Tumour cells are embedded in a variably collagenous to myxoid stroma, and a thin-walled vasculature may be present in myxoid areas. Multinucleated cells may be present. Mitotic figures are rare. A subset may have increased cellularity. Cartilaginous and osseous metaplasia is rare. Immunohistochemistry The tumour cells are positive for CD34, CD99, and nestin and may express EMA and SMA in a minority; they are negative for MUC4 and BCL2. Loss of RB1 expression is seen in most tumours. Differential diagnosis The stromal component of onychomatricoma is identical to that of acral fibromyxoma, but acral fibromyxoma lacks an epithelial component. Myxoid neurofibroma is less cellular and the tumour cells are positive for S100. Myxoid dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans is very rare on the digits and lacks the collagen component, and the tumour cells display a storiform pattern.
prognosis_and_prediction: These lesions are benign, but recurrence occurs in as many as 22% of cases. Metastases have not been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: The tumours show deletion of RB1, but this is not required for diagnosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: digital fibromyxoma; acral fibromyxoma. Not recommended: cellular digital fibroma.

media.legend: Superficial acral fibromyxoma. A lobular architecture is seen, with the tumour infiltrating into the subcutis and involving underlying bone.
Superficial acral fibromyxoma. A prominent myxoid stroma is observed.
Superficial acral fibromyxoma. A tumour with more collagenous stroma and a vaguely fascicular growth pattern.
Superficial acral fibromyxoma. A tumour with a more storiform growth pattern and conspicuous vasculature.
Cellular acral fibromyxoma. Acral fibromyxoma with increased cellularity.
Superficial acral fibromyxoma. The tumour cells are positive for CD34.
Superficial acral fibromyxoma. There is a fascicular growth of uniform spindle cells in a fibromyxoid stroma. Note the absence of cytological atypia.
Superficial acral fibromyxoma. The tumour cells show a loss of RB1 expression.

definition: Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumour (PFHT) is a plexiform tumour within the dermis and subcutis, showing a biphasic morphology characterized by a nodular growth of histiocytoid cells and fascicles of myofibroblastic spindle cells.
clinical:
The tumours present as slowly enlarging nodules and plaques, typically measuring about 20–30 mm.

---

Children, adolescents, and young adults are most commonly affected, with a reported median age ranging from 14.5 to 20 years (overall age range: 1–77 years). There may be a female predilection.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

There are no known consistent, reproducible molecular signatures. Single case reports have documented cytogenetic findings that include 46,X,del(X)(q13)/46,XX, 46,XY,t(4;15)(q21;q15), and 46,XY,-6,-8, del(4)(q25q31),del(20)(q11.2) with additional der (8) and (p22).
macroscopic: PFHT is a tan-white, firm, small to medium-sized cannonball-like or plaque-like tumour at the dermal to subcutaneous interface that appears to be entirely subcutaneous and rarely involves superficial skeletal muscle.
microscopic: PFHT is a fibroblastic-fibrohistiocytic, dermal–subcutaneous interface tumour composed of small to medium-sized, cannonball-like nodules of whorling, histiocyte-rich foci with osteoclast-like giant cells and/or fascicular spindled myofibroblastic fascicles in the subcutis. PFHT has a plexiform to poorly circumscribed architecture. Three histological patterns are based on the predominant cell type: myofibroblastic, histiocytoid, and mixed. Features of haemorrhage (to which the osteoclast-like giant cells are attracted), myxoid change, chronic inflammation (mostly in the pure myofibroblastic pattern), fat or adnexal trapping with perineural or peri-Pacinian corpuscle growth, stromal hyalinization, rare metaplastic bone, and pseudogranulomatous patterns may be observed. Mitotic activity is low, and cytological atypia, vascular invasion, and atypical mitoses are exceedingly rare. Immunohistochemistry There is expression of SMA in the spindled myofibroblastic foci and CD68 in the histiocytic cannonballs with osteoclast-type giant cells. The tumours are generally negative for CD34, desmin, EMA, keratin, and S100. Differential diagnosis This tumour can be confused with other dermal or subcutaneous reactive or neoplastic processes, including granulomata, fibromatosis, lipofibromatosis, myofibromatosis, fibrous hamartoma of infancy, nodular fasciitis, giant cell tumour of soft parts, so-called plexiform myofibroblastoma (which may be identical to pure myofibroblastic PFHT), and cellular neurothekeoma.
staging: Not applicable
prognosis_and_prediction: PFHT is a low-grade malignant tumour with indolent biological behaviour in most cases. Local recurrences are frequent (12–37.5%), but metastatic spread is distinctly uncommon, with locoregional lymph node metastases and distant metastases to the lungs observed in 2.4% and 1.9% of patients, respectively. Death from disease is exceptional.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumour. The tumour is located in dermis and subcutaneous adipose tissue and shows a plexiform growth composed of small cellular nodules.
Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumour. The small nodules are composed of bland and uniform histiocytoid cells with admixed osteoclast-like giant cells and haemorrhage.

Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumour. A fascicular growth of uniform spindle cells may be an additional or the predominant finding in a subset of these tumours. Also note the mitotic figure (on the left side of the field).

definition: Inclusion body fibromatosis is a benign myofibroblastic tumour characterized by eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions and the potential for local recurrence.
clinical:
Patients with the classic subtype present with an asymptomatic, dome-shaped/polypoid cutaneous nodule, typically no larger than 20 mm. Synchronous and/or metachronous lesions occur, sometimes affecting multiple digits, but simultaneous involvement of both the fingers and the toes is rare. Patients with the non-classic subtype present with solitary masses/nodules.

---

The classic subtype accounts for 2% of paediatric fibroblastic tumours. More than 80% of cases present by 3 years of age, with about 30% found at birth. No sex predilection exists. Rare cases occur in adults.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Unknown
macroscopic: The tumours are firm to rubbery, smooth-surfaced protuberant/polypoid dermal nodules. The cut surface is fibrous and off-white to grey in colour.
microscopic: Spindled cells have lightly eosinophilic cytoplasm and an elongated, cytologically bland nucleus, with low mitotic activity. Cells proliferate in whorls, interlacing short fascicles, or storiform arrays within a collagenous dermis, and they characteristically grow perpendicularly to the epidermis and around adnexa, occasionally infiltrating deeper tissues. A variable number of cells harbour a rounded, pale pink, intracytoplasmic (frequently paranuclear), 1.5–24 μm inclusion highlighted by trichrome (red), phosphotungstic acid–haematoxylin (dark purple), and Movats (pink) stains. Immunohistochemistry Cells express vimentin, muscle actin(s) in a peripheral tram-track pattern, calponin, desmin, and CD99. Inclusions mark with calponin-1 and occasionally with caldesmon.
prognosis_and_prediction: Large series of classic cases report recurrence rates between 61% and 75%. Lower recurrence rates are documented after initial complete (preferably wide) excision. Current treatment options include function-preserving excision for symptomatic lesions and either intralesional steroid injection or clinical observation (as tumours may spontaneously regress) for asymptomatic lesions. Approximately 25% of non-classic tumours may recur.
cytology: Cytology preparations yield plump spindled cells with intracytoplasmic inclusions in a collagenous background.
related_terminology: Acceptable: infantile digital fibroma/fibromatosis; recurring digital fibrous tumour(s) of childhood; recurring digital fibroma(s) of childhood/infancy.
subtypes: Classic (digital) inclusion body fibromatosis; non-classic (extradigital) inclusion body fibromatosis

media.legend: Inclusion body fibromatosis. A single protuberant nodule with an erythematous surface on the lateral aspect of the distal fourth toe.
Inclusion body fibromatosis. Dome-shaped cellular dermal nodule composed of spindled cells arranged in short fascicles and whorls.
Inclusion body fibromatosis. Spindled cells surround dermal adnexa.
Inclusion body fibromatosis. Spindled cells directly beneath the epidermis, with fascicles growing perpendicular to the surface.
Inclusion body fibromatosis. High-power view demonstrates spindled cells with elongated, cytologically bland nuclei and rounded, eosinophilic paranuclear inclusions that often indent the nucleus.
Inclusion body fibromatosis. Gömöri trichrome stain highlights the intracytoplasmic inclusions (red).

definition: Superficial fibromatoses (palmar, plantar, and penile) are nodular, locally recurrent fibroblastic/myofibroblastic proliferations.
clinical:
Palmar fibromatosis develops gradually and manifests as small, painless coalescing nodules forming cords or bands in the subcutaneous tissue and underlying fascial plane. Plantar fibromatosis is often asymptomatic and does not cause contractures, but pain may be present after periods of standing or walking. Penile fibromatosis manifests as firm nodules or plaques, causes abnormal curvature of the penis, and may elicit pain during erection and intercourse.

---

Palmar fibromatosis shows a prevalence of 1–2% in the population, affecting mainly adults, with a male predominance (M:F ratio: 3:1). Prevalence increases with age and is higher in populations of northern European descent, reaching 30% in age groups > 60 years. Plantar fibromatosis is less common and affects younger patients, including the paediatric population, where it shows a female predominance. Penile fibromatosis affects predominantly White populations of middle-aged adults, with a mean age of 55 years.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. There is no association with desmoid fibromatosis. Associations with microtraumas, epilepsy, diabetes mellitus, smoking, and alcohol abuse have been suggested. The development of palmar/plantar fibromatosis in relatives of paediatric patients suggests a familial causation.

---

Although the pathogenesis of superficial fibromatosis is driven at least in part by the WNT/β-catenin signalling pathway, this tumour lacks the CTNNB1 and APC mutations characteristic of desmoid fibromatosis.
macroscopic: The tumours are small, poorly defined, 5–30 mm nodules, intimately associated with a tendon or aponeurosis and extending into subcutaneous tissue. The cut surface is firm, greyish-yellow or white (depending on the collagen content), and slightly whorled.
microscopic: Superficial fibromatoses are characterized by three phases of growth (proliferative, involutional, and late stage). The proliferative stage consists of a cellular, bland proliferation of long fascicles of fibroblasts/myofibroblasts blending into tendons and aponeuroses. Neoplastic cells are elongated cells with tapering vesicular nuclei, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and pale eosinophilic cytoplasm. Mitotic figures may be increased, especially in children. In the background, a collagenous matrix (which increases in the late stages) is seen. Rarely, multinucleated giant cells and osseous or cartilaginous metaplasia are seen. Immunohistochemistry Neoplastic cells may be positive for SMA and focally for desmin. Rare cases display nuclear expression of β-catenin despite the absence of CTNNB1 or APC mutations Differential diagnosis Hyperplastic scars may resemble fibromatosis but tend to be non-infiltrative and lack β-catenin expression. Sclerotic fibromas have plywood-type collagen and usually express CD34. Nodular fasciitis has a more myxoid background resembling tissue culture.
prognosis_and_prediction: Superficial fibromatoses are benign. There is a high rate of local recurrence, which correlates with the extent of surgical intervention.
related_terminology: Acceptable: for palmar fibromatosis: Dupuytren disease/contracture; for plantar fibromatosis: Ledderhose disease; for penile fibromatosis: Peyronie disease.

media.legend: Superficial fibromatosis. Low-power view showing a characteristic multinodular growth pattern.
Superficial fibromatosis. Tumour cells are arranged in parallel fascicles separated by a collagenous stroma.
Superficial fibromatosis. The tumour is composed of spindle cells with bland ovoid nuclei with open chromatin and small nucleoli.
Superficial fibromatosis. Late-stage lesions are hypocellular and consist mostly of densely hyalinized fibrous tissue.

definition: Fibro-osseous tumour (FOT) of digits, arising in the soft tissues of the digits, is a localized, self-limiting, benign neoplasm composed of proliferating spindle cells and osteoblasts.
clinical:
FOT of the digits is a rapidly growing and often painful lesion. Random calcifications are often present on imaging studies. Over time, the lesion becomes hard and well demarcated.

---

The lesions have a broad age distribution, from infancy to late adulthood, but most patients are young adults.
pathogenesis:
A history of trauma is often elicited.

---

USP6 fusion genes are present in FOT. USP6 fusion genes are also encountered in nodular fasciitis, a tumour with overlapping morphology.
macroscopic: FOT is ovoid, 10–30 mm, pink-tan, gritty, and circumscribed.
microscopic: The lesion has areas resembling nodular fasciitis with bone in various stages of formation. It is hypercellular and composed of proliferating spindle cells that are oriented randomly or in short intersecting fascicles. The spindle cells have eosinophilic cytoplasm and plump fusiform nuclei with fine chromatin and conspicuous nucleoli. Normal mitoses may be numerous. The stroma is richly vascular and myxoid, and it contains fibrin, extravasated erythrocytes, scattered lymphocytes, and osteoclast-like giant cells. The spindle cells merge with poorly defined trabeculae and sheets of unmineralized woven bone that are rimmed by prominent osteoblasts with amphophilic cytoplasm and harbour large osteocytes. Differential diagnosis FOT and myositis ossificans are histologically similar, except that in the former there is usually no zonation pattern and the bone is located randomly throughout the tumour.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis is excellent; recurrence after simple excision is extremely rare.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular studies for USP6 rearrangement may be useful in the appropriate clinicopathological context.
related_terminology: Not recommended: fibro-osseous pseudotumour of digits.

media.legend: Fibro-osseous pseudotumour of digits. The lesion presents as a well-circumscribed subcuticular mass.

definition: Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus (FCTN) is a benign dermal-based mesenchymal lesion of fibroblastic/myofibroblastic lineage composed of short intersecting fascicles of bland spindled cells.
clinical:
FCTN typically manifests as a solitary, slowly growing, painless plaque-like or nodular skin lesion. Some agminate cases have been described, as well as atrophic plaques and exophytic tumours.

---

FCTN has a slight female predominance and usually affects young patients (median age: 10 years). Congenital cases have been described, especially on the trunk, as large infiltrated plaques.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

KHDRBS1::NTRK3 rearrangement has been reported in 1 case.
microscopic: FCTN is a poorly circumscribed lesion localized in the reticular dermis and commonly extending into the superficial subcutis. It is composed of bland spindle-shaped and ovoid cells arranged in a short intersecting fascicular pattern and entrapping appendages that are preserved. Cellularity is variable. Mitotic activity is absent. A storiform pattern may be observed. Epidermal papillomatosis and ectopic dermal adipose tissue are commonly observed. Elastic fibres may be decreased in number. Immunohistochemistry Expression of CD34 and SMA is described. Differential diagnosis FCTN overlaps clinically and morphologically with plaque-like CD34-positive dermal fibroma and dermatomyofibroma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Neither local recurrence nor distant metastasis have yet been reported. Spontaneous partial regression has been reported.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. Same lesion shown in <<34144>> at higher magnification. Note that adnexal structures are well preserved, and some adipocytes are entrapped in the tumour. Here cells are arranged in a storiform manner.

Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. Mild papillomatosis of the epidermis and a proliferation of bland spindled cells in the dermis are observed. Note the presence of adipocytes in the reticular dermis.

Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. The spindled cells are arranged in fascicles and have bland, undulating nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasmic processes. Scattered adipocytes in the reticular dermis are a frequent finding.
Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. Intersecting fascicles of bland spindled cells are seen.
Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. Atrophic congenital plaque on the back.
Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. Foci of short bland ovoid cells in the reticular dermis are seen, especially around the eccrine glands, sparing them (haematoxylin eosin saffron stain).
Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. The lesion is positive for CD34.
Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. Short spindle or ovoid cells are observed (haematoxylin eosin saffron stain).
Fibroblastic connective tissue naevus. Cellular infiltration of both the reticular dermis and the subcutis. Spindle-shaped and ovoid cells are arranged in a short intersecting fascicular pattern.

definition: Fibrous papule is a benign lesion, presumably of fibroblastic origin, that most commonly occurs on the nose or central face.
clinical:
Fibrous papule typically manifests as a dome-shaped, sessile papule that is solitary and sporadic in the vast majority of cases. Multiple (syndromic) fibrous papules may be associated with tuberous sclerosis, and less commonly with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome or multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. There is a tendency for multiple fibrous papules to occur in early childhood in tuberous sclerosis, whereas those associated with Birt–Hogg–Dubé syndrome or multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 are usually seen in adults.

---

Fibrous papules are most commonly seen in middle-aged adults.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Multiple fibrous papules in tuberous sclerosis are thought to occur due to constitutional activation of the mTOR pathway due to germline mutations in TSC1 or TSC2 (tuberous sclerosis), and similar mechanisms have been suggested for the pathogenesis of sporadic fibrous papules.
macroscopic: Fibrous papules manifest as well-circumscribed papular lesions with a tan or white cut surface.
microscopic: Classic fibrous papule has a dome-shaped configuration with dilated blood vessels within the dermis, surrounded by fibrotic or collagenized stroma with spindle-shaped or stellate fibroblasts. The overlying epidermis may show melanocytic hyperplasia. Histological patterns of fibrous papule may be hypercellular, pigmented, pleomorphic, clear cell, granular cell, epithelioid, or inflammatory. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes fibroma, melanocytic naevus (pigmented or epithelioid pattern), atypical fibroxanthoma (hypercellular or pleomorphic pattern), balloon cell naevus or xanthoma (clear cell pattern), and granular cell tumour (granular pattern).
prognosis_and_prediction: Fibrous papule is a benign lesion.
related_terminology: Acceptable: angiofibroma.

media.legend: Fibrous papule. A papular shape of a classic fibrous papule.
Fibrous papule. Hyalinized collagen is seen in the upper dermis, with dilated blood vessels and stellate fibroblasts.
Fibrous papule. Higher-power view of the stellate fibroblasts and the dilated blood vessels in the upper dermis.
Fibrous papule. Some lesions are more cellular.
Fibrous papule. Some lesions have a clear cell pattern.
Fibrous papule. A dome-shaped dermal lesion, with dilated blood vessels, that may display high cellularity.
Fibrous papule. Cellular pattern.
Fibrous papule. Epithelioid pattern.
Fibrous papule. Classic features of a fibrous papule.
Fibrous papule. Clear cell pattern.

definition: Desmoplastic fibroblastoma is a benign soft tissue tumour characterized by stellate fibroblasts in a fibromyxoid background.
clinical:
This tumour is a painless, solitary, slow-growing mass and predominantly subcutaneous, although it may involve skeletal muscle.

---

Desmoplastic fibroblastomas are rare. They predominantly affect adults (median age: 50–60 years) and show a male predominance.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Desmoplastic fibroblastomas have been reported to have translocations involving 11q12, including t(2;11)(q31;q12) and t(11;17)(q12;p11.2). The FOSL1 gene is located nearby (at 11q13.1), and the FOSL1 protein is overexpressed in these tumours.
macroscopic: Desmoplastic fibroblastoma manifests as a circumscribed, firm mass with a white-grey cut surface. It can be as large as 200 mm.
microscopic: Desmoplastic fibroblastomas are hypocellular tumours with bland, spindled to stellate fibroblasts and a fibromyxoid to delicate collagenous background. Immunohistochemistry is nonspecific; desmin, keratin, and CD34 are negative. The differential diagnosis includes desmoid-type fibromatosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: The behaviour of this tumour is benign, with no local recurrence after excision.
related_terminology: Acceptable: collagenous fibroma.

media.legend: Desmoplastic fibroblastoma. Hypocellular proliferation of distinctive, widely spaced, spindled to stellate fibroblasts in a fibromyxoid stroma.
Desmoplastic fibroblastoma. Hypocellular hyalinization with bland stellate fibroblasts.

definition: Elastofibroma is a benign soft tissue tumour characterized by abnormal elastic fibres, bland fibroblasts, and myxoid stroma.
clinical:
These tumours are slow-growing, typically solitary, and usually asymptomatic, but they can cause pain, limitation of movement, or scapular snapping/impingement.

---

Elastofibroma most commonly affects elderly adults, with a female predominance.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Some cases run in families; in one series, one third of the patients reported a familial history.

---

Elastofibromas have a variety of chromosomal abnormalities. Copy gains (including gains of Xq), alterations to chromosome 1, and t(8;12)(q22;q24.3) and/or t(2;19) and (X;1) rearrangements have been found in some of the cases.
macroscopic: Elastofibromas are poorly defined firm masses ranging in size from 50 to 100 mm. The cut surface is variegated grey and white, with small areas of adipose tissue.
microscopic: Elastofibromas are large and have poorly defined borders. They are often hypocellular with degenerative collagen fibres that are fragmented, thickened, and globular; these can be highlighted with Verhoeff elastic staining. Variable proportions of bland uniform small spindle cells, aggregates of mature adipocytes, and myxoid stroma are present.
prognosis_and_prediction: Elastofibroma is benign, and simple excision is curative.
cytology: There are bland spindle cells, fragmented degenerative collagen fibres (braid-like and globular) and mature adipocytes.
related_terminology: Acceptable: elastofibroma dorsi.

media.legend: Elastofibroma. Degenerative fragmented collagen fibres with bland spindle cells.
Elastofibroma. Elastin stain highlights fragmented, thickened, and globular collagen fibres.

definition: Pleomorphic fibroma is a benign, often polypoid, fibroblastic dermal neoplasm characterized by bizarre pleomorphic cells.
clinical:
The tumours are painless, single, slow-growing, fleshy polyps or papules.

---

This fibroma occurs in middle-aged adults.
pathogenesis:
Pleomorphic fibromas, when multiple and in young patients, may be associated with a genetic cancer syndrome involving TP53 (Li–Fraumeni syndrome).

---

These tumours have RB1 deletion and are negative for MDM2 amplification. Cases associated with Li–Fraumeni syndrome harbour TP53 germline mutations.
macroscopic: Pleomorphic fibromas are small, dome-shaped to polypoid, and relatively well circumscribed.
microscopic: These tumours are hypocellular and composed of dense, haphazardly arranged collagen bundles admixed with spindle cells and large pleomorphic cells that have hyperchromatic multilobulated nuclei with smudgy chromatin. Immunohistochemistry They are positive for CD34 and show loss of RB1 expression. There is aberrant p53 expression in Li–Fraumeni syndrome–associated cases. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes superficial atypical lipomatous tumour, pleomorphic lipoma, and atypical fibroxanthoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: These are benign tumours, with rare recurrence.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Pleomorphic fibroma. A dome-shaped papule with stellate hyperchromatic fibroblasts.
Pleomorphic fibroma. Collagen bundles admixed with atypical fibroblasts demonstrating degenerative nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromasia.
Pleomorpic fibroma. Lesion comprised of thickened collagen bundles with scattered cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic and pleomorphic nuclei.

definition: Gardner fibroma is a benign fibroblastic tumour composed of thick, haphazardly arranged collagen bundles, usually occurring in children and often associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
clinical:
Gardner fibromas are typically solitary but rarely multiple.

---

Most cases occur in children (especially boys); Gardner fibroma is uncommon in adults.
pathogenesis:
There is an association with Gardner syndrome. They are often associated with desmoid-type fibromatosis.

---

FAP-associated tumours have germline mutations in APC.
macroscopic: These are poorly defined tumours with a plaque-like growth pattern, rubbery consistency, and white cut surface. If the lesion contains an apparent fat component, the cut surface may show yellow soft areas. Tumours as large as 120 mm can be seen.
microscopic: These tumours are composed of dense collagen with clefts and cracks and bland spindle cells. Entrapped fat and mast cells can be seen. A helpful diagnostic feature is entrapment of adjacent adipose tissue and neurovascular bundles at the edge of the lesion. Immunohistochemistry β-catenin is positive, and nuclear accumulation of β-catenin is often observed, particularly in cases associated with FAP. CD34 is almost always positive, whereas SMA is negative. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes nuchal-type fibroma and desmoid-type fibromatosis. Some authors have proposed that a subset of nuchal-type fibromas are in fact Gardner fibromas.
prognosis_and_prediction: Gardner fibroma is a benign tumour with a rate of recurrence as high as 50%. Some patients may develop desmoid-type fibromatosis. Given the close association between Gardner fibroma and FAP, a diagnosis of Gardner fibroma should prompt screening of the family for FAP.
related_terminology: Acceptable: Gardner-associated fibroma. Not recommended: desmoid precursor lesion.

media.legend: Gardner fibroma. Dense collagen with clefts and cracks and bland spindle cells.

definition: Nuchal-type fibroma is a benign fibroblastic tumour characterized by abundant thick collagen bundles, most commonly arising in the posterior neck.
clinical:
Patients typically present with a long history of a solitary, superficial to deep, painless swelling; rarely, lesions can be multiple.

---

Nuchal-type fibroma has a male predilection and a peak incidence between the third and fifth decades of life.
pathogenesis:
There is an association with diabetes; in one series, 11 of 25 patients with nuchal-type fibroma (44%) also had diabetes. Some tumours are associated with Gardner syndrome.

---

A few tested cases were found to have APC mutations. One case had a mutation in MUTYH, which encodes a base excision repair protein and has also been implicated in familial adenomatous polyposis.
macroscopic: Nuchal-type fibromas are firm, poorly circumscribed masses, 10–80 mm in size, with a white cut surface.
microscopic: Nuchal-type fibromas are poorly circumscribed, hypocellular, and characterized by thick collagen fibres and small fibroblasts. Entrapped islands of fat, skeletal muscle, and nerves with traumatic neuroma–like changes can be seen. This feature is usually absent from Gardner fibroma, which is often otherwise indistinguishable from nuchal-type fibroma. Elastic fibres and small blood vessels are present between the collagen fibres. Immunohistochemistry Immunohistochemistry is not specific; the tumours are negative for desmin, actin, S100, and EMA. There may be nuclear expression of β-catenin. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes desmoid-type fibromatosis and Gardner fibroma (which may be related).
prognosis_and_prediction: Nuchal-type fibroma is benign. Excision is curative and local recurrence is rare.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Some cases may have mutations in APC or MUTYH; however, mutation analyses are usually unnecessary for the diagnosis.
related_terminology: Acceptable: nuchal fibroma. Not recommended: collagenosis nuchae.

media.legend: Nuchal-type fibroma. Thickened collagen fibres and small fibroblasts with entrapped fat.
Nuchal-type fibroma. The lesional cells are bland spindled fibroblasts. Extension into skeletal muscle is common.
Nuchal-type fibroma. The tumour is paucicellular and contains thick, haphazardly arranged collagen fibres entrapping adipose tissue.

definition: Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma (CAF) is a benign, locally infiltrative fibroblastic tumour with chondro-osseous foci, predominantly occurring in the distal extremities of children.
clinical:
CAF typically presents as a solitary painless mass. Multiple lesions are exceptional.

---

CAF is rare. It shows a predilection for male children, although adults can also (more rarely) be affected.
pathogenesis:
The etiology is unknown. Calcifying aponeurotic–like lesions have been reported in a family with Albright hereditary osteodystrophy.

---

CAFs have a recurrent translocation involving the promoter region of FN1 (exon 23, 27, or 42) on 2q35 and EGF (exon 17 or 19) on 4q25, resulting in the aberrant overexpression of EGF, which can be detected immunohistochemically. This fusion can also be seen in a subset of lipofibromatosis cases, which may represent CAF lacking calcifications.
macroscopic: CAF presents as a poorly defined mass measuring < 30 mm, with a firm consistency and variable calcifications.
microscopic: CAF is infiltrative and composed of bland spindled cells arranged in parallel fascicles with fibrous stroma. Chondroid foci can be seen, with or without calcification, surrounded by epithelioid cells. Chondroid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and calcific debris may be seen. Immunohistochemistry There is variable expression of MSA, SMA, CD99, S100, and CD68. Rare cases also label for CD34, CD57, PR, and EMA. β-catenin is negative. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes infantile digital fibromatosis (inclusion body fibromatosis), fibromatosis, and lipofibromatosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: CAF is benign, but the rate of local recurrence may be as high as 50%, and recurrence may occur years after initial excision. Children aged < 5 years are at higher risk of local recurrence. Rare metastasis and malignant (fibrosarcomatous) transformation have been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Detection of FN1::EGF fusion may be helpful in challenging cases.
related_terminology: Acceptable: juvenile aponeurotic fibroma; aponeurotic fibroma.

media.legend: Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma. Spindle cells arranged in fascicles surround areas of calcification containing epithelioid and chondroid cells and occasional multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cells.
Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma. A resection specimen showing an ill-defined greyish-white lesion with a gritty consistency.
Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma. The infiltrative spindle cell component is reminiscent of fibromatosis.
Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma is characterized by bland spindle cells and nodular zones of calcification.
Calcifying aponeurotic fibroma. Proliferation of spindled or epithelioid fibroblasts that tend to palisade around areas of calcification in a dense collagenous background.

definition: Sclerotic fibroma is a benign cutaneous fibrous tumour with a prominent storiform pattern and clefting. The tumours can be sporadic or associated with Cowden syndrome.
clinical:
Tumours are solitary or multiple, typically slow-growing, longstanding, painless, white to skin-coloured papules or nodules.

---

Sclerotic fibroma has a predilection for middle-aged adults. Cases associated with Cowden syndrome occur predominantly in men, while sporadic cases occur predominantly in women.
pathogenesis:
Sclerotic fibroma (in particular when multiple) has been associated with Cowden syndrome.

---

Tumours that arise in association with Cowden syndrome have loss of PTEN (10q23.3), resulting in loss of its expression.
macroscopic: Sclerotic fibroma typically appears as small, flesh-coloured papules or nodules of 5–30 mm in size.
