microscopic: Sclerotic fibromas are polypoid, well-circumscribed, hypocellular lesions with abundant collagen with plywood-like clefting, admixed with banal small spindle cells arranged in a storiform pattern. Myxoid change can be seen. The tumours express CD34. Differential diagnosis Dermatofibroma is the main differential diagnosis. Sclerosing dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans may also mimic a sclerotic fibroma, especially on partial biopsies.
prognosis_and_prediction: Sclerotic fibromas are benign.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Loss of PTEN by immunohistochemistry may suggest Cowden syndrome.
related_terminology: Acceptable: storiform collagenoma.

media.legend: Sclerotic fibroma. Hypocellular fibrotic tumour with a collagenous matrix in association with characteristic “plywood-like” clefting.
Sclerotic fibroma. Characteristic CD34-positive “fingerprint” pattern.

Sclerotic fibroma. Well-circumscribed neoplasm comprising bland spindle cells with characteristic thin, densely eosinophilic collagen bundles arranged in a storiform pattern or as parallel arrays (plywood pattern).

definition: Fibroma of tendon sheath is a rare benign tumour, presumably of (myo)fibroblastic origin, that arises in the tenosynovial soft tissue, usually attached to a tendon, and occurs predominantly in the upper extremities.
clinical:
Most tumours present as an asymptomatic to mildly painful, small (< 20 mm), slow-growing, and solitary mass, although multiple nodules have also been reported.

---

Fibroma of tendon sheath is rare, with a predilection to occur in middle-aged men.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

These tumours have been found to have gene fusions involving USP6 and a variety of partners, including PKM, RCC1, ASPN, COL1A1, COL3A1, MYH9, MIR22HG, CTNNB1, SPARC, CAP1, EMP1, CYTOR (LINC00152), NR1D1, RAB1A, and TNC. They may be a tenosynovial form of nodular fasciitis.
macroscopic: Fibroma of tendon sheath is well circumscribed, with a lobulated mass, a uniform grey to white cut surface, and occasional myxoid to cystic change.
microscopic: Fibroma of tendon sheath is composed of small to medium-sized bland fibroblastic spindle and stellate cells arranged in fascicles or a storiform pattern, set within a dense fibrocollagenous hyalinized matrix with slit-like spaces and dilated vascular channels. Some myxoid change, extravasated red blood cells, mononuclear inflammatory cells, and (rarely) giant cells can be seen. Cellular areas may also be present. Tumours with unusual histological findings such as a palisading growth pattern, epithelioid cells, and osteoclast-like multinucleated giant cells may have PKM or ASPN as a gene fusion partner. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes nodular fasciitis, myofibroma, and benign fibrous histiocytoma.
prognosis_and_prediction: Fibroma of tendon sheath is benign but recurs locally in about 25% of cases.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: USP6 rearrangement may support diagnosis in challenging cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: tenosynovial fibroma.

media.legend: Fibroma of tendon sheath. Sharply circumscribed hypocellular tumour with a hyalinized matrix containing slit-like spaces and blood vessels.
Fibroma of tendon sheath. Bland fibroblasts and slit-like capillary vessels within a hyalinized matrix.
Cellular fibroma of tendon sheath. Example showing foci of increased cellularity, with constituent spindle cells arrayed in a fascicular to storiform growth pattern resembling nodular fasciitis.

Fibroma of tendon sheath. A circumscribed, multinodular lesion composed of dense collagenous tissue with a variable number of plump grey epithelioid fibroblasts. There are admixed foamy macrophages, mild chronic inflammation, and haemosiderin; giant cells are not seen.

definition: Atypical lipomatous tumour (ALT) is an adipocytic tumour of borderline malignancy showing at least focal nuclear atypia in both adipocytes and stromal cells, and almost always associated with amplification of MDM2 and/or CDK4.
clinical:
ALT manifests as a nonspecific nodule or mass in the dermis or subcutis. Occasional exophytic tumours can mimic an acrochordon.

---

Primary cutaneous or dermal ALT is exceedingly rare; dermal involvement much more commonly constitutes extension from a more deeply situated tumour.
pathogenesis:
Nearly all are sporadic, but rare cases are associated with Li–Fraumeni syndrome.

---

ALT contains giant ring chromosomes containing amplified sequences from the 12q13-q15 region. These sequences contain the genes MDM2, CDK4, TSPAN31 (SAS), HMGA2 (HMGIC), and CPM, among others.
macroscopic: ALTs usually resemble mature fat, albeit with increased fibrous tissue and less well formed lobules.
microscopic: ALT is composed of a variable proportion of mature adipose tissue and irregular fibrous septa containing hyperchromatic stromal cells; rare lipoblasts may be seen. The number of pleomorphic cells and the degree of pleomorphism is variable. A rare finding in ALT is the presence of mature heterologous osseous or myogenic differentiation, which does not in itself imply dedifferentiation. Immunohistochemistry for MDM2 nuclear expression and FISH for MDM2 amplification are useful confirmatory tests, but FISH is more specific. A major pitfall is represented by nuclear MDM2 positivity in histiocytes in fat necrosis. ALTs associated with Li–Fraumeni syndrome are MDM2-negative; however, they express p53.
prognosis_and_prediction: Local recurrence is rare in dermal or subcutaneous ALT. Dedifferentiation is exceptional.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Detection of MDM2 (and/or CDK4) amplification distinguishes ALT from benign adipose tumours.
related_terminology: Acceptable: in the accessible soft tissues, atypical lipomatous tumour and well-differentiated liposarcoma are considered synonyms describing morphologically and genetically identical neoplasms; however, the term well-differentiated liposarcoma should not be used in superficial locations. Not recommended: atypical lipoma.

media.legend: Atypical lipomatous tumour. An irregular fibrous band containing enlarged, hyperchromatic stromal cells, the morphological hallmarks of atypical lipomatous tumour in any location.
Atypical lipomatous tumour. Adipocytes and stromal cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei in atypical lipomatous tumour. Lipoblasts are not required for this diagnosis.

definition: Pleomorphic liposarcoma is a pleomorphic, high-grade spindle cell sarcoma containing a variable number of pleomorphic lipoblasts. No areas of well-differentiated liposarcoma or other lines of differentiation are present.
clinical:
Patients present with a rapidly growing, nonspecific or occasionally fatty-appearing mass of the skin or subcutis.

---

Pleomorphic liposarcoma typically occurs in adults in later life.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Cytogenetic and molecular genetic studies have consistently identified multiple chromosomal copy-number and structural abnormalities similar to the findings in other high-grade pleomorphic sarcomas. Subcutaneous tumours have similar molecular abnormalities to deep-seated lesions. Like other pleomorphic sarcomas, pleomorphic liposarcomas show frequent loss of TP53, RB1, and NF1. Frequent gains in 1p21, 1q21-q22, 5p13-p15, and 7q22A are also seen.
macroscopic: Superficial pleomorphic liposarcomas are smaller than their deep-seated counterparts, which have a median size of 80–100 mm. Tumours may be circumscribed, but they are unencapsulated or poorly defined, infiltrative, and sometimes multinodular. The cut surface appears white to yellow, with frequent myxoid change and necrosis.
microscopic: The tumours contain a variable number of pleomorphic lipoblasts in a background of undifferentiated, high-grade, pleomorphic spindle cell sarcoma. Lipoblasts are required for the diagnosis, but they may be abundant or few in number. Rare cases consist of sheets of pleomorphic lipoblasts, sometimes showing epithelioid (epithelioid subtype) or small cell morphology. Myxofibrosarcoma-like histology may be infrequently seen in subcutaneous tumours. Differential diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes other pleomorphic spindle cell sarcomas that lack lipoblasts and other lipogenic tumours – mainly atypical lipomatous tumour and dedifferentiated liposarcoma (described in the WHO classification of tumours of soft tissue and bone [[WHO Classification of Tumours Editorial Board. Soft tissue and bone tumours. Lyon (France): International Agency for Research on Cancer; 2020. (WHO classification of tumours series, 5th ed.; vol. 3). https://publications.iarc.who.int/588.]]) – as well as spindle cell / pleomorphic lipoma.
staging: The American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and Union for International Cancer Control (UICC) TNM systems may be applied.
prognosis_and_prediction: The prognosis of dermal and subcutaneous pleomorphic liposarcoma is very favourable (unlike that of its more common deep-seated counterparts). Only rare cases of metastatic disease have been reported.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Absence of MDM2 amplification with a complex karyotype and widespread complex copy-number changes may help in the diagnosis. Specific reoccurring molecular alterations have not been reported.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Pleomorphic liposarcoma. Dermal pleomorphic liposarcoma composed of an undifferentiated spindle cell sarcoma containing numerous pleomorphic lipoblasts.

Pleomorphic liposarcoma. Diagnosis requires the presence of pleomorphic lipoblasts. Note lipid droplets indenting the pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nucleus. These cells may be rare or plentiful in any given tumour.

Pleomorphic liposarcoma. Epithelioid morphology resembling that of poorly differentiated carcinoma, adrenocortical carcinoma, melanoma, high-grade myxoid (round cell) liposarcoma, or renal clear cell carcinoma may be seen in a subset of cases.
Pleomorphic liposarcoma. Areas resembling myxofibrosarcoma are an infrequent finding in subcutaneous pleomorphic liposarcomas.
Pleomorphic liposarcoma. Ill-defined tumour composed of pleomorphic cells with a high degree of cytological atypia. Scattered pleomorphic lipoblasts are observed.

definition: Spindle cell / pleomorphic lipoma (SCL/PL) represents a morphological spectrum of the same benign adipocytic tumour. Spindle cell lipoma (SCL) is composed of varying proportions of mature adipocytes, bland spindle cells, and ropy collagen. Pleomorphic lipoma (PL) in addition contains pleomorphic and multinucleated floret-like giant cells.
clinical:
Patients with SCL/PL mostly present with a painless, slowly growing, mobile subcutaneous mass. The symptoms are usually of several years duration. The majority of tumours measure < 50 mm. Multiple lesions and a familial predisposition have also been described.

---

SCL/PL is most frequent among men aged between 45 and 60 years. Fewer than 10% of cases occur in women. SCL/PLs account for approximately 1.5% of adipocytic neoplasms.
pathogenesis:
Unknown

---

Partial or whole chromosome 13 and/or 16 deletions are seen. Breakpoints in 13q and/or deletions clustered around the region 13q14, where RB1 resides, may be detected. Single-nucleotide polymorphism analyses suggest that other genes may be involved in SCL/PL tumorigenesis. SCL may show deletions of chromosome 16. Two minimally deleted regions of interest in 13q14 have been described, the first of which involves RB1, RCBTB2, LPAR6, and CYSLTR2, and the second being a larger region encompassing MIR15A, MIR16-1, METTL1 (C12orf1), TRIM13, KPNA3, and DHRS12. Chromosome 12 polysomy within pleomorphic cells can result in focal MDM2 positivity by immunohistochemistry and may lead to misinterpretation as well-differentiated/dedifferentiated liposarcoma. However, MDM2 amplification is absent.
macroscopic: SCL/PL is grossly oval or discoid in shape. Depending on the proportion of adipocytes, spindle cells, and myxoid stroma, the cut surface may be yellow, grey-white, or myxoid. Extensively myxoid tumours can be gelatinous.
microscopic: SCL is well-circumscribed and usually encapsulated. Intramuscular and dermal tumours may have infiltrative margins. Mature adipocytes, bland spindle cells, and ropy collagen (thick refractile eosinophilic) bundles seen in variable combinations in a fibromyxoid stroma containing mast cells are characteristic features. The spindle cells are bland with uniform nuclei and are arranged randomly or in short fascicles in a school-of-fish pattern. Nuclear palisading, small cytoplasmic vacuoles, and focal lipoblasts may be seen. Occasional mitoses can be seen, but necrosis is absent. A vascular network of small to medium-sized thick-walled vessels may be present. PL in addition shows pleomorphic spindle cells and multinucleated floret-like giant cells with a ring of peripheral, radially placed, hyperchromatic nuclei around a central deeply eosinophilic cytoplasm. Morphological patterns include fat-poor SCL/PL, which is predominantly composed of spindle cells with little to no fat; myxoid SCL/PL, containing abundant myxoid stroma; and pseudoangiomatous SCL/PL, which is composed of dilated, branching, vascular-like spaces and pseudopapillary projections. In addition, a plexiform architecture, focal cartilaginous and osseous metaplasia, and extramedullary haematopoiesis have been reported. Immunohistochemistry The spindle and pleomorphic cells are positive for CD34, with loss of nuclear RB1. S100, SMA, desmin, and STAT6 are typically negative. Differential diagnosis SCL/PLs (particularly fat-poor patterns) must be distinguished from other CD34-positive superficial spindle cell lesions, including myxofibrosarcoma, dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, solitary fibrous tumour, and neurofibroma. PL may mimic atypical lipomatous tumour / well-differentiated liposarcoma and pleomorphic liposarcoma. Cellular angiofibroma and mammary-type myofibroblastoma have features overlapping with those of SCL/PL and are related entities. Herniated orbital fat may contain multinucleated floret-like giant cells similar to those in PL and stromal cells with reactive atypia that may be confused with atypical lipomatous tumour.
prognosis_and_prediction: SCL/PLs are benign tumours. Local recurrence is rare, even with incomplete resection.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Loss of the RB1 locus can be helpful in selected cases.
related_terminology: Not recommended: dendritic fibromyxolipoma.

media.legend: Spindle cell lipoma. A variable combination of adipocytes, bland spindle cells, and ropy collagen fibres.
Pleomorphic lipoma. Features of spindle cell lipoma with the addition of pleomorphic cells and multinucleated floret-like giant cells.
Myxoid spindle cell lipoma. Bland spindle cells, ropy collagen, and mature adipocytes in an extensively myxoid stroma.
Spindle cell lipoma. Pseudoangiomatous pattern.
Spindle cell lipoma. Low-fat pattern with bland spindle cells, ropy collagen, and little to no adipose component.

definition: Lipoma is a benign mesenchymal tumour composed of mature adipocytes.
clinical:
Lipomas present as a slow-growing, mobile and painless mass. Multifocality may be sporadic or syndromic. In familial multiple lipomatosis, subcutaneous lipomas develop, usually in the third decade, on the forearms, trunk and thigh. Multiple lipomas may also be seen in Proteus syndrome and Bannayan–Zonana syndrome.

---

Lipoma is the most common mesenchymal neoplasm in adults, typically presenting in the fifth or sixth decade, and is slightly more common in males. The diagnosis is uncommon in children.
pathogenesis:
The majority of lipomas are idiopathic. Familial multiple lipomatosis is usually autosomal dominant and the involved gene has been mapped to 12q14.3. Germline mutations in the PTEN tumour suppressor gene are common in patients with Proteus syndrome and Bannayan–Zonana syndrome.

---

The protein encoded by HMGA2 contains structural DNA-binding domains that play an important role in embryological adipogenesis. Structural aberrations resulting in deregulation of the HMGA2 gene are frequent in lipomas, with the most common being translocations involving 12q13-q15. Rearrangements involving 6p21 (HMGA1) and interstitial deletions of 13q have also been reported.
macroscopic: Lipomas are well-circumscribed, with a uniform glistening, yellow to cream cut surface. Some cases show macroscopic bone and/or cartilage.
microscopic: Lipomas display a thin capsule and are composed of lobules of mature adipocytes, dissected by thin, incomplete fibrous septa. Additional features include fat necrosis with foamy macrophages, fibrosis and myxoid change. In some lesions, metaplastic bone and/or cartilage may be seen. Adipocytes sometimes show intranuclear inclusions (Lochkern cells). Immunohistochemistry Lesional adipocytes are positive for HMGA2, which helps the distinction with normal adipose tissue. However immunohistochemistry is rarely necessary for the diagnosis. Differential diagnosis Distinction from atypical lipomatous tumour (ALT) is based on the presence of nuclear enlargement and hyperchromatism, and stromal atypical cells in the latter.
prognosis_and_prediction: Lipomas are benign but may rarely recur (in < 5% of cases) in a non-destructive fashion.
diagnostic_molecular_pathology: Molecular studies are usually not necessary for diagnosis. In challenging cases, studies for MDM2 amplification may be helpful to exclude ALT.
related_terminology: None

media.legend: Osteolipoma. Longstanding lipomas may contain metaplastic bone and/or cartilage.
Lipoma. Histologically, lipomas are composed of a uniform population of mature adipocytes.
Lipoma. Degenerate changes are not uncommon in lipomas, but cytological atypia, such as atypical hyperchromatic stromal cells, should be absent.
Lipoma. Macroscopically, lipoma is a well-circumscribed tumour with a uniform, glistening yellow cut surface.
Lipoma. A tumour composed of lobules of mature adipose tissue. Adipocytes have a uniform size, with small nuclei.

definition: Naevus lipomatosus superficialis (NLS) is a rare cutaneous hamartoma characterized by dermal ectopic adipose tissue.
clinical:
NLS manifests as slow-growing, skin-coloured to yellow, dome-shaped plaques formed by confluent papules and nodules. The overlying skin is wrinkled or cerebriform, sometimes with comedones. The plaques vary in size from 3 mm to 200 mm. There are usually no associated clinical abnormalities. Rarely, NLS can be associated with generalized folded skin (Michelin tyre baby syndrome).

---

NLS is rare. In the classic form, lesions arise at birth or develop in the first two decades of life. Solitary NLS has been reported in a wider age group (birth to 88 years). There is no sex predilection.
pathogenesis:
NLS is thought to represent a malformation. Deletion of 2p24 has been reported in 1 case.

---

The pathogenesis is unknown. It has been suggested that lesional adipocytes arise from precursor cells lying close to the blood vessels, analogous to the sequence of events in fetal adipogenesis.
macroscopic: NLS has a glistening, yellow to cream cut surface within the dermis.
microscopic: NLS is composed of aggregates of mature adipocytes at the level of the papillary and upper reticular dermis, typically around blood vessels. Accompanying connective tissue changes in the dermis include increased dermal capillaries inversely proportional to the fat content, irregularly distributed and sometimes thickened collagen, reduction of elastic fibres, and increased numbers of fibroblasts. The epidermis may show irregular acanthosis, follicular plugging, and (rarely) various abnormalities of folliculosebaceous units. Differential diagnosis NLS must be differentiated from lipoma and soft tissue fibroma with lipomatous stroma. Lipoma is typically a well-circumscribed subcutaneous nodular lesion composed mostly of mature adipocytes. Although thin connective tissue septa may separate lobules of adipocytes in lipomas, there is no dermis between the adipocytes like in NLS. Soft tissue fibroma contains groups of mature adipocytes in the stroma, but the lesion has a pedunculated silhouette. Soft tissue fibromas with fatty metaplasia are considered by some to be a solitary form of NLS.
prognosis_and_prediction: NLS is benign. Recurrence is exceptional.
related_terminology: Acceptable: naevus lipomatosus cutaneous superficialis. Not recommended: naevus lipomatosus cutaneous superficialis of Hoffmann–Zurhelle.
subtypes: Classic naevus lipomatosus superficialis; solitary naevus lipomatosus superficialis
